FATELY--Norman, 91, died at home on August 3, 2015. Born and raised in the Bronx, NY, he lived in Eastchester, NY for 52 years before moving to Whippany, NJ earlier this year. After graduating high school, Mr. Fately served in the Army Air Corp as an airplane mechanic. He then worked in operations at Alexander's, and later, Syms Department Stores until his retirement, after which he proudly worked with the Better Business Bureau until April of this year. He was a member of Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, NY, an avid golfer and member of the Willow Ridge Country Club for many years, and he deeply loved his dogs, Girlie and Freckles. Mr. Fately was the beloved husband of the late Margot, loving father of Andrew (Julie) Fately and Robert Fately, and devoted grandfather of David Bonda, Alex Bonda, and Kendall Fately. 1/3

CURRAN--John P. Fordham University mourns the death of John P. Curran, PhD, School of Pharmacy 1966. Curran, the benefactor of the Francis and Ann Curran Center for American Catholic Studies, died on August 1 at the age of 72. "John Curran was one of my heroes," said Joseph M. McShane, SJ, president of Fordham. "He was one of the most exemplary of Fordham's graduates: brilliant, kind, witty, intellectually curious, generous and filled with faith. It is no wonder, therefore, that he touched and inspired all who met him. My heart goes out to his family today. I know the Fordham family joins me in keeping John and his loved ones in our prayers." Curran and his wife, Constance, endowed the center in 2004, when it was just a "phone and a desk on the third floor of Keating Hall," said the center's founder, Mark S. Massa, SJ, the former Karl Rahner Chair in Theology. Born and raised in the Bronx, John Curran graduated from Fordham's School of Pharmacy in 1966 and received a doctorate in pharmaceutical economics from the University of Pittsburgh in 1971. His longtime career in pharmaceuticals included work in public policy research with Pfizer, Inc. and in drug analysis with G.A. Saxton, Wood Gundy, Inc., Dean Witter Reynolds, and L.F. Rothschild. He began his own hedge fund, Curran Capital Management, in 1987, from which he retired in 2002. Father Massa had established a center for Catholic study at Fordham in 2001, which opened one week after the tragedies of September 11. It remained a small program until the Currans, inspired by their close friendship with Father Massa, became its benefactors and named it in honor of John Curran's parents. In May, the Currans were awarded with Fordham's highest honor, the Presidential Medal, which has only been given 30 times in the history of the University. Since then, the Currans have been much more than benefactors and patrons to the Curran Center, said current director Christine Firer Hinze, PhD. The center, which celebrated its 10th anniversary in May, has grown to become a premier hub of Catholic studies. It offers numerous lectures and public conferences that explore diverse topics in Catholicism, including Catholic education, Catholic literature, black Catholic culture, and Latino/a spirituality. In addition to his wife of 47 years, Curran leaves a daughter, Meredith Rauhut; son Sean Curran; grandchildren Gavin and Kaelyn Rauhut; sister, Ann Mullan; and ten nieces and nephews. 1/3
STERN--Milton, The Wellesley girls and their guys bid sad farewell to their dear friend. Milt's wisdom and joie de vivre will be sorely missed. 1/3

SENCHAK--Evelyn. Evelyn Margaret Senchak, of Madison, passed away on Friday afternoon, July 17th, at Attic Angel Place in Middleton, Wisconsin. 'Ev or Evie' as her dear family and friends called her, celebrated her 95th birthday on June 7th of this year after celebrating the birth of her second great granddaughter on June 5th. Ev was born to George and Elizabeth Rapp in Elizabeth, New Jersey and grew up in Wayne along with her brothers, Chris and Bill, and sister Betty. Bill currently lives in Texas. She attended the Mountain View Grammar School and Pompton Lakes High School. After completing her training as registered nurse at Paterson General Hospital, she served during World War II, attending to returning troops. After the war she worked in the New Jersey offices of Dr. Forrest Chilton. She ultimately earned a BS in nursing. All three of her children, Andy, Doug and Laurie, were delivered by doctor Chilton at Paterson General. Ev married her high school sweetheart, Andrew Senchak on September 21st, 1941. After the war they lived in Wayne, New Jersey, Northridge, California, and Evanston, Illinois. They lived in Ocean Grove, New Jersey from 1980 until 2011. They were together for 69 years. Their marriage was marked by considerable overseas travel. Most notable was their stay in Paris where Ev studied at the Sorbonne and worked at the bookstore Shakespeare and Co. It was there that her lifelong passion for reading became partially satisfied. Evie was regarded as a gifted nurse with impressive intuition. This sensibility was also manifested in her deep, loving care for her family, friends and all members of the animal kingdom. It also found its way into her cooking, painting and writing. Her soups and salads nourished generations of neighborhood children in Wayne, Surf City, Northridge and Ocean Grove. She published a short story in the Saturday Evening Post and recently divulged her pen name after much pressure from her children. A Celebration of Life Gathering will be held from 2:30 to 3:30pm on August 25, 2015 at Attic Angel Place, 8301 Old Sauk Road, Middleton (second floor dining room). A service in Ocean Grove, New Jersey will be in September. A selection of Evie's paintings will be on display at these gatherings. Evie is survived by her brother Bill, her three children, six grandchildren, Phoebe and Christoper Banks, Alexander Case Senchak, Max Hunter Senchak, Simone Kaplan Senchak and Adrienne McKay Ranney and two great grandchildren, Ella and Nina Frankenburg. She was a cherished mother and will always be loved by Andy, Doug and Laurie. Please share memories at www.CressFuneral Service.com Cress Funeral Service, 3610 Speedway Road, Madison (608) 238-3434 1/3

WOOD--Richard J. Japan Society mourns the loss of Dr. Richard J. Wood, president 2006-2009. Among many accomplishments during his tenure, Wood strengthened and deepened understanding and friendship between the United States and Japan, steered the Society's centennial celebration highlighted by galas in New York and Tokyo, and created more programming opportunity globally. A Japanese philosophy and religion specialist, Wood was Professor and Dean Emeritus at the Yale University Divinity School, and a chair of the Japan-U.S. Friendship Commission of the United States Government and the U.S.-Japan Cultural and Educational Conference, an agency of the U.S. Department of State. In 2010 the government of Japan awarded him The Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star. In addition to his contributions to U.S.-Japan relations, he will be remembered for his indefatigable kindness, benevolence and support. Our hearts go out to his wife Judy, his children, grandchildren and all family and friends during this difficult time. Wilbur Ross, Chairman, and Motoatsu Sakurai, President 1/3

CARRARO--Amelia "Amy" Passed on August 1, 2015. Of Riverdale, NY, and long time resident of Malverne, Long Island. Born to Charles and Jean DiMassino, in Harlem, NY on August 5, 1932. Beloved wife of William "Red." Devoted mother of William (and wife Laura) and the late John (and wife Jacqui). Loving sister of the late John DiMassino (and wife, the late Nancy). Cherished grandmother of Nicholas and Thomas, cherished aunt to John and Therese. She was tough but loving, hardworking and honest. Her journey saw her moving from Harlem, to Brooklyn, then Queens, and finally home ownership in Long Island, in a place called Malverne. Here is where she raised her boys, worked at the local school as a teacher's aide, and not long after moved into retail sales and design at a home furnishings store, The Maple Center. She was also very proud of the work she did in her younger years, as a trained dental assistant. Amy was also known as the other half of the partnership with husband Red in the well know record auction dealership "The Jazz Hunter." It was their love for Jazz and collecting records that really defined who Amy and Red were. They hosted jam sessions at the house, went to all the clubs, and knew many of the musicians. This passion turned into a business which included a record auction having customers throughout North America, as well as in the U.K., Europe, India and Japan. Amy also spent years rescuing homeless dogs and cats . . . lots of cats, all the while feeding every bird in the neighborhood, or so it seemed. Her days were cut short, but she is joining dad and John, so she is in good hands. That said, I already miss her dearly. Hold all those you care for close. Bill Carraro. To celebrate her life, family will receive visitors at the Coffey Funeral Home, 91 North Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591 on Wednesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Telephone: 914-631-0983. Funeral Mass: Thursday, 10am at the Immaculate Conception Church, in Sleepy Hollow, NY. Interment at St. Raymond's Cemetery (New Section), Bronx. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to Villalobos Rescue, or North Shore Animal League, or a charity of your choice in her memory. 1/3

O'CONNELL--William John Daniel, born October 23, 1930, died August 3, 2015. Bill O'Connell of Waldwick, NJ, formerly of Ridgewood and the Bronx, leaves his beloved wife, Ann, loving children Sister Regina O'Connell, CSJP, Kathleen O'Connell, Patricia O'Connell and James O'Connell, dear children-in-law Ted Hoff and Lauren O'Connell, treasured grandchildren Tommy and Michael Hoff and Julia and Jack O'Connell, as well as countless fellow friends of "Bill W" with whom he generously shared, for over forty years, his kind and invaluable counsel, wisdom, insight and experience. Proud of and grateful for his Jesuit training, Bill was a fiercely loyal alumnus of Fordham Prep and a graduate of Fordham University. He also earned a master's from NYU. During his Army service in the Korean War, he was awarded the Bronze Star. Bill achieved considerable success in the financial planning field and retired as president and founder of Financial Horizons. During his retirement, he pursued his interests in writing, Irish Studies, classical music, and golf. Together with Ann, he was active in Voice of the Faithful. He enjoyed winters in Florida and remained an inveterate reader of printed newspapers and any printed word, a devoted New York Giants Football fan and a forever enthralled grandpa. He was a man of great integrity, dignity, intellect, generosity and faith. Visiting hours will be held on Thursday, August 6 at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ between 4pm and 8pm. A Mass of the Resurrection will be offered at St. Luke's Church, 340 N Franklin Turnpike, Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ at 10am, Friday, August 7, with interment to follow at Valleau Cemetery in Ridgewood. 1/3

SCAASI--Arnold. President Joyce F. Brown and the Fashion Institute of Technology community mourn the passing of Arnold Scaasi, a major figure on the fashion scene for more than half a century, dressing first ladies and celebrities in memorable style. The Museum at FIT displayed his exuberant designs in a 2002 solo exhibition that we recall with pride. He will be deeply missed. 1/3

SEILER--Dr. Sharon. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Dr. Sharon Seiler. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to her family. Scott N. Bolton, Rabbi Marc D. Ashley, President 1/3

FLAUM--Constance Stern, 93, died at home August 4, 2015. Married in 1942, to Mitchel the love of her life who died in 2011. Devoted mother of Stephen and Gary and loving grandmother of Rivka, Russell, Leah, and Isaac. She adored her sister Nona who is deceased. Graduated The Calhoun School in 1939 and named an Honorary Trustee. Graduated Parsons in 1941. She served her community as Hospital volunteer, den mother, class mother, dancing school mother, and President of the Stern Foundation. Will be remembered for best school lunches, best party giver-ever, loyalties, lifelong friendships, generosity, kindness, and wisdom. Services will be held 3:30pm, Thursday, August 6, at Ballard-Durand in White Plains, NY. 1/3

LYNCH--Josephine D. (nee Dexter) died at home Monday July 27, 2015 in Gladwyne, PA. Beloved wife of the late David B. Lynch, who died in 2001, and sister of the late Polly Newbold, who died in 2010, Joedy was the devoted mother of David, Tina Fiertz (Stuart) and Linda (Kevin Johnson), and devoted grandmother of Henry, Callie, Mimi, Louisa, Theo, Lucy and Annie. She attended The Shipley School and graduated in 1948 from St. Timothy's School in Stevenson, MD. In the 1950's Joedy was an accessories editor for Harper's Bazaar magazine in New York City. A memorial service will be held on Friday, October 9, 2015 at 4pm at St. Christopher's Church, 226 Righter's Mill Road, Gladwyne, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to The Bryn Mawr Hospital Foundation, Bryn Mawr, PA. Online condolences: www.donohuefuneral home. com 1/3

MURRAY--James G.,III, died of a heart attack on August 3, 2015. Jerry was born in New York City on June 8, 1943, to Eileen Fitzsimmons Murray and James G. Murray Jr. The family moved to Pittsburgh, where Jerry spent his youth. He attended Cranwell Preparatory School and graduated from the University of Notre Dame. Jerry enjoyed a successful 50-year career on Wall Street. In recent years, Jerry lived in Palm Beach, FL and enjoyed visits to Pebble Beach, CA, East Hampton, NY and Waterville, Ireland. Jerry loved golf, golf courses and the fellowship of the game. He drew his strength from his religious faith, his friends, and his family. Jerry is survived by his wife, Esther DeDeo Murray, his former wife Sandra Murray Hargreaves and their children James G. Murray IV, Deya Murray Warren and William Scot Murray, his son-in-law, Gus Warren, his grandchildren, Greta and Peter Warren, his stepson, Simon DeDeo, and his sister, Patricia Huse. A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue from 6:00pm-8:00pm on Thursday, August 6th. A funeral Mass will be celebrated Friday, August 7th at 10:30am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on Park Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Jerry's memory to the Rockne Heritage Fund for Men's Golf at the University of Notre Dame: 574-631-5150. 1/3

SCAASI--Arnold. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the passing of our Advisory Board Member and "Living Landmark" Arnold Scaasi. He loved New York and its buildings and was responsible for lighting the landmark Renwick Ruin on Roosevelt Island so the public could appreciate its beauty. Lloyd P. Zuckerberg, Chair. Peg Breen, President. 1/3
SCAASI--Arnold. "The Dramatist of Elegance" How glamorous you made us all look and feel. I shall always cherish the wonderful times I had with you and Parker. Kathleen B. Hearst 1/3

FRENTZ--William C. Of Cos Cob, CT, died August 1, 2015. Born May 21, 1934 in Chicago, IL, son of Hugo and Rose Frentz. His beloved wife, Joanne W. Frentz, pre-deceased him November 2014. Survived by a sister-in-law and nieces and a nephew. Upon graduating from Northwestern University with an MBA degree, he worked in commercial real estate investments, and served as Vice President at both Equitable and The Guardian Life Insurance Companies. 1/3
MINSKOFF--Nancy Lee. Darling girl, Happy 60th! From dear brother Sam, Precious daughter Margaux, Favorite cousin Lee and Ever-loving mom 1/3

HILLMAN--Elsie Hilliard. On August 4, 2015, Elsie Hilliard Hillman, devoted wife of loving husband Henry for 70 years, mother of Lea Simonds, Audrey Fisher, Henry Hillman, Jr. and Bill Hillman, grandmother of nine, great- grandmother of fourteen, civic and political leader, and philanthropist, died peacefully surrounded by her family at Shadyside Hospital in Pittsburgh. She was 89 years old. She was "Elsie" to anyone who she ever had the pleasure to meet and a groundbreaking leader for women in politics for over half a century. A former National Republican Committeewoman, she was a confidant and friend to Governors, Senators, Presidents, and hundreds of Pittsburghers from all walks of life. Still active in the community at the time of her death, she was chair of the Elsie H. Hillman Foundation, a trustee of the Hillman Family Foundations, co-chair of the UPCI and UPMC CancerCenter Council, and served as a board member of WQED, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, Hill House Association and director emeritus of several more organizations and universities. She was the recipient of eight honorary degrees and countless honors over the course of her life including being named a Distinguished Daughter of Pennsylvania. Elsie was recently recognized by the University of Pittsburgh Institute of Politics as the subject of a publication entitled, "Never a Spectator: The Political Life of Elsie Hillman," on her civic career and groundbreaking work as a political and community leader as well as an advocate for women and minorities in elected office. Her record of civic involvement is a testimonial to her complete devotion to serving people in any way she could. She will be greatly missed by many and her legacy will never be forgotten. Funeral arrangements will be private and for the immediate family only. A community memorial service to celebrate her remarkable life is being planned for Saturday, September 19th at 10:30am at Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Hillman Cancer Center at the University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute or to a charity of one's choice. 1/3
ROSEN--Jules. Condolences to the entire Rosen Family on their loss. The Zises Family 1/3

SEILER--Sharon Rachel, PhD, of Manhattan, an incomparable mother and wife, beloved daughter, and adored sister, died on August 4th at the age of 54. She is survived by her husband and daughter, Charles and Talia Spielholz; her mother, Harriet Seiler; and her sisters, Cynthia Albert and Stephanie Seiler. Her wry wit, kind heart, keen intellect and uncommon integrity will be missed by her aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, extended family, and many friends and colleagues. Dr. Seiler received a BS from Princeton University and a PhD from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and was an accomplished molecular biologist and businesswoman. She also was a dedicated member of Congregation Or Zarua, where she enjoyed chanting Torah. More recently she combined her scientific and business skills with her experience as a cancer patient to bring leading physicians in Manhattan together in an effort to improve the treatment of head and neck cancer. We hope that this effort will continue. Funeral services Friday, 10am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan. Contributions to Congregation Or Zarua, 127 E 82nd St, New York, NY 10028 or to Brian L. Schmidt, Director, Bluestone Center for Clinical Research at New York University, 421 1st Avenue, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10010-4086. 1/3

LIEBERMAN--Herman, died peacefully in his 97th year. He was a Brooklyn man - born in Brownsville, lived in Crown Heights and Sheepshead Bay - and was an avid Brooklyn Dodger fan. He served in the United States Army Signal Corps during World War II and knew Morse Code by heart. He loved studying foreign languages and spoke Yiddish, Hebrew, Latin and Spanish. He was completely devoted to his late wife, Florence and dedicated himself to her care during her long bout with Alzheimer's. He had an endearing personality and was always in a good mood, fond of jokes and puns; he never complained and was grateful for every kindness shown to him. He was deeply loved by his daughters Adele Tauber, Vivian Lieberman, and the late Frances Lieberman and his son-in-law, Ronald; his grandchildren Daniel (Natasha), Miriam (Zachary), Michael and Lisa; and his great- grandchildren, Flora, Zelig and Laszlo. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

BRESSLER--Jane Carol (Blechner), mother, wife, attorney, and philanthropist, 70, died on August 5th, of metastatic breast cancer after living with it for a valiant six and a half years. At home, surrounded by her sons, Lee, Scott, and Aaron, her stepdaughter, Amy, and her sister and brother, Barbara Sevde and Mark Blechner, Jane died in the same manner with which she approached every challenge in life - with strength and grace. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Madden, Brody, Eden, and Martin, and leaves a legacy of loving family and friends who will miss her kindness and generosity. She now joins her beloved husband, Martin, each of whom believed that love never dies, and her parents, Hannah and Norbert Blechner. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on August 6th at 10am. Donations may be directed to the Mt. Sinai Child Life and Creative Arts Therapy Department or the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund. We will miss her forever. 1/3

SHANOSKY--Judith, died peacefully on August 3, 2015. The cause of death was ovarian cancer, which she endured for eight years. She was 74. Born Judith Dornel Gasson in Reading, England, May 18, 1941, she emigrated from London in 1959, and made her home in New York City, Key West, Florida, and Westfield, New Jersey. She received her BA and MA in Art History at Kean University in New Jersey, where she ran a visiting artists lecture series in the 1980s. Judith was a widely respected and prolific weaver. She read three or four novels each week, was a mile-a-day swimmer and three-time marathon finisher. She is survived by her beloved husband of 52 years, Arthur Shanosky, her son Mark, daughter-in-law Tanya, daughter Samantha and son- in-law John, two grandsons, Primo and Pascal; and her brother and sister, Andrew and Rosemary Gasson of London, England. In addition to her family, she is survived by innumerable friends and fellow artists who will remember her for her passion, intensity, generosity and enthusiasms. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests donations be made in Judith's name to the Carol G. Simon Cancer Center in Morristown Medical Center. 1/3

HALBREICH--Susan Toni, LSCW, BSD, died peacefully at 68 after a long battle with uterine and breast cancers. Born December 31, 1946 to Gladys and Gerald Halbreich (deceased), Toni was a loving sister to Ellen Korney (Michael) and Michael Halbreich, an adoring aunt to Alison Lemer and beloved friend to many. Burial Thursday, August 6, 2015, 11:00am at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Avenue, Glendale, NY, 11385. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital or Puppies Behind Bars. 1/3

FELTON--Maxwell J.,M.D. On August 5, 2015. Beloved husband of 52 beautiful years to Rhetta, with whom he created a family tree overflowing with love and laughter. Loving brother-in-law to Susan Felton, and Bonnie and Steven Stern, and adored uncle to his many nieces and nephews. A mentor, confidante, and friend to all . . . In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Siteman Cancer Center/Washington University, Siteman Cancer Center, CB1204, 7425 Forsyth, St. Louis, MO 63105 directed to Dr. William Hawkins Pancreatic Research Fund or to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, Greater New York Chapter, 120 Broadway, Suite 1050A, New York, NY 10271 or to a charity of your choice. JOHNSON-- Woodrow E.,formerly of Garden City, NY, now a resident of Sarasota, FL., died suddenly at age 97 after a brief illness on August 1, 2015 at Mercy Hospital, Long Island, NY. He leaves his wife of 73 years, Nita, four children, nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Woody helped lead the development of the atomic power industry with the Westinghouse Corporation, as a designer of nuclear reactor systems for defense, power generation, scientific research and space travel. Services are scheduled at the Garden City Community Church, Saturday, August 8th, at 11am, where he and Nita were members for over 30 years. Donations can be made in his name to the tutoring program at Church of the Palms in Sarasota or Pittsburgh Pirates charities. 1/3

FEINSTEIN--Clifford. The Board of Directors and staff of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel wish to express their sincere condolences to Board Member Barry N. Winograd on the loss of his father-in-law Clifford Feinstein. May his memory forever be a blessing. Harold Handler, Chairman 1/3

SCHULTE--Vivian S. Died peacefully at her home in Manalapan, FL on July 21, 2015. She was 97 years old. An avid tennis player and fan, music lover and food journalist, Vivian was also an author of poetry and won several awards for her work. Vivian was born in New York City, daughter of the late Dr. Simon L. Sternfield and Pauline Tonkonogy Sternfield. A devoted wife to the late Arthur Schulte for 40 years, Vivian leaves behind an extended family of grandchildren, great grandchildren, nephews and a grand nephew and grand niece. She received a B.A. degree from Hunter College, an M.A. degree from Columbia University, and a Ph.D. from New York University. In 1941 she became Food Consultant and Lecturer for L. Bamberger and Co. in Newark and conducted a radio program on Nutrition for WOR during World War II to help homemakers make the most of available foods. She conducted classes in nutrition and food preservation in Newark under the auspices of the American Red Cross. She also served as Food and Home Editor for Fawcett, Hearst and Curtis Publications. Vivian won the American Dairy Association Award for distinguished food journalism. She was a member of Pi Lambda Theta, Honor Society of the Education profession and Kappa Omicron Nu, Honor Society of the Home Economics profession. Vivian was a member of the following: New York Academy of Sciences, American Dietetic Association, Greater New York Dietetic Association, Food and Nutrition Council of New York, American Home Economics Association and Les Dames DEscoffier; and was, in her later years, frequently found with friends at one of her favorite clubs, La Coquille in Manalapan, FL. Dr. Schulte, as she liked to be referred to, was an avid fan of the Metropolitan Opera and was known to participate from her seat from time to time. She was most proud in her later years of her poetry, for which she won numerous awards and was recognized in various publications. Dr. Schulte is survived by 5 grandchildren: Margot Levinson Gantz, Drew Levinson, John Levinson, Lucy Schulte Danziger, Peter Schulte; nine great grandchildren and four nephews: Tom, John, Mark and Jonathan Sternfield. There will be a memorial service held in the fall in New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider memorial donations to: The Hunter College Foundation; memo: Mothers Day Scholarship Fund in Honor of Vivian Schulte, at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, Room E1313, New York, New York 10065. 1/3

SKODNEK--Jean. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Jean Skodnek of Palm Beach, Fla. Together with her beloved husband Jack, she was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. Mr. Skodnek is a member of the ATS Palm Beach Chapter Board, and the ATS national Board of Regents. The couple's generous gifts to the Technion include the Jean and Jack Skodnek Dormitory in the Eastern Dormitory Village. Their legacy continues through their two sons, Drs. Richard and Kenneth Skodnek, who dedicated the Jean and Jack Skodnek Immunobiology of Aging Research Laboratory. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jack, Richard and Kenneth, and the entire Skodnek family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

He will always be remembered for his sharp wit and humor, loyalty and devotion to his family. A private service will be held. Shiva will be at the home of Bunny Ash, on Sunday and Monday evening 6-9pm. Contributions may be sent to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. 1/3

AVELON--Richard "Rich", of Cumberland Foreside, Maine, passed away August 3, 2015. Born March, 25th, 1966 in Oceanside, New York, son of Richard and Diane Aversano, Rich was a CUNY cum laude graduate with a BA in Computer Science and recently worked in Financial Services at Teradata. Rich was an adventurer, always living life to the fullest, and was loved by so many for his kind heart. He was a patient, devoted step-father and a gracious, loving husband. He was a passionate sailor and enjoyed spending days at sea with friends and family. He is survived by his wife Julie, step-daughter Michelle, parents, and sisters, Marianne, Bethann, and Suzanne. He will be missed by his many friends and extended family, upon whom his considerate spirit and true appreciation of life left a profound effect. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to SailMaine Scholarship Fund, through their website, sailmaine.org. 1/3

LEVINE--Ted M.,a resident of Rye, New York for 45 years passed away on Thursday, August 6th. He was 88 years old. Ted was born on March 8, 1927 in New York City. He received his undergraduate degree from Cornell University and master's degree from New York University. While serving as director of public relations for the Government of Puerto Rico in 1960, Ted came up with the idea to launch Development Counsellors International (DCI), a unique firm that would specialize in marketing places. Fifty-five years later, Ted's vision of DCI remains the same. Ted is survived by his wife of 58 years Patricia, his brother Bobby Levine, his sister Mimi Rockmore, his three sons David, Andy and Jeffrey, two grandsons Terrell and Evan, his three god children Amy, Andrew and Jeanette McDonald and their mother Susan McDonald. A memorial service will be held at the Graham Funeral Home at 1036 Boston Post Road in Rye, New York on Saturday, August 8th at noon. Burial at the Greenwood Union Cemetery will immediately follow. In lieu of flowers, the family encourages donations to the Rye Free Reading Room or the Rye Historical Society. 1/3
MILFORD--Kenneth. 1926-2015. Memorial Service Sunday, August 9, 3pm. Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam at 91st St., New York, NY. 1/3

STEINER--Helena on August 3, 2015. Reposing at Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Directors, 352 E. 87th St, New York, Sunday 2pm-5pm and 7pm- 9pm. Funeral Mass: Our Lady of Good Counsel RC Church, 230 E. 90th St., Monday, 10am. 1/3

SHANOSKY--Judith, died peacefully on August 3, 2015. The cause of death was ovarian cancer, which she endured for eight years. She was 74. Born Judith Dornel Gasson in Reading, England, May 18, 1941, she emigrated from London in 1959, and made her home in New York City, Key West, Florida, and Westfield, New Jersey. She received her BA and MA in Art History at Kean University in New Jersey, where she ran a visiting artists lecture series in the 1980s. Judith was a widely respected and prolific weaver. She read three or four novels each week, was a mile-a-day swimmer and three-time marathon finisher. She is survived by her beloved husband of 52 years, Arthur Shanosky, her son Mark, daughter-in-law Tanya, daughter Samantha and son- in-law John, two grandsons, Primo and Pascal; and her brother and sister, Andrew and Rosemary Gasson of London, England. In addition to her family, she is survived by innumerable friends and fellow artists who will remember her for her passion, intensity, generosity and enthusiasms. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests donations be made in Judith's name to the Carol G. Simon Cancer Center in Morristown Medical Center. 1/3

RICH--George. The Officers, Board members, and global staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) deeply mourn the passing of our retired Board member and devoted friend, George Rich, whose modest demeanor belied a lifetime of good works on behalf of Israel and Jewish needs worldwide. A survivor of the Budapest ghetto who was rescued by Raoul Wallenberg at age 13, George headed a major eyewear company here in the U.S. and, along with his beloved late wife, Martha z"l, was involved in a number of Holocaust memorial projects. A past member of JDC's Executive Committee and past chair of our Eastern Europe Committee, this sweet, quiet man cared deeply about the welfare and well-being of the hundreds of thousands of people whom we serve overseas. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children and grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing to all those whose lives he touched. Penny Blumenstein President Dr. Irving A. Smokler Chairman of the Board Alan H. Gill Chief Executive Officer 1/3

FITZGERALD--Frances S. Born December 2, 1937. Died August 2, 2015, following a short illness. Convent of the Sacred Heart 91st St. '55, Manhattanville College '59. She is survived by her husband Kenyon, daughters Irene FitzGerald, Louise North and Lydia B. FitzGerald, and four grandchildren, Hunter Geraghty, Ryan Geraghty, Nelson North III and Kenyon North. She was the light of all our lives. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Memorial Church of All Angels, Twilight Park, Haines Falls, NY 12436. 1/3

GREANY--Thomas G. Wynnewood, PA. Died July 31 at his daughter's home in St Louis, MO, at the age of 93. A General Contractor for 45 years and a US Naval Airship Command Pilot for 12 years. Graduated from St Joseph's Prep and Georgetown University School of Foreign Service. He is survived by four children and two grandchildren. Funeral Services and viewing at St. Matthias Church, Friday 11am, August 7th, Bala-Cynwyd, PA contact: tfgreany@gmail.com 1/3
FELTON--Dr. Max. Dearest Max, you were a gentle man, loved by all who knew you. You will be missed by all of us. The Greenfield Family 1/3
BHAVNANI--Ashok. In loving memory of Ashok Bhavnani who died July 25, 2015, in New York City. A reputed American architect, he is survived by his wife, Marjorie, and son, Raoul. 1/3

SEILER--Sharon Rachel, PhD, of Manhattan, an incomparable mother and wife, beloved daughter, and adored sister, died on August 4th at the age of 54. She is survived by her husband and daughter, Charles and Talia Spielholz; her mother, Harriet Seiler; and her sisters, Cynthia Albert and Stephanie Seiler. Her wry wit, kind heart, keen intellect and uncommon integrity will be missed by her aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, extended family, and many friends and colleagues. Dr. Seiler received a BS from Princeton University and a PhD from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and was an accomplished molecular biologist and businesswoman. She also was a dedicated member of Congregation Or Zarua, where she enjoyed chanting Torah. More recently she combined her scientific and business skills with her experience as a cancer patient to bring leading physicians in Manhattan together in an effort to improve the treatment of head and neck cancer. We hope that this effort will continue. Funeral services Friday, 10am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Manhattan. Contributions to Congregation Or Zarua, 127 E 82nd St, New York, NY 10028 or to Brian L. Schmidt, Director, Bluestone Center for Clinical Research at New York University, 421 1st Avenue, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10010-4086. 1/3

BRESSLER--Jane Carol (Blechner), mother, wife, attorney, and philanthropist, 70, died on August 5th, of metastatic breast cancer after living with it for a valiant six and a half years. At home, surrounded by her sons, Lee, Scott, and Aaron, her stepdaughter, Amy, and her sister and brother, Barbara Sevde and Mark Blechner, Jane died in the same manner with which she approached every challenge in life - with strength and grace. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Madden, Brody, Eden, and Martin, and leaves a legacy of loving family and friends who will miss her kindness and generosity. She now joins her beloved husband, Martin, each of whom believed that love never dies, and her parents, Hannah and Norbert Blechner. Funeral services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on August 6th at 10am. Donations may be directed to the Mt. Sinai Child Life and Creative Arts Therapy Department or the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund. We will miss her forever. 1/3

RICH--George. Founder and former President of Starline Optical Corporation, which introduced Safilo eyewear in the United States, died at his home in New York City on August 5 at the age of 83. The cause was complications from Parkinson's disease and Aphasia. His success in business was matched only by his love for, and devotion to his family. George was born in Budapest, Hungary in 1931. After his many years as President of Starline, he served on the Board and became Chairman of Eastern Europe for the Joint Distribution Committee (JDC), an organization that was particularly meaningful for him. In 1949, after surviving the Holocaust and World War II in Budapest, George escaped from communist Hungary to Austria, where he lived in a Displaced Persons Camp run by the JDC for three years. In 1954 he immigrated to the United States, where he served in the United States Army at Camp Kilmer as an interpreter for Hungarian refugees. George, and his wife Martha, who predeceased him, were active in many Jewish charities, including as founding members and benefactors of the Education Division of the Museum of Jewish Heritage - A Living Memorial to the Holocaust in New York City, Metro-West of New Jersey and Eternal Flame of New Jersey. George was instrumental in the erection of a Raoul Wallenberg statue in Parsippany, New Jersey. He credited Wallenberg with saving the lives of thousands of Hungarian Jews, including his own, in the last hours of the liquidation of the Budapest ghetto. Despite the fact that his formal education was interrupted by the war, he was a self-educated man who read widely on history, politics and current events and was always interested in engaging his friends in lively political debate. As a young man he studied classical piano, which left him with a life- long love of classical music and jazz. He was a fixture at Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola in Manhattan. He loved the United States and the freedom it gave him to be a loving father, a successful businessman, a valued member of the Jewish community and, as he would say, an all around "mensch." His values of integrity and hard work made him a mentor for his many colleagues. He is survived by his four children: Michael, Diane, Monica and Irina, their spouses Kathleen, Robert and Rod; his six grandchildren, Jason and his wife Rachel, Danielle and her husband Seth, Daniel, Laura, Marc and Julia, and his great grandson, Jake. Donations in George's memory may be made to Eternal Flame, www.eternalflame.org Services Friday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

CURRAN--John P. The staff, directors and trustees of Phelps Memorial Hospital Center (PMHC) and the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of former PMHC Director John P. Curran. John was one of PMHC's most gracious financial supporters. His dedicated service and generosity enabled the hospital to provide outstanding healthcare to the residents of Westchester and surrounding communities. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Constance, daughter Meredith Rauhut, son Sean, grandchildren Gavin and Kaelyn Rauhut, sister Ann Mullan, and ten nieces and nephews. Richard Sinni, Chairman, Board of Directors, Phelps Memorial Hospital Center Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System 1/3

RODGERS--C. R. Perry, Jr.,of Washington Crossing, Pennsylvania, and Vero Beach, Florida, died peacefully at his home on August 4, 2015. Born in Baltimore to the late Christopher R. P. and Charlotte Hundley Rodgers, he is survived by his wife, Toni M. Tracy, two children from his first marriage, Mary Rodgers Boughey (Simon) of London and Christopher R. P. Rodgers III (Danyel) of Sudbury, Massachusetts. He is also survived by three beloved grandsons, Perry, Tyler, and Zack Rodgers, nine sisters and brothers, numerous nieces, nephews, and in-laws, his former wife, Rosemary B. Rodgers, and a wide and wonderful circle of friends. A longtime resident of Princeton, New Jersey, he attended Princeton Country Day School, the South Kent School, and the University of Arizona before enlisting in the United States Marine Corps and serving proudly and honorably in Vietnam. He completed his undergraduate education at Rider University in Lawrenceville, New Jersey, and spent the bulk of his career in the insurance brokerage industry in Philadelphia and Manhattan, retiring from Crystal & Co. in 2009. After his retirement, he volunteered in a newly formed hospice unit of the VA Hospital in Lyons, New Jersey. Dedicated to the game of golf, he was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club, Springdale Golf Club in Princeton and Riomar Country Club and Quail Valley in Vero Beach. He was also a member of the United States Seniors Golf Association. A service in celebration of his life will be held on Tuesday, August 11 at 11:00 am in the Miller Chapel of the Princeton Theological Seminary, 64 Mercer Street, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory are suggested to the Kimmel Cancer Center at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia or to a charity that supports and honors military veterans. Services are under the direction of The Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, Princeton. 1/3

SANDLER--Dr. Ivan Seth, of Merrick, New York, on August 4, 2015. Born December 28, 1942, in Brooklyn, New York, son of Charlotte and Harry Sandler. Beloved husband of Joan Sandler. Loving father of Tracey Sandler and Karen Sandler, grandfather of Cora. Dr. Sandler graduated with an engineering degree from Cooper Union and received his Ph.D. from Columbia University. He was with the engineering-consulting firm Weidlinger Associates Consulting Engineers, retiring as a principal after 47 years. Dr. Sandler received the Mel Baron Award in 2003, given for unique contributions to computational structural dynamics and the shock- and vibration-related specialty fields, as well as for lifetime achievement. He was vice president of the Archaeological Institute of America, Long Island Society, member of Tau Beta Pi and an avid bridge player. 1/3

O'CONNELL--William John Daniel, born October 23, 1930, died August 3, 2015. Bill O'Connell of Waldwick, NJ, formerly of Ridgewood and the Bronx, leaves his beloved wife, Ann, loving children Sister Regina O'Connell, CSJP, Kathleen O'Connell, Patricia O'Connell and James O'Connell, dear children-in-law Ted Hoff and Lauren O'Connell, treasured grandchildren Tommy and Michael Hoff and Julia and Jack O'Connell, as well as countless fellow friends of "Bill W" with whom he generously shared, for over forty years, his kind and invaluable counsel, wisdom, insight and experience. Proud of and grateful for his Jesuit training, Bill was a fiercely loyal alumnus of Fordham Prep and a graduate of Fordham University. He also earned a master's from NYU. During his Army service in the Korean War, he was awarded the Bronze Star. Bill achieved considerable success in the financial planning field and retired as president and founder of Financial Horizons. During his retirement, he pursued his interests in writing, Irish Studies, classical music, and golf. Together with Ann, he was active in Voice of the Faithful. He enjoyed winters in Florida and remained an inveterate reader of printed newspapers and any printed word, a devoted New York Giants Football fan and a forever enthralled grandpa. He was a man of great integrity, dignity, intellect, generosity and faith. Visiting hours will be held on Thursday, August 6 at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Avenue, Ridgewood, NJ between 4pm and 8pm. A Mass of the Resurrection will be offered at St. Luke's Church, 340 N Franklin Turnpike, Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ at 10am, Friday, August 7, with interment to follow at Valleau Cemetery in Ridgewood. 1/3

WILLIAMS--John Mullarkey. On Wednesday, August 5th, 2015, John Mullarkey Williams, 88, died at home surrounded by family. He is survived by Joan, his wife of 61 years, son Roderick Williams, daughter Maris Baker, and three grandchildren. He graduated from Choate School and Princeton University. After serving in Korea, he began a successful career in advertising and public relations and retired from Dun & Bradstreet, where he was Manager of Corporate Communications. He was co-founder and president of Friends of the Bay, which saved the Oyster Bay Federal Wildlife Refuge, and was Mayor of the Village of Centre Island for 19 years until he retired. A life celebration will be held at Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club on September 27th at 4pm. A memorial fund has been established at Friends of the Bay. 1/3

DEMPSEY--Lawrence J.,died August 2, 2015 in Arlington, Virginia. He was 84 years old. The son of Wilfred E. Dempsey Sr. and Rachael (Sadie) Connors Dempsey, Larry was born and raised in the Chelsea and Inwood sections of Manhattan. After high school, he joined the Air Force where he served on active duty for four years and on reserve duty for 35 years, retiring as a Lt. Colonel with the Air Force Office of Special Investigations. Larry was also a proud member of the New York City Police Department, retiring in 1976 after serving as Lt. Commander of Detectives, New York City Department of Investigation and Inspector General of the City's Housing and Development Administration. During his tenure with the NYPD, Larry lived in Staten Island and earned his B.A. from Seton Hall University and his M.A. from New York University. After retiring from the NYPD, Larry was a professor at Jersey City State College, then moved in 1979 to the Washington D.C. area to assume the Federal positions of Assistant Inspector General for Investigations at the Agency for International Development and then the General Services Administration. He topped off his extraordinary career by becoming a consultant with the National Academy of Public Administration. Throughout his life, Larry actively pursued his passions for world travel, New York City history, and antiques and stamp collecting. In all his endeavors, he was a thoroughly gracious, kind and compassionate person. Larry is survived by his wife, Susan Gaffney, of Arlington, Virginia, and by four children from his previous marriage to Edna Bradbury Dempsey: Richard Dempsey, L. David Dempsey, Deborah Pensiero, and Jill Dempsey-Arner. He is also survived by six grandchildren and four great- grandchildren. His parents and three brothers Wilfred Jr., Gregory, and Robert preceded him in death. Burial will take place at a future time in Arlington National Cemetery. Funeral services are being made through Murphy Funeral Home, Arlington, VA. 1/3
LEVY--Arthur. Feb. 27, 1930 - Aug. 8, 2007 Always loved. Always missed. Barbara 1/3

KAMINE-BROWN--Carol. The Board, Staff, Clients and Friends of Concerned Home Managers for the Elderly are in mourning over the loss of our Executive Manager, Carol Kamine-Brown. Her huge heart was a blessing and a beacon for us all. Our thoughts and prayers are with her beloved daughter, Marissa. 1/3

MURPHY--Catherine S.,R.N., survived by Robert E. Murphy Sr., Peggy Murphy, Robert Murphy and Sr. Louis Marie Baxter, OP. Class of '52 Tolentine High School; '55 Bellevue Nursing School; '59 Hunter College; '76 Pace University. Nurse at New York Institute Special Education; Bronx Center for Multiple Handicapped Children; Providence Rest Nursing Home; Respicare Home Care; Bronx VA and Bellevue Hospitals. Wake at McNulty Funeral Home, Inc, 3006 Middletown Rd., Bronx, on Sunday and Monday, 4-8pm. Funeral at Our Lady of The Assumption Church, 1634 Mahan Ave., Bronx on Tuesday, 9:30am. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. 1/3

JACOBSON--George J.,passed away on August 6th at the age of 96. Loving father of Neil (Deirdre), and the late John. Beloved husband of Susan and the late Norma. Dear brother of the late Richard. Of the greatest generation and a World War II Veteran, he served his country as a steadfast navigator in the US Army Air Force. Our world has lost someone of real worth. Services Sunday, 9:45am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

FELTON--Dr. Maxwell. The loss of Uncle Max is deeply mourned by his sister- in-law Susan and nieces Cheryl, Miriam and Leslie. There has never been a brother-in-law or uncle that has demonstrated more kindness and compassion. He was always there for us over these 24 years since his brother Robert died. He will always have our utmost respect and gratitude. Uncle Max, we will always love and miss you. Susan Felton, Cheryl Felton and Neville Glajchen, Miriam Felton, Leslie and Howard Sklar and families. 1/3

LEHRMAN--Seymour, 98, passed away July 3, 2015. His wife Lucille Hecht left us in 1999. He leaves eight nieces and nephews - Marcia and Nancy Dunetz, Shoshanah Devorah, Judith and David Fleiss, Richard, Kenneth and Donald Lewis. Donations in his memory would be appreciated to the Wounded Warrior Project www.woundedwa rriorproject.org, The Broadway Bach Ensemble www.broadwaybach.org or any charity you choose. 1/3

FELTON--Maxwell J.,M.D. On August 5, 2015. Beloved husband of 52 beautiful years to Rhetta, with whom he created a family tree overflowing with love and laughter. Loving, devoted father of Nicole Felton and Paul Ginsberg, Aimee and Jonathan Freedman, Lauren and Jon Roberts, and Gregg and Marla Felton. Adoring grandfather of Sydney, Alex, and Benjamin Ginsberg, William Freedman, Molly and Jackson Roberts, and Nathalie and Andrew Felton. Loving brother-in-law to Susan Felton, and Bonnie and Steven Stern, and adored uncle to his many nieces and nephews. A mentor, confidante, and friend to all . . . If any of us lives a life filled with even half the joy and laughter and love that Max had in his, we would all be very lucky indeed. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to Siteman Cancer Center/Washington University, Siteman Cancer Center, CB1204, 7425 Forsyth, St. Louis, MO 63105 directed to Dr. William Hawkins Pancreatic Research Fund or to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, Greater New York Chapter, 120 Broadway, Suite 1050A, New York, NY 10271 or to a charity of your choice. Service Sunday, August 9, 1pm at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3
FELTON--Dr. Maxwell. Max, we will miss you sorely and will never forget all the good times we had together. Suellen and David Globus 1/3

ARENSBERG--Frederic Ph.D.,Psychoanalyst passed away on August 6th of cancer at the age of 80. He was well known for his use of empathic self psychology in his individual and group practice. He will be greatly missed by family, friends and patients. He is survived by his wife Leda, daughter Ronni, son Evan and sister Alice. Services will be held on Sunday, August 9th, 9:30am, at The Plaza Chapel in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The American Cancer Society. 1/3

SPITZER--Nancy Dinetz. June 21, 1939 - July 30, 2015. Born in Brooklyn, NY. Daughter of Shirley Greenberg and Benjamin Dinetz, sister of Lawrence Dinetz and Sandra Dinetz Cohan, died at home in Bridgehampton, NY. She is survived by husband Morton Edward Spitzer, sons Matthew Cook Spitzer and Douglas Sherman Spitzer and granddaughter Raphaelle Spitzer. She graduated 1957 George W. Wingate High School and 1961 Brooklyn College. Graduated from the Barbizon School for Modeling. Married in 1965. Employed in the 1960s by the New York City Department of Labor. Long-time Volunteer organizer for the League of Women Voters in Texas and New Jersey. Resident through her lifetime of New York, New Jersey (three times), Texas, California, and Massachusetts. Donations to the League of Women Voters or The Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center would be appreciated by the family. 1/3

FELTON--Maxwell J. Dad, As the heart and soul of our family, it is hard to imagine a life without you -- except for the fact that you passed on every piece of yourself to each of us so that we will never have to. Your incredible gifts of kindness towards your extended family and friends had no limits, and you probably could never have imagined the impact you had on the countless people whose lives you touched. You were the magnet that attracted all sixteen of your children and grandchildren and kept us glued together as we traveled from New York to Connecticut to Montana to Israel and beyond. We hung on your every word, spent hours singing your brilliant song lyrics, and simply wanted to be close to you to soak in your goodness, wit, and wisdom. We promise to honor your legacy and to take care of each other as you took care of all of us. Adoringly and Forever, Nikki and Paul Aimee and Jonathan Lauren and Jon Gregg and Marla . . . and all of your sweet chickadees 1/3

MARX--Patricia Lois (Wiener), 65 years old, died peacefully in her sleep surrounded by her loving family on August 6, 2015. She is survived by her daughter Tara and granddaughter Olivia. She will forever be in our hearts. Graveside Services Sunday, 11:30am, Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY. 1/3

The bride is a vice president at the Carlyle Group. The groom is a vice president at Morgan Stanley. They work in New York.
The bride is studying for a doctorate in clinical psychology, and the groom is the deputy chief of staff for a congressman.
The bride will start work as an associate at law firm next month. The groom is a law student.
The bride and groom met at Dartmouth. The bride’s father is an owner of the Philadelphia Phillies.
The bride is an analyst at Goldman Sachs; the groom is to become a management consultant at Bain & Company.
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 9, 2015.

WILLIAMSON--Susan K. The Skidmore College Board of Trustees and the entire college community mourns the recent death but celebrates the life of Susan Kettering Williamson, who passed away peacefully July 11 at age 78. Susan, a member of Skidmore's class of 1959, to whom Skidmore granted an honorary doctorate in humane letters in 1998, was a generous philanthropist, contributing to a range of organizations, primarily those serving youth, education, and the communities in which she lived. She was Skidmore's longest-serving trustee (1972-2012), guiding the board through the selection of four presidents, advising the college on its move to a new campus and to coeducation, and serving as a constant source of encouragement and support. She served on nearly every board committee and helped guide five major fundraising campaigns. She also held numerous volunteer positions, including reunion planner, class fund chair, and club volunteer. She widened student access through the Williamson and Kettering Scholars programs, supported the expansion of the Williamson Sports Center, and endowed two professorships: the Williamson Chair in Neuroscience and the David H. Porter Chair. In 2010 she rallied more than 10,000 donors through the Williamson Challenge to cap the Creative Thought, Bold Promise Campaign. But beyond all her public achievements, Susan was known for her personal warmth, quick wit, and quiet wisdom. She is survived by three daughters, a son, six grandchildren, a sister, niece Susan Kettering '80, and grandniece Amy Beck '15. Her husband, Peter, predeceased her. All of us in the Skidmore community offer our deepest condolences to Susan's family and friends. Linda G. Toohey, Chair, Board of Trustees Philip A. Glotzbach, President 1/3

HILLMAN--Elsie Hilliard. On August 4, 2015, Elsie Hilliard Hillman, devoted wife of loving husband Henry for 70 years, mother of Lea Simonds, Audrey Fisher, Henry Hillman, Jr. and Bill Hillman, grandmother of nine, great- grandmother of fourteen, civic and political leader, and philanthropist, died peacefully surrounded by her family at Shadyside Hospital in Pittsburgh. She was 89 years old. She was "Elsie" to anyone who she ever had the pleasure to meet and a groundbreaking leader for women in politics for over half a century. A former National Republican Committeewoman, she was a confidant and friend to Governors, Senators, Presidents, and hundreds of Pittsburghers from all walks of life. Still active in the community at the time of her death, she was chair of the Elsie H. Hillman Foundation, a trustee of the Hillman Family Foundations, co-chair of the UPCI and UPMC CancerCenter Council, and served as a board member of WQED, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, Hill House Association and director emeritus of several more organizations and universities. She was the recipient of eight honorary degrees and countless honors over the course of her life including being named a Distinguished Daughter of Pennsylvania. Elsie was recently recognized by the University of Pittsburgh Institute of Politics as the subject of a publication entitled, "Never a Spectator: The Political Life of Elsie Hillman," on her civic career and groundbreaking work as a political and community leader as well as an advocate for women and minorities in elected office. Her record of civic involvement is a testimonial to her complete devotion to serving people in any way she could. She will be greatly missed by many and her legacy will never be forgotten. Funeral arrangements will be private and for the immediate family only. A community memorial service to celebrate her remarkable life is being planned for Saturday, September 19th at 10:30am at Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Hillman Cancer Center at the University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute or to a charity of one's choice. 1/3

WOOD--Richard J. Japan Society mourns the loss of Dr. Richard J. Wood, president 2006-2009. Among many accomplishments during his tenure, Wood strengthened and deepened understanding and friendship between the United States and Japan, steered the Society's centennial celebration highlighted by galas in New York and Tokyo, and created more programming opportunity globally. A Japanese philosophy and religion specialist, Wood was Professor and Dean Emeritus at the Yale University Divinity School, and a chair of the Japan-U.S. Friendship Commission of the United States Government and the U.S.-Japan Cultural and Educational Conference, an agency of the U.S. Department of State. In 2010 the government of Japan awarded him The Order of the Rising Sun, Gold and Silver Star. In addition to his contributions to U.S.-Japan relations, he will be remembered for his indefatigable kindness, benevolence and support. Our hearts go out to his wife Judy, his children, grandchildren and all family and friends during this difficult time. Wilbur Ross, Chairman, and Motoatsu Sakurai, President 1/3

MORELLI--Phyllis B. 1933-2015. Phyllis Jacqueline Backer Morelli of Brooklyn, New York, passed away at the age of 82, on August 4, 2015. Beloved wife of dearly departed John D. Morelli; mother of Laura Morelli Conway, Steven and Johnny Morelli; sister of Joan Backer Meer; sister-in-law of Louis and Maria Morelli; mother-in- law of Kevin D. Conway and Rita Morelli; numerous beloved cousins, nieces, nephews and friends far too many to list. Phyllis was a woman of diverse talents, ranging from her early love of dance and the language arts, to her horticultural talents that became her creative outlet for many, many years. A 1954 Magna Cum Laude graduate of Brandeis University, where she met her husband John, Phyllis went on to teach Spanish while raising their three children. She loved to travel and capture memories with photographs. After retiring from teaching, Phyllis relished in nurturing her exotic plants, challenging herself with The New York Times crosswords and other puzzles, and enjoying classical music or world news on NPR. She delighted in her role as secretary/treasurer of her summer retreat in the Adirondacks. Phyllis will always be remembered as the beauty she was, inside and out, for her vivacious laughter and wit, her warm and loving character, her loyal friendship and her constant thoughtfulness. May she and her husband John be reunited in the hereafter for an eternity of love. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations to the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens, or deathwithdig nity.org in Phyllis's memory. 1/3

KINZ--Lance, art dealer, died on August 3, 2015 aged 64. He graduated from Kent State and the University of Cincinnati. With his partner Susan Reynolds, he continued to champion emerging and established artists. The gallery became Kinz + Tillou Fine Art in 2007 with partner Michelle Tillou and later moved from Chelsea to Brooklyn. He was a gentleman of integrity and taste, generous with his knowledge and respected by his colleagues. His unique vision and great spirit will be missed. A memorial will be held in the fall. POPPER--Dr. Lydia R. Her many friends here and abroad note with great sadness the death of our dear Lydia on August 6 at age 95. Lydia had a full and adventurous life. Forced to flee her native Vienna, she spent the war years in London and came to the US in 1947. At age 58 she fulfilled a long-time wish, receiving a Doctor of Law degree from the University of Vienna. In later years she was German diction coach at New York City Opera, Opera Orchestra of New York, and the Martina Arroyo Foundation, as well as with private students. Widowed twice, she was predeceased by her long-time companion, Dr. Bruno Roedl. Known for her rapier wit, her passion for music, art, languages and politics, her wonderful dinner parties, and her generosity to friends and causes, Lydia was truly one- of-a-kind. She was mentor and mother-confessor, cherished colleague and role model to young and old. She leaves an enormous hole in many hearts. 1/3

LIEBERMAN--Herman, died peacefully in his 97th year. He was a Brooklyn man - born in Brownsville, lived in Crown Heights and Sheepshead Bay - and was an avid Brooklyn Dodger fan. He served in the United States Army Signal Corps during World War II and knew Morse Code by heart. He loved studying foreign languages and spoke Yiddish, Hebrew, Latin and Spanish. He was completely devoted to his late wife, Florence and dedicated himself to her care during her long bout with Alzheimer's. May his memory be a blessing. 1/3

JONES--Howard W.,Jr., MD. We honor the life of Howard W. Jones, Jr., MD, 104, a pioneering medical visionary, dedicated mentor, internationally renowned gynecological surgeon, and the father of in vitro fertilization in the United States. Dr. Jones, along with his wife Dr. Georgeanna Seegar Jones, helped create America's first "test-tube" baby in 1981, transforming reproductive medical science and propelling the field from a dream to reality. Their innovations have enabled nearly 6 million births worldwide through in vitro fertilization. Dr. Jones served on the Board and was Honorary Chairman of the Board of the Jones Foundation for Reproductive Medicine until the time of his death. The Foundation funds groundbreaking research and the fellows and doctors trained at the Foundation share their knowledge around the world to serve mankind. Dr. Jones's keen mind, up until the end of his life, astonished his colleagues, friends and family. He continued to stay abreast of reproductive endocrinology, attend lectures and conferences, and ask probing questions during medical meetings. "One more question," he would proclaim in his deep voice. "Ageless, he never aged," said Dr. Alan DeCherney, director of the Program in Reproductive and Adult Endocrinology at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. Dr. Jones was born on December 30, 1910 in Baltimore, Maryland. It was a remarkable coincidence that he was delivered, at home, by his future father-in-law, Dr. King Seegar. His father was a physician and they went on house calls together in a horse and buggy. When Dr. Jones was 13, his father died and his aunt helped raise him. Dr. Jones attended the Friends School in Baltimore and Amherst College, where his professor of English was Robert Frost. Dr. Jones graduated from Amherst cum laude in 1931. Dr. Jones loved to recount how he fell in love with Georgeanna Seegar on February 29th, 1932 at a medical lecture. She later said that the evening changed her life. He assumed it was because it was the night she fell in love with him, too; she insisted it was because he inspired her to apply to medical school and become an endocrinologist. They were rarely apart, sharing one desk and one car. Dr. Jones served in WWII as the chief of a mobile surgical team in the United States Corp Fifth Auxiliary Surgical Group with General George S. Patton. When Dr. Jones was 94, he published a collection of love letters he and his wife wrote each day during the war. Dr. Georgeanna Seegar Jones died in 2005. In the 1950s, Dr. Jones collaborated on landmark cervical cancer studies and became the recognized expert at Johns Hopkins for genital abnormalities and reconstructions. In 1965, he, and his wife, who was the director of the Division of Reproductive Endocrinology at Johns Hopkins, and Dr. Robert Edwards, collaborated in the lab and succeeded at the first steps of in vitro fertilization. After mandatory retirement from Johns Hopkins, a former classmate, Dr. Mason Andrews, recruited Drs. Howard and Georgeanna Jones to the Eastern Virginia Medical School. They continued working on in vitro fertilization and had 41 failures before their first success, when Judith Carr gave birth to Elizabeth Carr on December 28, 1981, two days before Dr. Jones's 71st birthday. Over the years, Dr. Jones welcomed former patients who came with their toddlers to celebrate Mother's Day and baby photos adorned his office. Dr. Jones served with great distinction as Professor Emeritus of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Eastern Virginia Medical School. He was also Professor Emeritus at Johns Hopkins where he served as Professor of Gynecology and Obstetrics, acting Chairman of the Department, and Secretary General of the University Program for International Education. Dr. Jones received honorary degrees from the University of Cordoba, Old Dominion University, Amherst College, the University of Madrid, and Eastern Virginia Medical School. He is the recipient of the Medal of the College of France and the Distinguished Service Award of the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology. He launched the first ethics committee dealing with fertility as part of the American Society for Reproductive Medicine. At the age of 103, he wrote In Vitro Fertilization Comes to America: Memoir of a Medical Breakthrough, retelling his amazing career. A year earlier, he published Personhood Revisited: Reproductive Technology, Bioethics, Religion and the Law, an exploration into the legal and ethical implications of fertility treatments and a perspective on pending legislation seeking to define the union of a sperm and egg as a person. Dr. Jones published a dozen books and hundreds of scientific journal articles. Dr. Jones is survived by three children, seven grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. His son, Howard W. Jones III, MD, is Chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Vanderbilt University School of Medicine. A daughter, Georgeanna Jones Klingensmith, MD, is the Past Director of Pediatric Diabetes at the Barbara Davis Diabetes Center at the University of Colorado, and his son Lawrence Massey Jones is a Denver-based financial advisor. At a 100th birthday celebration Dr. Jones quoted his professor at Amherst in describing himself: "Two Roads diverged in a wood, and I -- I took the one less traveled by, And that has made all the difference."-- Robert Frost. The Board and staff of the Jones Foundation for Reproductive Medicine, millions of parents and children, and those who had the good fortune to be touched by his innovative genius and kind spirit honor the man who took the road less traveled. Howard P. Milstein Chairman Howard and Georgeanna Jones Foundation for Reproductive Medicine 1/3

POLLIS--Adamantia, 92, died Wednesday, August 5, 2015. Addie was a life-long resident of New York City, a place she loved. A George Washington High school graduate, she received a BA in Economics from Hunter College and an MA in Economics and a PhD in Political Science from The Johns Hopkins University. An early rebel, Addie broke the mold for young Greek American woman and committed herself to doing what she could about the injustices she saw in the world. She was a fighter for gender equality decades before this novel idea had a name. A career in the academy was, for Addie, the ideal way to pursue knowledge and social change as a teacher, researcher and activist. Addie was an internationally recognized scholar of Human Rights and of Modern Greek Politics. Throughout a distinguished teaching career at Hunter and at the Graduate Faculty of the New School for Social Research, from which she retired as Professor Emerita, she mentored many students and engaged in significant collaborative research with several of them and other scholars. Her love of teaching was a dominant force in her life. A notable project was the weekly radio program on New York City's WEVD - Free Voice of Greece - a key component of the international movement that toppled the Greek military junta in 1974. Addie is survived by her brother, Nicholas Pollis and sister-in-law, Carol, two nieces and a nephew, and many dear friends who will miss her greatly. She will be remembered as a pioneer and a force for good. A memorial service will be held in the fall. 1/3

FRENTZ--William C. Of Cos Cob, CT, died August 1, 2015. Born May 21, 1934 in Chicago, IL, son of Hugo and Rose Frentz. His beloved wife, Joanne W. Frentz, pre-deceased him November 2014. Survived by a sister-in-law and nieces and a nephew. Upon graduating from Northwestern University with an MBA degree, he worked in commercial real estate investments, and served as Vice President at both Equitable and The Guardian Life Insurance Companies. 1/3

TORRENCE--Jerry M. Jerry Melville Torrence, 80, passed away on the evening of Friday, June 19 at his home in New York City, after a long bout with mouth cancer. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife Judith Douglas Torrence in 2002. Jerry was born on February 10, 1935 in St. Charles, Madison County, Iowa, the only child of James and Laura Dawn Torrence. The family moved to Des Moines when Jerry was five, and his parents remained in that one house the rest of their lives. Jerry's entire education was through Iowa schools, from elementary school in Des Moines, to his years at North High, to his graduation with a BA in Business from the University of Iowa in 1957, where he pledged the Iowa Beta chapter of Sigma Alpha Epsilon in the spring of 1954. And for all his success and travel in later life, that Iowa foundation remained the single most important facet of his life, a memory that he supported emotionally and financially throughout his years. Jerry moved to Chicago after graduation to work at Marshall Field & Company, but an offer from Regal Rugs in New York in 1960 brought him to the city that that became his life. He drove through the Lincoln Tunnel that May in a convertible with Iowa plates, and a wooden ironing board lodged between luggage in the back seat and passenger's front seat. He stayed at Regal Rugs until his retirement in June of 2003. Jerry was fiercely loyal to his principles, the company and his customers, an invaluable asset to Regal. His social life paralleled his business career; Jerry's unique personality guaranteed that he did not go unnoticed in either a Board Room or a barroom. He became a fixture in some of the most popular retail stores, bars and restaurants in the booming Manhattan of the '60s through the '90s. Our collective recall of Jerry's antics at both work and play would fill a decent size coffee table book. The lasting legacy of the Torrence family, however, was their connection to St. Charles, and, in particular, the St. Charles Methodist Church. Jerry's parents, grandparents and Judith have been laid to rest at this beautiful ground, and Jerry contributed generously to the upkeep of the property for years. Jerry will be buried at St. Charles Cemetery next to his wife Judith on Saturday, August 29th, 2015. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be sent to St. Charles Methodist Church, St. Charles, IA 50240 and/or Fallen and Wounded Soldiers Fund, PO Box 33099, Bloomfield Hill, MI 48303-0003. 1/3
