He will always be remembered for his sharp wit and humor, loyalty and devotion to his family. A private service will be held. Shiva will be at the home of Bunny Ash, on Sunday and Monday evening 6-9pm. Contributions may be sent to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Calvin Joseph. Aug. 30, 1925 - Aug. 10, 2003 Cal died 12 years ago tomorrow but his loving spirit, kind affection, passion, and irrepressible joy in living continues to lift us up. To this day he inspires us to be completely genuine and to love life without reservation. For that we are eternally grateful. 1/3

JONES--Robert Wesley. July 24th 1929 - July 21st 2015. Born in Boston into a remarkable African American family, Robert Jones served as a Marine during the Korean War. He held a senior position in city government, then in a national African American construction firm before he opened his own successful real estate firm, Robert W. Jones and Associates. He became the first African American Counselor of Real Estate (CRE) in the United States. The map of his life is an inspiration: he was a groundbreaker and fighter for social justice in every role he played. He is survived by his wife Elaine, his sons Todd and Austin, four grandchildren and a large extended, transnational, transracial and transcultural family in the U.S. and beyond. Donations may be made in his memory to MJHS, 6323 7th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11220. 1/3

RODGERS--C. R. Perry, Jr.,of Washington Crossing, Pennsylvania, and Vero Beach, Florida, died peacefully at his home on August 4, 2015. Born in Baltimore to the late Christopher R. P. and Charlotte Hundley Rodgers, he is survived by his wife, Toni M. Tracy, two children from his first marriage, Mary Rodgers Boughey (Simon) of London and Christopher R. P. Rodgers III (Danyel) of Sudbury, Massachusetts. He is also survived by three beloved grandsons, Perry, Tyler, and Zack Rodgers, nine sisters and brothers, numerous nieces, nephews, and in-laws, his former wife, Rosemary B. Rodgers, and a wide and wonderful circle of friends. A longtime resident of Princeton, New Jersey, he attended Princeton Country Day School, the South Kent School, and the University of Arizona before enlisting in the United States Marine Corps and serving proudly and honorably in Vietnam. He completed his undergraduate education at Rider University in Lawrenceville, New Jersey, and spent the bulk of his career in the insurance brokerage industry in Philadelphia and Manhattan, retiring from Crystal & Co. in 2009. After his retirement, he volunteered in a newly formed hospice unit of the VA Hospital in Lyons, New Jersey. Dedicated to the game of golf, he was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club, Springdale Golf Club in Princeton and Riomar Country Club and Quail Valley in Vero Beach. He was also a member of the United States Seniors Golf Association. A service in celebration of his life will be held on Tuesday, August 11 at 11:00 am in the Miller Chapel of the Princeton Theological Seminary, 64 Mercer Street, Princeton. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory are suggested to the Kimmel Cancer Center at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia or to a charity that supports and honors military veterans. Services are under the direction of The Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, Princeton. 1/3

GRANT--Ellen Pierce, formerly of Purchase, NY and Jupiter, FL, passed away on August 5, 2015, following a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. Born on February 26, 1931, in Chicago, IL, Ellen was the second of the three children of Hyman and Thelma Pierce. Ellen was raised in Highland Park, IL, and graduated from Wellesley College in 1952. In the same year, Ellen married Gardner Lewis Grant and moved to Providence, RI, where she and Gardner had two children, Laura and Gardner, Jr. The family moved to Scarsdale, NY in 1962. Ellen is survived by her siblings, Daniel M. Pierce and Susan P. Axelrod, her children Laura Grant Zimmerman and Gardner L. Grant, Jr., her children-in-law, Dr. Franklin H. Zimmerman and Sulu Hegde Grant, and her grandchildren, Stacey, Richard, Sean and Shakira. 1/3
FELTON--Dr. Maxwell. Max, we will miss you sorely and will never forget all the good times we had together. Suellen and David Globus 1/3

KAMINE-BROWN--Carol. The Board, Staff, Clients and Friends of Concerned Home Managers for the Elderly are in mourning over the loss of our Executive Manager, Carol Kamine-Brown. Her huge heart was a blessing and a beacon for us all. Our thoughts and prayers are with her beloved daughter, Marissa. 1/3
KOTZEN--LeRoy M.,M.D. October 4, 1936-August 9, 2010. Forever cherished, the center piece of my life. Always, Linda 1/3
SCAASI--Arnold. "The Dramatist of Elegance" How glamorous you made us all look and feel. I shall always cherish the wonderful times I had with you and Parker. Kathleen B. Hearst 1/3
FRAUST--Howard. Sept. 5th 1946-August 9th 2005 We are still one, as ever and Always, Joan 1/3
GELLMAN--Howard. On the ninth anniversary of your passing, you are still remembered and missed. 1/3

FELTON--Maxwell J. Dad, As the heart and soul of our family, it is hard to imagine a life without you -- except for the fact that you passed on every piece of yourself to each of us so that we will never have to. Your incredible gifts of kindness towards your extended family and friends had no limits, and you probably could never have imagined the impact you had on the countless people whose lives you touched. You were the magnet that attracted all sixteen of your children and grandchildren and kept us glued together as we traveled from New York to Connecticut to Montana to Israel and beyond. We hung on your every word, spent hours singing your brilliant song lyrics, and simply wanted to be close to you to soak in your goodness, wit, and wisdom. We promise to honor your legacy and to take care of each other as you took care of all of us. Adoringly and Forever, Nikki and Paul Aimee and Jonathan Lauren and Jon Gregg and Marla . . . and all of your sweet chickadees 1/3

STEFANCIC--Karen Lynn, 57, passed away on June 11th after a brief illness. Karen is survived by her partner of 34 years, Greg Casadei; parents Delores and Marvin Kiesow; brother Ken (Karin) and his family. Karen spent her childhood in Milwaukee and graduated in 1975 from The University School. She received her BA from Wellesley College in Wellesley, MA in 1980. After several years working in New York City for Bergdorf Goodman in Retail Finance, she earned an MBA at Dartmouth. Karen resumed her career in New York as a Corporate Banker and Security Analyst, specializing in media, cable and telecommunications at Citibank, Credit du Nord, The Royal Bank of Scotland and the NAIC as a Credit Analyst. For many years, Karen was Alumnae President of Society Zeta Alpha at Wellesley College and a volunteer at the Greenwich, CT Library. Karen will be sorely missed by her dear friends, to whom she was intensely loyal. She loved her cats Tucker and Shadow, the beach, old movies, Motown and classical music. Karen was known in post-college days for her glamorous style and active social life. She was an incurable romantic and whenever we hear a song by Earth, Wind & Fire, we will picture Karen dancing. 1/3

SCHULTE--Vivian S. Died peacefully at her home in Manalapan, FL on July 21, 2015. She was 97 years old. An avid tennis player and fan, music lover and food journalist, Vivian was also an author of poetry and won several awards for her work. Vivian was born in New York City, daughter of the late Dr. Simon L. Sternfield and Pauline Tonkonogy Sternfield. A devoted wife to the late Arthur Schulte for 40 years, Vivian leaves behind an extended family of grandchildren, great grandchildren, nephews and a grand nephew and grand niece. She received a B.A. degree from Hunter College, an M.A. degree from Columbia University, and a Ph.D. from New York University. In 1941 she became Food Consultant and Lecturer for L. Bamberger and Co. in Newark and conducted a radio program on Nutrition for WOR during World War II to help homemakers make the most of available foods. She conducted classes in nutrition and food preservation in Newark under the auspices of the American Red Cross. She also served as Food and Home Editor for Fawcett, Hearst and Curtis Publications. Vivian won the American Dairy Association Award for distinguished food journalism. She was a member of Pi Lambda Theta, Honor Society of the Education profession and Kappa Omicron Nu, Honor Society of the Home Economics profession. Vivian was a member of the following: New York Academy of Sciences, American Dietetic Association, Greater New York Dietetic Association, Food and Nutrition Council of New York, American Home Economics Association and Les Dames DEscoffier; and was, in her later years, frequently found with friends at one of her favorite clubs, La Coquille in Manalapan, FL. Dr. Schulte, as she liked to be referred to, was an avid fan of the Metropolitan Opera and was known to participate from her seat from time to time. She was most proud in her later years of her poetry, for which she won numerous awards and was recognized in various publications. Dr. Schulte is survived by 5 grandchildren: Margot Levinson Gantz, Drew Levinson, John Levinson, Lucy Schulte Danziger, Peter Schulte; nine great grandchildren and four nephews: Tom, John, Mark and Jonathan Sternfield. There will be a memorial service held in the fall in New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider memorial donations to: The Hunter College Foundation; memo: Mothers Day Scholarship Fund in Honor of Vivian Schulte, at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, Room E1313, New York, New York 10065. 1/3

GOTTLIEB--Dorothy "Dottie", died in her sleep July 26, age 92. A life-long New Yorker, she moved to California to be near family for her last years. Dottie will be remembered by friends and family for her independent spirit and her life in activist politics. She and her husband Leo Fox loved sailing together. She had a million stories to tell, interesting and fascinating friends. Funny and hip, she was smart as a whip until the very end. Those who knew her wish her fair winds and following seas. 1/3

RUDGES--Seymour C.,of Longboat Key, FL, formerly of New York, passed away peacefully on the night of August 1st just 2 months shy of his 97th birthday. He is survived by his beloved wife of 27 years Judy (Chanin), two daughters, Sara Lynn Goldsmith (Harvey), and Patty Rudges, two grandchildren, Adam Goldsmith (Danielle) and Courtney Walker (Brian) and great grandchildren Tessa, Gray, Josie and Peyton. He is also survived by his step-children Robert Golub (Grace) and Richard Golub (Joan) and step-grand children Rebecca, Brian, Grant and Kaitie. Sy lived life to the fullest. He was an avid collector of Asian antiques and was able to indulge his passion for exotic travel. He loved his family, he loved his friends, he loved his life. He will always be remembered and dearly missed. 1/3

ZEFF--Joyce. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of Joyce Zeff, of Englewood, Colorado. Together with her beloved late husband Kalman (Technion B.Sc '51), she was a Technion Guardian, a designation for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. The Zeffs supported numerous Technion projects, including the Kal and Joyce Zeff Floors and Entrance in the Rabin Civil and Environmental Engineering Building, and the Kal Zeff Fellowship Fund. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Joyce and Kal's children: Diana Zeff Anderson, Ron Zeff, Michael Zeff, and Dana Zeff, and the entire Zeff family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeff Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

GIFFORD--Frank. Association to Benefit Children (ABC) was blessed by Frank Gifford's true friendship, his loyalty, and his devotion. He was an honest to goodness champion of the smallest and most vulnerable children. With grit and faithfulness he stood up for them, took the pain, won for them equal rights. He and Kathie brought hope and love and joy and justice, a voice for those who were suffering in silence. Together, he and Kathie Lee, built Cody House and Cassidy's Place, in honor of their own cherished children. It is a legacy of gentleness, compassion and love. 1/3

She is survived by her husband of 15 years, Timothy Faryniarz; two daughters Julia and Elahna Sobel-Faryniarz all of East Montpelier; her parents Alex and Bobbi Sobel of Palm Beach Gardens, FL/Oceanside, NY; and her sister Lauren Sobel Shapiro of West Orange, NJ. Funeral services will be held at 11am today August 11 in the Grand Ballroom at the Capitol Plaza Hotel, 100 State St., Montpelier, VT with interment to follow in Green Mount Cemetery. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the following charities: Camp Tel Yehudah, Prevent Child Abuse, Beth Jacob Synagogue, Montpelier, Central Vermont Humane Society. Services are being handled by Boucher and Pritchard Funeral Directors, Burlington, VT. 1/3

GIFFORD--Frank. Frank Gifford earned his legendary status as a New York Giant and broadcaster but to Bob and us he was also a dear and trusted friend, a part of our family. He was warm, witty, humane and loyal and we will miss him dearly. Our heartfelt sympathies to Kathie Lee and the entire Gifford family. Joan, Steve, Laurie, Jonathan and Lizzie Tisch and families 1/3

STARR--Sonya. Sonya Starr, a remarkable, beautiful and vivacious woman who loved and lived life to its fullest, died peacefully in her New York City apartment on Sunday, August 9, following a courageous battle with lymphoma. She was 68. Raised by a strong and loving grandmother and mother in a close-knit Russian family that had escaped Stalinist Russia, Sonya came with her family to New York City as a very young girl. When her father, a noted Dostoevsky scholar, joined the faculty at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the family relocated to Troy, NY, where Sonya, recognized for her intellectual promise, entered Russell Sage College at age 15. Receiving a master's degree in Russian Literature from the State University of New York at Albany and fluent in Russian, French and Spanish, Sonya realized she had a unique talent for business. She also had an appreciation for historic buildings, and at a time when inner cities in New York, such as Albany and Troy, were focusing on revitalization, she built a successful real estate company by acquiring, renovating and managing older residential buildings. Wide-ranging and accomplished, Sonya was a true Renaissance woman. She had a deep love of literature, art and nature, and was devoted to her two Yorkies, Misha and Sasha. With her life partner, she amassed an important collection of vintage photographs and sculpture. Sonya was also an accomplished gardener and took great pride in the exquisite natural landscape and sculpture garden she created at her summer home in East Hampton, NY. Her exceptional taste extended beyond the garden to her personal style and elegant decor of her homes. Her enthusiasm for life, wonderful humor, sharp intelligence and peerless creativity will be deeply missed by friends and family, and her memory forever cherished by Lisa Rosenblum her spouse and partner of 36 years. Donations in Sonya Starr's memory, in lieu of flowers, would be appreciated to: Citymeals-on-Wheels, New York, NY or the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, Wainscott, NY. 1/3

CLAY--Harris, 88, died peacefully on Saturday August 8, 2015. He is survived by his son, Jonathan C. Clay, grandsons James C. Clay and Harrison A. Clay, his brother Landon T. Clay, and four nephews. Born in New York City, Clay was a lifelong resident of Augusta, GA, where his family was associated with the textile industry. After attending Middlesex School in Concord, MA, he graduated with honors from Harvard College, Class of 1950. He also attended Harvard Law School and Harvard Medical School. He served our country in the Navy during World War II. He was a successful businessman with Minot Hooper & Co., New York, then CEO of J.P. King Manufacturing Co. in Augusta, GA. After the sale of the mill, he studied geology, and was President of Arctic Coast Petroleum, LLC and Mink Mining in Calgary, Canada. He had an unwavering passion for world travel and exploring the finest restaurants in France and Italy. He was a wine connoisseur and enjoyed the best wines from Bordeaux and Burgundy. He was an upstanding and moral individual. He contributed to education and medical research among his philanthropic endeavors. A memorial service will be held at his home in Augusta, GA. 1/3

VAUGHN--Terry. Oxford University Press mourns the passing of Terry Vaughn, friend, colleague, and fellow traveler. Terry was a legendary editor whose influence in economics and finance publishing was powerfully in evidence for decades and whose contributions spanned the programs of MIT Press, Princeton University Press, and Oxford University Press. His most important legacy, however, is his family and the network of friends and admirers he leaves behind. As we all struggle to make sense of the enormity and suddenness of this loss, the same sentiments are voiced again and again: "Terry was a great editor but an even better person." "Terry was one of the nicest people I met in publishing, such a lovely guy." "I remember him fondly and with admiration." "There was such an aura of vigor and eternal youth about him." Renowned for his passions and varied interests, his self-critical introspection, and his warmth and good will (as well as for a marvelously astute and pithy definition of game theory during an editorial meeting several years ago), Terry was a serious person with an easy laugh and a perpetually bemused air. We were very fond of him and we will miss him greatly. 1/3

MERRYMAN--John H. IFAR (the International Foundation for Art Research) mourns the loss of John Merryman, Professor Emeritus Stanford Law School and longtime member of our Law Advisory Council. He was Senior Advisor to IFAR's Art Law and Cultural Property Database, a dear friend, and a giant in the field of art law. Sharon Flescher, Exec. Dir. Anthony Williams, Chairman 1/3

JOHNSEN--Niels Winchester. Age 93, Rumson. After busy summer days with grandchildren and great-grandchildren, Niels Winchester Johnsen, 93, passed away at home in Rumson, New Jersey, on Friday, August 7, 2015. Niels was predeceased by his wife, Millicent Mercer Johnsen, on September 7, 2013, and their daughter, Gretchen Johnsen Bryant, on June 18, 2014. Niels was the son of Niels F. Johnsen and Anita Winchester Johnsen of New Orleans and was born in New Orleans. Niels retired in 2003 as Chairman of International Shipholding Corporation, the parent company of Central Gulf Lines, Inc. and Waterman Steamship Corporation. Niels was co-founder, with his father and brother, Erik F. Johnsen, of Central Gulf Steamship Corporation in New Orleans, April 1947. After attending Tulane University, Niels began his career in the maritime industry in 1942, serving over three and one- half years as an officer in the Merchant Marine at sea during World War II. During his sea duty, he survived two ship torpedo sinkings. After coming ashore in 1946, Niels joined States Marine Lines, a United States flag shipping company chaired by his father-in-law, Henry Dickson Mercer. Niels served as vice- president of chartering at States Marine in New York until February 1957 when he resigned to devote full time to Central Gulf. During the years 1957-1971, Central Gulf became the major United States flag shipping company operating between the United States and the Middle East- Southeast Asia. In 1971 Central Gulf merged with Trans Union Corporation. Niels became a director of Trans Union as a result of the merger. During the years 1971- 1979, Central Gulf continued its growth. In 1979 Trans Union spun off its shipping interests under the name of International Shipholding Corporation and Niels became Chairman. International Shipholding continued its dominant United States flag presence under Niels' and his brother Erik's leadership. In 1985 International Shipholding became the first United States flag carrier to enter the specialized pure car/truck carrier trade. At various times over his 60-year maritime career, Niels served on the board of managers of the American Bureau of Shipping and the board of trustees of the Seaman's Church Institute. For many years he was a trustee of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Corporation and a director of the Centennial Insurance Company and served as a director and chairman of the National Cargo Bureau. Over his long and distinguished career in the maritime industry, Niels' many achievements were given special recognition including the Seamen's Church Institute Silver Bell Award in 1988 and the Admiral of the Ocean Seas (AOTOS) Award in 1993. Niels was a member of India House, Rumson Country Club, Seabright Beach Club and Lyford Cay Club. He was a member of the First Presbyterian Church at Red Bank-Tower Hill and the Church of the Holy Cross in Vail, Colorado. Niels loved golf and was a long-time member of the United States Seniors Golf Association. Niels is survived by his brother, Erik F. Johnsen and his wife Barbara V. Johnsen; his two children: son Niels M. and wife Marlene; daughter Ingrid J. and husband William B. Barrett; seven grandchildren: Lisa J. and husband Michael S. Kane, Christina B. and husband Todd R. Robida, Elizabeth B. and husband Jeffrey T. Gardner, Jonathan W. and wife Carissa S. Barrett, and W. Brooks Barrett; Stephanie A. and husband Ken Moyers, and Heather C. Bryant; twelve great-grandchildren: Steven, Karl and Sofia Kane; Catherine and Benjamin Robida; Davis, Henry and Jack Gardner; Liam Barrett; and Harrison, Hayden and Hewitt Moyers. A service followed by a reception will be held at 11:00am on Thursday, August 13, 2015, at the Elberon Memorial Church, 70 Park Avenue, Elberon, New Jersey 07740. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in Niels' memory to the Elberon Memorial Church or Twin Lights Historical Society, Twin Lights Historic Site, Lighthouse Road, Highlands, New Jersey 07732. 1/3

FLIESLER--Christine, 83, of Woodside, NY, Monterey, MA and Marlborough, MA, on August 9. Bellevue music therapist, choral singer, caretaker. Alum Queens College, Music & Art. Survived by Vicki, Nancy, Marni, Henry, Martine. Graveside service Wednesday 2:50 pm in New Jersey. Info: Levine Chapels 617-277-8300. 1/3

KARGMAN--Milton Arthur, 92, of Roslyn Heights, NY passed away on August 7, 2015. He was the beloved husband of Gloria, the devoted and loving father of his four sons Jeffrey, Jonathan, Steven and Douglas (deceased), and the cherished grandfather of Brooke and Tyler. He studied at City College and then enlisted in the Army Air Corps during World War II. He received his LLB from St. John's University School of Law and his LLM in Taxation from New York University School of Law. He was the co-founder and senior partner of the law firm of Tolmack & Kargman, P.C. in New York. He was the ultimate family man--someone who was deeply devoted to ensuring the happiness, success and well-being of all of the members of his family. He always considered himself to be incredibly fortunate to have met and married his lovely wife Gloria - they had just celebrated their sixty-second wedding anniversary only days before he passed away. He was enormously proud of his sons and all that they had accomplished and the values they represented, and he was also excited and proud to see his grandchildren developing into impressive young adults and achieving success in their own right. He led through his example of hard work, perseverance, integrity, and his unrelenting optimism and positive outlook embodied in his favorite motto, "Onward and Upward." He was highly regarded and admired for his work in the healthcare industry, and he was a frequent speaker at conferences and a regular contributor to professional journals. He enjoyed the good company of family friends and playing golf with his fellow members at The Muttontown Club where he formed many close friendships over a period of forty years. He will be missed terribly by his entire family, his friends and everyone who knew and came in contact with this terrific man. Funeral services will be held graveside at 1:30pm on Thursday, August 13 at Old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, Springfield Gardens, Queens, NY 11413. 1/3

GRACE--William J.,on August 9th, 2015 of East Hampton, NY. Beloved husband of Mary Therese. Loving father of Melissa, Billy, and Jennifer. Cherished grandfather of four. Memorial Mass Thursday, August 13th at 11:15 at St. Mary's Church, Manhasset, NY. 1/3

BARNETT--Laura. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Laura Barnett, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Laura's husband, Jack; her children, Philip and Pamela Barnett, and Howard and Cathy Barnett; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

SCAASI--Arnold. Literacy Partners regretfully announces the death of our iconic co-founder, Arnold Scaasi, who passed away on August 4th, age 85. Along with his husband, Parker Ladd, and dear friend Liz Smith, Mr. Scaasi's legendary generosity helped tens of thousands of adult New Yorkers learn to read. 1/3

SANDLER--Will B.,age 84, of New York City and Dunewood, Fire Island, passed away on Saturday, August 8, 2015 after a long illness. It is with profound sorrow that the partners, associates and staff of Troutman Sanders mourn the passing of its former esteemed senior partner (recently retired). Will was a leader of the firm's real estate department and contributed much to its development. He was a mentor and friend to all of the attorneys with whom he came in contact. Never too busy to lend a helping hand or assume responsibility for another attorney's project. He was admired and respected by his clients whom he represented with the highest degree of professionalism, giving them the best professional and business advice during his almost 60 years as an active real estate practitioner. A 1956 graduate of Columbia Law School and a 1953 cum laude with honors graduate of Brooklyn College. Will was a dear friend of those of us at Troutman Sanders and he will be sorely and truly missed. To his wife, children and grandchildren, sister and family, we extend our heartfelt sympathies. Troutman Sanders LLP 1/3

GIFFORD--Frank. Frank Gifford earned his legendary status as a New York Giant and broadcaster but to Bob and us he was also a dear and trusted friend, a part of our family. He was warm, witty, humane and loyal and we will miss him dearly. Our heartfelt sympathies to Kathie Lee and the entire Gifford family. Joan, Steve, Laurie, Jonathan and Lizzie Tisch and families 1/3
GLUCK--Dorothy. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime member, Dorothy Gluck. We express to her family our deepest sympathies. 1/3

FLIESLER--Christine, 83, of Woodside, NY, Monterey, MA and Marlborough, MA, on August 9. Bellevue music therapist, choral singer, caretaker. Alum Queens College, Music & Art. Survived by Vicki, Nancy, Marni, Henry, Martine. Graveside service Wednesday 2:50 pm in New Jersey. Info: Levine Chapels 617-277-8300. 1/3

GIFFORD--Frank. Association to Benefit Children (ABC) was blessed by Frank Gifford's true friendship, his loyalty, and his devotion. He was an honest to goodness champion of the smallest and most vulnerable children. With grit and faithfulness he stood up for them, took the pain, won for them equal rights. He and Kathie brought hope and love and joy and justice, a voice for those who were suffering in silence. Together, he and Kathie Lee, built Cody House and Cassidy's Place, in honor of their own cherished children. It is a legacy of gentleness, compassion and love. 1/3

SOBEL--Lara Kim. East Montpelier, VT, 48, died suddenly on Friday August 7, 2015 in Barre, VT. She was born in Oceanside, NY on February 26, 1967 the daughter of Alex and Bobbi (Schwartz) Sobel. Lara received her BA and Masters degrees from the University of Vermont. Lara was employed by the State of Vermont as a case worker for Department of Children Services. She is survived by her husband of 15 years, Timothy Faryniarz; two daughters Julia and Elahna Sobel-Faryniarz all of East Montpelier; her parents Alex and Bobbi Sobel of Palm Beach Gardens, FL/Oceanside, NY; and her sister Lauren Sobel Shapiro of West Orange, NJ. Funeral services will be held at 11am today August 11 in the Grand Ballroom at the Capitol Plaza Hotel, 100 State St., Montpelier, VT with interment to follow in Green Mount Cemetery. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the following charities: Camp Tel Yehudah, Prevent Child Abuse, Beth Jacob Synagogue, Montpelier, Central Vermont Humane Society. Services are being handled by Boucher and Pritchard Funeral Directors, Burlington, VT. 1/3

SCARANGELLA--Jack, a longtime resident of New Rochelle, died peacefully on August 9, 2015. He was 92. Services by Lloyd Maxcy & Sons Beauchamp Chapel, Inc., 16 Shea Pl., New Rochelle. For complete obituary, please visit: www.lloydmaxcy.com 1/3

SCAASI--Arnold. Literacy Partners regretfully announces the death of our iconic co-founder, Arnold Scaasi, who passed away on August 4th, age 85. Along with his husband, Parker Ladd, and dear friend Liz Smith, Mr. Scaasi's legendary generosity helped tens of thousands of adult New Yorkers learn to read. 1/3

McGOVERN--Ann. Goddard Riverside Community Center mourns the passing of Ann McGovern, a board member for 18 years. She was an adventurer, poet, and beloved children's book author whose generous spirit shone through in everything she did. We extend our condolences to her family. Betsy Newell, President Stephan Russo, Executive Director 1/3

SANDLER--Will B. Will B. Sandler, 84, passed away peacefully at his Manhattan home on August 8th surrounded by his loving wife Muriel and children Aviva, Casey, Greg and Jennifer. Beloved grandfather of Jack, Joshua and Molly and loved by his sons-in-law Adam and Omar. For Will the practice of Law was a passion and for nearly 60 years he worked tirelessly perfecting his craft. He was dedicated to his clients and his partners and took great satisfaction working through complex issues and cases. His passion and caring extended into every aspect of his life and was most evident among his close friends and family. Will's relentless work ethic, his shrewd sense of humor and his tenderness for the people in his life will be remembered always. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Tuesday, August 18 at The Waldorf Astoria. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Will's memory to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation: jdrf.org and the ASPCA: aspca.org. 1/3
GIFFORD--Frank. We will always cherish the wonderful times we shared together. Love, The Konecky Family 1/3

MURRAY--Sue. Age 76 of Wayzata, MN and Naples, FL, passed away August 7, 2015. Preceded in death by her mother, Helen Laird, and her sister, Nancy Sweeney. Sue was born May 2, 1939 in Elizabeth, New Jersey and grew up in Point Pleasant where she graduated high school. She attended the State College of New Jersey and graduated with a degree in Physical Education. She married Kenneth Richard Murray on August 24, 1961, and was a teacher for several years in Elizabeth, NJ, Toms River, NJ, and Cranford, NJ. In addition to New Jersey, Sue lived her life in Rhode Island, Ohio, Minnesota and Florida, and made lifelong friends in each place. Sue took a personal interest in everyone she met, finding each person's unique story and gifts. Sue was an amazing wife, mother, sister, aunt, grandmother and friend. She was generous of her time and love, and unstoppable in her resolve to help those around her. She most enjoyed spending time catching-up on the lives of her family and friends on the phone, around a table, or at an event. She continues to inspire all who knew her with how she lived her life. She was always direct but positive above all else, fearlessness in the face of obstacles, and unstoppable in her resolve to help her family and friends to realize their dreams. Sue was also generous in sharing her time and energy through serving and supporting many charitable organizations that embodied her passion for helping others. Sue will be missed, held always close in our hearts, and will never be forgotten. Sue is survived by husband, Kenneth; daughters, Megan (Derek) Hayes and Margot (Eric) Olness; grandchildren, Alex Hayes, Linden Olness, Griffin Olness, and Fletcher Olness; and brothers, Donald Laird and Richard Laird. Mass of Christian Burial is 11:00am Friday, August 14 at The Church of St Bartholomew, 630 Wayzata Blvd E, Wayzata, MN 55391. Visitation is 5:00--7:30 on Thursday, August 13 at the David Lee Funeral Home, 1220 Wayzata Blvd East, Wayzata, MN 55391 and 1 hour before the Mass on Friday at church. If you wish to make a memorial, Sue was active in many great organizations including The Shelter for Abused Women and Children in Naples, The Abbott Northwestern Hospital Foundation, The Basilica of St. Mary, and Fraser. We love and miss you so much!! 1/3

ROSE--Louise B. Gutstein. Died on August 11th at age 72. Louise is the beloved wife of Sidney. She deeply loved her grandchildren, Emma and Rebecca. A writer and humorist, she published a novel and short stories. She was also a professor who was admired, respected, and loved by her students. Additional survivors are her sister Lillian and her husband Wayne, her stepson Benjamin, her stepdaughter-in-law Ilana, her sister-in-law Toby Muss and her husband Stanly Muss and her nephew Jake. Services will be held at "The Riverside" at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Thursday, August 13th at 11:15am. 1/3
ROTHWELL--Alex. Forever loved. Always in our hearts. Rothwell & Forlines families 1/3

KARGMAN--Milton Arthur, 92, of Roslyn Heights, NY passed away on August 7, 2015. He was the beloved husband of Gloria, the devoted and loving father of his four sons Jeffrey, Jonathan, Steven and Douglas (deceased), and the cherished grandfather of Brooke and Tyler. He studied at City College and then enlisted in the Army Air Corps during World War II. He received his LLB from St. John's University School of Law and his LLM in Taxation from New York University School of Law. He was the co-founder and senior partner of the law firm of Tolmack & Kargman, P.C. in New York. He was the ultimate family man--someone who was deeply devoted to ensuring the happiness, success and well-being of all of the members of his family. He always considered himself to be incredibly fortunate to have met and married his lovely wife Gloria - they had just celebrated their sixty-second wedding anniversary a few days before he passed away. He was enormously proud of his sons and all that they had accomplished and the values they represented, and he was also excited and proud to see his grandchildren developing into impressive young adults and achieving success in their own right. He led through his example of hard work, perseverance, integrity, and his unrelenting optimism and positive outlook embodied in his favorite motto, "Onward and Upward." He was highly regarded and admired for his work in the healthcare field, and he was a frequent speaker at conferences and the author of many articles. He enjoyed the good company of family friends and playing golf with his fellow members at The Muttontown Club where he formed many close friendships over a period of forty years. He will be missed terribly by his entire family, his friends and everyone who knew and came in contact with this terrific man. Funeral services will be held graveside at 1:30pm on Thursday, August 13 at Old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, Springfield Gardens, Queens, NY 11413. 1/3

GRACE--William J.,on August 9th, 2015 of East Hampton, NY. Beloved husband of Mary Therese. Loving father of Melissa, Billy, and Jennifer. Cherished grandfather of four. Memorial Mass Thursday, August 13th at 11:15 at St. Mary's Church, Manhasset, NY. 1/3

SCAGLIONE--Fred. The Council of Family and Child Caring Agencies mourn the passing of New York Nonprofit Press founder and editor emeritus, Fred Scaglione. The New York Nonprofit Press was the first publication that focused exclusively on the nonprofit world in New York. Since 2002, NYNP provided extensive, detailed coverage of issues facing nonprofits, including the effects of legislation, government, and funding bodies on nonprofit agencies. "He gave voice to the interests and concerns of these agencies, our staff, and most importantly to our clients, when few others paid attention," said COFCCA CEO James F. Purcell. "His vision and commitment to doing that and to speaking truth to power will be an enduring legacy." 1/3

COHEN--Harris David Jan. 25, 1967-Aug. 13, 1985. 30 long years and still thinking about you and missing you every day. Our memories are beautiful; our hearts are broken. Much Love, Mom, Dad, Jonathan, Lisa, Jake & Benjamin 1/3

LIEBERMAN--Dr Frieda. Our loving mother Dr Frieda Lieberman passed away Saturday night, August 8th after 97 years of age. She was a Principal of Yeshiva Israel Salanter, Yeshivah Rabbi Moses Soloveichik and Solomon Shechter, schools in the NY area and inspired her students to reach great heights. Our mother will be missed by us and we will never forget her thirst for knowledge. To the very end she was at her favorite place, the 92nd St Y. Mom, we will always remember and love you, your loving sons Jess and Jay, daughters-in-law Pat and Penny. Our mom leaves behind her grandchildren/ great grandchildren, nieces and nephews and their children. 1/3

KARGMAN--Milton. The Officers, Board of Governors, The Women's Group, Members and Staff of The Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member, Milton Kargman, and extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Gloria Kargman and their family. Robert Sherman, President 1/3

HONSTEDT--Gary M.,of New York City, New York, died on August 9, 2015. He was 66 years old. Gary was born on June 18, 1949, in Mineola, New York, the only child of the late Herman Honstedt and the late Marjorie Honstedt Collen. He attended Valley Stream North High School and Hawthorne College, from which he graduated in 1971. Gary's professional career spanned a period of over 40 years, beginning with his time as a real estate appraiser at the Williamsburgh Savings Bank. Gary achieved his greatest professional success as Executive Vice President of the Commercial Real Estate Lending Division at Independence Community Bank, growing the commercial real estate lending division from a small, regional operation, to a multifaceted, national commercial real estate lending platform. Gary will always be remembered for his love and devotion to his family. He will similarly be remembered for his passion for life, for the people who were a part of his every day life, and for sports, particularly his Yankees, Rangers, and NY Giants. He enjoyed traveling with his family, swimming, gardening, and playing with his beloved golden retriever, Maggie. Gary is survived by his partner in life, Susan Stropnicky, his two daughters, Stacey Polanskyj and Kerry Boyens, his two sons-in-laws, Peter Polanskyj and Timothy Boyens, his six cherished grandchildren, Cassie Polanskyj, Ava Boyens, Maddie Polanskyj, Jack Boyens, Damian Polanskyj, and Lindsay Polanskyj, his nephew William Stropnicky and his niece Kate Stropnicky. In honor of the life of Gary Honstedt and the causes that touched his heart, donations can be made in Gary's memory to the Garden of Dreams or the Wounded Warrior Project. 1/3

LIFF--Samuel. A gentleman of the theatre the likes of which we'll never see again. Biff dedicated his entire work life to "show business" and loved and laughed and worked so hard every day. An inspiration to so many, and loved by all. From long before My Fair Lady to last season's The Visit, we have lost one of the all time greats. He was our 96 year old Broadway Baby nonpareil. A little bit of our anchor is gone with his passing. A true artists' advocate, Biff's tone of Agenting inspires our own work everyday. Our sincere condolences to his wife Lisette, and all his SRO friends and admirers. Memorial service to be announced. The Rolfe Company, Inc. 1/3

Our sincere condolences to Claire, their children, and the many people whose lives he influenced. Laura Forese, President, NewYork-Presbyterian Healthcare System Gary J. Zuar, Chairman of the Board, New York-Presbyterian/ Queens Stephen S. Mills, President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian/ Queens 1/3

HONSTEDT--Gary. With broken hearts, we express our profound sense of loss at the tragic passing of Gary Honstedt. He will forever be remembered in our hearts. Ralph Herzka Meridian Capital Group 1/3

LIFF--Samuel. It couldn't not happen. We've lost our Biff -- for now at least. A great and a true friend. He was smart, tough, funny, peacemaking and a genuinely nice guy. We hug his beloved Listette close to our hearts, and say to all who were touched by the Biffer, "To Life!" Mickey & Bruce 1/3

ROBINSON--Janet W.,85, a lifelong resident of White Plains, NY, died at home on August 12 with her beloved husband of 64 years, Stanley, by her side. She is the adored mother of Nancy, Susan and James Robinson (Jenny Lefcourt). Zoe is her treasured grandchild. Janet is survived by her devoted brother Robert Wolff and his wife Marcia. A memorial service will be held at Kol Ami Synagogue in White Plains; Friday, August 14 at 11:30am. 1/3

SANDLER--Will Burt "Sandler", "Will", "Willie", "Wilbur"-- a great law and business partner, mentor, confidante, and wise counsel-- and to all who knew him, an incredibly caring and thoughtful friend. Will was all of those to me from the day we met thirty-five years ago through our late mutual friend, Sidney Fetner. Amazingly, Will and I spoke nearly every day and almost never exchanged a single cross word. I attribute this to Will's brilliance and ability to distill any issue to its very essence. I will miss my friend and partner more than I can say. My wife, Jayne, and I will always have Will in our hearts. Our deepest condolences to Muriel, Greg, Aviva and Omar, Casey, Jenny and Adam and Joshua, Jack and Molly. David M. Swersky and Jayne Sosland 1/3

MATNEY--Laurice (nee Grayeb), of Atlantic Beach, NY, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away in her home on the morning of August 12, 2015. Beloved mother of Louise, Arthur Jr., Evelyn, and Virginia. Proud grandmother of eleven, and great-grandmother of seven. Those who knew her will always remember her strength, unending hospitality, sense of humor, and amazing skills in the kitchen. KARGMAN--Milton Arthur, 92, of Roslyn Heights, NY passed away on August 7 2015. He was the beloved husband of Gloria, the devoted and loving father of his four sons Jeffrey, Jonathan, Steven and Douglas (deceased), and the cherished grandfather of Brooke and Tyler. He studied at City College and then enlisted in the Army Air Corps during World War II. He received his LLB from St. John's University School of Law and his LLM in Taxation from New York University School of Law. He was the cofounder and senior partner of the law firm of Tolmack & Kargman, P.C. in New York. He was the ultimate family man--someone who was deeply devoted to ensuring the happiness, success and well-being of all of the members of his family. He always considered himself to be incredibly fortunate to have met and married his lovely wife Gloria - they had just celebrated their sixty-second wedding anniversary a few days before he passed away. He was enormously proud of his sons and all that they had accomplished and the values they represented, and he was also excited and proud to see his grandchildren developing into impressive young adults and achieving success in their own right. He led through his example of hard work, perseverance, integrity, and his unrelenting optimism and positive outlook embodied in his favorite motto, "Onward and Upward." He was highly regarded and admired for his work in the healthcare field, and he was a frequent speaker at conferences andthe author of many articles. He enjoyed the good company of family friends and playing golf with his fellow members at The Muttontown Club where he formed many close friendships over a period of forty years. He will be missed terribly by his entire family, his friends and everyone who knew and came in contact with this terrific man. Funeral services will be held graveside at 1:30pm on Thursday, August 13 at Old Montefiore Cemetery, 121-83 Springfield Boulevard, Springfield Gardens, Queens, NY 11413. 1/3
FISHMAN--Michael Alan. Aug. 19, 1963 - Aug. 13, 1995. Until we meet again, lovingly remembered, Family and friends 1/3

KRONFELD--Fred. Our handsome, wonderful, most special brother-in-law Fred, who put up a valiant fight to the very end. We will miss him more than words can say. We are comforted knowing he will be reunited with Zelda, who he missed desperately. Our hearts are filled with sorrow, along with our nieces and nephews, Michelle, Gary, Nicole, Jamie, Andrew, Perry and Michael. We love you. Marianne and Harvey Bernstein 1/3

KRONFELD--Fred. Rest in peace our adored and cherished Uncle Freddy. We will truly miss you, especially on the holidays. Give a big kiss to Aunt Zelda from us. Our love and sympathies to our cousins, Andrew, Gary, Michelle, Jamie, Nicole, Perry and Michael. Jodi, Bob, Stacey, Phil, Brad, Mira and families 1/3

KRONFELD--Fred N.,passed away peacefully in his sleep Tuesday morning, August 11 at the age of 86 after a long battle with diabetes. Born June 20, 1929, he was the son of Edith and Max Kronfeld. Predeceased by his beloved wife Zelda of 59 years on December 10, 2012, Fred was the loving father of Gary (Michele), and Andrew, and adored and cherished "Poppy" to Michael, Perry, Jamie, and Nicole. He is survived by his brother Arthur (Mona), as well as his former business partner and brother-in-law, who really was a brother to him, Harvey Bernstein, and sister-in-law Marianne, as well as many treasured nieces, nephews, and their children. Growing up in Brooklyn, NY, Fred was a track star for Lincoln High School and was given an athletic scholarship to The University of Oklahoma. After one year, he transferred to the Wharton School at The University of Pennsylvania where he graduated with a degree in Finance. He then went on to The University of Florida where he received his MBA in Economics. Fred served in the armed forces from 1953-1955 before going to work as a Vice President for Pan Am Airlines. He then moved on to have a successful business career at Spirite Industries Inc., a manufacturing company specializing in women's undergarments where he was partners with his brother-in-law. He was innovative in his business approach and was one of the first in the industry to begin sourcing and importing finished products from Korea and Hong Kong in the 1970's. A man of great integrity, Fred always believed in doing the right thing. He had high moral standards, and was very philanthropic without ever looking for any notoriety. He loved his collection of sports cars, travelling, art, and enjoyed playing golf with his sons and his friends-- but above all his family came first. He will be remembered every day, but greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Englewood Hospital or New York Presbyterian Hospital in Fred's memory. 1/3
GIFFORD--Frank. We will always cherish the wonderful times we shared together. Love, The Konecky Family 1/3
COHN--Donald J. Dec. 19, 1929 - Aug. 13, 2013. His family remembers him with love. 1/3

GITTLIN--Bruce. It is with deep sorrow we note the sudden passing of our dear friend, Bruce Gittlin, a sweet, loving and kind man. Our hearts go out to his wife, Ethel, and family. May the fond memories of your lives together bring you peace and comfort. With heartfelt love, Schlossberg, Jennings and Debra West families 1/3
LeBOW--Guy Matthew. June 11, 1916 -August 14, 2008 I miss you. AlwaysyourBarbara 1/3

KRONFELD--Fred N.,passed away peacefully in his sleep Tuesday morning, August 11 at the age of 86 after a long battle with diabetes. Born June 20, 1929, he was the son of Edith and Max Kronfeld. Predeceased by his beloved wife Zelda of 59 years on December 10, 2012, Fred was the loving father of Gary (Michele), and Andrew, and adored and cherished "Poppy" to Michael, Perry, Jamie, and Nicole. He is survived by his brother Arthur (Mona), as well as his former business partner and brother-in-law, who really was a brother to him, Harvey Bernstein, and sister-in-law Marianne, as well as many treasured nieces, nephews, and their children. Growing up in Brooklyn, NY, Fred was a track star for Lincoln High School and was given an athletic scholarship to The University of Oklahoma. After one year, he transferred to the Wharton School at The University of Pennsylvania where he graduated with a degree in Finance. He then went on to The University of Florida where he received his MBA in Economics. Fred served in the armed forces from 1953-1955 before going to work as a Vice President for Pan Am Airlines. He then moved on to have a successful business career at Spirite Industries Inc., a manufacturing company specializing in women's undergarments where he was partners with his brother-in-law. He was innovative in his business approach and was one of the first in the industry to begin sourcing and importing finished products from Korea and Hong Kong in the 1970's. A man of great integrity, Fred always believed in doing the right thing. He had high moral standards, and was very philanthropic without ever looking for any notoriety. He loved his collection of sports cars, travelling, art, and enjoyed playing golf with his sons and his friends-- but above all his family came first. He will be remembered every day, but greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Englewood Hospital or New York Presbyterian Hospital in Fred's memory. 1/3

BERGER--Lynne Flexner. 1916-2015. Passed away on August 10, 2015. Artist and art therapist. Loving mother of Lucette and Lee Runsdorf. Beloved stepmother of June and Michael Carrera, and Donald and Lynne Flexner. Cherished grandmother of Elise and Brian Napack, and Nina and the late Jim Runsdorf. Devoted great-grandmother to Alexa and Kate Runsdorf, and Ella and Graham Napack. 1/3

LIFF--Samuel. It couldn't not happen. We've lost our Biff -- for now at least. A great and a true friend. He was smart, tough, funny, peacemaking and a genuinely nice guy. We hug his beloved Listette close to our hearts, and say to all who were touched by the Biffer, "To Life!" Mickey & Bruce 1/3

LIFF--Samuel. A gentleman of the theatre the likes of which we'll never see again. Biff dedicated his entire work life to "show business" and loved and laughed and worked so hard every day. An inspiration to so many, and loved by all. From long before My Fair Lady to last season's The Visit, we have lost one of the all time greats. He was our 96 year old Broadway Baby nonpareil. A little bit of our anchor is gone with his passing. A true artists' advocate, Biff's tone of Agenting inspires our own work everyday. Our sincere condolences to his wife Lisette, and all his SRO friends and admirers. Memorial service to be announced. The Rolfe Company, Inc. 1/3
KOWALD--Elaine Radack. KOWALD--Kenneth, both 88, Port Washington, NY. Died after lengthy illnesses on August 12th. Memorial service to be announced later. 1/3
GORE--Chester A. 8/14/18 - 4/19/97 Celebrating your birthday and your life. You still inspire, amuse, and guide us. Loving you always. Eloise and Allen 1/3

ROBERTS--Terry A. Passed away at the age of 70 years old in Sands Point, NY after a battle with cancer. She was an amazing mother to David and Jamie and a cherished mother-in-law to Lisa. An incredible grandmother to her five grandchildren Jordan, Rachel, Kasey, Alyssa and Adam who adored her. She was so loved and supported by her truly amazing sister Dedee and brother-in-law Stephen Lovell. She made happiness wherever she went. She had a smile that lit up any room. She valued and cherished her family and friends above all else. She was constantly surrounded by her loved ones. Throughout her amazing life she had more adventures and experiences than most people dream of. She lived a life of pure happiness and loved truly. Although she may be gone we will never forget our "ma soeur" our "madre" our grandmother and our love. 1/3

Along with her beloved, Donald, her children and family we mourn her passing. Surely beautiful memories will live forever in the hearts of those whose lives she touched. 1/3

Retired in 1999 from Van Cleef & Arpels as Executive Vice President, she is survived by sisters Maria Startin and Josephine Ma'arop, her four nieces and nephews, and five grand-nieces and grand-nephews. 10:30 am Funeral Mass at Holy Family Church, 315 East 47th Street, New York, NY. NEWHOUSE--Susan Marley, of New York, passed away at her home on Thursday, August 13, 2015 at the age of 80. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Donald E. Newhouse, her sister, Nanci Bronsteen (Robert Bronsteen), both of New York, and her children, Steven O. Newhouse (Gina Sanders), Michael A. Newhouse (Elyse Newhouse) and Katherine Newhouse Mele (Dr. Joseph Mele), all of New York. Also surviving are six grandchildren in New York: Andrew W. Newhouse, Alexander J. Newhouse, David H. Mele, Sarah I. Mele, Robert S. Newhouse and Kate I. Newhouse. Susan, (known to many as Suzy), was born in Syracuse, NY, the daughter of Harry Marley and Lillian Cooper Marley. She graduated from Wellesley College in 1955 at the age of 19. Later she became a Trustee of Wellesley and, along with her husband, established the Susan and Donald Newhouse Center for the Humanities at Wellesley. Along with Jacques D'Amboise, Susan founded the National Dance Institute in 1976, and served on its Board of Directors for many years. She was also a trustee and longtime Chairman of the Board of The Fresh Air Fund, where she is Fresh Air Fund Chairman Emeritus. Additionally, she was a trustee of Temple Emanu-el (and a member of its Dialogue with St. Patrick's committee), the New York Public Library, the Collegiate School, and a member of the Board of Directors of the Paper Bag Players, and Lincoln Center Theater, where she is an Honorary Trustee of Lincoln Center Theater. A private family service will be held at Temple Emanu-el. A memorial service, in celebration of her life, will be held at a future date. Contributions in her honor can be made to the Association for Frontotemperal Degeneration. Radnor Station Building 2, Suite 320. 290 King of Prussia Road, Radnor, PA 19087. Funeral services by Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. 1/3

CITRON--Dr. Ronald Dr. Ronald Citron, a pioneer in cancer prevention and early detection, died on July 23 at his home in Napa Valley, CA. He was 74. After early research in immunology and clinical work in medical oncology, Dr. Citron focused on preventive oncology. His passion for making cancer prevention and early detection accessible to the public came from years of seeing patients who had come to him too late for treatment to work. In 1992, Dr. Citron created The Clinical Computer, a home computer health risk assessment based on genetic analysis. In 1997, his book Dr. Citron's Evolutionary Diet and Cookbook was published. Born Ronald Seth Citronbaum in Manhattan in 1940, Dr. Citron attended medical school at NYU. He did research at the Institute for Immunology Basel and for the NIH and was on the faculties of USC and UCLA. He was medical director of the Los Angeles Free Clinic from 1969 to 1971, medical spokesperson for the American Cancer Society, and a technical consultant to thirtysomething. In retirement, Dr. Citron enjoyed sailing, making art, and tooling around his vineyard in his old truck. He is survived by his wife, Kathye Citron; his stepchildren Karen Murphy and Thomas Murphy; and his grandson Archimedes Lee. 1/3

SCHEURER--Edwin Charles. June 1, 1933-August 14, 2010 My darling Eddie - Five long years without you and the heartache never ends. But my memories are beautiful and lasting. Life with you was pure joy. We love and miss you so very much. Edie, your children and grandchildren 1/3

NEWHOUSE--Susan. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of our beloved Sue. A Director for many years and an Honorary Trustee, Sue loved the Theater and she especially loved our theater. She never missed a show or, for that matter, a board meeting, and she was always unfailingly kind, supportive, and intelligent. She was one of those rare people who only saw the good in others, and she was an enthusiastic and respectful friend. Sue had real intellectual curiosity and artistic sensitivity, and one must add that she was a snappy dresser -- which made her just about perfect. We extend our sympathy to her devoted husband Donald, and to her entire family, including Michael and Elyse who is a member our Board, Kathy and Joe, Steven and Gina, and all of Sue and Donald's grandchildren. The Newhouse family's presence in our lives is nothing short of miraculous. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Eric M. Mindich, President Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director 1/3

SCOTT--John Gavin. John Scott, LVO, D.Mus honoris causa, June 18, 1956-- August 12, 2015. The Rector, Wardens, and Vestry of Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, on behalf of the parish, announce the death of their beloved Organist and Director of Music (2004-- 2015). He is survived by his wife, Lily Ardalan Scott; his children, Emma and Alex, and their mother, Jane Lumsden; and his sisters Judith Schatunowski and Helen Church. Lily Scott is expecting their first child in September 2015. John was born in 1956 in Wakefield, Yorkshire, UK, where he became a Cathedral chorister. While still at school he gained the diplomas of the Royal College of Organists and won the major prizes. In 1974, he became Organ Scholar of St. John's College, Cambridge under Dr. George Guest. John made his debut in the 1977 Promenade Concerts in the Royal Albert Hall, playing Reubke's Sonata on the 94th Psalm. He was the youngest organist to appear as a soloist in the Proms. On leaving Cambridge, John was appointed Assistant Organist at London's two Anglican Cathedrals: St. Paul's and Southwark. During this time he won first prizes from Manchester and Leipzig J.S. Bach International Organ Competitions in 1978 and 1984 respectively. In 1985, John became Sub-Organist of St. Paul's Cathedral, and in 1990 he succeeded Dr. Christopher Dearnley as Organist and Director of Music. During his 26 years at St. Paul's, he was responsible for the nine weekly choral services, concerts, and for the music at a number of high profile events including the service to mark the Queen's Golden Jubilee in 2002 for which he wrote the anthem, Behold, O God Our Defender, based on Psalm 84. He also directed the music at the memorial service at St. Paul's after 9/11. John was made a Lieutenant of the Royal Victorian Order, a personal gift from the Queen, in recognition of his work at St. Paul's Cathedral. In the summer of 2004, John was appointed Organist and Director of Music at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue, where he directed the Choir of Men and Boys until his death. John worked tirelessly with the boys of Saint Thomas Choir School, the only choral boarding school in North America. An exceptional choral trainer, John was monumental in shaping the lives of young choristers and generations of church musicians. His Missa Dies Resurrectionis has been performed each Easter at Saint Thomas since its premiere in 2011. John conducted the Choir of Men and Boys in numerous recordings including Mozart's arrangement of Handel's Messiah and Faure's Requiem. In 2015, John and the Choir of Men and Boys began a major collaboration with Resonus Classics which recently produced a new recording of Motets by J.S. Bach. At Saint Paul's John played a complete cycle of the organ works of J.S. Bach in 2000 and followed this in subsequent years with the organ symphonies of Vierne and Widor, as well as the complete works of Franck and Buxtehude. At Saint Thomas, he performed complete cycles of the organ works of Buxtehude in 2007, Messiaen in 2008, and the six organ symphonies of Louis Vierne in 2009. His most recent solo recital at Saint Thomas took place in June, 2015 with a program of works by J.S. Bach that was based on a recital by Mendelsohn at the Thomaskirche, Leipzig in 1840. John was equally renowned for inspiring church musicians to his impeccable standards. For the last several years, John has spearheaded Saint Thomas Church in one of its most ambitious projects to date: the building of a new pipe organ by Dobson Pipe Organ Builders of Lake City, IA. The new organ, which is expected to be completed in 2018, has already been named the Irene D. and William R. Miller Chancel Organ in honor of Dr. John Scott. He insisted that Bach's motto, Soli Deo Gloria (Glory to God alone) be carved in the new organ case of the Miller-Scott Organ as a reminder of the importance of liturgical music. As an organist, John performed on five continents, premiered many new works written for him, and worked with various specialist ensembles. In recent years he performed recitals at the Thomaskirche, Leipzig; Notre Dame, Paris; Disney Hall, Los Angeles; Merton College, Oxford; and Royal Albert Hall, London. He once said "I envy other musicians who can take their instrument with them when they travel. For me, it's a new instrument each time". In addition to his work as a conductor and organist, John has published many choral compositions and arrangements and has jointly edited two compilations of liturgical music for the Church's year published by Oxford University Press. His numerous organ recordings include the sonatas of Elgar, organ music by William Mathias, Durufle and Mendelssohn, as well as two discs of Dupre. He also recorded the solo organ part in Janacek's Glagolitic Mass with the London Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas. The funeral service will be at Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue; the date and time will be posted at saintthomaschurch.org. Donations may be made in John Scott's memory to the MillerScott Organ Fund. Please make checks payable to Saint Thomas Church Fifth Avenue; 1 West 53rd Street; New York, NY 10019-5496. The Reverend Canon Carl F. Turner, Rector Kenneth F. Koen, Warden Kazie Metzger Harvey, Warden 1/3

SANTORINEOU--Maria, M.D.,of Riverdale, NY, passed away on Monday, August 10, 2015 after a long courageous battle with lymphoma. She was born in Athens, Greece. After graduating from the Medical School of Athens University she came to the United Stated to broaden her knowledge and pursue an academic career. After two years of rotating internship at Lynn (Massachusetts) and two year internship and residency in St. Louis (Missouri) she continued her training at Boston Chidlren's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, on fellowship in Pediatric Hematology Oncology. Later on she joined the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine treating patients and teaching until she retired as full clinical Professor in Pediatrics. Her life was spent in selfless devotion to her patients, her profession and family. She is predeceased by her sister Olympia and is survived in New York by her sister Tina, her nephew Victor, and his wife Ingrid and daughter Sophia and in Greece by her niece Irene and her family. She was an exemplary doctor and an exceptional human being. For all of us she will remain a lifelong inspiration in humanity, adherence to science, highest principles, sincerity and determination. A Memorial Service will he held at the Williams Funeral Home in the Bronx, telephone 718-548-1100 at a later date. 1/3

NEWHOUSE--Susan M.,The Board, staff and children of National Dance Institute (NDI) mourn the passing of beloved founding Board member and director emerita, Susan Newhouse. Our beautiful dream-maker, her exceptional passion, commitment and advocacy made 40 years of joy and success possible for generations of NDI children throughout New York City and the world. Always with a twinkle in her eye, Susan's gracious and giving spirit allowed others to soar and discover their own talents. Her remarkable dedication to the causes dear to her was only outshined by her love and devotion to her extraordinary family. We extend our deepest sympathy to Donald, Kathy, the entire family, and all who adored her. Susan's magnificent legacy will live on in every run, jump and leap of the children of National Dance Institute. NEWHOUSE--Susan Marley. The Fresh Air Fund, its Board of Directors and staff mourn the passing of Susan Marley Newhouse, Chairman Emeritus of The Fresh Air Fund. Susie was a dedicated leader, wonderful person and cherished friend who inspired all of us who were fortunate enough to know her. She was admired, respected and adored by the Fresh Air family, and we will miss her leadership, charm and warm personality. We offer our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences to her entire family, especially her husband Donald Newhouse, who is a long-time supporter of The Fund. Susie's commitment to The Fresh Air Fund began in 1982 when she joined the Board of Directors. She became the Chairman of the Board in 1987 and served in that position for 24 years. She continued on as Chairman Emeritus from 2011 until her death. She is a champion for New York City's boys and girls who are the beneficiaries of her generosity of spirit and support. Susie's leadership has forever changed the lives of countless Fresh Air children. With heartfelt gratitude for her commitment, tireless work and compassion, thanks to Susie, New York City's neediest children have shared the joys of country life with volunteer families, enjoyed our camps and have new doors of opportunity through educational programs. Her support has been invaluable. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our distinguished colleague and dear friend. She always found the time to make Fresh Air children smile. We will never forget that smile and grace. William P. Lauder, Chairman of the Board John N. Irwin III, President Jenny Morgenthau, Executive Director Emeritus Fatima A. Shama, Executive Director The Fresh Air Fund 1/3

NEWHOUSE--Susan Marley, of New York, passed away at her home on Thursday, August 13, 2015 at the age of 80. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Donald E. Newhouse, her sister, Nanci Bronsteen (Robert Bronsteen), both of New York, and her children, Steven O. Newhouse (Gina Sanders), Michael A. Newhouse (Elyse Newhouse) and Katherine Newhouse Mele (Dr. Joseph Mele), all of New York. Also surviving are six grandchildren in New York: Andrew W. Newhouse, Alexander J. Newhouse, David H. Mele, Sarah I. Mele, Robert S. Newhouse and Kate I. Newhouse. Susan, (known to many as Suzy), was born in Syracuse, NY, the daughter of Harry Marley and Lillian Cooper Marley. She graduated from Wellesley College in 1955 at the age of 19. Later she became a Trustee of Wellesley and, along with her husband, established the Susan and Donald Newhouse Center for the Humanities at Wellesley. Along with Jacques D'Amboise, Susan founded the National Dance Institute in 1976, and served on its Board of Directors for many years. She was also a trustee and longtime Chairman of the Board of The Fresh Air Fund, where she is Fresh Air Fund Chairman Emeritus. Additionally, she was a trustee of Temple Emanu-el (and a member of its Dialogue with St. Patrick's committee), the New York Public Library, the Collegiate School, and a member of the Board of Directors of the Paper Bag Players, and Lincoln Center Theater, where she is an Honorary Trustee of Lincoln Center Theater. A private family service will be held at Temple Emanu-el. A memorial service, in celebration of her life, will be held at a future date. Contributions in her honor can be made to the Association for Frontotemperal Degeneration. Radnor Station Building 2, Suite 320. 290 King of Prussia Road, Radnor, PA 19087. Funeral services by Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue. 1/3
