BUCKSBAUM--Melva. The Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art express with profound sadness the passing of Melva Bucksbaum, beloved Trustee and wife of longtime Board member Raymond J. Learsy. A passionate supporter of the arts and culture in the US and abroad, Melva served as a Trustee of the Whitney Museum of American Art for nearly two decades. Melva embodied the risk-taking and artist-centric vision of Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, establishing the Bucksbaum Award in 2000 and naming the Bucksbaum, Learsy, Scanlan Conservation Center in the Whitney's new building. Believing that art is our collective heritage to be shared by all, she donated dozens of artworks to the Whitney. We are immensely proud to continue Melva's legacy and to have her name linked in perpetuity to the Museum through the Melva Bucksbaum Associate Director for Conservation and Research--a position which her loving daughter Mary named in her honor. Melva made an enormous difference in a multitude of lives through her kindness, spirit and resources. She set a shining example that a good life is made by giving back. Melva was an extraordinarily courageous woman and her steadfast commitment to art and artists, her infectious optimism, elegance, and beautiful smile will be deeply missed. To know Melva was to love her, admire her and be embraced by her warmth. She was a gift to all of us who knew her. We extend our most heartfelt sympathy to Ray Learsy, Mary Bucksbaum Scanlan and Patrick Scanlan, Glenn and April Bucksbaum, Gene Bucksbaum, her grandchildren Martin, Stella, and Justin, her entire family and the many individuals whose lives she touched with her altruism and friendship. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Chairman of the Executive Committee, Neil G. Bluhm Co-Chair, Laurie M. Tisch Co-Chair, Rich DeMartini President, Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director 1/3

PRATT--Jane Stone, died August 11 at the age of 86 in Palm City, FL after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Janey was born in Philadelphia, PA on October 20, 1929 to Betty and James K. Stone. She graduated from Agnes Irwin School followed by Bryn Mawr College in 1951. She was an active athlete, playing field hockey, lacrosse, tennis and figure skating. After graduation, she worked briefly as a buyer in the retail clothing trade in New York City before becoming a teacher in New Jersey and Long Island, NY. In 1955, while pursuing a masters degree in education, she met and married John Teele Pratt and lived in Hamilton, MA followed by Martha's Vineyard. In 1977 she and her husband moved to Beaufort, SC, where she lived until 1984, when she moved to Loblolly Bay, Hobe Sound, FL where she and her husband remained until moving to Sandhill Cove, Palm City, FL in 2004. Always dedicated to bettering the lives of children, Jane Pratt taught grade school in New Jersey, New York, South Carolina and Florida. She was active in Girl Scouts of U.S. and the Boys & Girls Club and was elected a Life Emeritus Director of the Hobe Sound Boys & Girls Club. In 2014 a special reading program entitled "The Janey Pratt 'Be READy' program" was established as a pilot program helping children with reading difficulties. The program was extremely successful and received an award as the best new program in all Florida Boys & Girls clubs. A special study room in the new Indiantown Club was dedicated to her in 2014. A memorial service will be held at St. John's of Lattingtown, LI on October 9, 2015 at 11:00am. Contributions in her memory may be sent to: Hobe Sound Boys & Girls Club, Be READy Program, 11500 Lars Ave., Hobe Sound, FL 33450. 1/3

DeGARMO--K. Scott, passed away on August 15 at his home in Riverdale, NY, surrounded by wife, Barbara, and beloved daughters Madden Manion (Terrance) and Julie DeGarmo (Douglas Dietrich). He is also survived by four precious grandchildren, Jack and Tommy Manion and Anika and Graydon Dietrich; his brother, John DeGarmo, and sister, Mary Toof. Scott had a long and varied career in newspapers, magazines and, most recently, as owner of magazine and trade show company Broadband Communities. A memorial service celebrating Scott's life will be held Friday, August 21, at 12:30pm at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, NY. Donations can be made to curepc.org. 1/3

BROPHY--Edward "Buddy" Joseph, of Congers, NY was abruptly taken from this world while biking on Sunday, August 16th, 2015. Edward was born on September 29th, 1937 in New York City. He served in the military, was a retired New York City lieutenant and teacher. He then found his true calling as an artist. This included painting, sculpting, writing, singing, and playing harmonica and guitar. He was an avid outdoorsman; member of the Adirondack Mountain Club, enjoyed tennis, running, biking, and the beach. Edward is survived by his daughters Colleen and her husband Chris Bondy, Claire and her husband Anthony Ianno, grandchildren Kate Bondy, Jake Bondy, Eleanor Ianno, and countless relatives from his two predeceased sisters Patricia Jones and Mary Smith. A celebration of life will be held Wednesday, August 19th at Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home, 101 South Finley Ave, Basking Ridge, NJ from 4pm-8pm. In lieu of flowers, please feel free to make a donation to the Environmental Defense Fund. For further information please contact Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home at 908-766-0250, or to light an online condolence candle, please visit our website at www.gcfuneralhome.com 1/3

BUCKSBAUM--Melva. The art world has lost one of its greatest gems, Melva Bucksbaum. She will be remembered for her artist-loving spirit, passion for art, grace, curiosity, and goodness. Love and sympathy to Ray, Mary, Glenn and the entire family from the Brooklyn Museum Board and staff. 1/3

BAKER--Beverly, (July 16, 1926-August 17, 2015). Never married, but definitely not a spinster, Bev, a lifetime resident of New York City, is survived by her brother, Jay; sister-in-law, Patty; nephew Stephen and wife Nadine and their children, Zoe and Micah; niece Stephanie and husband Chris Ribera and their children, Jessie, Jay, Jentrie, and Kristie, and her beloved cat, Pearl. Her love of life extended to her love of the arts. She loved the Roundabout Theatre, the NYC Ballet, the New York Philharmonic and Broadway's dramas. Weighing in at 78 pounds, she was no lightweight. She supported the arts and Queens College where she received her undergraduate degree in 1947, and the University of Pennsylvania, where she received her Masters in Social Work in 1949. Her career after involved helping Jews resettle in America. A world traveler, she collected African and Inuit art, as well as Limoges and Halcyon Days boxes as petite as she was. She will be remembered for her loving warmth, her twinkling eyes, and her infectious ribald laugh. A memorial service will be held on Friday, August 21, 2015, at Riverside Chapel, West 76th and Amsterdam at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, her memory may be honored by donations to Queens College, the Roundabout Theatre Company, or the NY ASPCA. 1/3
DALY--Joseph, April 7, 1930 - August 8, 2015. Husband, father, actor, teacher. Memorial Services in New Jersey August 15; in NYC August 23 at Producers' Club. 1/3

RAY--Ellen, of New York City and New Orleans died in New York on June 11, 2015, at age 75, from complications of cancer. Born in Grand Island, Nebraska, a great-niece of the author Willa Cather, Ray was a documentary filmmaker, publisher, journalist, and activist. During the Vietnam War, Ray worked for the National Lawyers' Guild's Military Law Project in Okinawa, supporting the legal defense of U.S. soldiers who opposed the war in Vietnam. Her films include "Stand Up Grenada," which documented Maurice Bishop's first anniversary as Prime Minister of Grenada and the U.S. government's efforts to destabilize his government. From 1978 to 2000, Ray was a co-publisher of the magazine Covert Action Information Bulletin. Together with William Schaap, her husband of 44 years, she published Lies Of Our Times, a magazine that detailed inaccuracies in articles published by The New York Times and other mainstream press. With Michael Ratner, Ray was co-author of "Guantanamo: What the World Should Know", the first book to expose torture in Guantanamo prison. As president of Sheridan Square Press, Ray published "On the Trail of the Assassins," the memoir of New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison, which became a primary source for Oliver Stone's film, "JFK." In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, Ray and Schaap lived part-time in New Orleans, where they volunteered and provided legal services and other support for people affected by the storm. Ray is survived by her husband and many friends and loved ones. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 20th, at 4:00pm, at St. Mark's-Church-in-the- Bowery, 131 East 10th Street, New York, NY. 1/3
BUCKSBAUM--Melva. With great sadness, I bid farewell to my dearest friend. With heartfelt condolences to Raymond and the Bucksbaum family. Barbara Hauben Ross 1/3

BOYD--Marian, age 54, of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, died on August 15 of complications from ovarian cancer. She was a beloved partner to her husband, Carl Baldassarre, a passionate mother to her children, Marie, Juliana and Justin and the cherished baby sister of Susan Boyd Schroeder and Don Boyd. Her joyful spirit, courage, kindness and laughter will never be forgotten. 1/3

KAPLAN--Martin E. It is with the utmost sadness that the Baruch College community mourns the passing of alumnus Martin Kaplan '59. Kaplan devoted his time, talents and business acumen to serve Baruch College in many ways. A trustee of The Baruch College Fund since 2001, including service as vice president for several years, he chaired the Investment Committee and was vice chair of the Baruch Means Business Campaign. His wise counsel was sought and universally respected by college leaders and his fellow trustees. He and his wife, Laurie, were extraordinarily generous to Baruch, naming two classrooms as well as the Martin and Laurie Kaplan Computing and Technology Center. In appreciation for his loyal dedication, Baruch honored him with its Alumni Allegiance Award in 2009. We extend our deepest sympathy to Laurie, their sons Douglas and Lawrence and Marty's many friends, colleagues and admirers. Mitchel B. Wallerstein, President, Baruch College, Max Berger '68, President, The Baruch College Fund 1/3

FUBINI--Gaby, of Great Neck, originally of Rome, Italy, August 16th, age 91. Devoted Mom and Nonna. Services August 19 at Riverside Nassau North, 11am. Donations in her memory: Ability Beyond pam.szen@abilitybeyond.org 1/3

KAPLAN--Martin E.,on August 16, 2015. Born July 14, 1937. Beloved and devoted husband of Laurie, adored father of Lawrence and Douglas, cherished grandfather of Grace, Grayson, and Hunter. Former President/Partner of KR Capital Advisors, Inc; Chairman, Institutional Trading Advisory Committee, New York Stock Exchange; Senior Vice President, Director of Equity Trading and Managing Director, Merrill Lynch, where he worked 29 years. This larger-than-life and fun-loving man will be profoundly missed. Services Wednesday, August 19, 10am at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Ave., at 55th St. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in his memory to Division of Cardiology, Columbia University Medical Center, 177 Fort Washington Ave., Room 435, New York, NY 10032. 1/3
KAPLAN--Martin. A true friend--caring, generous, fun-loving--an all around great guy. We will miss you. Jackie and Gerry 1/3

TROVATI--Susan. Our sincerest condolences to Susan's beloved daughters, Robyn and Joslyn, and her brother Stuart. We will always love and miss our "Susarino". Nan, Murray, Elise, Stephen and all the Marmon family. 1/3

HUGGIN--Diana Montgomery Hyland, on August 17, 2015. Beloved wife of David, Diana was born in Smithfield, North Carolina November 10, 1941, graduated from Duke University, obtained a Master of Arts in Teaching degree from Harvard University, taught public school music and later was a highly regarded real estate agent in Durham, NC. Surviving, in addition to David, are David Christopher Hyland and Jonathan Franklin Hyland, sons by a previous marriage, grandchildren Brandon, William and Parker, a brother, Jesse Franklin Montgomery III and a sister, Janet Montgomery. Contributions may be made to the Triangle Land Conservancy, 514 South Duke Street, Durham, NC 27701, or First Presbyterian Church, 305 East Main St., Durham, NC. A memorial service will be held on August 29, 2015 at 11:00am at First Presbyterian Church, Durham, NC. 1/3
DeGARMO--Scott. Broadband Communities notes with great sadness the passing of our CEO, Scott DeGarmo, whose leadership, commitment and integrity have guided and inspired us for the last decade. 1/3

FEIN--Zlatta "Zee," (nee Birch). Beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother passed away peacefully on Tuesday, August 18, 2015. Born in Brooklyn on May 13, 1930 and raised in Queens, NY. The matriarch of her family, a world traveler and a beloved 4th and 5th grade teacher, Zee is predeceased by her loving husband, Irving, and her sister Miriam "Mimi," and survived by devoted daughters Janet and Iris (Peter), and cherished granddaughters Gillian, Lynnie and Dana. Services Thursday, at 10am, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY. 1/3

BOND--Julian. The George School community mourns the passing of distinguished graduate Julian Bond, Class of 1957. Julian embodied the Quaker principles of non-violent social action and truth-seeking. He was an example for our students throughout his lifetime and will continue to inspire future generations for years to come. Our deepest sympathies go out to his wife, Pamela, his children, and all whose lives were touched by this extraordinary man. George School Board of Trustees and Head of School Nancy Starmer 1/3

GORELOV--Yan. A loving husband, brother, father, grandfather and friend, Yan's warmth and selflessness touched everyone who surrounded him. While his love of life and commitment to family will be greatly missed, they will surely live on through his wife, brother, children and grandchildren who survive him. Donations in honor of Yan's life and memory may be made to Uniting Against Lung Cancer. 1/3
ARKIN--Albert J. April 17, 1909 - August 19, 1985 Dad - 30 years - seems like almost yesterday. Love, Joan 1/3
CHRISTMAN--Henry M. As long as there's life, you're with me. Abraham Feldman 1/3

KIM--Mr. Hak Yong, (May 21 1932-August 17, 2015). Known to all his friends as "Captain Kim" and "Ajae: Big Uncle," was born in Jerae, Gimcheon as the oldest son of a farming family who was originally descended from the King Suro of Kaya Kingdom. Captain Kim graduated from the Korean Naval Academy in 1956 with the 10th Cadet class. He also studied Anti Submarine Warfare with the United States Navy in San Diego and served as an officer of ROK Navy until 1970. He served in Vietnam War as a personnel staff to the commander of ROK Naval Squadron along side the U.S. Navy and Marine forces from 1966 to 1968. He joined Korean Line shipping company in 1970 and then joined Maritime Overseas Corporation in New York City in 1974 and immigrated to New York in 1976 with his family. He was a pioneer in International Merchant Marine operation for the Korean shipping industry and he was a licensed Port Captain, a prestigious international port pilots license held by few in the world. He was an avid reader, a mathematician who lived principled life of personal and professional integrity and generosity to the others. Captain Kim is survived by his wife of 58 years, Mrs Chungsin Park, and his daughter Younghee and her husband Jarett Wait, and his son Sungkwon Michael Kim and his wife Heather and younger brother, Dr. Chilyong Kim and his family. His daughters Myunghee Kim Shin and Soohee Kim Oh were predeceased. His nine grandchildren Jennifer, Spencer, Eddie, Diane, Danielle, Jarett, Kate, Alex and Uno bid him a farewell with their love and respect. 1/3

RATNER--Robert M. April 19, 1922 - August 18, 2015. Treasured by his wife of 62 years, Rhoda, to whom he was devoted. Beloved father of Susan Ratner and Lloyd Ratner (Andrea), and grandfather of Emily. Also survived by his brother Lester. WW II Veteran. He loved his family and friends and they loved him. Services August 20, 2015 10:00am at Gutterman's Inc. 175 N. Long Beach Rd. Rockville Centre, NY. 1/3

BAKER--Beverly, (July 16, 1926-August 17, 2015). Never married, but definitely not a spinster, Bev, a lifetime resident of New York City, is survived by her brother, Jay; sister-in-law, Patty; nephew Stephen and wife Nadine and their children, Zoe and Micah; niece Stephanie and husband Chris Ribera and their children, Jessie, Jay, Jentrie, and Kristie, and her beloved cat, Pearl. Her love of life extended to her love of the arts. She loved the Roundabout Theatre, the NYC Ballet, the New York Philharmonic and Broadway's dramas. Weighing in at 78 pounds, she was no lightweight. She supported the arts and Queens College where she received her undergraduate degree in 1947, and the University of Pennsylvania, where she received her Masters in Social Work in 1949. Her career after involved helping Jews resettle in America. A world traveler, she collected African and Inuit art, as well as Limoges and Halcyon Days boxes as petite as she was. She will be remembered for her loving warmth, her twinkling eyes, and her infectious ribald laugh. A memorial service will be held on Friday, August 21, 2015, at Riverside Chapel, West 76th and Amsterdam at 3pm. In lieu of flowers, her memory may be honored by donations to Queens College, the Roundabout Theatre Company, or the NY ASPCA. 1/3

HUGGIN--Diana Montgomery Hyland, on August 17, 2015. Beloved wife of David, Diana was born in Smithfield, North Carolina November 10, 1941, graduated from Duke University, obtained a Master of Arts in Teaching degree from Harvard University, taught public school music and later was a highly regarded real estate agent in Durham, NC. Surviving, in addition to David, are David Christopher Hyland and Jonathan Franklin Hyland, sons by a previous marriage, grandchildren Brandon, William and Parker, a brother, Jesse Franklin Montgomery III and a sister, Janet Montgomery. Contributions may be made to the Triangle Land Conservancy, 514 South Duke Street, Durham, NC 27701, or First Presbyterian Church, 305 East Main St., Durham, NC. A memorial service will be held on August 29, 2015 at 11:00am at First Presbyterian Church, Durham, NC. 1/3

ELAM--Brentin Curry. Passed away peacefully at his home surrounded by his wife and five children on August 19, 2015. Born in Jeffersonville, KY in 1939, he moved to Manhattan in 1968, where he found his true home. Brent was a founding director of the National Association of Futures Trading Advisors where he served on the CTA/CPO Advisory Committee and the NFA's Business Conduct Committee. Brent retired in 2012 when he began a new career as a volunteer gardener with the Central Park Conservancy. He loved reading, dancing and music. He is survived by his mother, wife, five children and six grandchildren. Brent will be sorely missed and will rest ever gentle on our minds. AUERBACH-- Howard M. (Mickey), died peacefully on August 17, 2015. Survived by his wife, Andrea, his daughter, Joy Elyssa and his brother, Richard. TRICOMI--Marie, on August 20, 2015. Born in Park Falls, Wisconsin in 1922. Marie was a proud graduate of Abbott Northwestern School of Nursing and served as a United States Army nurse in Europe during WWII, where she met her husband of 62 years - the late Vincent J. Tricomi, M.D. Marie is survived by her six children; Frank, Mary Marotta (Nicholas), Nancy Capobianco (Robert), Ellen Schantz (Ed), Charles, and Linda Rizio (Ray). Loving grandmother of 18 and great-grandmother of three. Visitation Sunday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Inc., 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10am, St. Anne's R.C. Church, Garden City, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery Westbury, NY. 1/3
CONNOLLY--Amalia Ivry. Aug. 22, 1960 - Mar. 22, 2013. Dearest, darling Amalia You are so loved and missed. 1/3
RITTER--Tony. It's been one long year. I can still hear your voice, I can still see your dynamite blue eyes. Miss you and love you. Sher 1/3

HOYT--Henry H.,Jr., died on August 17th, in his home in New York City. He was 88. Born in 1927 to Henry H. Hoyt and Anna O. Hoyt, Henry H. Hoyt, Jr. grew up in South Orange, New Jersey. He distinguished himself as a student at Pingry School in the class of 1945, and at Princeton University in the class of 1949, where he graduated with A.B. cum laude. He served in the U.S. Army from 1946 to 1947. In 1950, he joined the pharmaceutical and consumer products company, Carter- Wallace, Inc. where he rose to become Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer in 1974 until his retirement in 2000. He served on the Board of the Pingry School and the American Paralysis Association, now the Christopher Reeve Foundation. He was a long standing supporter of the following institutions, The Metropolitan Opera (Member of the Association), New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell, and New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Eye Advisory Council. Mr. Hoyt's first wife, Muriel Christie Hoyt, predeceased him. He is survived by his wife, Molly Levy Hoyt, his two daughters, Heather H. Georges and Holly Heyward Hoyt, and his four grandchildren. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Naomi. Beloved wife of 65 years to Alex, devoted mother of Susan and Nina, mother-in-law of Marc and Jamie, cherished grandmother of Remy, Jake, Belinda, Darryn and Cole. She was a designer and owner of a fabric and wallpaper company. Her creativity, overwhelming kindness, fierce loyalty and sense of humor will always be treasured. Naomi, you were the light of our lives. Services will be at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam and 76th St. on Sunday, August 23rd at 11:30am. 1/3

KAPLAN--Martin E. Marty, longest serving Chairman, Institutional Traders Advisory Committee to the Board of Directors, New York Stock Exchange. 29 years at Merrill Lynch, Senior Vice President, Managing Director and Head of Equity Trading. Mentor to many, friend to all who were privileged to know him. Coach to those who lead in the securities industry today - Bob, Brian, Tom T., Ed, and many, many more. President for 25 years of KR Capital, brought great returns to clients with integrity, hard work and great care. Wonderful husband, father, grandfather, brother and dearest friend. Rest in Peace, lift one with Jackie Boy. Dick and Lori 1/3

HUT--Betty Schloss. On August 19, 2015. Born in 1923 to Norman and Beatrice Schloss, she was married for 58 years to Alan Hut until his death in 2001. Cherished mother of Steve (Margaret), Peggy (the late Bradley Diggs), Tom (Eve Peterson), and Ginny (Robert Cartwright). Adored and adoring Beena to Nick, Chris, and Katie Hut; Matt and Benjy Diggs; Ryan Cartwright; and Willa and Grace Hut. Great-grandmother of five. Betty was a graduate of Dalton School and Smith College; a spirited camper at Camp Fernwood; a resident of Manhattan (28 years), Scarsdale (25 years), and Palm Beach, FL (38 years); and an indefatigable volunteer as PTA President, court worker for Jewish Board of Guardians, board member of Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School, and counselor, board member, and winner of the Volunteer of the Year and Unsung Hero Awards with Planned Parenthood of the Palm Beaches. She was an enthusiastic theater-goer, reader, dog-lover, and bridge and golf player. Smart, feisty, and funny, Betty was passionate about her friends, causes, and most of all her family. A private memorial service will take place later in the summer. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America or a charity of your choosing. 1/3

PHILIP--Cynthia Owen. Writer and historian Cynthia Owen Philip died on August 19, 2015. Born in Providence, Rhode Island in 1928, she was a graduate of Smith College (1950), and pursued graduate studies at the Harvard School of Design and the Union Theological Seminary. Her marriage to Nicholas Worthington Philip of Claverack, New York, ended with his death in 1975. Cynthia Philip is survived by her children and grandchildren. Funeral service at St John the Evangelist, Barrytown, NY, on August 24, 11am. Committal at Oak Hill Cemetery, Washington, D.C. on August 26, 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations to N-Y Historical Society or Riverkeeper. 1/3

KUFLIK--Madeline. It is with profound sorrow we mark the passing of Madeline Kuflik. We believe this could be the first time the words Madeline and sorrow are used together. A more positive, loving and happy person will not be found. We shared our happiest and most important milestones together. She loved and was loved. Sid, Joanna and Elana your loss lives in our hearts. May Madeline's memory bring comfort to you and all of us who were so privileged to have known her. The Schrager and Wagner Families. 1/3

HAYES--Dennis E.,marine geophysicist, plate tectonics pioneer, tenured Columbia University professor, who advanced mapping of the world's ocean floors, died at home in Manhattan on August 6, of Parkinson's Disease. He was 76. He produced an atlas of the Southern Ocean bottom, charted key geologic structures below the South China Sea, explored the margins of Western Africa and Southeast Asia, and advanced ideas on how the earth's interior influences ocean depths globally. He was an explorer and adventurer, and his interests lay beneath the ocean floor. "The water just gets in my way," he liked to say. Hayes was Chief Scientist on the Vema in 1975 when it became the first research ship to sail more than one million miles. In 1979, soon after China reopened to the West, Hayes led the first United States - China joint exploration of geologic structures beneath the South China Sea. Data he collected is germane to today's conflicts among China and other nations over territorial sea rights, seafloor geology, and its relationship to land masses. Hayes wrote about the prospect of sealing nuclear waste into the seafloor, and about international management of mineral resources off Antarctica. In 2004, the international scientific community named a 400-kilometer- long feature in the Ross Sea off Antarctica in his honor, named the Hayes Bank. A microscopic protozoan, Prunopyle hayesi, extracted from a sea bottom drill core on one of his cruises, was also named in his honor. He was a Guggenheim Fellow and Fellow of the American Geophysical Union and the Geological Society of America. Son of William and Gertrude Hayes. He is survived by his wife, the former Leslie Eve Price; a sister, Pat Hart; three daughters, Jennifer Gregory, Elizabeth Elliott, Katherine Hayes; and step-daughter Elan Price Barish; and nine grandchildren. Dennis was a Renaissance man. He could build anything, fix anything, cook anything. Handsome, athletic, cool, modest, fair, kind, a good and understanding listener, a dry wit. A great role model loved and admired by friends and family. A framed 1756 quote hung in his office: "To be sure, I lose the fruits of the earth, But then I am gathering the flowers of the sea." 1/3

BINGHAM--W. Richard "Dick." Died peacefully at his cherished home in Fishers Island, NY on August 18th surrounded by his loving family. The loss is felt for this family man who was a lifetime keen intellect, Navy Veteran, respected financier, philanthropist, civic affairs strategist, competitor and avid sportsman. He was foremost a loving husband and father dedicated to his extended family and friends and having as he called it "the fortunate opportunity to experience a lifetime of participation in problem solving and creation of new entities." Dick was born in New York City and grew up in Bucks County, PA and Hillsborough, CA. He attended Hillsborough School, Town School for Boys (Class of '49), Middlesex (Class of '53), Stanford University (Class of '57), and Harvard Business School (Class of '61). He attended the Universities of Geneva and Paris. Throughout every stage of his life he held a myriad of leadership positions beginning at Stanford where he was President of Phi Delta Theta Fraternity, and head of campus security. He served as Line Officer aboard the U.S. Navy destroyer, U.S.S. Davis, from 1957-1959. He remembered his naval service fondly which contributed to his unwavering love of the ocean. Dick was characterized by and often closed remarks on occasion with this line taken from his US Navy days, "May fair winds and following seas accompany you." Following his military service, Dick began his career on Wall Street at the investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb, and Co. in 1961. As a partner, Director of Investment Banking, a member of the Executive Committee and Board of Directors, he advised many companies and countries on capital raising activities. He continued his career as a partner of Lehman Brothers in 1977 where he was Director of Investment Banking, Corporate Finance, and Mergers and Acquisitions and a member of the Board. In 1988 he founded American Industrial Partners (AIP) which became a respected, ground-breaking private equity firm. As a savvy investor and President of AIP, Dick and his American Industrial Partners team raised four funds and led multiple investments in diverse industrial companies while he served on a number of corporate boards. In 1996, during Mayor Frank Jordan's administration in San Francisco, Dick was appointed Honorary Consul to the Republic of Lithuania. Also, during that time, he was appointed to the newly formed San Francisco's Committee on Jobs where the primary focus was to promote a business climate that allowed San Francisco to remain a desirable place to live, work, and operate a business. Throughout his life, Dick was dedicated to philanthropy and offered his services and support to many Bay Area institutions over the years. His philanthropic interests reflected his love of the wonders of the world, nature, the ocean, music, and the arts. His most memorable philanthropic lifetime achievement was the California Academy of Sciences located in Golden Gate Park, San Francisco. He served as Chairman of its Board from 1996 until it's reopening in 2007. He was extremely proud of what he and the board accomplished, especially literally knocking on doors to aid in the passing of Proposition B, which was pivotal in the process to completely rebuild the Academy into the world-class science and educational institution that it is today. As an adjunct to the Academy, he envisioned and worked tirelessly to raise private monies needed to fund the Music Concourse Garage which lies between the Academy and de Young Museums. He served as Chairman of that board. He passionately believed that education and educational pursuits were important for individuals and society. To him, saving and rebuilding the Academy was the tangible apex of that passion. His efforts helped ensure the Academy remained in Golden Gate Park as a state-of- the-art learning center and museum. Dick also is past trustee of The Town School for Boys, Marin Country Day School, The Urban School, The Bay School, Middlesex School, The World Affairs Council, St Johns Church on Fisher's Island, and CPMC Foundation. He was a member of the Pacific Union Club, the Burlingame Country Club, The San Francisco Golf Club, and the Fisher's Island Club. Dick is survived by his loving wife, Wendy Wasson Bingham, adoring children, Lock, Frances, and Grace Bingham, and devoted sister Betsy Bingham Davis. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Dick's memory to the California Academy of Sciences, which was an important cause for Dick. 1

STRICKLER--Nancy C. Nancy C. Strickler, age 88, died on August 8, 2015. She was a resident of London, England and died while hospitalized there after several years of declining health. She was born and raised in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. Her parents were Lt. General Daniel Bursk Strickler and Caroline Bolton Strickler. General Strickler was a former Commanding General of Pennsylvania's 28th Infantry Division and also served as Lt. Governor of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. Nancy was a graduate of Bryn Mawr College. As a young adult she traveled abroad and then settled in England where London was her primary home for the rest of her life. She had a career as an Administrator for the Department of the Army of the United States Government. She converted to Catholicism and was an active member of the Church. She had a keen mind and took great pleasure in keeping abreast of events in the world at large. She was accomplished in foreign languages, speaking French, German, Italian and Russian. Nancy enjoyed the bustling life of the neighborhood where she lived in London, first in Knightsbridge and then, for many years, on Walton Street in Chelsea, just a few blocks from Harrods. She had great love for her daughter Caroline Scott who was raised in London and now lives in Uppingham, England with her husband Roland Scott. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Viola McLachlan, Daniel McLachlan and Juliet Evans and by two great-granddaughters, all of whom live in England. She is further survived by her younger brother, Daniel B. Strickler, Jr. of New York City. 1/3

CALIMAFDE--John, passed away on August 5, 2015 in Old Greenwich, CT, surrounded by his family. John co- founded the New York IP and litigation firm, Hopgood, Calimafde, Judlowe & Mondolino. Upon retirement, John was credited with having tried the most patent cases of any attorney in the U.S. He was often introduced as the "Dean of the Patent Bar" when lecturing to attorneys throughout the United States. During World War II, he served in the 10th Mountain Division (Ski Troops) and subsequently as a Lieutenant in the post-war Japanese provisional government. After the war, he graduated with an electrical engineering degree from the University of Michigan and received his law degree from Fordham University. Beyond his professional and athletic successes, John will be remembered foremost for his character - his unwavering cheer, optimism, humility, and integrity. He is survived by his wife, Annette; his two daughters, six grandchildren, three great- grandchildren and his sister. 1/3

KUFLIK--Madeline Beth. Madeline Beth Kuflik (nee Cohen), passed away peacefully on August 20 after fiercely and ferociously battling pancreatic cancer for 40 months. She is survived by her beloved husband Sidney, her cherished daughters Joanna and Elana, and her loving sister and brother-in- law, Vivian and Paul Malta. Madeline was a true child of The City. Born in Brooklyn, raised in Queens, she lived most of her adult life in Manhattan. A graduate of the University of Maryland and Emory University Law School, Madeline was a customs and international trade trial lawyer for the U.S. Justice Department before joining Panasonic in 1983, eventually becoming Assistant General Counsel. She remained at Panasonic for nearly 30 years before her illness caused her to retire. Her laughter, vibrancy, kind heart, intelligence, loyalty and warmth made her beloved by all who were fortunate enough to know her. MELLO--H. Joseph "Joe", 73, of Manhattan, died suddenly on August 19, 2015. Born in Brooklyn, he was the son of the late Dominic and Prudence (Bellanti) Mello. Mr. Mello was raised a proud Italian and was admired for his unwavering Iove of his family. Mr. Mello is survived by his beloved cousins Pina (Tomarchio) Pergolizzi, Prudence (Bellanti) McCafferty, Russ Tomarchio, Louise (Alimenti) Clarke, Arlene (Alimenti) Rosica, Marie Alimenti, Lorraine (Alimenti) Sacchetti, as well as many other loving family members and friends. The clear patriarch of the Bellanti family, "Uncle Joe" was uncle and godfather to more nieces and nephews than can be counted. Mr. Mello served in the United States Army as a Captain in Vietnam during the Tet Offensive. He devoted his professional career to the law. After graduating from Cornell University in 1963 and New York University Law in 1966, he was admitted to the New York State Bar in 1967. For nearly half a century, he provided clients counsel on intellectual property, copyright and commercial litigation issues. He began his career and became a partner at Golenbock and Barrel LLP and continued as a valued partner of Thelen Reid and Priest LLP. Mr. Mello was active in the New York State Bar Association (NYSBA) and had served as Chairperson of the Copyright Law Committee of the Intellectual Property Section of the NYSBA. He concluded his career at Winston and Strawn LLP, retiring in 2011 and since then remaining in service Of Counsel. A man who loved to gather at a table with family and friends, Joe was a connoisseur of food and wine and an aficionado of conversation, famous for passing on family history through wonderful storytelling. Each day, he relished his New York Times and took great joy in discussing all the news. He loved to travel, often with his dear friends from Cornell University, and especially to his ancestral home of Sicily, which was never far from his heart. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends and will be remembered forever by those who had the privilege to know him. Family and friends may visit Torregrossa Funeral Home, 345 Avenue U, Brooklyn, NY on Monday, August 24, 2015 from 2pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Tuesday, August 25, 2015 at St. Athanasius Church at 10:30am, at 2154 61st Street and Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, NY. Burial to immediately follow at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the "H. Joseph Mello '63 Scholarship Fund" at Cornell University in the College of Arts and Sciences in his memory. Cornell University, P.O. Sex 25842, Lehigh VaHey, PA 18003--9692 or go to website: giving.comell.edu and refer to "ways to give." 1

GOODMAN--Arthur Herbert, born in Brooklyn, March 27th, 1940, passed away quietly on Saturday, August 15th, after a sudden final illness. Following a decade of bravely-fought disease, including organ transplant and multiple cancers, his last minutes transpired peacefully with his family surrounding him in a circle of love. Arthur showed his rare gift with numbers and logical reasoning from his earliest years, as when preparing the family taxes from the age of seven. His lively irreverence, his charisma, and his masterful organizational skills revealed themselves en suite when he expressed his disdain for his teacher at Flatbush Yeshiva a bit too colorfully, earning in consequence from the head Rabbi the role of book monitor for the school year, only to receive a special prize at year's end for best monitor in the Yeshiva's history, complete with a medal in a velvet-lined box. After attending University of Pennsylvania, Wharton undergrad where he concentrated on insurance, and then Harvard Law School, he began his iconoclastic career by quitting his white-glove law firm after a) learning that an original and creative argument on a case was both acknowledged and rejected as such and b) balking at having to climb to the far reaches of the library ladder to pull a Vermont casebook. From then on, he thrived as a sole practitioner and business owner, developing a unique expertise in estate planning, writing the briefest yet most airtight wills imaginable. He built a successful property- casualty insurance agency named after his father - a life-long true believer in and seller of life insurance for New York Life - Charles Goodman and Company. He also served faithfully through the decades as President of the FMA Group. Awesomely productive, for most of his career Arthur typically worked at lightning speed from dawn until late morning, taking afternoons and evenings off to attend to his home and family. (Of course, he never situated himself far from a telephone, even knowing the location of every pay phone in the county, and then some.) In another example of his uncanny efficiency and mathematical instincts, not to mention his aversion to exercise, Arthur enjoyed a quiet renown for his unusual game of tennis: by way of keen anticipation and perfect reading of the angles, he seemingly could return virtually any shot on the court without moving more than a few inches. All his life, Arthur challenged all those around him to think for themselves, and to truly think. He was a problem- solver extraordinaire, and could readily minimize the most arcane, complex ideas to simple, accessible terms. Everyone enjoyed his charming eccentricities, such as his playing chess virtually, board and pieces all in his mind, calling out his moves (much to the bemusement of his young nephew Michael, who had eagerly accepted his uncle's invitation to play, upon hearing Uncle Arthur announce "Pawn to Rook four" with no chess set in sight). Practical, compassionate, and innovative, he would minimize fees for those in need: by bartering his legal services, by giving careful instructions as to time - consuming work clients could accomplish themselves, charging them only for a quick review, and by other inventive means. His generosity was immense, its recipients legion; with it, he literally saved lives. In his heyday, he possessed a supreme confidence and flatly refused to abide social norms for convention's sake. Ever a jokester, Arthur played marvelous pranks, and included humor in everything from his saucy email address to cheeky covert messages in commissioned artwork. He had a tremendous sense of fun, and spent his best years making a joyful game of life with his beloved wife Lois. He nearly always had a twinkle in his eye, and, although uber-responsible, he never let life's demands interfere with life's delights. He inspired countless family members and friends with his light-hearted love of living. He is survived by his soulmate, wife, and best friend of nearly four decades, Lois; deeply loved daughters Monica and Gabrielle; adored daughter Susanne Mordoh, and sole and steady son Steven Rubenstein; dear younger sister Denise Levine and brother-in-law David; treasured daughters and sons-in-law Amy Rubenstein, Michele Turchiano, Jonathan Mordoh and Scott Higson; and cherished grandchildren Jake, Stephanie, Perri, and Alex. In keeping with his wishes, there will be no funeral, service, or shiva. A spirited celebration of his life will take place in the autumn. In lieu of flowers or donations, to honor Arthur, love deeply, give generously, laugh heartily, and and carpe the best out of every last diem. Arthur was a giant of a man in every way - mind, body, heart, and soul. Our sadness too is vast. But he has left us with an equally colossal legacy of love and laughter to compass our grief, and guide us abidingly through the years to come. 1/3

HOFFMAN--John Brooks, M.D.,passed away on Thursday, June 11, 2015 about 1:50pm from cardiac arrest. Born in Rahway, New Jersey in 1918, son of John and Eva Brooks Hoffman. He attended Blair Academy and graduated in 1936. He attended Williams College from which he received a BA degree. He attended Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons and graduated in 1943 with a M.D. degree. Then he went on active duty in the U.S. Army Medical Corp and was discharged as a Captain. In December 1942, during a black out in New York City (it was wartime), he ran into Jane Helwig, a student nurse at Presbyterian Hospital and two and one-half years later, they were married on June 14th, Flag Day, in 1945. He is survived by five children: Nancy L. of Seattle, WA; Susan J. of Malvern, PA; Deborah A. of Villanova, PA; J. Brooks, Jr. of West Barnstable, MA; and Peter K. of Fairfield, CT, seven grandchildren, and eight great-grandchildren. He came to Greenwich in 1950, where he opened his office to practice his specialty. He was the first doctor in Greenwich with American boards in his specialty. He eventually became Chairman of the Department of OB/GYN in Greenwich Hospital. He retired in 1985. In 1991, he was awarded the Distinguished Citizen Award by the Greenwich Boy Scouts. He was Co-chairman of the "Greenwich 350 Celebration", a year-long party in 1990, to celebrate the Town's 350th year. His father had been a collector of autographs and old documents. From him, Brooks grew to be a collector of Early Americana of some note; his collection of presidential autographs (while they were in office). He gave over 300 articles of Early Americana to the Chapin Library at Williams, and helped with the purchase of the Declaration of Independence and also donated the first British answer to the Declaration. Blair Academy was also given many valuable pieces of Americana. His long period of 67 years to Blair Academy will be remembered by all who had any association with Blair. He was a Trustee for over 45 years, during which he served as Chairman of the Board for 16 years and 10 years as Chairman of the Executive Committee. In 1993, the school awarded him a Citation of Merit and an Emeritus position on Staff. In honor of his wife, he established a scholarship at the Columbia University School of Nursing. He used to say that he played a significant role in the delivery of over 3500 babies. (He did not deliver the babies, the mothers did that!) He also did over 2500 surgical procedures in his career, and finally he loved to say that he tried to play a supporting role in the raising of five children with Jane. Service will be held in the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich, at 11:00am Saturday, September 12, 2015. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the First Presbyterian Church of Greenwich One West Putnam Ave. Greenwich, CT 06830 or a charity of your choice will be appreciated. 1/3

PERLE--Elizabeth. Elizabeth "Liz" Perle, died peacefully at her home in San Francisco on August 20 after living with breast cancer for more than eight years. Liz was born at New York City's Lenox Hill Hospital on April 13, 1956 and was the only child of Ellen Kraus Perle and E. Gabriel Perle. She spent her early childhood years in Rowayton, Connecticut, before returning to New York City. She attended the Riverdale Country School for Girls in the Bronx and Hampshire College in Amherst, Massachusetts, and later transferred to Yale University, from which she received a bachelor's degree in 1977. After college, Liz lived briefly in San Francisco before returning to New York City and embarking on a successful 20-year career in book publishing. Liz worked in a variety of positions, ranging from marketing director to publisher, at Times Books, Bantam Books, Prentice Hall Press, Addison Wesley and William Morrow/Avon. Liz moved to San Francisco in 1997, where she was Editor at Large at HarperSan Francisco Publishers. In addition to her career as a book publisher and editor, Liz authored two highly-acclaimed non- fiction books: When Work Doesn't Work Anymore: Women, Work and Identity (Delacorte Press, 1997) and Money: A Memoir (Henry Holt, 2006). In 2002, Liz co-founded Common Sense Media, a non- profit organization in San Francisco that has become the nation's most widely recognized and trusted source of information about media and entertainment for children, parents, educators, policymakers and others. For many years, Liz served as Common Sense Media's editor-in-chief and later joined the group's board of directors. Common Sense Media recently established the Liz Perle Fellowship for Editorial Excellence, which will offer one-year training fellowships to promising young editors. In 2013, Liz appeared in the Emmy-nominated HBO documentary film 50 Children: The Rescue Mission of Mr. and Mrs. Kraus, which was produced and directed by Steven Pressman, Liz' husband. The film tells the previously unknown story of Liz' maternal grandparents, Gilbert and Eleanor Kraus, who rescued 50 Jewish children from Nazi-occupied Vienna and brought them to the United States in 1939. Liz Perle is survived by her husband Steven, son David Perle McKenna and stepdaughter Roshann Pressman. Donations in her memory to the Carol Franc Buck Breast Care Center at UC San Francisco would be warmly appreciated. 1/3

FALISE--Robert A.,82, a lawyer, died at his home in Florida on August 13, 2015. Robert Alphonse Falise was born in New York City in 1932, graduated from Columbia College in 1954 and received his J.D. from Columbia University School of Law in 1956. He served as Assistant Director of the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights from 1960-1961 and prior to that as an Army Judge Advocate officer for the Secretary of the Army. Mr. Falise was in private practice with Olwine Connolly Chase O'Donnell & Weyher in the early 1960's and prior to that with Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine. He served as Vice President and General Counsel of Dictaphone Corporation from 1966 to 1980. He then became Vice President and Corporate Counsel of RCA Corporation from 1980 to 1986, and served as Executive Vice President of Irving Bank Corporation until 1988. From 1991 until his death, Mr. Falise was Chairman of the Manville Personal Injury Settlement Trust, which was formed to settle asbestos personal injury claims. In 2001, Mr. Falise was selected by Texaco, Chevron and the FTC as Chairman and Divestiture Trustee of the Texaco Alliance Trust. Mr. Falise was an avid sailor, classic car enthusiast, and an active member in the Metropolitan Club, The Brook, the New York Yacht Club as well as Quail Valley River Club and Orchid Island Golf & Beach Club in Vero Beach. Survivors include his wife of nearly 50 years, Katharine Falise of Vero Beach, FL; two children, Katherine (Phillip) Knapp of Sea Ranch Lakes, FL and Christina Falise of New Milford, CT and four grandchildren: Robert Knapp, Kia Knapp, Kari Bjorlin and Christina Bjorlin. Mr. Falise was preceded in death by his daughter, Elizabeth Bjorlin. A private memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, NY. Memorial donations may be made to VNA Hospice House, 901 37th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960. 1/3

MOSES--Ken. February 21, 1944 - August 17, 2015, of Stillwater, MN. Died of complications of autism. Theater technology degree, Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University), 1965. Instructor at Syracuse University Drama Department 1966-67. Career in professional theatre: Broadway, Off-Broadway, London's West End, regional and community theatres. Succeeded the late Larry Berthelson as director of Pickwick Puppet Theatre (the New York Public Library for the performing Arts has recently acquired the archives of the Pickwick Puppet Theater; the archive is now the property of the Bill Rose Theater Division, New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center and these materials may be seen there) 1975 recipient of UNIMA Citation of Excellence award for collaboration with Berthelson on Stravinsky's "Pulcinella." Produced and directed Mozart's "Magic Flute" at Lincoln Center. Produced an original adaptation of Cervantes' "Don Quixote" with a score by Manuel de Falla. Taught workshops and classes in theatre arts at many theatre festivals. Around-the-world trip 1987-90. Active in Civil Rights advocacy and education, concentrating on disability and GLBT rights. Wrote regulations for New Jersey Personal Assistance Services Program. Received the first Stillwater Human Rights Award, 2006. Audio Describer for blind theatre- goers in Minnesota; assisted artists with disabilities in art exhibits and literary readings. Developed and designed the unrealized Stillwater Downtown Theatre. As a person with undetected autism, he remained a lifelong misfit and his family life centered on his cats George (1968-86) and Ozzie (2001-present) Survived by longtime friends Paul Brown, St. Mary's Point, MN; Joseph Hupcey, Florham Park, NJ (whose children became his nieces and nephew); Susan Clark, Juneau, AK; and Trevor Vasey, San Diego, CA; and numerous other colleagues. Cabaret Celebration pending, Bradshaw Funeral Homes, 2800 Curve Crest Boulevard, Stillwater, MN 55082. 651-439-5511. 1/3

She was a great friend, a gracious and wonderful lady. 1/3

DEBEVOISE--Dickinson R. Judge Dickinson Debevoise, on August 14, 2015, Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise died peacefully at his home in Summit, New Jersey. Son of Josephine R. and Elliott Debevoise, Debevoise was born on April 23, 1924, in Orange, New Jersey. He was predeceased by his wife of 64 years, Katrina Leeb Debevoise, and by two younger brothers, Elliott Debevoise, Jr., and Peter Huntington Debevoise. He attended the South Orange public schools and Deerfield Academy, and graduated from Williams College in 1948 and from Columbia Law School, where he served on the Law Review. Debevoise served in the 294th Combat Engineer Battalion in World War II. On June 7, 1944, during the Normandy landings, the Battalion's transport ship, the Susan B. Anthony, was sunk off Utah Beach. The soldiers climbed into other vessels and then into landing craft before proceeding to the beach. Debevoise served as squad leader with the rank of sergeant in the Battalion's campaigns in Normandy, central France, the Hurtgen Forest on the German frontier, and the Battle of the Bulge, returning to Germany for the War's concluding campaign and, after VE Day, joining the occupation forces in Berlin. He was awarded the Bronze Star Medal. In February of 1951, the most important event of Debevoise's life took place - his marriage to Katrina S. Leeb. In April of that year, he was recalled into the Army, and served during the Korean War as a first lieutenant in the Army Security Agency. He and his wife Trina spent the first year of their marriage living in Army posts in Camp Pickett, VA, and Fort Devens, MA. Between 1952 and 1953, Debevoise served as law clerk to Chief Judge Phillip Forman of New Jersey's United States District Court. In 1953, he became associated with the Newark law firm of Riker, Emery & Danzig (now Riker, Danzig, Scherer, Hyland, & Perretti), becoming a partner in 1957. For 26 years he engaged in a general practice that included commercial and corporate law and state and federal litigation. During this period, he was actively involved in the civil rights movement. In 1964, as Chairman of the Essex County, NJ Bar Association Civil Rights Committee and as part of the Lawyers Constitutional Defense Committee, Debevoise recruited other New Jersey lawyers to join him representing civil rights workers in Mississippi participating in the Mississippi Freedom Summer. Following this, he oversaw the formation of the Newark Legal Services Project, of which he served as President for the next five years. He continued his efforts to combat endemic urban poverty and racial injustice through his work with The Fund for New Jersey (as Trustee) and the New Jersey Institute for Social Justice (as Director and Vice President). Additional public service included chairing the New Jersey Clients' Security Fund and the Governor's Workmen's Compensation Study Committee, the New Jersey Supreme Court's Disciplinary Review Board, and the Lawyers Advisory Committee of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. He dedicated nearly 23 years to the Hospital Center of Orange, New Jersey, serving as General Counsel, Trustee and Vice President. On the education front, he served as Trustee of Williams College from 1969-1974, during a pivotal time in the College's history when it transformed itself from a fraternity-based institution to a non- fraternal residential college, and was a founding Trustee of Ramapo College of New Jersey and Chair of its Board of Trustees from 1971-1974. He served as Adjunct Professor of Constitutional Law at Seton Hall Law School between 1991 and 1994. In 1979, President Jimmy Carter appointed Debevoise a District Court Judge for the District of New Jersey, in which position he served until his death. There he handled a wide variety of civil and criminal cases, ranging from complex securities matters to civil rights matters. Among his notable cases were the 1996 arraignment of Unabomber Ted Kaczynski; the 1985 collapse of the financial firm Bevill, Bresler & Schulman, in which he authored a landmark decision addressing the rights of investors in securities repurchase agreements, or "repos," and his 1983 ruling declaring New Jersey's "moment of silence" law an unconstitutional attempt to circumvent the U.S. Supreme Court's ban on state-sanctioned prayer in public schools. Extending his initial 15 years of judicial service with an extraordinary 21 years as a senior status judge, Debevoise earned a nationwide reputation as a consummate jurist, deeply respected by members of the bench and bar alike for his intellect, fairness, and passionate commitment to justice. ebevoise spent summers throughout his life on the shores of Casco Bay, at Mere Point, Maine, a summer haven for him and his wife Trina, their children and grandchildren. There, he pursued his lifelong passions of sailing and rowing. In 1980, he furthered his efforts to preserve unspoiled land on the Maine coast by donating a conservation easement of half of 90-acre Upper Goose Island in Casco Bay to the Nature Conservancy of Maine. Debevoise is survived by four daughters, Kate S. Debevoise of Yarmouth, Maine, Josephine (Josie) D. Davies of New Canaan, CT, Mary (Molly) D. Rennie of Short Hills, NJ, and Abigail (Abby) D. Boozan, of Short Hills, NJ. In addition, he is survived by Josie's husband, Ralph Davies and Abby's husband, Dr. John Boozan, and by seven grandchildren - Ralph N. Davies, Jr., Heidi L. Davies, Samuel R. Davies, Katrina S. Rennie, Victoria B. Rennie, Gerard H. Byrne, and Philip H. Byrne - and by three step grandchildren - Peter M. Boozan, Matthew C. Boozan and Henry W. Boozan. A memorial service will be held at Trinity & St. Philip's Cathedral, 608 Broad St., Newark, NJ at 11am on Saturday, September 19th. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to St. Stephen's Church, 119 Main St., Millburn, NJ 07041-1115, the New Jersey Institute for Social Justice, 60 Park Pl, Suite 511, Newark, NJ 07102-5504, Lamda Legal Defense and Education Fund, Inc. 120 Wall St., Suite 1500, NY, NY 10005-3904, or a charity of choice. 1/3

GLUCK--Richard. Richard Francis Gluck, age 77, of Pittsfield, VT, died on Friday, August 14, 2015, at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Memorial Hospital. Dick was born in Brooklyn, NY, on June 15, 1938, the son of Sarah Fern Fisher and Frederick Francis Gluck. He attended the Regis School in New York City and graduated from the Brooklyn Preparatory School. Dick married Noel Finnegan of Brooklyn, NY on December 18, 1971. They spent their honeymoon at the Chalet Killington. While working in New York City, Dick and Noel lived in Rowayton, Conn. Dick was an avid skier and spent most winter weekends at his Pittsfield house skiing Killington with Noel and their numerous friends. He had a small boat and enjoyed fishing in Long Island Sound and cooking his catch. Dick was also a marathon runner. He ran in seven New York City marathons finishing one marathon in less than three hours! Dick loved to cook and prepare meals for his Christmas Parties and gatherings of friends. After spending many years working on Wall Street, Dick formed his own headhunting agency. He retired from his business in 1993 and moved to his home in Pittsfield. He worked at the Killington ski area for 12 years as a ski instructor. Not only did he teach skiing, Dick entertained his students and fellow instructors with his humorous stories and jokes. For 12 years, Dick and Noel organized Team Killington to participate in the Komen Race for the Cure. Team Killington raised a significant amount of money for the Cure and received awards for having the largest group of Family and Friends participating in the race. The Glucks' barbecue at their Pittsfield home for the 100 or more race participants was a highlight of the summer season. Dick is survived by his wife Noel of 43 years; three brothers: Fred and Linda of Santa Barbara, CA.; Bill and Arlene of Concord, MA.; Stephen of Salem, CT.; and two sisters: Ginna and Charlie of Cherry Hill, NJ. and Gay and Peter of Naples, FL. Dick's passing is the end of an era for the Pittsfield/Killington communities. As our unofficial Mayor, he will be sorely missed. Contributions may be made to Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Rutland Humane Society or a charity of your choice c/o Clifford Funeral Home, 2 Washington Street, Rutland, Vermont 05701. The family wishes to thank all of Dick's friends for their love and support during his illness. A celebration of Life will be held Friday, August 28, 2015 at 3:00pm at the Summit Lodge on the Killington Access Rd., Killington, VT. 1/3

SHEEN--Deborah L.,died on August 9. Deborah ("Debbie") was born to Leah and Milton Sheen in Brooklyn and given the middle initial L in honor of the opening of Luna Park on Coney Island managed and owned by her father, Milton. Debbie was raised in Brooklyn and moved to New York City to be a teacher. She married and raised her sons Michael and Andrew. She then moved to Florida in the 80's with her two sons and lived in Palm Beach Gardens. She was a sister to Stephanie Sheen Scholnick (Leonard), mother to Michael Simon (Alison) and Andrew Simon (Katharina), and grandmother to Lauren, Nathan, Chloe, Ella and Jake. Debbie was full of love and kindness and lived with a spirit of giving and generosity. With an open heart, she opened up her home welcoming a variety of people and characters into her life. She treated all with caring and curiosity. She always looked for the best in people. She always trusted and gave whatever she could and sometimes more than maybe she should have. She loved her family dearly and is survived by her sons and grandchildren. Her love and spirit for life lives through everyone she touched. Debbie will be missed by many. Donations in Debbie's honor and memory can be made to: Speak Up for Kids of Palm Beach County, Inc. P.O. Box 1896, W. Palm Beach, FL33402 http://www.galpbc.org/ donat ions.html 1/3

Music Class Today! By David Weinstone. Illustrated by Vin Vogel. 32 pp. ­Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 4)
 
“Shake your eggs high! Shake your eggs low!” Sound familiar? You’ve been to those neighborhood classes that introduce many toddlers (and parents) to music — and organized learning. But as Weinstone, the former punk rocker behind the popular Music for Aardvarks program, knows, not every child jumps right in. As the others rock out with their bearded teacher, one little guy needs time. By the end of this friendly, stylishly illustrated rhyme-fest, he’s got the beat and hates to say goodbye.

ARONSON--Barbara Smith. September 8, 1925 - August 17, 2015. The family and friends of this extraordinary woman wish to acknowledge her relentless pursuit of life. Barbara's enduring interests in the Arts and her unceasing quest for knowledge were the lifelong hallmarks of her intellect and passion to learn "why". Born to Ruth and Casper Smith of Lynbrook, NY, Barbara and her brother Eugene were introduced to music, art, and the theater, as well as the wonders of an interdenominational spiritual world. Barbara was trained as a classical pianist, and played and sang on RKO Radio shows while still in high school. She attended Oberlin College, while matriculating at Barnard College. In 1946, she was one of very few women to receive a Master's Degree (in History) from Columbia University. After a brief marriage to Robin Mahaney, she married Howard Greenwald, a business man, with whom she had three sons, Alan, David, and Donald. Divorcing in 1965, she met and married the love of her life, Herbert Aronson, a prominent lawyer, CPA, and one time mayoral candidate from Mt. Vernon, NY. For the next 50 years, she resided in Chappaqua, NY where, after the death of her husband in 1982, dedicated herself to community service including local thrift and book stores and the Northern Westchester Hospital. She was also an active member of the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship of Northern Westchester. She loved the Fellowship, with its' interest in discussing the "big questions" of life. Always an apt student, rumor had it she did quite well in the weekly Humor class, too. In addition to her immediate family, which includes grandchildren Jesse, Alexandra, Cathryn, Olivia, James, Tess, and Grace, and daughters-in-law Susan (Adlin) Greenwald and Catherine Swift, Barbara attracted and maintained a diverse group of loyal friends throughout her remaining years. These friends, from all walks of life, and of all ages, were attracted to her innate kindness, thoughtfulness, and intellectual vigor and inquisitiveness. She was an exemplar of traditional values, and the "eternal verities of life". And she will be missed. A celebration of her life and times will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship of Northern Westchester, 236 S. Bedford Road, Mt Kisco, NY, on Sunday October 4th at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please hug a loved one today. 1/3

CAHN--Alice, artist and former teacher at the Hebrew Home for the Aged, the Bailey Avenue Senior Center, and until recently the Riverdale Senior Center, died on August 21, 2015 at the age of 84. Alice knitted and crocheted; made clothing, jewelry, mosaics, and furniture; built a small boat; and created sculpture out of clay, cloth, metal, found objects, and recycled materials. Alice and her husband, the late Maurice Cahn, were married for 26 years. She was much loved by her three daughters and their spouses Mara (Dave), Lisa (Jean), and Ayla. She was an inventive and playful grandmother to Milo, Riva, Talia, and Lucas. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to PBS, NPR, or the Visiting Nurse Service of NY. 1/3

HUT--Betty Schloss. On August 19, 2015. Born in 1923 to Norman and Beatrice Schloss, she was married for 58 years to Alan Hut until his death in 2001. Cherished mother of Steve (Margaret), Peggy (the late Bradley Diggs), Tom (Eve Peterson), and Ginny (Robert Cartwright). Adored and adoring Beena to Nick, Chris, and Katie Hut; Matt and Benjy Diggs; Ryan Cartwright; and Willa and Grace Hut. Great-grandmother of five. Betty was a graduate of Dalton School and Smith College; a spirited camper at Camp Fernwood; a resident of Manhattan (28 years), Scarsdale (25 years), and Palm Beach, FL (38 years); and an indefatigable volunteer as PTA President, court worker for Jewish Board of Guardians, board member of Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School, and counselor, board member, and winner of the Volunteer of the Year and Unsung Hero Awards with Planned Parenthood of the Palm Beaches. She was an enthusiastic theater-goer, reader, dog-lover, and bridge and golf player. Smart, feisty, and funny, Betty was passionate about her friends, causes, and most of all her family. A private memorial service will take place later in the summer. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America or a charity of your choosing. 1/3

RINGLE--Sophie, on August 23, 2015 at the age of 99. Loving Wife of the late Samuel. Devoted Mother of Arnold (Susan), Norman and the late Selwyn (Susan). Beloved Grandmother of four. Cherished Great-Grandmother of seven. Graveside services, 11am Tuesday, August 25, 2015 at Montefiore Cemetery Laurelton, NY. Services handled by Parkside Memorial Chapels Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

ADELMAN--Francine Elaine (nee Holland). November 6, 1925 - August 22, 2015. Passed away peacefully on August 22 at the home of her dear friend and caregiver, Dina Gadocha, in Sarasota, FL with her children at her side. Fran wed Stanley Adelman in 1948 after meeting on a blind date and cherished their loving 65-year marriage until Stan passed away in 2013. Among her many accomplishments--Suffolk County, NY spelling champ at age 13, summa cum laude Syracuse University, managing editor of the Syracuse Daily Orange, associate editor of True Detective magazine, art tour producer, New York delegate to the first National Women's Conference in 1977, founder of the Calhoun High School Substitute Enrichment Program, press secretary for legislative and Congressional campaigns, Vice President Nassau County NOW, and much more. Fran was most proud of her tenure as president of the Merrick (New York) Library where she was a fierce champion for intellectual freedom. Fran is survived by her sons, Larry, Jim and Jon, their respective spouses, Andrea Snow, Cindy Jaynes and Nancy Adelman, and loving grandchildren, Stella, Jessica, Sam, Jake and Sophie. She will be dearly missed. Donations can be made to Planned Parenthood. 1/3

POLKOWITZ--Maurice. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Mr. Maurice Polkowitz and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3
CANTOS--Susan. March 8, 1947, died on August 21, 2015. Beloved wife of Joel, mother of Lisa, and grandmother of Jill and Rachel Weidman. 1/3
RUBIN--Rhoda. 9/11/30- 8/24/75. 40 years gone, missed forever. The warmth of your flame remains. Love, Debbie 1/3

RONIN--Harold. Joined wife and best friend, Rosalind, in heaven on August 22. Left this world with peace and dignity, surrounded by family. Best father in the world to Bonnie and Judy. Wonderful father-in-law to Jeff and Marc. Adored Papa of Robert, Andrew, Jennifer and Adam, Jonathan and Aurelie, and Elizabeth. "Great Papa" to Molly and Evan. Devoted brother, uncle, cousin and friend. It's unanimous - he was everyone's favorite! 1/3

CAHN--Alice, August 21st. We depart from a compassionate, loving mother, and wonderful friend. An artist and a teacher of the many expressions of the visual arts. A lover of the fullness of life. Alice, we will miss you. Love, Bob 1/3

REILLY--William Patrick, Esq. Died August 17, 2015 at his beloved summer home in Rhinelander, WI. Born August 29, 1935 in Lynbrook, NY and educated at Bucknell University and UVA Law School, Bill became Managing Partner of Gould and Wilkie in New York, also serving on the Advisory Board of the Salvation Army. He retired from Westchester, NY to Ft. Myers, FL in 2002. He is survived by his wife Jane Letherman Reilly, daughters Karin Reilly (by his first wife, Renate Runde Reilly) and Christine L. Borner, and three grandchildren. His humor and quiet generosity to all will be missed. 1/3

HOYT--Henry H.,Jr., died on August 17th, in his home in New York City. He was 88. Born in 1927 to Henry H. Hoyt and Anna O. Hoyt, Henry H. Hoyt, Jr. grew up in South Orange, New Jersey. He distinguished himself as a student at Pingry School in the class of 1945, and at Princeton University in the class of 1949, where he graduated with A.B. cum laude. He served in the U.S. Army from 1946 to 1947. In 1950, he joined the pharmaceutical and consumer products company, Carter- Wallace, Inc. where he rose to become Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer in 1974 until his retirement in 2000. He served on the Board of the Pingry School and the American Paralysis Association, now the Christopher Reeve Foundation. He was a long standing supporter of the following institutions, The Metropolitan Opera (Member of the Association), New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell, and New York Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Eye Advisory Council. Mr. Hoyt's first wife, Muriel Christie Hoyt, predeceased him. He is survived by his wife, Molly Levy Hoyt, his two daughters, Heather H. Georges and Holly Heyward Hoyt, and his four grandchildren. 1/3

STRICKLER--Nancy C. Nancy C. Strickler, age 88, died on August 8, 2015. She was a resident of London, England and died while hospitalized there after several years of declining health. She was born and raised in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. Her parents were Lt. General Daniel Bursk Strickler and Caroline Bolton Strickler. General Strickler was a former Commanding General of Pennsylvania's 28th Infantry Division and also served as Lt. Governor of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. Nancy was a graduate of Bryn Mawr College. As a young adult she traveled abroad and then settled in England where London was her primary home for the rest of her life. She had a career as an Administrator for the Department of the Army of the United States Government. She converted to Catholicism and was an active member of the Church. She had a keen mind and took great pleasure in keeping abreast of events in the world at large. She was accomplished in foreign languages, speaking French, German, Italian and Russian. Nancy enjoyed the bustling life of the neighborhood where she lived in London, first in Knightsbridge and then, for many years, on Walton Street in Chelsea, just a few blocks from Harrods. She had great love for her daughter Caroline Scott who was raised in London and now lives in Uppingham, England with her husband Roland Scott. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Viola McLachlan, Daniel McLachlan and Juliet Evans and by two great-granddaughters, all of whom live in England. She is further survived by her younger brother, Daniel B. Strickler, Jr. of New York City. 1/3

LEBOFF--Irma, nee Kaplan, died August 21, 2015. Wife of Allen. Mother of Susan Leboff (Bruce Weiner), David Leboff (Patrice O'Dea-Leboff) and Kenneth Leboff (Hilary). Sister of Rita Gollin (Richard), also survived by nine grandchildren. Services were held Sunday, August 23, 2015 at 2:30pm at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. Shiva will be observed Monday 7-9pm at the home of Kenneth and Hilary Leboff. Shiva Tuesday 6-9pm at the home of Didi Lacher and Charlie Donaldson. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, www.cancer.org. Services were handled by Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael Sacks, Philadelphia, PA. 1/3

MOST--Jack L. On August 22. Beloved son of Henrietta M. Most. Loving husband of Irma. Dear father of Jeffrey, Peter, Ann, and Jane. Devoted grandfather of Morgan, Kyle, Benjamin, Chloe, Lulu, and Maxine. Services 1pm Tuesday, Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. Forest Hills, NY. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. 1/3

SCHREIBER--Robert A.,was born on September 6, 1942 and grew-up in Brooklyn, NY. He attended Brooklyn Tech and obtained a scholarship to Cornell where he played football, lacrosse, and track. There he met his beloved wife, Helen. Rob started his career at IBM and eventually became an early adaptor of technology in the securities industry, working at Salomon Brothers and retiring as an EVP at Smith Barney. He was diagnosed with MS in 1986. He and Helen vowed to travel the world while he was still able and navigated his wheelchair across every continent except Antarctica. Rob died on August 22nd with his body embattled, but his mind, compassion, and endless generosity intact. Donations: tischms.org. Services Tuesday, August 25, 11am Hellman Memorial, Spring Valley, NY. 1/3

KAZIS--Rose Leah. The Board of Directors and staff of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel wish to express their sincere condolences to board member Joel Kazis on the loss of his mother Rose Leah Kazis. May her memory forever be a blessing. Harold Handler, Chairman 1/3

BRODKIN--Irving, 101, died of natural causes. He retired 1979 as Director Department of Development, Jewish Theological Seminary. Pre-deceased by his wife Sylvia, 2005. Survived by sons Marc and Joel, daughter-in-law Antoinette, granddaughter Mary Rebecca. 1/3
ROSTON--Mary C.,on August 19. The world lost a great person. Services at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, 11am August 26. 1/3

O'ROURKE--Joanne Deirdre, of Manhattan, died peacefully on August 21, 2015 at the age of 73. Beloved sister of Noreen O'Rourke, Marguerite O'Rourke (Benedict Arbutiski), Kathleen McCue (Eugene), and Eileen Tweedy (Ed), and predeceased by her brother Eugene O'Rourke (Jacqueline). Adored aunt and treasured friend to many. Services will be held at Andrett Funeral Home 353 2nd Avenue, NYC on Tuesday August 25th from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial at Church of the Epiphany, East 22nd Street and Second Avenue, NYC on Wednesday August 26th at 11am. 1/3

GOLDIN--Joel, D.M.D.,77, of Scarsdale, New York, on August 21. He was a devoted husband for 46 years of Ellen (Rein). Loving and proud father of Spencer and Edward (Sarah), adoring and adored grandfather of Brooke and Harry, brother of Howard. Respected dentist and professor of prosthodontics, gardener, lover of the arts and true friend. Donations in Joel's memory may be made to Young Concert Artist or New York Botanical Garden. 1/3
LANGERMAN--Bea. Redhead. How lucky we were to be touched by you. Never will you be forgotten. Love always, Herb and Brian 1/3
