HOYT--Henry H. Jr. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Henry H. Hoyt Jr., who was a distinguished member of the Board for over 35 years. Mr. Hoyt served as a Member of the Association from 1979 to 1987, as an Advisory Director from 1987 to 1991, and was then again elected Member of the Association, serving since 1991. On behalf of everyone at the Met, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Molly Levy Hoyt; his daughters, Met Young Associate Director Heather Hoyt Georges and Holly Heyward Hoyt; and to his family and friends. Ann Ziff, Chairman of the Board Judith-Ann Corrente, President & CEO Peter Gelb, General Manager 1/3

SCHEINER--Ann McGovern, died peacefully in her Manhattan home on August 8, 2015 of cancer, surrounded by her loving family. She was 85 years old. Ann was a noted author of more than 55 children's books, a collage artist, a poet, and an adventurer; see www.annmcgovern.com. Ann is survived by her four children Peter McGovern (Jeanne Levasseur), Charles Scheiner (Jill Sternberg), Ann C. Scheiner (John Mulligan), and James Scheiner (Sybil Scheiner); her three grandchildren Sharon Mulligan, Chris Mulligan (Marian Seat), and Dennis Mulligan; and her companion Ralph Greenberg. In lieu of flowers, donations in Ann's memory may be made to Sponsors for Educational Opportunity and Goddard Riverside Community Center. A memorial will be held on Thursday, September 10th at 5:30pm at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and 64th St. Details will be on her blog at www.anniesoctopuses. word press.com. 1/3

RINGLE--Sophie, on August 23, 2015 at the age of 99. Loving Wife of the late Samuel. Devoted Mother of Arnold (Susan), Norman and the late Selwyn (Susan). Beloved Grandmother of four. Cherished Great-Grandmother of seven. Graveside services, 11am Tuesday, August 25, 2015 at Montefiore Cemetery Laurelton, NY. Services handled by Parkside Memorial Chapels Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

BRUMBERG--Peter, 86, beloved husband of Barbara and devoted father of Richard (Aija) and Gary (Wendy) and four grandchildren. Esteemed friend. He served in the US Navy; RPI '51, MgtE, Vice President Felton International. Enjoyed RV Travels, Sports, Music and Bridge. Service Today at Gutterman's Inc., Rockville Centre, NY at 11am. All deeply mourn his passing. 1/3

FOSTER--Estelle. (1925-2015). We mourn the death of our brilliant, beloved mother, Estelle Foster, who died on August 20, 2015, at the age of 90 years. Essie was a radiant spirit; a bright flame whose agile mind and irrepressible wit enchanted all who knew her. Essie's encompassing interest in politics, literature, and world events was undiminished even in the last moments of her life. Her love for her children was more than love; it was a pure joy that bathed us in its special warmth. She was born on the Lower East Side of New York in 1925, where her father, the esteemed Rabbi Benjamin Fleischer, presided over congregation Beth Hamedrash Hagodol. After a brief stint studying at the Martha Graham School for dance, Essie attended Brooklyn College and then received her Master's degree in early childhood education. In 1950, she married Israel (Hal) Foster, a union that lasted 64 years. Essie and Hal were devoted to raising their five children. The untimely death in 2003 of their youngest son, Rafe, and in 2012 of their eldest born, Michael, changed their lives forever and weakened them both physically and emotionally. Essie spent the last five years lovingly tended in the home of her daughter Tamar and was predeceased in November by her husband. She is survived by her bereft daughters, Stacy, Tamar, and Jody, her sister, Judith Yockel, and her eight grandchildren. Essie, you were our source and our lodestone, our harshest critic and our fiercest advocate. Your light will burn in our hearts forever. 1/3

KAZIS -- Rose Leah. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Rose Leah Kazis, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Rose's children, Joel (Sara), Ellen (Don), and Lewis (Beatrix); her grandchildren; and entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

TAYLOR--John C.,3rd. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of our former partner, current Of Counsel, friend and colleague, Bud Taylor. We express our deepest sympathies to Jane, Holly and to all members of the family. 1/3

BRUSTMAN--Edith (Wachman), of Yonkers, New York passed away peacefully in her sleep at home on Saturday, August 22nd. Edith, affectionately known to those around her as Edie, was predeceased by her husband, Al, and is survived by her children, Lois (Marc Lust) and Jayson (Joan Opotzner) as well as her beloved grandchildren: Alyssa (wife to Andrew), Daniel (fiance to Rachel), Ben, Allison, and Marci. Edith had a master's degree in education and spent over 40 years as a teacher in the New York City public school system, in Harlem and the Bronx. Since her retirement, she had been a major asset to her son's law office. In addition, she was a constant fixture at Bloomingdale's as well as Knicks, Nets, and Mets games. She touched the lives of countless people, quickly making friends everywhere she went. She had a charismatic personality, a great sense of humor, an impeccable sense of style, and was known for her tremendous insight and wisdom. Edith was truly larger than life and will be profoundly missed by all who knew her. 1/3

MANN--Ingrid Ziska, died peacefully on August 17, 2015 in Newton, NJ. Born in Vienna, Austria, to Maria and Franz Ziska on January 10, 1927. Met her beloved husband, Roland at the end of WWII in Austria while working for the Red Cross. Accompanied him to India 1950-53 and completed an MS in Library Science from Columbia University. Worked as librarian in the New York Public Library, moved to Germany, and finally to Kings Langley, UK where she lived from 1972-2011. Her novel, The Danube Testament (1998), glowingly reviewed in The Spectator, won the Society of Authors Sagittarius Prize for best first novel by an author over 60. Returned to the US in 2011. Remembered for her devotion to husband, father and children, her warmth and heartwarming smile. Loved walking, classical music, poetry and gardening. Survived by her children, Elisabeth, William and Christopher, and five grandchildren. Online condolences at: www.smithmccrackenfuner alhome.com. 1/3

WESTON--Lewis M.,of Floral Park, NY and Boca Raton, FL and long-time resident of Great Neck, NY, passed away on Sunday, August 23, 2015 of natural causes. Born in 1926 in Brooklyn, Lew enjoyed a successful career with Goldman, Sachs as a partner and was active in many industry groups. Generous, unselfish and kind, he was a passionate supporter of Technion in Haifa, Israel, and other important causes. His diverse interests spanned the New York Islanders, Bermuda and automobiles. He is survived by his wife Libby; his four children and five grandchildren. Beatrice, his first wife, predeceased him in 1986. An interment service will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, at 11am on Wednesday, August 26th. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to the American Technion Society or to support kidney disease research. 1/3

SISENWEIN--Branna. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of our cherished friend and Benefactor. Together with her beloved late husband, Irving, Branna was a passionate supporter of medical research for more than 60 years. This extraordinary couple forged a philanthropic partnership to help eradicate blindness and other diseases of the eye. In 2001, they established the Branna and Irving Sisenwein Chair in Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences through a gift that represented, at that time, the largest contribution for a named chair in the history of the College of Medicine. In recognition of their exemplary commitment to the medical school and longtime advocacy of medical research, Yeshiva University bestowed honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degrees on both Irv and Branna in 2007. We already miss Branna's elegant and spirited presence and extend our deepest sympathy to her niece, Dr. Elin Gursky, and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Albert Einstein College of Medicine Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean 1/3

EVERT--James. one of the greatest American tennis teaching professionals of all time--passed away peacefully in Fort Lauderdale, Friday, August 21, 2015. Evert, 91, was surrounded by his loving family. The son of Charles John and Christine Marie Grotz Evert, he was born September 9, 1923 in Chicago, Illinois. He was an All-American player for Notre Dame in the 1940s. In 1947, he won the Canadian Championships. He earned a No. 11 ranking in the U.S. But it was as a teaching professional of the highest order that he built his lofty reputation. In that arena, he was unsurpassed. Evert moved from Chicago to Florida with his wife, Colette, in 1948. For 49 years, he was the city of Fort Lauderdale's tennis director. He became a fixture at Holiday Park--fittingly renamed the Jimmy Evert Tennis Center in 1997--where he taught a wide range of top flight junior players. He was most proud of the fact that all five of his children reached at least the final of a national junior championship in the United States. His renowned daughter, Chris Evert, became one of the best women players in history, securing 18 Grand Slam singles titles, winning at least one major title for 13 consecutive years (1974-86), and finishing seven seasons as the No. 1 ranked woman in the world. The work he did at Holiday Park was extraordinary. Not only did he coach and groom all of his kids as players, but he worked with other standouts across the years including world No. 1 Jennifer Capriati and two highly ranked players who both resided in the world's top ten--Brian Gottfried and Harold Solomon. All of those players came under guidance, as did 1963 U.S. Championships finalist Frank Froehling. The way he raised his kids and shaped them as tennis players and people was exemplary. As Chris Evert once said, "He would not criticize me ever for losing a match. I always tried to win for him. In a nutshell, my Dad created the ideal environment for me to compete. He gave me the space I needed and in his own quiet way brought out the best in me by not asking me to be more than myself. As great as he was as a coach he was even greater as a father. He worked hard as a father, too, and read to us and sang to us and took us swimming and took care of all five kids with my mother. He took us to church and was an unbelievably active parent, so active that he took all of his kids with him to work so the family could be together and he could keep an eye on us." Evert was admired immensely for his understated manner and humility. As Bud Collins said, "Jimmy Evert invented tennis in Florida. He loved tennis and you gave a gift to tennis in Fort Lauderdale. He showed all five of his children and his many students how to love tennis and how to live a life." Chris Evert asked him once why he started all of his kids playing tennis. I thought he might give me a glamorous answer like 'My goal for you is to be No. 1 in the world' but he said, 'I started all of you playing so I could keep the family together.' As a man he was exposed to fame, wealth and success but he remained unaffected and untouched. Once a Japanese tennis promoter walked into our house with $25,000 in cash when I was a young player. He wanted me to play a one night exhibition in Japan. My Dad told him to close the briefcase and please leave our house. That was my Dad. He was the most moral, ethical, dignified person I ever knew. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Colette, son Drew (Penny) Evert, of Delray Beach, FL; daughter Chris Evert, of Boca Raton, FL; daughter Jeanne Dubin of Delray Beach, FL; son John (Mary) Evert of Boca Raton, FL; daughter Clare (Steven) Evert-Shane of Aspen, CO; and his 10 grandchildren: Anna Evert- DeHoag, Lauren Evert- Crawford, Eric Dubin, Catherine Aspenwall, Alex Mill, Nicky Mill, Colton Mill, Siena Evert, Tatum Shane and Remi Shane; and three great- grandchildren, Andrew, Lillian and Hailey; his brother, Gerald Evert and wife Audra, of Little Rock, Arkansas, sister-in-law Ruth Evert of Columbus, Georgia. He was predeceased by two brothers, John Evert and Charles Evert and a son-in-law, Brahm Dubin. In lieu of flowers, friends of the Evert family are asked to donate to the Jimmy Evert Scholarship Fund, which will honor Mr. Evert's legacy of enriching children's lives through the sport of tennis. Funds will go to provide private lessons and educational enhancement for underserved and at-risk children throughout the U.S. Checks can be made payable to the USTA Foundation - Jimmy Evert Fund and sent to 70 West Red Oak Lane, White Plains, NY 10604. Visitation will be held on Tuesday, August 25, 2015 from 6-8pm at Fred Hunters Downtown Fort Lauderdale Home, 718 S. Federal Hwy., Fort Lauderdale. A funeral mass will be held on Wednesday, August 26, 2015 at 11am at St Anthony Catholic Church, 901 NE 2nd St. Fort Lauderdale, FL. www.fredhunters.com 1/3

COLLINS--Reverend Monsignor Timothy S.,died peacefully on Saturday, August 22, 2015 at the Cardinal O'Connor Clergy residence in Bronx, New York. He was 86 years old. Msgr. Collins was born in Grosse Pointe, Michigan to John Timothy Collins and Dorothea Holmes. The family moved to New York City in 1931, and then to Bronxville, New York in 1938. In 1948, Msgr. Collins graduated from the Portsmouth Priory School (now Portsmouth Abbey) in Portsmouth, Rhode Island. After graduation, he entered the Benedictine Monastery at Portsmouth Priory. Msgr. Collins engaged undergraduate studies at the College of Notre Dame, and continued his studies at Benedictine College in Atchison, Kansas. He then returned to Portsmouth Priory where he worked with students as a teacher, track coach and dorm master. He left Portsmouth to spend time in Abiquiu, New Mexico, at the Monastery of Christ in the Desert, a small monastery founded by two monks from Portsmouth Priory. In 1976 Msgr. Collins was incardinated into the Archdiocese of New York, and began his work in the Bronx. He became deeply involved in the community and served as an active member of the community board during a time in which much of the Bronx was recovering from extreme poverty. He served as Chaplain at Bronx Lebanon and Misericordia Hospitals. From 1982-1986 Msgr. Collins was Pastor of the Parish of Saints Philip and James. From 1986-1994 he was Pastor of St. Barnabas Church, where he had overall responsibility for the parish and its elementary and high schools. His installation as Monsignor took place in 1990. In 1994, Msgr. Collins became Pastor of Our Lady of the Rosary Church in Manhattan (the Mother Seton Shrine). Monsignor Collins was a beloved man of the Church, and of his large extended family. He was pre-deceased by his sister, Marianna Collins Tostanoski of Scarsdale, NY. He is survived by his brother, Richard Collins of Vero Beach, FL, and twelve nieces and nephews: DeeDee Tostanoski of Alexandria, VA; Edward Tostanoski, Jr. (Teresa) of Mt. Kisco, NY; Timothy Tostanoski (Maureen) of Danbury, CT; Katie Frosinini (Riccardo) of Florence, Italy; Jean Tostanoski (Edward Higham) of Armonk, NY; Nancy Tostanoski (Brian Hogan) of Scarsdale, NY; Patty Tostanoski of Suffern, NY; Jacqueline Hullar (John) of Menlo Park, CA; Richard Collins, Jr. (Jennifer Blessing) of Brooklyn, NY; John Timothy Collins (Kathy) of Glen View, IL; Stephen Collins (Julie Sunderland) of Omaha, NE; and Christopher Collins (Judy) of New York, NY; and 26 grand-nieces and nephews. Visitation will be Thursday, August 27th at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY from 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. On Friday, August 28th, at St. Barnabas Church, Bronx, NY there will be a viewing from 8:30am to 9:30am, followed at 10:00am by The Mass of Christian Burial, which will be celebrated by His Eminence Cardinal Timothy Dolan. Interment will take place at Holy Mount Cemetery, Eastchester, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to NY Catholic Foundation, Archdiocese of NY, Egan Pavilion, 101 First Ave, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

STROUD--Marion Boulton. The Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with deep sadness the passing of Marion "Kippy" Stroud, longtime and dear friend and a founding member of the Whitney's National Committee. Kippy was a dedicated champion of the arts and artists which she supported, nurtured and inspired through the visionary Fabric Workshop and Museum which she founded in Philadelphia in 1977 and the Acadia Summer Arts Program in Maine better known as "Kamp Kippy". A true original, Kippy will be remembered for her spirit, generosity and lasting contributions to so many in the contemporary art world. Our deepest sympathies to her cousin Patterson Sims and extended family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chair Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Neil G. Bluhm, Co-Chairman Laurie M. Tisch, Co-Chairman Richard M. DeMartini, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director 1/3

GRAVINO--Helen Patricia (nee De Vincent), February 6, 1924-August 25, 2015. Helen was pre-deceased by her first spouse Harold E. Raveche who was a typhoon hunter for the US Navy and died in action in WWII. She is survived by her spouse of 43 years, Blaise Gravino and sister Lee Cutrone. Loving mother of Harold J. Raveche, PhD and mother-in-law of Elizabeth S. Raveche, PhD. She was devoted grandmother to John V. Raveche, BA Princeton '01, spouse Lark and father of Troy; Justin B. Raveche, BS MIT '02, spouse Ashley and father of Avery and Fiona; Bernice H . Garnett, BA UPENN '04, MS Columbia '06, PhD Harvard '13, spouse Reyn and mother of Winona; and Elizabeth Chaudry, BA Yale '07, MS Boston University '12, spouse Nameer. Helen retired as an Administrative Officer, Division of Patents and Council, Exxon Mobil. She was a volunteer at the American Cancer Society Gift Shop in Little Neck, N.Y. She valued education and success foremost. Helen had a passion for life and unconditional love for her family. She will always be remembered as a source of motivation and inspiration. She was tireless in ensuring everyone's happiness. Reposing at Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, 45-09 Little Neck Pkwy., Little Neck, N.Y. (corner of Northern Blvd.) on Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday 9:45am at St. Anastasia Church, 245 St. and Northern Blvd., Douglaston, N.Y. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, N.Y. www.doylebshafferfh.com 1/3

BINGHAM--W. Richard "Dick." Died peacefully at his cherished home in Fishers Island, NY on August 18th surrounded by his loving family. The loss is felt for this family man who was a lifetime keen intellect, Navy Veteran, respected financier, philanthropist, civic affairs strategist, competitor and avid sportsman. He was foremost a loving husband and father dedicated to his extended family and friends and having as he called it "the fortunate opportunity to experience a lifetime of participation in problem solving and creation of new entities." Dick was born in New York City and grew up in Bucks County, PA and Hillsborough, CA. He attended Hillsborough School, Town School for Boys (Class of '49), Middlesex (Class of '53), Stanford University (Class of '57), and Harvard Business School (Class of '61). He attended the Universities of Geneva and Paris. Throughout every stage of his life he held a myriad of leadership positions beginning at Stanford where he was President of Phi Delta Theta Fraternity, and head of campus security. He served as Line Officer aboard the U.S. Navy destroyer, U.S.S. Davis, from 1957-1959. He remembered his naval service fondly which contributed to his unwavering love of the ocean. Dick was characterized by and often closed remarks on occasion with this line taken from his US Navy days, "May fair winds and following seas accompany you." Following his military service, Dick began his career on Wall Street at the investment banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb, and Co. in 1961. As a partner, Director of Investment Banking, a member of the Executive Committee and Board of Directors, he advised many companies and countries on capital raising activities. He continued his career as a partner of Lehman Brothers in 1977 where he was Director of Investment Banking, Corporate Finance, and Mergers and Acquisitions and a member of the Board. In 1988 he founded American Industrial Partners (AIP) which became a respected, ground-breaking private equity firm. As a savvy investor and President of AIP, Dick and his American Industrial Partners team raised four funds and led multiple investments in diverse industrial companies while he served on a number of corporate boards. In 1996, during Mayor Frank Jordan's administration in San Francisco, Dick was appointed Honorary Consul to the Republic of Lithuania. Also, during that time, he was appointed to the newly formed San Francisco's Committee on Jobs where the primary focus was to promote a business climate that allowed San Francisco to remain a desirable place to live, work, and operate a business. Throughout his life, Dick was dedicated to philanthropy and offered his services and support to many Bay Area institutions over the years. His philanthropic interests reflected his love of the wonders of the world, nature, the ocean, music, and the arts. His most memorable philanthropic lifetime achievement was the California Academy of Sciences located in Golden Gate Park, San Francisco. He served as Chairman of its Board from 1996 until it's reopening in 2007. He was extremely proud of what he and the board accomplished, especially literally knocking on doors to aid in the passing of Proposition B, which was pivotal in the process to completely rebuild the Academy into the world-class science and educational institution that it is today. As an adjunct to the Academy, he envisioned and worked tirelessly to raise private monies needed to fund the Music Concourse Garage which lies between the Academy and de Young Museums. He served as Chairman of that board. He passionately believed that education and educational pursuits were important for individuals and society. To him, saving and rebuilding the Academy was the tangible apex of that passion. His efforts helped ensure the Academy remained in Golden Gate Park as a state-of- the-art learning center and museum. Dick also is past trustee of The Town School for Boys, Marin Country Day School, The Urban School, The Bay School, Middlesex School, The World Affairs Council, St Johns Church on Fisher's Island, and CPMC Foundation. He was a member of the Pacific Union Club, the Burlingame Country Club, The San Francisco Golf Club, and the Fisher's Island Club. Dick is survived by his loving wife, Wendy Wasson Bingham, adoring children, Lock, Frances, and Grace Bingham, and devoted sister Betsy Bingham Davis. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Dick's memory to the California Academy of Sciences, which was an important cause for Dick. 1

BURROWS--Lewis, M.D.,died on August 23, 2015 after a fall at home. Dr. Burrows was born in New York to Alexander and Lillian on March 21, 1931. He married Rochelle Kaufman in 1954 and together raised three sons, Adam, Ethan, and Whitney. He is survived by his wife and sons; his sister Arlene and brother-in-law Irwin Birnbaum; cousins Ira and Francine Sturman; daughters-in-law Marie, Paula, and Nancy; and grandchildren Sofie, Luke, Allie, Jordan, Hudson, and James. Dr. Burrows attended NYU, where he majored in English, and NYU School of Medicine. He completed an internship at Ohio State University and a residency at The Mt. Sinai Hospital. After military service at Loring Air Force Base, he joined the staff at The Mt. Sinai Hospital, rising to Professor at The Mt. Sinai School of Medicine. After a fellowship in the emerging field of Organ Transplantation with Nobel Laureate Peter Medawar in London, Dr. Burrows performed the first kidney transplant at The Mount Sinai Hospital in 1967 and assumed leadership of the hospital's transplantation program. During his career, Dr. Burrows mentored hundreds of trainees, authored numerous articles on immunology and transplant medicine, and maintained an extraordinary devotion to his many patients. His other great passion was his family. Funeral services will be held at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla on August 26 at 11:00 a.m. In lieu of flowers donations to Baltimore Lab School, 2220 St. Paul St., Baltimore, MD, 21218. 1/3

The New York Academy of Dentistry 1/3

COLLINS--Reverend Monsignor Timothy S.,died peacefully on Saturday, August 22, 2015 at the Cardinal O'Connor Clergy residence in Bronx, New York. He was 86 years old. Msgr. Collins was born in Grosse Pointe, Michigan to John Timothy Collins and Dorothea Holmes. The family moved to New York City in 1931, and then to Bronxville, New York in 1938. In 1948, Msgr. Collins graduated from the Portsmouth Priory School (now Portsmouth Abbey) in Portsmouth, Rhode Island. After graduation, he entered the Benedictine Monastery at Portsmouth Priory. Msgr. Collins engaged undergraduate studies at the College of Notre Dame, and continued his studies at Benedictine College in Atchison, Kansas. He then returned to Portsmouth Priory where he worked with students as a teacher, track coach and dorm master. He left Portsmouth to spend time in Abiquiu, New Mexico, at the Monastery of Christ in the Desert, a small monastery founded by two monks from Portsmouth Priory. In 1976 Msgr. Collins was incardinated into the Archdiocese of New York, and began his work in the Bronx. He became deeply involved in the community and served as an active member of the community board during a time in which much of the Bronx was recovering from extreme poverty. He served as Chaplain at Bronx Lebanon and Misericordia Hospitals. From 1982-1986 Msgr. Collins was Pastor of the Parish of Saints Philip and James. From 1986-1994 he was Pastor of St. Barnabas Church, where he had overall responsibility for the parish and its elementary and high schools. His installation as Monsignor took place in 1990. In 1994, Msgr. Collins became Pastor of Our Lady of the Rosary Church in Manhattan (the Mother Seton Shrine). Monsignor Collins was a beloved man of the Church, and of his large extended family. He was pre-deceased by his sister, Marianna Collins Tostanoski of Scarsdale, NY. He is survived by his brother, Richard Collins of Vero Beach, FL, and twelve nieces and nephews: DeeDee Tostanoski of Alexandria, VA; Edward Tostanoski, Jr. (Teresa) of Mt. Kisco, NY; Timothy Tostanoski (Maureen) of Danbury, CT; Katie Frosinini (Riccardo) of Florence, Italy; Jean Tostanoski (Edward Higham) of Armonk, NY; Nancy Tostanoski (Brian Hogan) of Scarsdale, NY; Patty Tostanoski of Suffern, NY; Jacqueline Hullar (John) of Menlo Park, CA; Richard Collins, Jr. (Jennifer Blessing) of Brooklyn, NY; John Timothy Collins (Kathy) of Glen View, IL; Stephen Collins (Julie Sunderland) of Omaha, NE; and Christopher Collins (Judy) of New York, NY; and 26 grand-nieces and nephews. Visitation will be Thursday, August 27th at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY from 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm. On Friday, August 28th, at St. Barnabas Church, Bronx, NY there will be a viewing from 8:30am to 9:30am, followed at 10:00am by The Mass of Christian Burial, which will be celebrated by His Eminence Cardinal Timothy Dolan. Interment will take place at Holy Mount Cemetery, Eastchester, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to NY Catholic Foundation, Archdiocese of NY, Egan Pavilion, 101 First Ave, New York, NY 10022. 1/3

WESTON--Lewis M. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) deeply mourn the loss of distinguished leader and generous friend Lewis M. Weston of Floral Park, NY and Boca Raton, FL. A retired partner of Goldman Sachs & Co., Mr. Weston devoted more than four decades to the ATS, the Technion and Israel, reaching, with his beloved wife Libby, the rank of Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of support. The couple established the Beatrice Weston Unit for the Advancement of Students, providing counseling to students from pre-university through graduate level, and the Libby and Lewis M. Weston Laboratory for Spectroscopy of Optoelectronics Materials, and led several missions to the Technion, including the one celebrating Israel's 60th anniversary. A local, national and international leader, Mr. Weston served as ATS president and chairman of the Board; as a member of the Technion Board of Governors; and as the longest serving president of the New York Metropolitan Region, which he led for a decade. He also led major investment policy changes, which built the ATS endowment fund through its principal period of growth on behalf of the Technion. Mr. Weston was honored with the Technion Medal--the university's highest honor, as well as a Technion Honorary Doctorate and Honorary Fellowship. We extend our sincere condolences to Libby Weston, and the entire family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeffrey Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

She is survived by her three sons, Richard, Robert and Neil, their wives Elizabeth, Michele and Michele, and seven grandchildren, Jake, Emma, Jack, Nell, Max, Kate and Jonah. She will be remembered for her smile, style, intelligence and love for family. Ann will be buried in a private ceremony on August 31, 2015. If so inclined, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter. 1/3

FELDMAN--Stanley David, 92, of White Plains, NY, died peacefully, August 25th, after a valiant struggle with Parkinson's. Son of the late Rose and Bernard Feldman, he was a sterling husband, father and grandfather. An alumni of the University of Vermont, he was a decorated Veteran serving in the Pacific in the Engineer Corps during World War II. As a prominent businessman in the paper industry for over 50 years, he opened many early inroads into Europe and Asia, traveling the world and making lifelong friends across continents and bridge tables. He was president of the Regency Whist Club for seven years and long-time board member of the Children's Day Treatment Center (now West End Day School). He is survived by his wife of 46 years, Barbara Chernin Feldman; sons, Jonathan Feldman, Eric and Mickey Goldfine; daughter Rose Caserta; grandchildren Adam and Zachary Goldfine, Max, Stacey and Jack Caserta, Jacob and Sacha Feldman; sister Joan Kron; daughters-in-law Kim Goldfine, Karen Croner and Danielle Polay; son-in-law Patrick Caserta; brother-in-law Don Lord; nephews Daniel Kron, Tony Lord and Jonathan Marder; nieces Jill Simonson, Susan Zelouf and Jane Martin. He was aided in his last years by the dedicated care of Jose Rey Gallardo (Bong) and Melvin Valcorza. Stanley was a uniquely sweet and caring family man, who took on responsibility willingly and gave great joy to everyone around him. Burial will be private. 1/3

LENTINE--Debra Schachter, of Williston, VT, passed away peacefully at home on August 24, following a battle with brain cancer. Debra's radiant spirit, positive outlook, and ceaseless good humor enchanted all who knew her. She taught middle school in Stowe and Williston for nearly 30 years. She is survived by husband John Lentine, daughter Morgan McConnell, parents Ann and Stanley Schachter, brother John Schachter (Lori Klein), nephew Sam Schachter, step-daughters Amelia and Devin McConnell, step-daughter Nicole Lentine, step-son Andrew Lentine, and dozens of loving cousins, aunts and uncles. Debra's passion this past decade was the Dragonheart Vermont Sisters team, a breast cancer survivor dragon boat team that competed all over the world. She embodied the heart and spirit of the team, sharing her joy, kindness, and love of life with each and every member. 1/3

BACKER--Henrietta L. Born September 25, 1924. Died August 24, 2015. Married for 56 years to the late Bernard Backer, with whom she shared a lifetime of commitment to social and economic justice. As an educator she touched the lives of generations of first-graders, teaching them how to learn and always enjoying the miracle that happens when a child becomes literate. Lifelong member of the Workmen's Circle; a founding member of the Democratic Socialists of America, and a member of the Princeton Housing Commission. Mother of Jo Backer Laird, Richard Backer, and the late Louise Uphoff; grandmother of six; and great-grandmother of six, all of whom loved and cherished her beyond words. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the presidential campaign of Bernie Sanders. There will be no memorial service. The family will be sitting Shiva through Sunday. 1/3

WINKLEMAN --Irene. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Irene Winkleman, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Irene's nieces and nephews, Ted Wender (Vickie) and Jill Spitz (Richard); her great nieces and nephews; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

GOLDHAND--Judith (Judi), surrounded by her family, daughters Jill, Joanne, sons-in-law Robert Cohen and Justin D'Arms, her life's companion Asher B. Dann, her stepchildren Laurence (Suzanne) and Michael Dann, and her grandchildren Cecilia and Katrina D'Arms and Carter Cohen. Graduate of UCLA in 1961. Daughter of Betty Pinkert and Raymond Ziff. Sister of Lois Brooks. In cherished memory services at Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500, on Friday at 9:30 am. 1/3

TOWNSEND--Peter Wesley, 1948-2015, of Belgrade, Maine. Formerly of New York City. A woodsman in the city, Peter was a stay-at-home dad, Architect, builder, chef (he would say cook), traveler, hiker, and lover. He taught us how to love and be loved. While starting Una Architectural Studios, he resurrected homes including our little brick building (with rooftop jungle) at One White Street. He raised us as he learned to cook from our neighbors: Chanterelle, Duane Park Patisserie, and Franklin Station Cafe. He was always on the other side of the counter at 3pm when Lucca and Nina would come home from school with friends in tow. There were many half-days in Hoboken, birthdays in Coney Island, bike rides over bridges, trips to Di Palo's, and breakfasts at Socrates after judo with Sensei Oishi. Every summer we traveled from NYC to Maine, where he taught us to camp, kayak, build fires. While the family was decidedly urban, Messalonskee Lake also seemed like home. He was at home anywhere--small towns in Italy, the Adirondacks and the Pine Barrens, atop Tumbledown or Borestone. Countless people and places held his heart. In Italy, he instantly wove himself into the fabric of communities. Speaking Italian, he charmed locals with his adoration for their lands and foods. The woodsman trekked through the jungle, climbed the base of a glacier and prepared freshly caught trout with soon-to-be family in Ecuador. After 30 years in New York City, he created our true home on Messalonskee Lake. Every morning he would go for his swim, finding turtles, saying hello to neighbors. This week he went for a swim and didn't come back. He passed away quickly of a heart attack doing what he loved in a treasured place. He left behind a world of love, people, spaces, and lake creatures. Known far and wide for his pie, pesto, and potato salad, Peter will always feed our hearts. He's there for every bite. He is in every mountain, lake, turtle, loon call, every perfectly located iron hook and desk and light and window, every bike ride, every paddle, everywhere. We will miss him. A celebration will be held Saturday August 29th from 1-3pm at the Maine Lakes Resource Center in Belgrade Lakes. All are welcome. 1/3

PARKS-PARSONS--Toni, died on August 24, 2015 in England. Parks was born on November 4, 1940 to photographer Gordon Parks and first wife, Sally Parks. A photographer, her 2011 exhibition "Bridging the Gap: Photography by Gordon Parks and Toni Parks" revealed her talent and love for her father. The Gordon Parks Foundation mourns her death and will preserve her work. 1/3

STROUD--Marion (Kippy) Boulton, died suddenly on August 22. She was born on March 22, 1939. The only child of Marion Sims Rosengarten Stroud and Dr. Morris W. Stroud, she was raised in Philadelphia and graduated from the Chatham Hall School in Virginia and the University of Pennsylvania. Enormously energetic, creative, generous, and tirelessly hard-working and driven, Stroud was multi- facetted, as esteemed as a leading professional and patron in contemporary art as well as for owning National Open Championship Retrievers and several times her Labradors, which she greatly loved, were the high-winning competition dogs in the United States. In 1977, after serving as Artistic Director of the Philadelphia inner-city educational Prints in Progress program, she founded and remained artistic director of The Fabric Workshop and Museum (FWM) in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania until her death. The Fabric Workshop - and latter its Museum of its holdings and major exhibition spaces and program - began as an experimental cloth print shop hosting two-week artist residencies. It has evolved into an international, non-profit center for the commissioned production of major projects with artists including Marina Abramovic, Anne Hamilton, Joan Jonas, William Kentridge, Lorna Simpson, Sarah Sze, Richard Tuttle, and Bill Viola. Stroud curated numerous exhibitions there and wrote for and edited numerous FWM publications, including the award winning New Material as New Media: The Fabric Workshop and Museum, Doug Aiken A-Z Book (Fractals), Comfort Zone, Lee Bul: Live Forever II, Jorge Pardo, Material Pleasures/The Fabric Workshop at The Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia, A Decade of Pattern, and An Industrious Art and Cai Guo- Qiang: Fallen Blossoms (2010), winner of the International Association of Art Critics award for Best Project in a Public. Over thirty years ago, as an outgrowth of inviting her friends to stay with her on Mount Desert Island, she founded the dynamic Acadia Summer Arts Program, a private summer resident fellowship program on Mount Desert for artists, scholars, and outstanding practitioners of all disciplines, including art museum directors, curators, arts administrators, academics, and patrons. It has hosted hundreds of guests and their families. Stroud served as a long-time trustee of the Philadelphia Museum of Art and was Chair of its Prints, Drawings, and Photographs Committee, and a member of its 20th Century Art and African American Art Committees. She was a member of the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art, Art Table, and the American Crafts Council and was a panelist and reviewer for the National Endowment of the Arts and for the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts. She was awarded Maine's Skowhegan Governor's Award for outstanding service to art and artists. Stroud lived in Philadelphia, Palm Beach, Florida, and on Mount Desert Island. She is survived by a large and devoted family of Rosengarten, Sims, and Stroud cousins and a multitude of friends across the US and around the world. Contributions in her memory should be made to the Fabric Workshop and Museum in Philadelphia. Condolences may be expressed at www.jordanfernald.com 1/3

CHRISTIDIS--Aurora. A native of New York City and longtime resident of Los Angeles, born October 26, 1950, Aurora was the eldest daughter of Mariya Sperdakos-Papachristidis and Phrixos Papachristidis. An avid reader, she graduated Phi Beta Kappa and Magna cum Laude from New York University and received both a JD and MBA with Honors from Columbia University. She was a fierce fighter for what she believed in, against the curtailment of any freedom, and a devoted animal advocate. With a brilliant and intuitive mind, Aurora was a born entrepreneur and acknowledged expert in executive recruitment. Among her outstanding career achievements were the establishment of successful pay television services in Turkey and Latin America. At the time of her death, she was involved as a business consultant with three growing companies: high tech digital security, business insurance and a real -estate-driven media service. An unforgettable character, her joyful enthusiasm was contagious. Aurora loved to celebrate life's big occasions. A superb chef, she cooked gourmet meals for family and friends. Strong, wise, loving, kind, funny--with an incredible zest for life--she touched the hearts of everyone she met. Aurora died peacefully at UCLA Ronald Reagan Medical Center from complications following open-heart surgery on August 18, 2015, the anniversary of her mother's passing in 2012. Her husband, Neil Pennella, has been her beloved companion, business partner and caretaker for over forty years. He never left her side and adored her with all his heart. She is also survived by her siblings Basil Papachristidis, Thaleia Christidis, Ophelia Rudin and Alex Papachristidis, their families including nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews--a large extended family with whom she was extremely close--and her three cherished dogs Rosie, Bloomie and Scamp. Memorial Services will be held in her honor in New York and Los Angeles at dates to be determined. In lieu of flowers, please donate to Animal Rescue Foundation, arfhamptons.org in NY; or Amanda Foundation, amandafoundation.org in CA. 1/3

SPIEGLER--Dr. Gerhard E. on August 24, 2015. Husband of Ethel and devoted father of Karin E., Eric J., and Mark D. Spiegler; grandfather of Sarah M. and Emma C. Gordon; and brother of Hanna Elledge. His Service will be held on Saturday, August 29, 2pm in the Auditorium of Rosemont Presbyterian Village, 404 Cheswick Pl., Rosemont, PA 19010. Contributions may be made to Salvation Army, American Heart Association, or US for UN Refugee Agency (www.unhcr.org). 1/3

MORRIS-FARBER--Dr. Nina (formerly Khinoy), 72, of Sunnyside, Queens, a teacher, writer, poet, and pianist, died Sunday, August 16, of pancreatic cancer at her home. She graduated from the Philadelphia High School for Girls and magna cum laude from Bryn Mawr College. She obtained her Ph.D. in German literature from NYU in 1979. Nina began her career teaching English at the Park School in Baltimore, then moved to New York and worked at Columbia Artist Management and as an editor at Continuum Books, where she once had the temerity to edit the prose of Alfred Kazin (who was not amused by her suggestions) and a piece by E.L. Doctorow (who responded warmly to her changes). Her intellectual curiosity, interest in human relationships, and a deep-rooted belief in fostering the talents of younger generations led her back to teaching. She began her 22-year tenure in the New York Public Schools in 1988 teaching in alternative schools and concluded her career in the English department at Forest Hills High School. Her poetry, critical essays, short fiction, and translations appeared in numerous publications beginning in the 1970s. Nina is survived by daughter, Gavriela Bogin-Farber, and son-in-law, Maximillian Bodoin, of Boston; brother, Paul Farber, and sister-in-law, Michaela Farber, of Philadelphia; nephew and niece, Noah and Caroline Farber; and loving cousins and dear friends. 1/3

GRIESA--Christine M.,passed away in comfort and peace the morning of August 26th. She was the beloved wife of U.S. District Judge Thomas P. Griesa. Also, a close and dear aunt of Christopher P. Meyer. Services to be announced. 1/3

GOLDIN--Dr. Joel. We deeply mourn the passing of Joel Goldin, a treasured founding member of the Board of Directors of Young Concert Artists since l964. Joel was a constantly involved, enthusiastic and vigorous part of YCA for over 50 years. He is already greatly missed by all of us. We send our love and sympathy to Ellen and his family. Susan Wadsworth, Director Michael N. Ambler, Chairman Young Concert Artists, Inc. 1/3

COSGROVE--William J.,of Upper Saddle River, NJ, passed away on Tuesday, August 25. He was 82. Bill spent thirty years at Citibank, where he retired as a Senior Banker, Senior Credit Officer in 1991. He then served as Executive Vice President at Citadel Group Representatives Inc. until 2004. In retirement, he served on several boards including Hudson City Bancorp, Inc., John Hancock Funds where he served as Lead Trustee, The Scholarship Fund for Inner-City Children, and the Arcola Country Club where he was a member for many years. Bill taught as an adjunct Professor at the Lubin Graduate School of Business of Pace University and as an instructor at the American Institute of Banking where he also served as President. He held a B.A. from Fordham College, an MBA from New York University and a J.D. from Fordham University School of Law. He was admitted to the New York Bar and the United States Supreme Court Bar. Bill also served as a medic in the United States Army. Bill was active in the Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Marilyn as well as his children Ellen and her husband James, Bill and his wife Marianne, and Sean and his wife Cathleen as well as his two granddaughters, Keira and Chelsea. Visitation will be held on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Van Emburgh-Sneider-Pernice Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave, Ramsey. A funeral mass will be celebrated at The Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River on Saturday, August 29 at 12:15pm. Interment will follow at Ascension Cemetery in Airmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Scholarship Fund for Inner City Children, Archdiocese of Newark, 171 Clifton Avenue, Newark, NJ 07104 or visit www.sficnj.org. Please send tributes, memories and condolences to vanemburghsneider.com. 1/3

WINKLEMAN--Irene, 90, passed away on August 25th. She was the daughter of Louis and Gussie Winkelman and twin sister to the deceased Ruth Wender. Irene is survived by her nephew Ted Wender (Vickie) and Jill Spitz (Richard), as well as four great nieces and nephews, Daniel, Austin, Jenny and Max. Irene was a life-long resident of New York City, and long-time member of Park Avenue Synagogue, who was active in Jewish life and a concerned philanthropist. She was a graduate of Mt. Holyoke College and during her career, was a spokesperson and writer in the oil industry. Irene loved to travel and surely will be missed by all. 1/3
KORNREICH--Susanne L. 2/18/29-8/27/08 If you knew Susie.... In our hearts today, always and forever. Kathy, Sam, Lisa and Andrew 1/3

BURROWS--Lewis. The Mount Sinai Health System is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Lewis Burrows, MD, Professor Emeritus, and former Professor of Surgery at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. Respected by his colleagues and beloved by his patients, Dr. Burrows performed The Mount Sinai Hospital's first successful kidney transplant in 1967, and was a seminal figure in the creation of Mount Sinai's transplant service. Among Dr. Burrows' many contributions to the medical field was his work in creating a noninvasive technique known as functional imaging, using radioactive tracers to measure kidney blood flow and function. He also hypothesized that perioperative blood transfusions would reduce immunity and lead to an increased recurrence in colorectal cancer--a theory that was later confirmed in several studies and expanded to other malignancies. The Mount Sinai community extends heartfelt condolences to his family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, Mount Sinai Health System; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

DOMANICO--Thomas. Hall of Fame medical advertising executive, dies at 74. Tom Domanico, a quintessential New Yorker whose Medical Advertising Hall of Fame career spanned the golden years of healthcare growth from the 1960s to the present day died peacefully on Monday at home in Greenwich, Connecticut. Born in Brooklyn, raised in Queens, schooled in art and advertising at the New York Community College and engaged for over 40 years in Manhattan advertising agencies, his career flourished when he joined the six person, New York branch of Vicom Associates, a San Francisco shop which he helped grow as Chairman/CEO over the next 27 years into Draft/FCB Healthcare, a 600-person division of the global advertising and marketing giant. Throughout his career, he was known as a highly creative, skilled executive who was a congenial but fierce competitor. His awardwinning work for such blue-chip advertisers as Pfizer, Merck and Roche stands among the best in the industry. He was trusted and respected by his colleagues and competitors alike, known for his quick-wit, his professionallevel jazz piano playing, and his many personal contributions to industry affairs. He is survived by his wife, Maritza and two grown daughters, Gina and Christa. Visitation will be from 2-5pm and 7 to 9pm at Village Chapels, 67-67 Eliot Avenue, Middle Village, Queens, NY. Services will be held at 10:45am Friday morning at Our Lady of Good Hope Catholic Church on Eliot Avenue at 71st Street. Interment will follow at St. John's Cemetery, Metropolitan Ave. and 80th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, from the Thomas Domanico page at villagechapels.com. 1/3

BRYSER--Ronald, better known to loved ones as Ronnie, passed away on the evening of August 24th, 2015 at the age of 70. Ronnie worked the door at 230 Fifth, where he became a mainstay with his gift of gab and impeccable fashion sense. Over the years, coworkers did not view Ronnie as just a colleague or friend, but rather a member of their family. He will be missed greatly. Services for Ronald Bryser will be held at 230 Fifth Rooftop Bar on Friday, August 28th at 12pm. 1/3

STROUD--Marion Boulton. The Board of Trustees, Artist Advisory Committee and Staff of the Fabric Workshop and Museum (FWM) deeply mourn the loss of our visionary founder, leader and long-time friend, Marion (Kippy) Boulton Stroud. A supporter of the arts and artists, curator, author and arts administrator, Kippy pioneered the practice of direct support to artists through her unique residency program at the Fabric Workshop and Museum, founded in Philadelphia in 1977. Her deep and abiding encouragement of artists to advance the boundaries of their practice by offering them opportunities to experiment in a vast range of media resulted in the FWM long record of groundbreaking residencies and exhibitions and the Museum's important collection of 20th and 21st century art. The unique works of art created at FWM are shown with regularity throughout the United States and the world in major museums and cultural venues. Kippy was deeply and passionately devoted to artists and the artistic community and provided her unstinting support. She believed in the power of experimentation and creativity and fostered access to arts for everyone. Kippy broke down barriers--within social structures and within the process of art making. We extend our deepest sympathy to Kippy's family of cousins-- Rosengartens, Sims and Strouds--and to her extended family of artists and arts professionals who have been so deeply inspired by her generous and giving spirit. Katherine Sokolnikoff, President of the Board Stewart Cades, First Vice President Ann Loftus, Second Vice President of the Board John Ravenal, Chairman of the Artist Advisory Committee 1/3

KNAPP--Philip B.,on August 25, 2015. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. 1/3

KLEIN--Janice Hall, 93, died on Monday, August 24th of 2015. She was the daughter of the late Marjorie and Maurice Quilligan of Brooklyn, and the granddaughter of the late Matthew J. Hall and Leila J. Hall of Mamaroneck, NY. Janice was born on January 1st, 1922, and her mother always said that Janice was her "New Year's baby." A graduate of Bay Ridge High School in Brooklyn and of Hunter College (New York City), for ten years she was Reserve Director of Bozell & Jacobs Inc. (now Bozell Worldwide). Throughout the 1940s and 1950s, she had numerous articles and poems published in American and Canadian magazines. In recent years she published "Loving Language: A Child Embraces Her Life Through Words" and "Gestalt Graphology," a collection of papers by her late second husband, Felix Klein. In 1962 her marriage to Ralph Bottenus resulted in the birth of her daughter, Valerie H. Q. Bottenus, who was the light of her life. Four years after Ralph's death she married Felix Klein, a world renowned Austrian-born gestalt graphologist and founder of the National Society for Graphology. Janice studied and worked with him in his business, Manhattan Handwriting Consultant, which she carried on after his death in 1994. She was an encouraging and patient teacher who brought out the very best in her students. She later sold the business to a former student, Evy Tishelman Karambelas, who operates it under the name Felix Klein School of Graphology. Janice was herself the light of many people's lives. Her ebullient and generous spirit, her keen mind and razor-sharp intellect, and her love for and appreciation of beauty (and her desire to share it with others) made Janice an unforgettable presence. She cultivated and maintained legions of close friendships, many of which had begun in her youth and others in her senior years. A devoted correspondent, she was known for her newsy and beautifully handwritten letters and envelopes decorated with colorful stickers. She loved traveling and was particularly smitten with Venice; Janice was made an honorary member of one of her favorite organizations, Save Venice, when she was nearly 90. Her absence will leave an enormous hole in many hearts, but most of all, in the heart of her daughter Valerie, who adored her precious Buddha infinitely and will love her eternally. In addition to Valerie, she is survived by three stepsons (Thomas, of Portland, OR; Howard, of York, PA; and Peter, of Clifton, NJ) and three nieces (Dianne Ginsburg, of River Falls, WI; Jeannie Seitz, of Collins, IA; and Marjorie Vickery, of Sun City, AZ). A private wake will be held at 10am on Saturday, August 29th, at Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home in Mamaroneck, NY, followed by interment at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Rye, NY. A memorial service for Janice will be held in Manhattan on Saturday, September 12th. 1/3

LURIE--Abraham, on August 25, 2015 at the age of 97. Beloved husband of the late Nettie, loving father of Susan (Don) and Debra (George). Cherished grandfather of Raphael and Anna. Devoted partner of Anita Gurian. A person of keen intellect, commitment to social change and social justice, Abe was one of the great innovators in social work. His health and mental health program models continue to be used globally. He embodied the best in practice, research, management and program innovation. His work will be carried on by the many people he taught, mentored and inspired and by his writings which number in the hundreds. 1/3
DOMANICO--Thomas. With extreme sadness, FCB Health mourns the passing of Tom Domanico, one of the foundational pillars of our agency. Our deepest sympathy to Martiza, Gina and Christa. FCB Health 1/3

ANGEVINE--Dolores Ellen Lataniotis, was born in Detroit, MI on October 14, 1932 and died August 25, 2015. Memorial Service Sunday, August 30, 2015 in Kaul Funeral Home, 28433 Jefferson Avenue, Saint Clair Shores, MI 48081. Visiting hours 10am to 12 noon; Memorial service, 12 noon to 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Wayne State University at 5475 Woodward, Detroit, MI 48202. Please leave a condolence message or share a memory at: www.KaulFuneralHome.com 1/3

The family encourages friends to support the New York Women in Communication Foundation. 1/3

McCORMACK--Sister Una, O.P. - The Board of Directors and staff of Catholic Guardian Services wish to express their deep sorrow at the passing of Sister Una McCormack, O.P., former and longtime executive director of Catholic Home Bureau, one of our predecessor agencies. Sister Una devoted her ministry to the care of children, women, and families in need. Countless people were touched by her compassionate service. She began as a social worker aiding orphaned, abandoned and abused children and went on to head two major foster care agencies: Cardinal McCloskey Children & Family Services and Catholic Home Bureau. In the mid-1980's, she oversaw development of Incarnation Children's Center, believed to be the nation's first residence for babies and young children with AIDS. She will be greatly missed. Rory Kelleher Chair of the Board Craig Longley Executive Director 1/3

WASHOR--Michael S.,on August 28, 2015. Beloved husband of Joan, devoted father of Cindy Kanusher, Marc, Steven and Douglas Washor. Cherished brother of Patricia Morelli, grandfather of eight. Graveside service Sunday, August 30, 11am, Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, New Jersey. 1/3

FEINSTEIN--Mitchell, devoted husband and best friend to wife Lori Hoberman, constant companion, coach and confidante to son Sammy, source of unflagging love and goodness to his parents, his sister and his mother-in-law, and the glue that held so much together with his characteristic wisdom and modesty. We are hurting for you and for the magnitude of the family's loss. Our condolences, fortitude, enduring friendship and love go out to you to help you through this most difficult period. Jerry & Ruthie Kestenbaum, Zach & Rina, TJ & Erica, Joe & Jesse. 1/3

KAPLAN--Lloyd Arthur, Publicist, writer and strategist, who counseled government, business and non-profit leaders over a career that spanned five decades, died on Thursday of complications from amyloidosis. He was 80, although many people will find that hard to believe. He worked diligently and effectively to the end of his life. He is survived by his wife of 25 years and business partner, Lisa Linden, his children Zachary and Polly Kaplan, daughter-in-law Daphne Klein, and grandchildren Tiger and Atticus Kaplan and Olivia Dylewski. Born to Sarah (Simon) and Moses Kaplan, Lloyd grew up in the Bronx. He received a BA from NYU (1955) and MFA from Yale University (1958). He served as Director of Public Affairs, New York City Planning Commission (1961-1975), Special Assistant to Mayor Abraham Beame and Chief of Staff to First Deputy Mayor John Zuccotti (1975-78), Deputy New York State Housing Commissioner (1978-81), Executive Vice President at Rubenstein Associates (1981-1996), and Chairman of LAK Public Relations (1996-2015). He loved classical music, theater, literature, art and antiques, Cape Cod, the North Fork, good wine, and life. Interment will be private. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, October 2nd, at Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83rd Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Citymeals-on-Wheels, or Alzheimers Association of New York City would be appreciated. 1/3

WILSON--Henry. Henry "Hal" Tyler Wilson, of New York City died suddenly on August 26, 2015 while vacationing with his family in Newport, Rhode Island. Hal was born on August 15, 1959 in Richmond, Virginia to Dr. Henry Harrison Wilson, Jr. and Therese Labrusse Wilson. He graduated from St. Christopher's School in Richmond, Virginia in 1977, the University of Virginia in 1981, and he received his Master of Business Administration from the University of Virginia Darden School of Business in 1986. He served as the Co- Managing Partner of Northwood Ventures, a leading venture capital and private equity firm where he worked for the last 24 years. Prior to this he worked in the investment banking division of Merrill Lynch, and the commercial lending division of the Irving Trust Company. Hal was a member of the Board of Directors of St. Bernard's School in New York City. He is survived by his parents; his loving wife, Alison Griscom Wilson; his three children, Henry Harrison Wilson III, Sophie Grace Wilson and Preston Griscom Wilson; his sisters, Anne Wilson Fafara (Richard) and Caroline Wilson McLean (Steve); his brother, Harrison Maireaux Wilson (Cackie); and nine nieces and nephews. His professional accomplishments not withstanding, Hal will be remembered for his integrity, cheerful demeanor, selflessness, love of life, and most of all, his passion for and commitment to his family. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, New York at 11:00am on Tuesday, September 1, 2015. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions in Hal's memory be made to any of the following schools: St. Bernard's School in New York City, St. Christopher's School in Richmond, Virginia, and The Nightingale- Bamford School in New York City. For more information or online condolences, please visit: www.oneillhayes.com 1/3

KRINGDON--Sylvia. With deep sadness, we mourn the loss of a wonderful wife, an inspirational Mother, a dedicated "Gibby" and a caring Aunt. She passed early the morning of August 25th. Her life will be celebrated the afternoon of October 3rd at Cedar Glen Lakes in Whiting, NJ. KANTOR--Howard M.D. Howard Lionel Kantor M.D., passed away peacefully on August 13, 2015 surrounded by three generations of his loving family. He was 90. He was an accomplished doctor, athlete, world traveler and lover of the arts. He is survived by Gloria, his devoted and loving wife of 68 years; by his three children, Lauren, Karen and Jonathan; and by seven grandchildren, Rachel, Sara, Julia, David, Danielle, Allison and Benjamin. Born in Kansas City, MO on October 17, 1924, he was one of three children. He grew up in Tulsa, Oklahoma, where he was an Eagle Scout and an exceptional student; he skipped two grades in school and graduated high school at the age of 15. He received a prestigious military scholarship to attend college at Rutgers University and then medical school at Columbia University in New York. After receiving his medical degree, he went on to become a pediatrician. He served in the military first as a private in the Army during the Second World War and then as a captain in the Air Force during the Korean War. Following his military service, Kantor entered private practice initially as a pediatrician in Syosset, NY, subsequently focusing solely on allergy-immunology in Huntington, NY. He served as the President of the Nassau Suffolk Allergy Society of New York in 1985-87. A talented practitioner, he had a loyal patient following that included multiple generations of families. With extraordinary dedication and enthusiasm, he continued his medical practice until the end of his life. He loved nature and the outdoors and spent many vacations throughout his life with his extended family hiking and skiing in the Rocky Mountains. He was an exceptional athlete and was especially accomplished in tennis. He and his wife, during their long and loving marriage, together traveled to 60 countries. He was a sculptor, a painter, an accomplished gardener, and loved to dance. We remember him for his commitment to his profession, his loving devotion to his family and friends, and his ability to live life to the fullest. 1/3

KEHOE--Elizabeth Foulk, died peacefully at her residence in Greenville, RI this past Tuesday. She was 92. Ms. Kehoe was born in Beijing, China and grew up in Manhasset, NY. She graduated from Vassar College in the class of 1944, and began a career in New York as a public relations staff writer for NBC, where she met and later married David Drew Zingg. In the 1960s she worked at Irvington House at NYU Medical Center and then at the Metropolitan Opera National Council. Throughout her life she was passionate about music, from cabaret to Broadway and the opera. After her retirement, she and her second husband, Richard G. Kehoe, moved to Lyme, and Chester, CT. She is survived by three sons and five grandchildren. 1/3

KAGEL--Stuart Todd, Sr.,71, of Brooklyn Heights, NY died unexpectedly Tuesday at his summer home on Skaneateles Lake. Born in Sebring, FL to Lewis and Elizabeth Kagel, Stuart graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall where he was a three-sport athlete. Following that, he attended UNC Chapel Hill, graduating in 1966. Stuart played UNC football and was a member of Alpha Tau Omega fraternity. After college, he joined the JC Penney Co in their executive training program, and subsequently became a co- owner of Kelly Slax, an apparel company. Stuart continued his entrepreneurial vision, starting several companies in the 1990's. In 2000 he co-founded 24 Seven Inc., a global strategic staffing and recruiting company, headquartered in New York City. Stuart was an avid outdoorsman as well as a sporting art and antiques collector. In 2014 he completed his unique collection of original art by every Federal Duck Stamp artist since its inception in 1934. He is survived by his partner of 27 years, Celeste Gudas; two sons, Stuart Todd (Alejandra) Kagel, Jr. of Fairfield, CT and James Albert Kagel of Brooklyn Heights; two daughters, Eleanor Elizabeth Kagel and Katherine Gudas Kagel, both of Brooklyn Heights; one brother, Colin Todd (Jane) Kagel of East Haddam, CT; one sister, Kathleen Hutchins of Princeton, NJ; three grandchildren, Emma Chamberlain Kagel, Gabriela Burnham Kagel, and Stuart Todd Kagel, III; and six nieces and nephews, Colin, Jr., and Joshua Kagel, and Bevin, Lewis (deceased), Elizabeth, and Colin Cherot. A memorial service will be held on September 9th at 11:00am at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights. Memorial donations may be made to Skaneateles Lake Association http://skaneate leslake.org/support-the-sla- through-amazon-smiles/ or Finger Lakes Land Trust http://fllt.org/donate/. 1/3

Devoted partner of Anita Gurian. A person of keen intellect, commitment to social change and social justice, Abe was one of the great innovators in social work. STROUD--Marion Boulton. The Board of Trustees, Artist Advisory Committee and Staff of the Fabric Workshop and Museum (FWM) deeply mourn the loss of our visionary founder, leader and long-time friend, Marion (Kippy) Boulton Stroud. A supporter of the arts and artists, curator, author and arts administrator, Kippy pioneered the practice of direct support to artists through her unique residency program at the Fabric Workshop and Museum, founded in Philadelphia in 1977. Her deep and abiding encouragement of artists to advance the boundaries of their practice by offering them opportunities to experiment in a vast range of media resulted in the FWM long record of groundbreaking residencies and exhibitions and the Museum's important collection of 20th and 21st century art. The unique works of art created at FWM are shown with regularity throughout the United States and the world in major museums and cultural venues. Kippy was deeply and passionately devoted to artists and the artistic community and provided her unstinting support. She believed in the power of experimentation and creativity and fostered access to arts for everyone. Kippy broke down barriers--within social structures and within the process of art making. We extend our deepest sympathy to Kippy's family of cousins-- Rosengartens, Sims and Strouds--and to her extended family of artists and arts professionals who have been so deeply inspired by her generous and giving spirit. Katherine Sokolnikoff, President of the Board Stewart Cades, First Vice President Ann Loftus, Second Vice President of the Board John Ravenal, Chairman of the Artist Advisory Committee 1/3

FOX--Gerald S.,of Plainview, NY. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, and friend, passed away peacefully on August 23, 2015. He was 88 years old. A man of many talents, passions, and great intellect, Jerry served in the U.S. Navy during the Second World War and later graduated from the City College of New York. He went on to earn a Master's Degree in Electrical Engineering from the Newark College of Engineering. As an employee of Grumman Aerospace Corporation, he worked on emergency back up systems for the acclaimed F-14 fighter jet. He was also a superb cook and won the New York State Cooking Championship of 1969. Jerry was a founding member of the Gustav Mahler Society of New York and served as its president from 1987 to 2009. His encyclopedic knowledge of, and passion for Mahler was widely respected. He lectured frequently at the annual Colorado Mahlerfest, prestigious universities, and other venues. He also wrote record and concert reviews for the American Record Guide. Without doubt, Jerry's greatest passion was for his family. He is survived by his beloved wife, Florence, to whom he was married for 62 years; three daughters, Rena Klosk of Franklin Lakes, NJ, Dr. Janis Fox of Brookline, MA, and Shari Tsivya Fox of Beit Shemesh, Israel; sister, Blossom Fox of NYC; and nine grandchildren. He was also deeply loved by his sons-in-law, Steven Klosk and Richard Corn. His family was the light of his long, rich, and wonderful life, and he considered himself the luckiest man in the world. 1/3

McCORMACK--Sister Una, O.P. - The Board of Directors and staff of Catholic Guardian Services wish to express their deep sorrow at the passing of Sister Una McCormack, O.P., former and longtime executive director of Catholic Home Bureau, one of our predecessor agencies. Sister Una devoted her ministry to the care of children, women, and families in need. Countless people were touched by her compassionate service. She began as a social worker aiding orphaned, abandoned and abused children and went on to head two major foster care agencies: Cardinal McCloskey Children & Family Services and Catholic Home Bureau. In the mid-1980's, she oversaw development of Incarnation Children's Center, believed to be the nation's first residence for babies and young children with AIDS. She will be greatly missed. STROUD--Marion Boulton. It is with great sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art has learned of the sudden passing of Marion (Kippy) Boulton Stroud. Kippy, of Philadelphia, Palm Beach, Florida, and Mount Desert Island in Maine, was a member of the International Council since 1995. Enormously energetic, creative, generous, and hardworking, she was a multifaceted talent who was beloved by her many friends, including artists and colleagues from around the world. Among her passions were The Fabric Workshop and Museum in Philadelphia, which she founded and where she remained artistic director until her death; the Acadia Summer Arts Program on Mount Desert Island; the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where she was a trustee; ArtTable; and the American Crafts Council. Kippy will be sorely missed. Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President Emerita Sharon Percy Rockefeller, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art 1/3

KAPLAN--Lloyd Arthur, Publicist, writer and strategist, who counseled government, business and non-profit leaders over a career that spanned five decades, died on Thursday of complications from amyloidosis. He was 80, although many people will find that hard to believe. He worked diligently and effectively to the end of his life. He is survived by his wife of 25 years and business partner, Lisa Linden, his children Zachary and Polly Kaplan, daughter-in-law Daphne Klein, and grandchildren Tiger and Atticus Kaplan and Olivia Dylewski. Born to Sarah (Simon) and Moses Kaplan, Lloyd grew up in the Bronx. He received a BA from NYU (1955) and MFA from Yale University (1958). He served as Director of Public Affairs, New York City Planning Commission (1961-1975), Special Assistant to Mayor Abraham Beame and Chief of Staff to First Deputy Mayor John Zuccotti (1975-78), Deputy New York State Housing Commissioner (1978-81), Executive Vice President at Rubenstein Associates (1981-1996), and Chairman of LAK Public Relations (1996-2015). He loved classical music, theater, literature, art and antiques, Cape Cod, the North Fork, good wine, and life. Interment will be private. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, October 2nd, at Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83rd Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Citymeals-on-Wheels, or Alzheimers Association of New York City would be appreciated. 1/3

JENNINGS--Richard. Richard Townsley Jennings, a remarkable and beloved man, died unexpectedly from complications due to a medical procedure on August 13. Born in New York City in 1933, he grew up in a close-knit, hard-working family. His mother, Cora and father, Alfred, were intelligent people of character who raised two sons, Richard and his older brother, Donald, and their niece, Virginia, raised as Richard's sister. By the time he was 15-years-old, he lost both his brother and father, and went on two years later, to put himself through college at Columbia University where he majored in music and business. He was the first in his family to attend college. A fine and gifted pianist, upon graduating from Columbia, Richard was a soldier in the Korean War where he entertained the troops. This ability to reduce the suffering of others, and to offer the music he so loved, brought him much joy. When he returned, he tried with his characteristic steady determination to become a professional jazz pianist and composer, and made one record called, "He Loves Me." Shortly thereafter, he met Regina, a young Peruvian beauty and fellow lover of music and literature. A person of unshakeable character, Richard began writing jingles to provide for his bride and their beloved son, Christopher, born shortly after they married in New York City. He went on to have a 40- year distinguished career as an advertising executive, where he implemented the "Bob, for Texaco, Hope" commercials, wrapping up at Saatchi & Saatchi. He was a first class Ad man with the temperament of a gentle and gifted introvert. When it came to being a parent, Richard was ahead of his time. In addition to providing for his family's basic needs, he thoroughly enjoyed cooking for them, reading to his kids, singing with them and helping them get ready for school. He spent countless hours teaching his son what it meant to be an honorable man, how to work diligently to achieve goals, how to care for others even and especially when great sacrifice was required, and loved spending time with him going to see every New York sports team, then briskly walking to Grand Central Station, sometimes whistling to a favorite Frank Sinatra tune on the way home. His daughter Pilar, born four years after Christopher, quickly developed a boundless love for him. They were the shy, bookish ones in the family, with a shared and passionate love of learning. Throughout her childhood, she watched him with awe as he finished The New York Times crossword puzzle in the time it took her to tie her shoes. He often complained, with his marvelously dry sense of humor, that the puzzle was too easy that day, then affectionately tap her on the head with the rolled up paper. When she learned the word "erudite," she realized that it was the perfect way to describe her father, a history buff, politico, and lover of the written word. It is with immense sadness, endless gratitude and love, that we say goodbye. Richard was a profoundly devoted father, grandfather to Carley, Samantha, and Mattie, a caring friend, a person of true character, intellect, culture, and consummate joyful foodie. A truly good and loving man. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to support students who are first in their family to attend college at Columbia University's School of General Studies. Mailing address: Office of the Dean, School of General Studies, 612 Lewisohn Hall MC4103, Columbia University, New York, NY 10027. 1/3

RICHARD--Harold Van Buren, aged 100, died peacefully in York Harbor, ME on August 27th, 2015. Raised in New York City, Van attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH and graduated from Princeton University, class of 1936. After serving in World War II as a Destroyer Escort Skipper in the Pacific, he lived in Brookville, NY and headed C.B. Richard & Co., retiring to Vero Beach, FL in 1983. A lifelong philanthropist, he was an avid golfer, bridge player and world traveler. A kind and thoughtful man with a very positive approach to life, his generosity and spirit will never be forgotten by his family and many friends. Predeceased by his son Peter and his wife of 65 years Jane, he is survived by his loving family; daughter Phyllis Fritts (Guy), daughter-in-law, Virginia Richard and five grandchildren; James Fritts (Diana), Garret Fritts, William Z. Richard (Erica), Travis Richard, Cecily Beach (Charles) and six great-grandchildren. A Celebration of his life will be held this fall in Vero Beach, FL. Visit www. lucaseatonfuneralhome.com 1/3

KNIGHT--Frances "Peg" F. (nee Floyd) 95, of Saddle River passed away on August 27, 2015. Born in Savannah, GA she has lived in Saddle River since 1961. A member of St. Bartholomew's Church in Ho Ho Kus, Peg was an active volunteer for The Red Cross, the Forum School of Waldwick and The Junior League of Bergen County. Peg was a true enthusiast and benefactor of Hackensack University Medical Center, The New York Philharmonic and The Metropolitan Opera. She had a passion for traveling and enjoyed every corner of the world. Beloved wife of the late William T. Knight, III (1997). Devoted mother of Rex Knight and his wife Nancy of Westchester, NY. Loving grandmother of Jennifer, Douglas and Kristen. The family will receive family and friends on Sunday from 3-7pm at Vander Plaat- Vermeulen Memorial Home, 530 High Mountain Road, Franklin Lakes. Funeral Services Monday 11am at St. Bartholomew's Church, Ho Ho Kus. Interment St. Bonaventure Cemetery, Savannah, GA. The family request donations in memory of Frances to the Heart and Vascular Hospital at the Hackensack University Medical Center Foundation, 361 Essex Street, Suite 301, Hackensack, NJ 07601. For further information please visit www.vpmemorial.com or call (201) 891-4770. 1/3
GINGOLD--Jeffrey I. 8/31/87. Remembered, Loved. Arl, Bon and the gang 1/3

KAPLAN--Lloyd. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the untimely death of our member, Lloyd Kaplan. Lloyd was deeply committed to his community and will be sorely missed.
