GLASER--Gerry "The Glaze," died peacefully at his home in New York City on August 24th surrounded by his loving family. He is survived by his wife, Mary Cagney, son Matthew Glaser, daughter Claudia Glaser-Mussen, son-in-law Jim, step-sons Frank Vitiello and Jamie Vitiello, daugh- ters-in-law Lara and Juli, grandchildren Jacob, Mikayla, Kai, Francesca, and Fiona and his brother Milton. There will be a memorial celebration on Sunday, November 1, 2015. Please contact the family for details. 1/3
WILLIAMS--Susan. Intrepid, innovative, multi-talented. Artist, loving mother, grandmother and friend. AIR pioneer. Susan seized life. We mourn her. The Founding Members of AIR Gallery. 1/3

HAKIM--Michael, son of Albert and Luna, husband of Claire, father of Lissa, Jackie, and Ari, grandfather of Bodhi, Kai, Hannah, Lillie, Matthew, Brooke, and Lindsay. Brother of Fred (deceased), and Ethel H. Matarasso. Funeral 1pm today at 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. Shiva at home Sunday 5-9pm, Monday- Thursday 12-9pm. 1/3

KAPLAN--Lloyd, made us think and made us laugh - made us smile at his sense of wonder and made our eyes roll at his sense of humor. He amazed us with his intellect and amused us with his wackiness. He raised our spirits and raised the bar for everything we did. He had a noble mind and a noble heart and now our hearts are broken. "Good night sweet prince. And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest." Steve Alschuler and Hannah Arnold 1/3

LEVINE--Steven, of Randall Manor, Staten Island, on August 28th. Beloved husband of Carmen (Margie). Devoted father of Robert and the late Melissa. Cherished grandfather of Makenzie and Makalya. Loving brother of Marilyn Sass. Mr. Levine was a former Vice President at Moody's Investors and a Deputy Budget Director for the New York City Mayor's Office. Funeral Service from Menorah Chapels Inc, 2145 Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, Wednesday 9:30am. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady Queen of Peace Church, 10:30am. Visiting hours Tuesday evening 7pm to 9:30pm. 1/3

KAPLAN--Lloyd Arthur, Publicist, writer and strategist, who counseled government, business and non-profit leaders over a career that spanned five decades, died on Thursday of complications from amyloidosis. He was 80, although many people will find that hard to believe. He worked diligently and effectively to the end of his life. He is survived by his wife of 25 years and business partner, Lisa Linden, his children Zachary and Polly Kaplan, daughter-in-law Daphne Klein, and grandchildren Tiger and Atticus Kaplan and Olivia Dylewski. Born to Sarah (Simon) and Moses Kaplan, Lloyd grew up in the Bronx. He received a BA from NYU (1955) and MFA from Yale University (1958). He served as Director of Public Affairs, New York City Planning Commission (1961-1975), Special Assistant to Mayor Abraham Beame and Chief of Staff to First Deputy Mayor John Zuccotti (1975-78), Deputy New York State Housing Commissioner (1978-81), Executive Vice President at Rubenstein Associates (1981-1996), and Chairman of LAK Public Relations (1996-2015). He loved classical music, theater, literature, art and antiques, Cape Cod, the North Fork, good wine, and life. Interment will be private. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, October 2nd, at Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 7 West 83rd Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Citymeals-on-Wheels, or Alzheimers Association of New York City would be appreciated. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Bessie, on August 29th. We mourn the loss of Bessie Friedman, wife of the late Bernard. Beloved mother of Irma (Stephen) and Mark (the late Karen). Devoted grandmother of Rona, Jocelyn (Alan), Bradley and Abigail. Loving great-grandma of Miles. We will miss her intelligence and her wit, and cherish her love of family. 1/3

KEHOE--Elizabeth Foulk, died peacefully at her residence in Greenville, RI this past Tuesday. She was 92. Ms. Kehoe was born in Beijing, China and grew up in Manhasset, NY. She graduated from Vassar College in the class of 1944, and began a career in New York as a public relations staff writer for NBC, where she met and later married David Drew Zingg. In the 1960s she worked at Irvington House at NYU Medical Center and then at the Metropolitan Opera National Council. Throughout her life she was passionate about music, from cabaret to Broadway and the opera. After her retirement, she and her second husband, Richard G. Kehoe, moved to Lyme, and Chester, CT. She is survived by three sons and five grandchildren. 1/3

FRUCHTMAN--Paula, (daughter of Sylvia and Edward Ehrlich) passed away on August 29, 2015. She was the loving wife of Arthur Fruchtman, who predeceased her. She was the dedicated mother of Beth Rosenthal (Jess), William Fruchtman (Bebe), Jason Fruchtman (Ellen). Doting grandmother to Jacob, Jonah, Carly, Julia and Aaron. Funeral services will be held 11:30am Monday, August 31, 2015 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ with interment to follow at the Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing, NY. Shiva will be observed at 55 Waterford Rd. in Montville, NJ. Shiva will also be observed from Tuesday until Saturday night at 14 Phipps Lane Plainview, NY 11803. Donations can be made to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

FRANKEL--Miriam D.,"Mimi" died peacefully in her sleep on August 28, 2015 in her home in Valhalla, NY. Born on July 7, 1921 in Brooklyn, NY to Max and Ann Drexler, Mimi received a BA from Hunter College and an MA from Queens College, both in education. She worked first as an occupational therapist, and then for the majority of her career as an educator-- as an elementary school teacher and ultimately as a nursery school director, at the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Queens, NY. She married Arnold J. Frankel of Bronx, NY, founder of Aceto Corporation. Arnold and Mimi remained happily married for over 50 years until his death in 1998. With a passion for Jewish culture and tradition, Mimi worked as a docent at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, and along with her husband, donated generously to both Jewish and other charitable organizations. Her family remembers her amazing generosity, love, and sharp and witty intellect. Her enthusiasm for life was felt by all who knew her. As the "matriarch" of the Frankel family, she was a warm and loving mother, wife, sister, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt, mother-in-law and friend. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Alan and Jodi Frankel, and predeceased by her daughters, Hinda Squires Levy and Janet Frankel Staub. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Max Frankel, Peter Squires, Leon Frankel, Eli Staub, Rena Staub, Jessica Frankel, Amanda Squires, and Adam Frankel, as well as her great- grandchildren, Priya and Ezra Kasargod-Staub and Henry Frankel. www.Ballard-Durand.com 1/3

PETRILLO--Ted, of Fishkill, NY; Nokomis, FL; Fremont, NY and formerly Mt. Vernon, Rye Brook, and Manhattan, died August 30, 2015. He was Founder and Principal of Westage Companies Development Corporation. Survivors include his wife, Marilynn H. Petrillo; son, Ted Petrillo; daughters, Karen Quito, Debra Mortirano, and Dina Herz; stepchildren, Melissa McCoy and Craig McCoy; 13 grandchildren; three great- grandchildren; and sister, Eileen Petrillo. Visitation is 4- 8pm on Wednesday, September 2 at the McHoul Funeral Home of Fishkill, Inc., Fishkill, NY. A Mass will be offered at 10am, Thursday, September 3 at St. Mary's Church, Fishkill, NY, with interment at Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be directed to continue Ted's life work of caring and doing for others and the community through the Ted Petrillo Community Fund, c/o Community Foundation of Orange & Sullivan, online at: cfosny.org. For directions, tributes, and contributions, please visit: mchoulfuneralhome.com. 1/3

PARADISE--Stephen J.,82, of East Orleans, Massachusetts, passed away on August 25, 2015, following a long battle with cancer. His parents were Joseph and Lillian Liss Paradise of Rye, New York. He was a graduate of Lafayette College and New York University Law School. He was assistant counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission and was involved in its special study of the securities markets in 1964. He was counsel to the U.S. Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs and staff director and general counsel of the U.S. Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources between 1967 and 1980. While there, he helped pass legislation involving migrant workers, OSHA, and the federal urban transit program. He joined the New York Stock Exchange in 1980 and served as senior vice president, Congressional and regulatory relations, from 1988 until his retirement in 1996. Mr. Paradise is survived by his wife, Bobbie, his son David and his wife, Rachel Graham, his son John, his daughter, Susan, his grandchildren Kyra, Dylan, Julia, and Jackson, and his sister Judith Moskowitz. He is predeceased by his sister Gail Paradise Kelly. For online condolences, please visit: www.nickersonfunerals.com 1/3

RIZOULIS--Katherine Vogian. June 4, 1930 - August 29, 2015. Katherine Rizoulis passed away on August 29, 2015, in New York. She joins her deceased and loving husband Menelaos (Manny). Katherine was blessed with a loving family: her daughters Joanna and Anne along with their husbands Seth and Ferdinand; wonderful grandchildren, Griffen, Sophia, Eve and Katherine; and her devoted siblings Peter and Mary Ann, in addition to her brother-in -law Edmund. Katherine grew up in Springfield, MA, attended Mount Holyoke College and earned her master's degree in education from Columbia University. She pursued doctorate studies at Columbia and was committed to education and cultural enrichment throughout her life. Katherine and her husband Manny were happily married for nearly 50 years and raised their family in New York. She will be missed by many and leaves a beautiful lasting legacy of devotion to family and friends. 1/3

SEXTON--Rex, on August 31, 2015 of Philadelphia, PA. Husband of Rochelle Cohen. Brother of Sharon (Jack) Owen and Robert Scott Sexton. Brother-in-law of Marion Cohen. Rex was an acclaimed writer and artist. Services will be held in Cherry Hill, NJ. Platt Memorial Chapels, Cherry Hill, NJ. 1/3

SACKS--Oliver, M.D. The Board and staff of The New York Botanical Garden regret the death of Dr. Oliver Sacks. We have lost not only a great neurologist and humanitarian, but also a consummate botanist and active Board Member. Oliver was mentored as a young man by Prof. Dr. Marie Stopes, the leading British botanist, and therein began his long interest in cycads and ferns. Oliver made regular Wednesday trips to the Garden. It was not unusual to see his large, distinctive car already in the parking lot early on those days. His love of plants resulted in The Island of the Colorblind and Oaxaca Journal. Oliver was one of the most active members of the American Fern Society. His appreciation of the plant world is demonstrated in Awakenings, in which he describes bringing his patients to the Garden not just as a therapeutic exercise but also as an experience in serenity and awareness. In 2011 Oliver was awarded the Gold Medal, the Garden's highest honor, which is presented to individuals who have made significant contributions to the life of the Garden and the advancement of plant research and conservation. We extend our condolences to Oliver's longtime colleague Kate Edgar and his partner Billy Hayes. Maureen K. Chilton, Chairman Gregory Long, CEO and The William C. Steere Sr., President Dennis Wm. Stevenson, Ph.D., Vice President for Botanical Research and Cullman Curator 1/3

HALPERIN--Richard, 70, Noted International tax attorney and accomplished photographer died Sunday after a courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his loving wife, Jane, his stepdaughter, Sarah Herman, and his brother, Robert. Services will be at 11:30am Wednesday, September 2nd at Frank E. Campbell. 1/3

ARISOHN--Irma, age 91, died peacefully at home in Boca Raton on August 30, 2015. Beloved mother of Mark and Brad, and mother-in-law of Diane and Bobbi; adored grandmother of Josh, Mike, Jessy, and Matt; cherished great-grandmother of Ellie, Noah, and Jazzy; devoted aunt of David and Ray; dearest sister of Shirley and treasured wife of Harvey. Intense love of family was the guidepost of her life. She expressed her creativity and love of beauty through painting, needle work, papier etoile, and beading. Her involvement in the Center for Group Counseling as a facilitator, fund raiser and psychodramatist brought her great satisfaction and joy. She will be missed by all. Donations to Hospice by the Sea, West Palm Beach, FL. 1/3

POUCHIE--Steven Vibert, passed away on Friday, August 28, 2015. Visitation will be held at Sisto Funeral Home, 3489 East Tremont Ave, Bronx, NY 10465 on Thursday, September 3, 2105 from 2-9pm (718-892-2102). A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Friday, September 4, 2015 at Saint Frances de Chantal Church at 10am. Interment will follow at Saint Raymond's Cemetery. A Latin Jazz musician, arranger, band leader, producer and educator, Steve played the vibraphone using two mallets. His style was compared to Cal Tjader and Tito Puente. One reviewer said Steve "laid the foundation for the new style of vibes playing and performance" and another called him "an extremely intellectual rhythmist" and likened his sound design to "water colour-like imagery." Steve and his wife, Naomi, also created and hosted the popular cable show Latin Jazz Alive and Kickin'. Born to Puerto Rican parents and raised in New York City, Steve graduated from Stuyvesant High School and New York's Bard College. In addition to live performances, Steve collaborated with a formidable array of artists both in live performances and on three critically-acclaimed albums: "North by Northeast," "El Puente" and "Vibe Mania." "North by Northeast" was recently nominated for a Grammy. For his work as a music and technology educator Steve was awarded the distinguished New York Liberty Medal. In presenting Steve with the medal the honorable Michael Bloomberg said, "These men and women have made important contributions to their community through time, work, talent and wisdom." Steve is survived by beloved family, including wife, Naomi; mother Dolores; siblings Carolyn (Michael) Graham and Michael (Lisa) Pouchie; and by many adored nieces and nephews. 1/3

McCORMACK--Sr. Una, OP, of Sparkill, NY, died August 26. Teacher, administrator, Sister and friend to many. Executive Director Catholic Home Bureau (1972-2000) and Director, Dept. of Child Care Catholic Charities (1990-2002). Donations: Dominican Convent, Sr. Mary Murray, President, 175 Route 340, Sparkill, NY 10976. 1/3

WILSON--Henry "Hal". St. Bernard's School mourns the loss of Hal Wilson, parent, trustee, and friend. A Virginia gentleman with a twinkle in his eye, he left us much too soon. We shall miss him terribly. St. Bernard's School 1/3

LANE--Peter, of Rye, NY, passed away on August 29, 2015. Peter practiced law in New York for 50 years and served as Rye City Court Judge. Friends and family will honor his memory at the Community Synagogue of Rye. The service is scheduled for 9:30am on Wednesday, September 2, 2015. 1/3

INDELMAN--Robert "Bob," Samalman passed away on July 20, 2015 at New York Presbyterian Hospital - Queens. He was 72. A Memorial Service was conducted on July 23, 2015 at Parkside Memorial Chapels in Forest Hills, NY. Burial followed at Old Montefiore Cemetery in Queens, NY. A Memorial Grave Stone is also planned in his honor at the Gan Shmuel Kibbutz in Israel. Bob was born on June 30, 1943, In Manhattan. He graduated Forest Hills High School and George Washington University. He received Master's Degrees in the Arts from Rutgers University and in Philosophy from George Washington University. During the course of his career, he engaged in government affairs and economic consulting as well as teaching at institutions of higher learning in the New York and Washington, DC areas. Bob was an avid runner and was proud of completing the New York City Marathon. Bob's birth parents, Alexander Samalman, and Bella Messer (a/k/a Massar) Samalman, died when Bob was a child. Following their deaths, Bob was adopted by Bernard and Rochelle Indelman. They predeceased Bob, as did his birth siblings Herbert and Bella. Bob is survived by a number of relatives and good friends. Many memories were shared at his Memorial Service. Bob will be missed by all who knew and loved him. 1/3

He is survived by his sister, Joan Scott, his sons Paul and Stephen and daughters Kathleen Kammerman, Christine Denton, Elizabeth Worsham, eight grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. His wife of 60 years passed away in 2006. Calling hours are 4-8pm on Thursday, September 3 at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Resurrection Church, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY at 10am Friday, September 4 followed by interment in Greenwood Union Cemetery, also in Rye. 1/3

POUCHIE--Steven Vibert, passed away on Friday, August 28, 2015. Visitation will be held at Sisto Funeral Home, 3489 East Tremont Ave, Bronx, NY 10465 on Thursday, September 3, 2105 from 2-9pm (718-892-2102). A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Friday, September 4, 2015 at Saint Frances de Chantal Church at 10am. Interment will follow at Saint Raymond's Cemetery. A Latin Jazz musician, arranger, band leader, producer and educator, Steve played the vibraphone using two mallets. His style was compared to Cal Tjader and Tito Puente. One reviewer said Steve "laid the foundation for the new style of vibes playing and performance" and another called him "an extremely intellectual rhythmist" and likened his sound design to "water colour-like imagery." Steve and his wife, Naomi, also created and hosted the popular cable show Latin Jazz Alive and Kickin'. Born to Puerto Rican parents and raised in New York City, Steve graduated from Stuyvesant High School and New York's Bard College. In addition to live performances, Steve collaborated with a formidable array of artists both in live performances and on three critically-acclaimed albums: "North by Northeast," "El Puente" and "Vibe Mania." "North by Northeast" was recently nominated for a Grammy. For his work as a music and technology educator Steve was awarded the distinguished New York Liberty Medal. In presenting Steve with the medal the honorable Michael Bloomberg said, "These men and women have made important contributions to their community through time, work, talent and wisdom." Steve is survived by beloved family, including wife, Naomi; mother Dolores; siblings Carolyn (Michael) Graham and Michael (Lisa) Pouchie; and by many adored nieces and nephews. 1/3

JACOBOWITZ--Walter E.,M.D., of Morristown, NJ. Beloved husband of Suzanne. Devoted father of Glenn Jacobowitz, Dana Yormark and Karen Mayerson. Dear brother of Elaine Rubenstein and five grandchildren. Service Sunday in Riverside Cemetery at 10:30am. For information "Eden Memorial Chapels" (201) 947-Eden. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Abraham, on September 3 in Boca Raton, FL. He was the beloved husband of the late Adele Goldstein, loving father of his children Marilyn and Michael Fedak, Robert and Frances and devoted long-time companion of Alma Kamino. He will be missed by all his family and friends. There will be a private family service on Sunday, September 6th. 1/3

EDELHERTZ--Millicent Ray, 87, of NYC, died on September 2nd. Sister of the late Estelle Fishman and the late Herbert Edelhertz. Loving aunt of Theodore Fishman, Joan Fishman, Jean Edelhertz, and Paul Edelhertz. Great-aunt to Jeremy, Michael, Emma, Benjamin, Cabe, Zachary and great-great-aunt to Samuel. Services Sunday, 1pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

SIMON--Arthur, was a brilliant scholar (University of Alabama, Wharton School, Oxford), and savvy businessman (president of Eagle Button Co.) but first and foremost a devoted family man and passionate fan of the Alabama Crimson Tide college football team. Arthur J. Simon was born in Brooklyn on February 12, 1927. After serving in the Army during World War II, he wed Bobby Colby, the beginning of a 60-year marriage. He and Bobby traveled the world: China, Russia, Antarctica, archeological digs in Africa among the highlights. But autumn Saturdays meant trips to Tuscaloosa, Alabama, for football games. He was also a medalist in table tennis at the Senior Olympics and Maccabee Games, and a longtime little league baseball and softball manager. Mr. Simon died peacefully on September 1 in Hackensack, NJ. He is survived by wife Bobby, his son Casey Simon and his wife JoAnn and son Ryan, and daughter Meri Simon and her husband, Michael Mayer. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to the University of Alabama, c/o Amy Baker-Parton, director of development, College of Human Environmental Sciences, Box 870158, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487. Attention: Arthur and Barbara Simon scholarship fund. 1/3

CULHANE--Thomas J.,on September 2, 2015. Devoted husband and father. USMC Veteran, NYPD Detective, Attorney, New York State Assemblyman, Commissioner of New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission and Commissioner of State Commission of Investigation. Beloved husband of Alice Akins Culhane. Loving father of Stephen (Gail) Culhane, Christine Lichte (Arthur), Matthew Culhane (Laurie), Thomas, the late John, Terrence Culhane (Eileen), Beth Ann Robins, Barbara Mullaney (Patrick), Karen Marini. Stepfather to Debbie Villagio. Grandfather of 26 and great-grandfather of 13. Cherished brother of Daniel Culhane. Funeral Mass: Saturday September 5, 2015, 9:30am at St. Thomas More Church, Breezy Point, NY. Interment: Gate of Heaven Cemetery Valhalla, NY. 1/3

GOLDSON--Henry, 90, died in Manchester, NJ. A graduate of NYU, he spent 35 years as a professional engineer and retired in 1987 in Placentia, CA. He moved to New Jersey in 1991. A veteran of WWII he was awarded the Bronze Star, two Battle Stars and a Combat Infantry Badge. He is survived by his wife Phyllis, son David, daughter Elizabeth and four grandchildren. Services are Friday, September 4, 10am at Oliverie Funeral Home, Manchester, NJ. 1/3

VANDERSTEEL--William, of Alpine, NJ, passed away on August 18, 2015 at 96 years of age. He is survived by his five children: Stod, Marion, Bill, Ann and Tina. A loving description of his life can be found at www.legacy.com. A celebration of his life is planned for October 3rd in Alpine and another in Tequesta, Florida, November 15th. 1/3
REITMAN-WEINSTEIN--Eva. Born 8/15/13 - Died 9/4/89. I think of you every day and will never stop missing you. With love and kisses - Erica 1/3

TANCER--Norma, (nee Gorschen) of Teaneck, NJ. Born September 29, 1917 - Died September 2, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Dr. M. Leon Tancer, adored mother of Jo Ann and Steven, treasured mother-in-law of Nancy Tancer and Martin Hennessey, cherished grandmother of Jason, Matthew and Lauren. Funeral services will be held Friday, September 4, 2015 at 10:00am at Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ 07601. The shiva period will be observed at the Tancer residence, 837 East Lawn Drive, Teaneck, NJ Friday from 2:00pm through Sunday 9:00pm. In lieu of flowers, should friends desire the family requests donations to the Alzheimer's Association. Website: www.alz.org/donate.asp. 1/3

O'CONNOR--Garrett, MD.,(Annacurragh, Aughrim, Co. Wicklow and Beverly Hills, California) on September 1st 2015 peacefully at home in Ireland. Beloved husband of Fionnula Flanagan and loving father of Matthew and Turlough O'Connor and Mary Lee-Woolf. Deeply mourned by the Buckley, O'Connor, Flanagan, Kavanagh and Corcoran families, devoted daughters-in-law Julie O'Connor and Mary Cleary; grandchildren, Kalina and her partner Ryan, Tom, Finnian, Serena, Clayton, Aidan, Olivia; great grandchildren Mason and Cove, friends and colleagues. Funeral Service, Saturday, September 5th, 3.30pm Mount Jerome, Dublin. California Memorial at a later date. Donations if desired to the Rise Foundation, www.therisefoundation.ie. 1/3

POMEROY--Aloyise (Haskins) 95, a longtime resident of Block Island, RI who wintered in Newport, died July 26, 2015 in the John Clarke Nursing Home in Middletown after a period of failing health. She was the wife of the late Lawrence Pomeroy, a Block Island Times Bayberry Award recipient and public activist on utility and environmental issues. Mrs. Pomeroy was a former member of the board of trustees and a volunteer at Block Island's Island Free Library, the school board and the vestry of St. Anne's by the Sea Episcopal Church. She was a keen birdwatcher and was involved in animal rescue both on Block Island and in Newport. A native of Virginia, Mrs. Pomeroy attended St. Margaret's School of Tappahannock, VA. Mrs. Pomeroy served for many years as assistant to the headmistress of The Brearley School in Manhattan. She is survived by stepsons Lawrence K. Pomeroy (Helen M. Pomeroy) of Manhattan and Block Island; and Joseph B. Pomeroy (companion Mildred Kazeniac) of Westford, MA., as well as numerous cousins in Richmond, VA. Mrs. Pomeroy was the doting step-grandmother of Patrick H. Pomeroy, Peter C. Pomeroy and Lawrence B. Pomeroy, the children of Lawrence K. Pomeroy; and great-grandchildren Pier and Piper Pomeroy, the children of Peter C. Pomeroy. She is also survived by a niece, Nancy Albers of Winston-Salem, NC; nephew Ronald Stephen Haskins of Kernersville, NC; and grand-nephew Matthew Green of Winston-Salem, NC. 1/3

HOPKINS--Carol. Born Ellen Carol Stutz in Chicago, Illinois on December 24, 1927. Died peacefully at her home in Evanston, Illinois on August 28, 2015. Beloved mother of James Dennis Hopkins, Jr. (Laura), Ellen Hopkins Suarez (Mario), Ann Rice (Dale), Paul Hopkins, Matthew Hopkins (Colleen), Martha Sheridan (Leo), and Elizabeth Heltzer (Michael). Treasured grandmother of Katherine Tierney Lester (Jeff), Rebecca Tierney Koepsel (Chris), Hannah Tierney; Jack, Daniel, James and Claire Sheridan; Henry, Rose, George and Estelle Heltzer. Proud great-grandmother of Bridget and Maeve Lester; Emmett and Blythe Koepsel. While raising her children she obtained a Masters Degree in Special Education and taught for twenty three years before retiring as Chair of the OShaughnessy Learning Development Program at Loyola Academy in Wilmette, Illinois. She was committed to learning and family. We are grateful for her faith and her love, and for making us better people. Special thanks to North Shore University Health System Hospice, Joy Cachola, and Angela Manraqui for their compassion and loving care. 1/3

Charles M. Benbrook, formerly the chief scientist at the Organic Center, left the nonprofit organization in 2012 after concluding that he could get more traction for his research, which has questioned G.M.O. crop safety, by joining a university.

Kevin Folta, chairman of the horticultural sciences department at the University of Florida, began to correspond regularly with executives at Monsanto in early 2013. He soon teamed up with the company and other industry representatives to defend their genetically engineered crop technologies as they lobbied Congress and other government authorities. Dr. Folta has said he worked as an independent scientist. But Monsanto helped cover his costs.
Bruce M. Chassy, now a professor emeritus at the University of Illinois, is another academic who was recruited to help out with GMO Answers.

AMGOTT--Julia. May 14, 1920, died in Viera, FL, September 3, 2015. She is survived by her beloved husband of 69 years, Gilbert, and by her sons Gordon (Vicki) and Theodore (Colleen). Services 11am, Sunday, Florida Memorial Gardens. 1/3

GILBERT--Milton. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of RiverSpring Health and the Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed former Chairperson and trustee emeritus, Milton Gilbert. For over 20 years Milton led the Hebrew Home, transitioning it from a highly regarded nursing home into a nationally acclaimed senior care organization. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Elma, Shelley, Fred and the entire Gilbert and Fehrenbach families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Jeffrey Maurer, Chairman, Board of Trustees Daniel Reingold, President and CEO RiverSpring Health 1/3

GILBERT--Milton A. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Milton A. Gilbert. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Elma, and their family. Robert D. Lang, President Harvey Karofsky, Secretary 1/3

WEISFELD--Florence Goodman, MSW, died on September 3 after a long illness. She was born in Brooklyn and graduated at age 20 from Hunter College. She attended graduate school at Washington University in St. Louis, where she met her cherished husband Frank. Faigy enjoyed a long, diverse and rewarding career in social work. She was a tireless worker for peace and justice; loved humanity, life, travel. animals of every type, etymology, Jewish history and all things Yiddish. She had friends of many ages and from many countries. She is survived by her loving family and friends. Please do good deeds in her memory. 1/3

GOLDSON--Henry, 90, died in Manchester, NJ. A graduate of NYU, he spent 35 years as a professional engineer and retired in 1987 in Placentia, CA. He moved to New Jersey in 1991. A veteran of WWII he was awarded the Bronze Star, two Battle Stars and a Combat Infantry Badge. He is survived by his wife Phyllis, son David, daughter Elizabeth and four grandchildren. Services are Friday, September 4, 10am at Oliverie Funeral Home, Manchester, NJ. 1/3

BURMAN--Martin, 69, of Manhattan and Rockaway, died suddenly following a stroke. Musician, song writer, teacher, beloved brother to Ruth, brother-in-law to Chris, Michael and Sally, uncle to Elena, Nick, Ben, Casey, Ian and Alden, step-father to Jason, husband to Linda, and friend to many. He will be missed. 1/3
LEINKRAM--Norma Carlin. September 19, 1916 - August 25, 2015, wife of the late Norman Leinkram. Mother of Hara Braun (Kenneth) and Gail Folloder (Mark). The best mother. Loved by all. 1/3

HOPKINS--Carol. Born Ellen Carol Stutz in Chicago, Illinois on December 24, 1927. Died peacefully at her home in Evanston, Illinois on August 28, 2015. Beloved mother of James Dennis Hopkins, Jr. (Laura), Ellen Hopkins Suarez (Mario), Ann Rice (Dale), Paul Hopkins, Matthew Hopkins (Colleen), Martha Sheridan (Leo), and Elizabeth Heltzer (Michael). Treasured grandmother of Katherine Tierney Lester (Jeff), Rebecca Tierney Koepsel (Chris), Hannah Tierney; Jack, Daniel, James and Claire Sheridan; Henry, Rose, George and Estelle Heltzer. Proud great-grandmother of Bridget and Maeve Lester; Emmett and Blythe Koepsel. While raising her children she obtained a Masters Degree in Special Education and taught for twenty three years before retiring as Chair of the OShaughnessy Learning Development Program at Loyola Academy in Wilmette, Illinois. She was committed to learning and family. We are grateful for her faith and her love, and for making us better people. Special thanks to North Shore University Health System Hospice, Joy Cachola, and Angela Manraqui for their compassion and loving care. 1/3

GOLDSTEIN--Abraham, on September 3 in Boca Raton, FL. He was the beloved husband of the late Adele Goldstein, loving father of his children Marilyn and Michael Fedak, Robert and Frances and devoted long-time companion of Alma Kamino. He will be missed by all his family and friends. There will be a private family service on Sunday, September 6th. 1/3

MIXTER--David M. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of David M. Mixter, a Life Trustee, who made extraordinary service contributions to the Hospital for more than half a century. He joined our Board of Trustees in 1960, and in 1995, was honored with the Distinguished Trustee Award. Over the years, Mr. Mixter along with his late wife Stephanie supported the Campaign for Research at HSS and played a critical role in advancing the Hospital's mission to improve the lives of patients affected by musculoskeletal disease and injury. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Carol Baldwin and his entire family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon- in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3
CAVIANO--Michael L. Happy Birthday Darling. Miss you so much. Life with you was magical. Love, Dolores 1/3

NEWMAN--Evelyn E. Our beloved "Oma," died at age 95 on September 1 in St. Louis. The "Queen of St. Louis Fundraising" left her mark on the city she loved by founding a wide range of civic institutions: the Greater St. Louis Book Fair, ScholarShop, the Gypsy Caravan, Little Shop Around the Corner, Wishing Well, Forest Park Forever, First Street Forum, the Newman Money Museum at Washington University, the Butterfly House at Faust Park, and many others. Leaving college early to marry, she always said she attended "the University of Eric Newman" (later receiving an honorary doctorate from University of Missouri-St. Louis). Eric and Evelyn, our "Opa and Oma," made an inspiring couple through 75 years of pun-filled marriage and adventure, traveling to almost 200 countries and gathering together generations of family in St. Louis, their Mississippi River bluff house in Alton (Illinois), Pango Pango (Jamaica), and Martha's Vineyard. Recently, she started "The Savvy Sage," a travel blog for the over-80 set. Oma is survived by Opa, daughter Linda Schapiro, son Andy Newman (Peggy), brother Julian Edison (Hope), her five grandchildren, Josh (Geula), Dan (Amber), Abigail (Jason), Tony (Meredith), and Kate (David), and 10 great-grandchildren, all of whom will always cherish her boundless energy, creativity, and curiosity. She requested no mourning or service and that people who wish to celebrate her life should donate to their favorite local charities. 1/3
GORMAN--Cliff. Oct. 13, 1936 - Sept. 5, 2002 TO YOU MY LOVE I GIVE MY HEART. GAYLE 1/3

CUMMING--Ian James, died on August 21, 2015 at the age of 84. Born in London, England to Annie and Jim Cumming, he attended the Uppingham School and then served in the Royal Artillery regiment of the British Army. Ian was a Scotsman at heart, longtime rugger, playful soul and Hasher through and through. He founded the Singapore Hash House Harriers in 1962 and the New York Hash in 1978. He was very active with St. James Episcopal Church and served on the Yonkers YMCA Board of Directors and St. John's Riverside Hospital Board of Trustees. Ian is survived by his wife Jane, whom he married in 1957, his sons, James and Ruaridh, his sister Edina and three grandchildren. Memorial donations may be directed to the YMCA of Yonkers, NY. On-On. 1/3

KAGEL--Stuart Todd, Sr. Stuart Todd Kagel Sr.,of Brooklyn Heights, NY died unexpectedly August 18, 2015 at his summer home on Skaneateles Lake. Born February 7, 1944 in Sebring, FL to Lewis and Elizabeth Kagel, Stuart graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall where he was a three-sport athlete. Following that, he attended UNC Chapel Hill, graduating in 1966. Stuart played UNC football and was a member of Alpha Tau Omega fraternity. After college, he joined the JC Penney Co in their executive training program, and subsequently became a co- owner of Kelly Slax, an apparel company. Stuart continued his entrepreneurial vision, starting several companies in the 1990's. In 2000 he co-founded 24 Seven Inc., a global strategic staffing and recruiting company, headquartered in New York City. Stuart was an avid outdoorsman as well as a sporting art and antiques collector. In 2014 he completed his unique collection of original art by every Federal Duck Stamp artist since its inception in 1934. He is survived by his partner of 27 years, Celeste Gudas; two sons, Stuart Todd (Alejandra) Kagel, Jr. of Fairfield, CT and James Albert Kagel of Brooklyn Heights; two daughters, Eleanor Elizabeth Kagel and Katherine Gudas Kagel, both of Brooklyn Heights; one brother, Colin Todd (Jane) Kagel of East Haddam, CT; one sister, Kathleen Hutchins of Princeton, NJ; three grandchildren, Emma Chamberlain Kagel, Gabriela Burnham Kagel, and Stuart Todd Kagel, III; and six nieces and nephews, Colin, Jr., and Joshua Kagel, and Bevin, Lewis (deceased), Elizabeth, and Colin Cherot. A memorial service will be held on September, 9th at 11am at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights. Memorial donations may be made to Skaneateles Lake Association: skaneateleslake.org/support- the-sla-through-amazon- smiles/ or Finger Lakes Land Trust http://fllt.org/donate/. 1/3
PARKAS--Philip. Memorial Service on Wednesday, September 9, 2015 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., at 5pm. 1/3

RONSON--Betty. She has left us in her 100th year. Born into an immigrant family, Betty made her own way in this land of promise. She will be remembered as self reliant and fiercely independent from the beginning to the very end. She has been a valued friend and member of our extended family for 56 years. GILBERT--Milton, 99, died peacefully September 4th at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Born in New York, he founded Gilbert Trucking/Flexi-Van. Milton is survived by Elma, his wife of 75 years, daughter Shelley Fehrenbach and son-in-law Fred Fehrenbach, as well as grandchildren, Jonathan Kalikow (Amy) and Jill Heller, and great-grandchildren Sydney, Julia, Luke, Samantha, Phoebe and Audrey. 1/3

NEWMAN--Evelyn E. Our beloved "Oma," died at age 95 on September 1 in St. Louis. The "Queen of St. Louis Fundraising" left her mark on the city she loved by founding a wide range of civic institutions: the Greater St. Louis Book Fair, ScholarShop, the Gypsy Caravan, Little Shop Around the Corner, Wishing Well, Forest Park Forever, First Street Forum, the Newman Money Museum at Washington University, the Butterfly House at Faust Park, and many others. Leaving college early to marry, she always said she attended "the University of Eric Newman" (later receiving an honorary doctorate from University of Missouri-St. Louis). Eric and Evelyn, our "Opa and Oma," made an inspiring couple through 75 years of pun-filled marriage and adventure, traveling to almost 200 countries and gathering together generations of family in St. Louis, their Mississippi River bluff house in Alton (Illinois), Pango Pango (Jamaica), and Martha's Vineyard. Recently, she started "The Savvy Sage," a travel blog for the over-80 set. Oma is survived by Opa, daughter Linda Schapiro, son Andy Newman (Peggy), brother Julian Edison (Hope), her five grandchildren, Josh (Geula), Dan (Amber), Abigail (Jason), Tony (Meredith), and Kate (David), and 10 great-grandchildren, all of whom will always cherish her boundless energy, creativity, and curiosity. She requested no mourning or service and that people who wish to celebrate her life should donate to their favorite local charities. 1/3

POMEROY--Aloyise (Haskins) 95, a longtime resident of Block Island, RI who wintered in Newport, died July 26, 2015 in the John Clarke Nursing Home in Middletown after a period of failing health. She was the wife of the late Lawrence Pomeroy, a Block Island Times Bayberry Award recipient and public activist on utility and environmental issues. She was a keen birdwatcher and was involved in animal rescue both on Block Island and in Newport. A native of Virginia, Mrs. Pomeroy attended St. Margaret's School of Tappahannock, VA. Pomeroy) of Manhattan and Block Island; and Joseph B. Pomeroy (companion Mildred Kazeniac) of Westford, MA., as well as numerous cousins in Richmond, VA. ISRAEL--Larry H.,died July 29 in Bethesda, Maryland at the age of 95, after a brief illness. He was the loving husband of the late Audrey Westerman Israel for 50 years. He is survived by his children Howard Israel (Mary Rose) and Susan Israel (Alan Herschenfeld), his grandchildren Benjamin and Samuel Herschenfeld, his sister Fern Stephens, and many nieces and nephews. He was a beloved, kind, and generous family member, mentor and friend. Larry Israel was an innovative and pioneering media executive who helped shape modern television and radio. He strove for and achieved excellence and commercial success throughout his career, and used his business leadership roles to serve the communities in which he worked. Under his leadership, Westinghouse Broadcasting put the first commercial all-news radio station on the air (WINS in New York in 1963), then expanded the format to Philadelphia (KYW) and Los Angeles (KFWB). Throughout his career as a broadcast executive, he consistently supported, nurtured and defended good, independent journalism and quality programming, and made decisions about programming and advertising standards that put public welfare first. He was an early leader in bringing diverse talent into broadcast news, and one of the first to recognize the value of live sports on television, acquiring exclusive rights for major league baseball for an independent station group in the 1950s. Larry Israel was born in McKeesport, PA November 4, 1919. He served in the Army during World War II, and graduated from the University of Missouri School of Journalism in 1948. He began as a reporter, then moved to broadcast management beginning at WDTV, the Dumont station in Pittsburgh. He later worked for Westinghouse broadcasting, where he eventually served as President of the Station Group, Chairman of the subsidiary TVAR, and Executive Vice-President of Westinghouse Broadcasting Company. He joined Post-Newsweek Stations as Chairman and Chief Executive in 1968, leading the expansion and development of the Washington Post broadcast properties and changing the format of WTOP radio in Washington to all-news. He eventually became Executive Vice-President, then President (from 1973-1977) of the Washington Post Company. After leaving the Post Company, he invested in and led the North American Broadcasting Company. Larry Israel was honored in 1972 with the prestigious University of Missouri School of Journalism Honor Award for Distinguished Service in Journalism, based on his lifetime achievement. Contributions to a scholarship in his memory may be sent to: Larry H. Israel Memorial Scholarship, University of Missouri School of Journalism, Office of Advancement, 103 Neff Hall, Columbia, Missouri 65211. 1/3

McGOVERN--Ann, died peacefully in her Manhattan home on August 8, 2015. Ann was a noted author of more than 55 children's books, a collage artist, a poet, and an adventurer; see www.annmcgovern.com. DENMAN--Leroy Gilbert, Jr.,97, of San Antonio, TX, saw his long and productive life draw to a close on Saturday, August 29th. The son of Mary Louise Carter Denman and Leroy Gilbert Denman, he came from a distinguished legal and ranching family. His grandfather, Judge Leroy Denman, was an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of Texas and founded the prestigious law firm of Denman, Franklin and Denman in 1899. Leroy Denman, Jr.'s respect for the Rule of Law came early. Educated at the University of Texas for both his undergraduate and law degrees, he was a member and President of the Sigma Chi Fraternity, the Chancellors Honorary and the Phi Delta Phi Law Fraternity. Last year, he celebrated as a member of the State Bar of Texas for 75 years. In 1985, the Leroy G. Denman, Jr. Professorship of Real Property Law was established in his name at the University of Texas. While pursuing his education, Denman studied in Spain at the Complutense University of Madrid, the National Antonino's University of Mexico City, Mexico, and the Sorbonne in Paris, France. Following his graduation, he was recruited by the War Department to serve as an Assistant in Economic Matters at the American Embassy in Guatemala City, Guatemala and later in Buenos Aires, Argentina from March, 1942 to September, 1946. He then returned to the United States to serve in the Advocate General's office of the United States Army, Washington, D.C. Embarking on his legal and business career, he joined the legal firm of Denman, Franklin and Denman in San Antonio, Texas in 1946. Denman was Chairman of San Antonio Loan and Trust Company and later became Chairman and President of Southwest Texas Corporation in 1950, overseeing extensive ranching interests in Texas, California, Arizona and Illinois that at one time totaled almost 1.5 million acres. The greatest wildlife preserves in Texas history - the St. Charles Ranch with its Whooping Crane reserve and the Powderhorn Ranch with its extraordinary multitude of wild birds, antelope, boar and deer - were created by Denman and his father. He loved with great passion all of God's blessings - the land for its ranching abundance, the sea for his beloved sailboat, Aquarius II and the skies above where he flew his Cessna planes for 600,000 miles over 67 years of flying. . Public service was an important part of his highly dynamic life. He was the attorney and advisor for the King Ranch for over 50 years and its first non-Member President. He is Trustee Emeritus of the Caesar Kleberg Foundation for Wildlife Conservation, the Tobin Foundation, the Nordan Trust, the George W. Brackenridge Foundation, the Ewing Halsell Foundation, and the Texas Bio Medical Research Institute. Denman served for ten years as a Member and later Chairman of the Public Service Board/ San Antonio, TX. He was a member of The Order of the Alamo, San Antonio German Club, The Argyle Club, The Club Giraud and the San Antonio Country Club. Denman is survived by his wife of 43 years, Diana Destine Sandefer Denman and their daughter, Destine Denman Holmgreen and his children, Margaret Denman Branton, Emily Denman Thuss, Deirdre Denman Glober and nine grandchildren. Honorary pallbearers: Bruce Bugg, Corbett Christie, Tio Kleberg and Mel Weingart. Visitation was held at the residence on Thursday, September 3rd from 5:30pm to 7:30pm. A Memorial Service was held on Friday, September 4, 2015 at 1:30pm at First Presbyterian Church, 404 N. Alamo, San Antonio, TX 78205. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to either The Caesar Kleberg Foundation for Wildlife Conservation, P.O. Box 1555, Kingsville, TX 78364 or The Texas Bio Medical Research Institute, P.O. Box 760549, San Antonio, TX 78245-0549 or to a charity of your choice. You are invited to sign the Guestbook at: www.porterloring.com. Services with Porter Loring Mortuary, San Antonio, TX. 1/3

HOLLENBECK--Burton George, Sr. beloved husband, father and grandfather died peacefully in New Rochelle, NY on August 28th at 88. His life reflected an unwavering commitment to family, community and faith. Born on August 3, 1927 in Jersey City, NJ. At 17, enlisted in the U.S. Navy, during WWII. Graduated Seton Hall University, married Mildred Clohessy on December 16, 1950. Settled in Metuchen, NJ and devoted the next 65 years to loving and providing for his family. A prominent figure in commercial real estate in New York City, beginning at Helmsley-Spear in 1957. During a long and distinguished career, Burt served as executive officer of several prominent real estate brokerage firms including Cross & Brown and Helmsley-Noyes. His accomplishments: Young Man of the Year in New York Real Estate, Chairman of the Young Men's and Women's Real Estate Association of New York, Governor of the Real Estate Board of New York, Chairman of the Brokerage Division of the Real Estate Board of New York, Governor of the Wall Street Club, Director Emeritus of the Bankers Federal Savings, and Governor of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association. Upon retirement, Burt served on the vestry of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Metuchen, NJ. In the Navy, he acquired a love of the sea and spent decades boating the eastern seaboard. Burt is survived by Mildred, sons Burton Jr. and Kenneth, their respective spouses, Elizabeth and Lisa, daughter Lynn, her husband, David Breindel, five grandsons: Zachary and Damon Hollenbeck, Daniel, Jeremy, and Alex Breindel, cousin Joy Jekelis, her husband, Al, sons Daniel and Matthew, and two nephews: Christopher and Jonathan. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Metuchen, NJ, September 12, at 11am. A reception at the church will follow. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested contributions be made to the Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

GARRITY--John "Jack", one of Massachusetts' and Boston University's most outstanding hockey players, passed away on August 31, 2015, following a long illness, at the age of 89 in Brookline, Massachusetts. Jack is a Member of the United States Hockey Hall of Fame; Boston University Athletic Hall of Fame; Massachusetts Hockey Hall of Fame; and Massachusetts Football Coaches Hall of Fame. Jack was a hockey phenom at Medford High School. After serving in the Army Air Corps in WWII, he was one of just three non-college players to play for the 1948 US Olympic Hockey Team in St Moritz, Switzerland. Following the Olympics, he entered Boston University where he rewrote B.U. hockey and NCAA records. In his first varsity year, Jack broke the NCAA single season scoring record with 84 points (51 goals, 33 assists), leading B.U. to the NCAA finals. The next year, he co-captained BU and recorded 57 points on the way to another NCAA Final Four. He was selected to the '50 and '51 All American Hockey Teams. More than 60 years later, Jack still holds the single season goals and points records at B.U. and his 85 career goals (in only two years) ranks sixth on the all- time B.U. hockey list. In 1954, Jack began his teaching and coaching career, which would span over 40 years, from Archbishop Williams High School, Quincy High School to Milton Academy. Married 61 years, Jack's beloved wife Jean died in 2006. Jack is survived by his six children Jack Jr., Jill, Jeff, Jonathan, Christopher, Steven, their spouses and 11 grandchildren. The family will hold a celebration of Jack's life at the Milton Academy Chapel in Milton, MA on December 12, 2015. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Friends of B.U. Hockey. 1/3

SCOTT--Thomas C. Scott Jr. September 3, 1930 - August 31, 2015. Thomas Coster Scott Jr. passed peacefully on Monday, August 31 at his home in Charlottesville, VA. He was 84 years old. He was born September 3, 1930 and was raised in Baltimore, Maryland. Heavily recruited to play football by several of the top college programs in the country, Tom chose The University of Virginia. Although football was where Tom found his true calling, he earned 10 varsity letters in the sports he participated in, including first team All American honors in Football and Lacrosse, a first for any student athlete at UVA. He played in the East West Shrine and College All- Star games. He was voted the best All-Around Athlete in the history of UVA. The University retired Tom's football jersey, number 65, in 2007 in honor of his achievements on and off the field. After graduating from college, Tom joined the National Football League. He played six seasons as linebacker for the Philadelphia Eagles, and was named the NFL Rookie of The Year in his first season. In 1959, he went on to the New York Giants and played during an era now described as the Giants' Golden Years. The team competed in NFL Championship games in 1959, 1961, 1962, and 1963. During these years, Tom was named All-Pro in seven of his 12 seasons with the NFL. At the close of the 1964 season Tom retired as a player, and became assistant defensive coach for the Giants. Tom is preceded in death by his first wife Joan Davis Scott, and son Thomas C. Scott III. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Linda Scott; daughter- in-law Susan Scott of Cranford, NJ; son David Scott of Deep River, CT; daughter Sandra and husband Leslie Dale of New Canaan, CT; son Michael and wife Alison Scott of Charlotte, NC; and daughter Patricia Scott of Rowayton, CT. He is survived by eight grandchildren: Owen Scott, Ian Scott and Emma Scott, Andrew Scott and Sam Scott, Ashley Larence and husband Eric Larence, and Charles Scott and William Scott. At the time of his passing Tom and Linda were looking forward to welcoming their first great-grandson. In lieu of flowers, please honor Tom Scott's memory with a donation to the Virginia Athletics Foundation, PO Box 400833, Charlottesville, VA 22904. 1/3

HARTFIELD--Freda L.,on August 29, 2015 of Key Largo, FL. Beloved wife of the late David Hartfield Jr. Survived by her loving sister Helen Lustick Krulevitz and many special nieces, nephews and step-sons Philip Burling and Peter Hoe Burling. Funeral Services will be private. 1/3

PAPPAS--Dr. George D.,died peacefully at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx at midday on Wednesday, August 12th at the age of eighty-eight. He had struggled with kidney failure and first onset diabetes. A lifelong pioneer in scientific research whose interests consistently traversed the fields of anatomy, cell biology, and neuroscience, George was known to his students as an expansive and vibrant lecturer - yet also to his closest colleagues, family, and friends - as an incomparable host and Mediterranean chef. Science, politics, and rogue humor animated his life and his inimitable approach to quotidian realities. Beyond the legacy of his intellectual accomplishments, he will be profoundly missed by those who loved him dearly. 1/3

WEISFELD--Florence Goodman, MSW, died on September 3 after a long illness. She was born in Brooklyn and graduated at age 20 from Hunter College. She attended graduate school at Washington University in St. Louis, where she met her cherished husband Frank. Faigy enjoyed a long, diverse and rewarding career in social work. She was a tireless worker for peace and justice; loved humanity, life, travel. animals of every type, etymology, Jewish history and all things Yiddish. She had friends of many ages and from many countries. She is survived by her loving family and friends. Please do good deeds in her memory. 1/3

ALLEY--James Burke Jr.,a Cowboy and a Gentleman, Dies at 79. A 50-year resident of Santa Fe, New Mexico, died peacefully Wednesday at Christus St. Vincent Hospital due to congestive heart failure. He was the son of James Burke Alley and Esther Hall Alley of Oyster Bay, New York. His father worked for President Franklin D. Roosevelt as the lead counsel for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which played a major role in overcoming the Great Depression in the United States. Jim's mother insisted on a first rate education that began at Green Vale School and continued at Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard College and the University of Virginia School of Law. Jim loved sports and seemed to be good at all of them: wrestling, playing football and captaining the lacrosse team at Exeter. In later years he enjoyed skiing at Taos, fishing at Crystal Brook and playing squash at the Kiva Club with friends like Bud Kelly and Walter Burke. He was a quick study at both polo and cowboy polo, the latter of which resulted in the 1975 national championship as a member of the Santa Fe Sheriff's Posse. Together with Abel Davis, Jim Ritchie and Phil Naumberg, Jim founded the original Santa Fe Polo Grounds where they played polo during the summers of the 1980s. In the winters, Jim enjoyed skiing in Taos and knew where to find the apres ski martinis Ernie Blake had hidden in the trees. He was the sort of athlete who played to win, celebrated the touchdowns of others, and kept quiet about his own. He had a curious nature: he worked as a roustabout in the Oklahoma oil fields while in school, completed basic training in the U.S. Army in Texas after college, and then worked as a corporate lawyer at Debevoise and Plimpton in New York City, but he found his true calling as a lawyer in Santa Fe serving the interests of every constituency that came to him for help. He had served as a member of the New Mexico State Bar since 1965 and valued his partners of more than 30 years, Jim Rubin and Lenny Katz. He was strongly opposed to undesirable development and served on the board of the New Mexico Environmental Law Center. In the late 1960s, as the attorney for the Upper Pecos Association, he fought an initiative to put a paved 26-mile highway across Elk Mountain in his beloved Pecos Wilderness, and the case went all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court before the highway proposal was finally defeated. He served on several corporate boards, but he also invested time in education, and was a member of the board of trustees that saved the Santa Fe Prep School during challenging years. From 1961 to 1969, Jim was married to Helen C. Lamberton (Gates) with whom he had two children, Anne L. Alley and James B. Alley III. He married Maria Elisabeth Werner in 1971 at Songa Church in Sweden and they had one daughter, Kristina E. Alley, and in marriage he gained another son, Carl M. Kawaja. Elisabeth and all of his children were by his side as he died. Elisabeth was the love of his life, and he learned to speak Swedish (very poorly), drink Aquavit (quite well) and dance around a midsummer pole (happily). Jim liked to say about special people that God broke the mold after he made them. There was no mold for someone like Jim, he had the feel of someone built by hand. He had a love of manly things - hunting, cigars, football on TV, his beautiful Swedish wife, but he also had a sophisticated palate for food, travel and artful things. He had a soft heart. He cried at his wedding to Elisabeth and when he took his younger daughter to college. He was childish in the best way, putting spit balls in a straw at The Shed restaurant, firing them at strangers and blaming his grandchildren when accused. In his later years, Jim enjoyed horseback riding in the Pecos Wilderness he had helped to save, but most of all he savored traveling the lengths of the Lower and Upper Ausable Lakes in an Adirondack guide boat with his best friend, Nicholas A. Farrell, aged 11, his grandson. He was predeceased by his brother, Dr. Harrison H. Alley, and his sister, Jane J. Edgerton, and is survived by his sister, Cynthia A. Andrews, his wife Elisabeth, his children Kristina, James, Carl, and Anne and her husband John S. Ferrara, and Jim's grandchildren, Nicholas and Linnea, children of Kristina and her husband Timothy G. Farrell, and Catherine, Marcus and Noelle, children of Carl and his wife Gwendolyn N. Holcombe. A celebration of Jim's life will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to Adirondack Trail Improvement Society (ATIS) www.atistrail.org or the scholarship fund in his name at Santa Fe Prep School: www.sfprep.org/giving. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Sara S.,102, wife of the late Samuel Kaufman, died peacefully on September 1, 2015. Loving mother of Carol Kaganov and Henry Kaufman, grandmother of Erica Kaufman (fiance Dan Asher), mother-in-law to Alan Kaganov and Meryl Unger. Sara, formerly of Albany, NY, was lovingly cared for as a longtime resident of the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale. BLAIR--The Hon. William McCormick Jr.,98, was a long time public servant, and colleague of Adlai E. Stevenson and John F. Kennedy. In the 1960s, he served as Ambassador to Denmark, Ambassador to the Philippines, and the first General Director of the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington D.C. In the 1940s and 1950's, he was senior advisor and assistant to Adlai E. Stevenson when Stevenson was Governor of Illinois, and Democratic candidate for President in 1952 and 1956. Stevenson often said that Blair was indispensable. After his service as Ambassador, Blair was elected head of the Council of American Ambassadors in Washington D.C. Known for his impeccable style and passion for movies and politics, Blair was often consulted for his nuanced perceptions on coming elections. He followed all of the candidates' histories and progress with the same ardor he gave to every news station. He was a graduate of Stanford University and the University of Virginia Law School, and was an Air Corps officer in World War II in the China-Burma-India theater and awarded the Bronze Star. He became Stevenson's key assistant when Stevenson was elected Governor of Illinois in 1948. In Stevenson's two national campaigns and later, he traveled with Stevenson in 50 states and 64 countries. He played a top role in bringing Stevenson and John F. Kennedy together in Kennedy's 1960 campaign. Bill Blair joined the Kennedy administration in 1961. After Stevenson was defeated by President Eisenhower, he joined Stevenson in 1955 in a new law firm in Chicago including W. Willard Wirtz and Newton N. Minow, which later became part of the New York firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison. After Kennedy became President, the President appointed Stevenson Ambassador to the United Nations, Wirtz as Undersecretary and later Secretary of Labor, Blair as Ambassador to Denmark, and Minow as Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. Stevenson said, "I regret having only one law firm to give to my country." In recognition for service in Denmark, Blair received the Commander's Cross of the Order of the Dannebrog, First Class, and from the Philippines the Order of Sikatuna, Rank of Commander. Growing up in Chicago, he was deeply influenced by his grandmother, Louise DeKoven Bowen, who worked very closely with Jane Addams to help the underprivileged. Known for his profound social conscience, Bill cared deeply about civil and human rights and was a man who treated everyone with dignity. He was also deeply concerned about animal welfare and insisted on only owning shelter dogs. Ambassador Blair was preceded in death by his son, William, and is survived by his wife of more than 53 years, Deeda, in New York. Died Saturday, August 29 and the service will be private. If desired, contributions in his memory may be made to William Blair III Fund, the Washington Humane Society, 4590 Mac Arthur Boulevard, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20007. 1/3
NETZER--Corinne. Always fabulous, she became divine on 9/5/13. A supernova is born in just 730 days. 1/3
GOLD--Elaine. Governor of Shenkar College in Israel. Dynamic Leader of American Committee. Scholarship Supporter, mentor to students. She will be sorely missed. Susan Pernick Committee President 1/3

TAYLOR--John Chestnut 3rd, "Bud", died peacefully at his home in Savannah, Georgia, on August 23. Born on January 7, 1928 in New York City, he was an alumnus of The Hill School, Princeton University and Yale Law School. He joined the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison in 1950, leaving for two years when commissioned to the Judge Advocate General during the Korean War. He also took a two year leave from his law practice to become President of AEA Investors. At Paul Weiss, he was a managing partner specializing in entertainment and corporate law. Taylor was an esteemed leader, mentor and friend to many. Known to most as Bud, Taylor was gracious, kind and generous, dedicating much of his energy and resources to helping improve the lives of the less fortunate. His belief in education led him to serve on the Devereux Foundation Board of Trustees and to Chair the Board of Trustees of AFS Intercultural Programs. While Chairman of the Carnegie Corporation Board of Trustees, he worked to promote democratic change in South Africa and expand the reach and funding of early childhood education programs among many other endeavors. Taylor endowed the Joseph E. Willis Memorial Scholarship Fund at Yale Law School, as well as the Bud Taylor Family Support and Education Fund at Devereux. In addition, he was devoted to his family, friends and community. He was predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Dolores (Sunny) Sunstrom Taylor, his son, John Taylor, and his brother, Joseph Taylor. He is survived by two daughters: Jane Taylor and Anne (Holly) Taylor, and four grandchildren: James Salem, Leigh Salem, Kathryn Bambino and Lauren Bambino. In lieu of flowers, his family prefers that remembrances be made in memory of Bud Taylor for the Bud Taylor Family Support and Education Fund, Devereux Foundation, 444 Devereux Drive, Villanova, PA 19085. 1/3

KLEIER--Jonathan. Dear Jonathan, Our guardian angel, our love. Six years and it is still impossible to bear this world without you. Our hearts are forever broken and we love and miss you forever. Love you, The Family 1/3
GILBERT--Milton A. I will miss my dear friend of 90+ years. We shared so many good memories. Barbara and I extend our love and sympathy to Elma, Shelley and the family. Love, Bentley 1/3

ZAJAC--Tom. "Oyez, Oyez, Oyez." Nottingham Fair Early Music Ensemble (Grant, Susan, Johanna, Karen, Betsy, Henry, Paul, Maria Olga, Nell) sends this notice of profound love for Tom Zajac, the Town Crier, our l'Homme Arme forever. 1/3

KAGEL--Stuart Todd, Sr. 24 Seven mourns the untimely loss of our co-founder, colleague and friend. Stuart was a respected leader in the apparel and specialized recruiting industries, always willing to share his experience and wisdom to nurture countless professionals throughout their career. We will miss his exemplary leadership, his characteristic sense of humor and inimitable style. We will carry his legacy into the future by working toward achieving the vision he had for our company. 1/3

DUBNO--Karen Brooke, on September 1, 2015. Beloved wife of Clifford. Loving sister of Lorna, Elyse and Peter. Devoted daughter of Vera. Donations in Karen's memory may be made to the New York Public Library or Hunter College Annual Fund. A memorial service will be held at a later date. 1/3

POLKOWITZ--Maurice S. Maurice "Reese" S. Polkowitz, born August 27, 1918 to Samuel and Stella Polkowitz, died peacefully in New York City on August 18, 2015. Reese grew up in Perth Amboy, New Jersey, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, then served in the Army during World War II. On June 1, 1946, he married Louise Nierenberg. They moved with their two children to South Orange, New Jersey, in 1955 and, in 1973, to New York City. Owner of Polkowitz Motors, a Buick and Cadillac agency in Perth Amboy, Reese earned great distinction, including the nation's top award for Cadillac fleet dealers in 1980. Following the death of his beloved wife in 1997, he traveled widely with his cherished companion, Elaine Fabrikant. Reese was known for his infectious smile, vitality, intelligence, family values, decidedly conservative beliefs, love for the arts and culture, and generosity toward Jewish causes. He will be greatly missed by his children Ellen Kleiner and Gary Polkowitz of Santa Fe, NM, grandchildren Jordi (Karen) Kleiner of Chicago, IL, and Devin (Christa) Kleiner of Seattle, WA, great-grandchildren Eli and Bryn Kleiner of Seattle, nieces and nephews, cousins, longtime friends, his caregiving companion Frank, and his sweetheart Rita Dennison. May his spirit live on in all who loved him! 1/3

DINITZ--Arthur M.,age 81, died peacefully on Thursday, August 27th at his home in Westport, CT after a valiant battle with cancer. Founder of Transpo Industries, Arthur will be remembered as a pioneer in transportation safety and infrastructure preservation. Recognized as one of ARTBA's 100 Transportation leaders of the 20th Century, he was proud that the company he built has helped save thousands of lives. The field of transportation safety was the driving force in his life and he cherished the friends he made over the decades of service, regardless of affiliation, competition or partnership. He will be remembered for his quick smile, hearty handshake and bear hugs. He is survived by his loving wife Eleanor, children Andrew Dinitz and Karen Dinitz, step-children Wendy Owens and Jeff Fuhrman, nine grandchildren, sisters Beverly Segal, Rhea Rosenzweig and Sheila Harris, many nieces, nephews and close friends. He was predeceased by his first wife Linda P. Dinitz. Gifts in Arthur's memory can be made to the "ARTBA Foundation Transportation Safety Program" at 1219 28th Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20007 www.artba.org/foundation/ 1/3

KRAMER--Kieron. Devoted brother and uncle, and dearest friend to so many, died from a complication of illnesses on August 20th. He was 67 years old. He was born April 22, 1948 to Sam and Carol Kramer; jewelry artists in Greenwich Village, New York. A positive life force who with his quick wit and sharp intellect influenced the lives of all who were fortunate enough to know him. He was the "greatest teacher" and mentor to so many of his students. As the long-time editor of The Eastwick Press, he was dedicated to the craft of journalism and invested much of his time to his already considerable skill as a master of the English language. As a life-time soccer fanatic, player, coach, referee, he was known for fairness, and for love of the physical and artistic aspects of the game. He was the proverbial scholar and gentleman, and keen observer of this unfathomable world. He was a kind man and we are left shaking our heads at his loss. He is survived by his brother John Kramer of Williamstown, MA; niece Carol Jane Kramer of Brooklyn, NY and nephew John "Chico" Kramer of Greenwich Village, NY as well as his kith and kin, the educators, artists, soccer nuts and gadabouts of Western Massachusetts. 1/3
GREENWALD--Irwin Daniel. Sept. 6, 1918 - Feb. 17, 2013 Dad, during these difficult times, I miss your wisdom, warmth and gentle ways. Love, Ronny 1/3
HUNT--Margaret Steuart, on June 20, 2015. Beloved mother of Cecilia McIvor Hunt. Preceded in death by her cherished husband, Cecil McIvor Hunt. 1/3

HOPKINS--Carol. Born Ellen Carol Stutz in Chicago, Illinois on December 24, 1927. Died peacefully at her home in Evanston, Illinois on August 28, 2015. Beloved mother of James Dennis Hopkins, Jr. (Laura), Ellen Hopkins Suarez (Mario), Ann Rice (Dale), Paul Hopkins, Matthew Hopkins (Colleen), Martha Sheridan (Leo), and Elizabeth Heltzer (Michael). Treasured grandmother of Katherine Tierney Lester (Jeff), Rebecca Tierney Koepsel (Chris), Hannah Tierney; Jack, Daniel, James and Claire Sheridan; Henry, Rose, George and Estelle Heltzer. Proud great-grandmother of Bridget and Maeve Lester; Emmett and Blythe Koepsel. While raising her children she obtained a Masters Degree in Special Education and taught for twenty three years before retiring as Chair of the OShaughnessy Learning Development Program at Loyola Academy in Wilmette, Illinois. She was committed to learning and family. We are grateful for her faith and her love, and for making us better people. Special thanks to North Shore University Health System Hospice, Joy Cachola, and Angela Manraqui for their compassion and loving care. 1/3

BIONDI--Gio. Painter, photographer and armchair historian, Gio Biondi passed away on August 7, 2015. Gio was born in Genoa, Italy on June 9, 1932 and moved to New York City with his young bride Anna in 1962. During the next 53 years, he devoted himself entirely to his painting, his photography and eventually to a book on early American history. All his life, he never lost his sense of wonder nor his ability to see life through an artist's eyes. His curiosity and keen eye for the ironic and unusual are reflected in his photos of Manhattan street scenes and his surrealist oil paintings. He leaves behind Anna, his daughter Gianna, his son-in-law John, his brothers Marco and Lillino, his grandchildren Evander, Aidan and Ariana, as well as many more beloved family members and friends both here and in Italy. New York City is a little less interesting without that ever-inquisitive elderly man wandering its streets, a camera in one hand and a cane in the other. A memorial service will be held at the home of his good friend John Ziegler, 60 East 12th Street, on Sunday, September 13, 2015 from 3-5pm. 1/3

STEINGESSER--Richard H.,71, on August 31, 2015. We, his children, Deborah and David; his sister, Stephanie B. Hamburg (nee Steingesser); and his brother-in-law, C. Bruce Hamburg, are saddened by Richard's passing and will remember him always. 1/3

QUINE--Stephen John. December 12, 1965 to August 23, 2015. Bank of America Managing Director Stephen John Quine, whose character was shaped by his scholarly intellect, legendary funny-bone, intense sentimentality and utter devotion to his family, died suddenly on Sunday, August 23rd at Northern Westchester Hospital, New York, his beloved wife and two sons at his side. He was only 49. Stephen was born on December 12, 1965 in Niskayuna, NY, the second of two children of Dr. John Peter Quine, a Principle Engineer at General Electric, and Jean Hotaling Quine. Due to his clarity of thought and compassion for others, his mother, who died when Stephen was 17, thought he would become a minister. Brought up with values he later instilled in his own sons, Stephen attended Niskayuna High School, where he played varsity baseball and basketball. He graduated Magna Cum Laude with a Bachelors of Science in Electrical Engineering from Union College and honors from IEEE Eta Kappa Nu and Tau Beta Pi. Although he had a solid scientific background, his love of literature coupled with an analytical mind led him to Albany Law School. He was a member of the Law Review, as well as the Justinian Society, a legal organization dedicated to maintaining the honor of the legal profession. Stephen met his wife of 23 years, Rebecca Ruoff, while in Law School. The attraction was instant between the strikingly beautiful blonde and 6-foot-4 law student with the movie star looks. They married in 1992 and soon moved from Manhattan to Chappaqua to raise their children. Although Stephen often worked 16 hours a day and some weekends, he was an extremely devoted husband and father. He was happiest either on the field pitching baseballs or teeing off at Whippoorwill with his two sons. After passing the New York and Connecticut bar exams, Stephen was hired at the New York Law Firm of Clifford Chance Rogers & Wells LLD. Whisked away by their top client, Merrill Lynch, in 2002, he held several executive positions, finding his true calling when Merrill Lynch and Bank of America merged in 2010. As the Senior Global Risk Executive for B of A's Leveraged Finance, Healthcare and Gaming and Leisure Businesses, Stephen managed a team of 45 Risk Executives, as well as a portfolio of companies with billions of dollars of exposure. He oversaw some of the highest volume, extremely competitive businesses within the bank--businesses that faced intense regulatory scrutiny and had visibility at the most senior levels. Said one admiring co-worker, "He could untangle the most complex issues into basic and easy to understand building blocks... He was a perfectionist with an unyielding drive for excellence while having fun doing it." Stephen is survived by his wife, Rebecca Ruoff Quine; sons Adam Stephen and Matthew Stephen of Chappaqua, NY; his sister Susan Quine Laurilliard of Niskayuna, NY; and three nephews and two nieces. Both parents are deceased. 1/3

ALLEN--Doris J.,89, of Tenafly, NJ, passed away September 2. A brilliant, warm and loving wife, mother, grandmother and sister with tremendous wit and wisdom, boundless creativity and exquisite taste. A Madison Avenue pioneer: the first woman director of print traffic at Benton & Bowles. Later at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, she was the pharmacology course administrator and executive editor. Born in Brooklyn, the younger daughter of George Jaffe and Rose Natelson Jaffe. Graduated from Girls Commercial High School, then earned a B.A. in English and speech at Brooklyn College. She credited her drama/speech professor, Joseph H. "Skip" Davidson, with helping her develop the confidence that won her a lifetime of friends and admirers. Member of the Advertising Women of New York and a former president of the American Technion Society's Women's Division, Tenafly chapter. Predeceased by her husband Melvin K. Allen. Survived by daughters Jane E. Allen of Los Angeles and Claudia H. Allen (Philip C. Stahl) of Chicago; beloved grandchildren, Benjamin and Isabel Stahl of Chicago; nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Funeral services 10am Tuesday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ, with burial at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the NYU Joan H. Tisch Center for Women's Health, NYU Office of Development, One Park Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10016. 1/3

NEWMAN--Evelyn E. Our beloved "Oma," died at age 95 on September 1 in St. Louis. The "Queen of St. Louis Fundraising" left her mark on the city she loved by founding a wide range of civic institutions: the Greater St. Louis Book Fair, ScholarShop, the Gypsy Caravan, Little Shop Around the Corner, Wishing Well, Forest Park Forever, First Street Forum, the Newman Money Museum at Washington University, the Butterfly House at Faust Park, and many others. Leaving college early to marry, she always said she attended "the University of Eric Newman" (later receiving an honorary doctorate from University of Missouri-St. Louis). Eric and Evelyn, our "Opa and Oma," made an inspiring couple through 75 years of pun-filled marriage and adventure, traveling to almost 200 countries and gathering together generations of family in St. Louis, their Mississippi River bluff house in Alton (Illinois), Pango Pango (Jamaica), and Martha's Vineyard. Recently, she started "The Savvy Sage," a travel blog for the over-80 set. Oma is survived by Opa, daughter Linda Schapiro, son Andy Newman (Peggy), brother Julian Edison (Hope), her five grandchildren, Josh (Geula), Dan (Amber), Abigail (Jason), Tony (Meredith), and Kate (David), and 10 great-grandchildren, all of whom will always cherish her boundless energy, creativity, and curiosity. She requested no mourning or service and that people who wish to celebrate her life should donate to their favorite local charities. 1/3
GILBERT--Milton A. I will miss my dear friend of 90+ years. We shared so many good memories. Barbara and I extend our love and sympathy to Elma, Shelley and the family. Love, Bentley 1/3

Mark, Jr. (2000) Memorial Scholarship, Manhattan College, 4513 Manhattan College Parkway, Bronx, NY 10471. 1/3
