ALLEY--James Burke Jr.,a Cowboy and a Gentleman, Dies at 79. A 50-year resident of Santa Fe, New Mexico, died peacefully Wednesday at Christus St. Vincent Hospital due to congestive heart failure. He was the son of James Burke Alley and Esther Hall Alley of Oyster Bay, New York. His father worked for President Franklin D. Roosevelt as the lead counsel for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which played a major role in overcoming the Great Depression in the United States. Jim's mother insisted on a first rate education that began at Green Vale School and continued at Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard College and the University of Virginia School of Law. Jim loved sports and seemed to be good at all of them: wrestling, playing football and captaining the lacrosse team at Exeter. In later years he enjoyed skiing at Taos, fishing at Crystal Brook and playing squash at the Kiva Club with friends like Bud Kelly and Walter Burke. He was a quick study at both polo and cowboy polo, the latter of which resulted in the 1975 national championship as a member of the Santa Fe Sheriff's Posse. Together with Abel Davis, Jim Ritchie and Phil Naumberg, Jim founded the original Santa Fe Polo Grounds where they played polo during the summers of the 1980s. In the winters, Jim enjoyed skiing in Taos and knew where to find the apres ski martinis Ernie Blake had hidden in the trees. He was the sort of athlete who played to win, celebrated the touchdowns of others, and kept quiet about his own. He had a curious nature: he worked as a roustabout in the Oklahoma oil fields while in school, completed basic training in the U.S. Army in Texas after college, and then worked as a corporate lawyer at Debevoise and Plimpton in New York City, but he found his true calling as a lawyer in Santa Fe serving the interests of every constituency that came to him for help. He had served as a member of the New Mexico State Bar since 1965 and valued his partners of more than 30 years, Jim Rubin and Lenny Katz. He was strongly opposed to undesirable development and served on the board of the New Mexico Environmental Law Center. In the late 1960s, as the attorney for the Upper Pecos Association, he fought an initiative to put a paved 26-mile highway across Elk Mountain in his beloved Pecos Wilderness, and the case went all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court before the highway proposal was finally defeated. He served on several corporate boards, but he also invested time in education, and was a member of the board of trustees that saved the Santa Fe Prep School during challenging years. From 1961 to 1969, Jim was married to Helen C. Lamberton (Gates) with whom he had two children, Anne L. Alley and James B. Alley III. He married Maria Elisabeth Werner in 1971 at Songa Church in Sweden and they had one daughter, Kristina E. Alley, and in marriage he gained another son, Carl M. Kawaja. Elisabeth and all of his children were by his side as he died. Elisabeth was the love of his life, and he learned to speak Swedish (very poorly), drink Aquavit (quite well) and dance around a midsummer pole (happily). Jim liked to say about special people that God broke the mold after he made them. There was no mold for someone like Jim, he had the feel of someone built by hand. He had a love of manly things - hunting, cigars, football on TV, his beautiful Swedish wife, but he also had a sophisticated palate for food, travel and artful things. He had a soft heart. He cried at his wedding to Elisabeth and when he took his younger daughter to college. He was childish in the best way, putting spit balls in a straw at The Shed restaurant, firing them at strangers and blaming his grandchildren when accused. In his later years, Jim enjoyed horseback riding in the Pecos Wilderness he had helped to save, but most of all he savored traveling the lengths of the Lower and Upper Ausable Lakes in an Adirondack guide boat with his best friend, Nicholas A. Farrell, aged 11, his grandson. He was predeceased by his brother, Dr. Harrison H. Alley, and his sister, Jane J. Edgerton, and is survived by his sister, Cynthia A. Andrews, his wife Elisabeth, his children Kristina, James, Carl, and Anne and her husband John S. Ferrara, and Jim's grandchildren, Nicholas and Linnea, children of Kristina and her husband Timothy G. Farrell, and Catherine, Marcus and Noelle, children of Carl and his wife Gwendolyn N. Holcombe. A celebration of Jim's life will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to Adirondack Trail Improvement Society (ATIS) www.atistrail.org or the scholarship fund in his name at Santa Fe Prep School: www.sfprep.org/giving. 1/3

BARON--Morris, was born on October 5, 1918 to David and Sarah Baron and died peacefully at his home on Thursday, September 3. His family, including his loving sister, Pauline, was by his side. He was a lifelong resident of Great Neck, where he returned after receiving a purple heart for his military service in Europe in World War II. He married Cecily Shanberg on March 4, 1947 and together, they raised their family of four boys, David, Stephen, Ronny and Bruce. His business endeavors began with a gas station. He went on to become a Lincoln Mercury dealer and started Baron Motors, and later, Port Motors, Lincoln Mercury dealerships with his brother-in-law and best friend, Bernie Cohen. He is survived by his wife, Cecily, his sons David (Iris), Stephen (Andrea) and Ronny (Kerry) and by 11 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He left a legacy of accomplishments and he will be profoundly missed by all who loved him. 1/3
MELLON--Sean F. Your smile and laughter are missed even more 5 years later. Love - Mom, Dad & Liam 1/3

ISRAEL--Larry H.,died July 29 in Bethesda, Maryland at the age of 95, after a brief illness. He was the loving husband of the late Audrey Westerman Israel for 50 years. He is survived by his children Howard Israel (Mary Rose) and Susan Israel (Alan Herschenfeld), his grandchildren Benjamin and Samuel Herschenfeld, his sister Fern Stephens, and many nieces and nephews. He was a beloved, kind, and generous family member, mentor and friend. Larry Israel was an innovative and pioneering media executive who helped shape modern television and radio. He strove for and achieved excellence and commercial success throughout his career, and used his business leadership roles to serve the communities in which he worked. Under his leadership, Westinghouse Broadcasting put the first commercial all-news radio station on the air (WINS in New York in 1963), then expanded the format to Philadelphia (KYW) and Los Angeles (KFWB). Throughout his career as a broadcast executive, he consistently supported, nurtured and defended good, independent journalism and quality programming, and made decisions about programming and advertising standards that put public welfare first. He was an early leader in bringing diverse talent into broadcast news, and one of the first to recognize the value of live sports on television, acquiring exclusive rights for major league baseball for an independent station group in the 1950s. Larry Israel was born in McKeesport, PA November 4, 1919. He served in the Army during World War II, and graduated from the University of Missouri School of Journalism in 1948. He began as a reporter, then moved to broadcast management beginning at WDTV, the Dumont station in Pittsburgh. He later worked for Westinghouse broadcasting, where he eventually served as President of the Station Group, Chairman of the subsidiary TVAR, and Executive Vice-President of Westinghouse Broadcasting Company. He joined Post-Newsweek Stations as Chairman and Chief Executive in 1968, leading the expansion and development of the Washington Post broadcast properties and changing the format of WTOP radio in Washington to all-news. He eventually became Executive Vice-President, then President (from 1973-1977) of the Washington Post Company. After leaving the Post Company, he invested in and led the North American Broadcasting Company. Larry Israel was honored in 1972 with the prestigious University of Missouri School of Journalism Honor Award for Distinguished Service in Journalism, based on his lifetime achievement. Contributions to a scholarship in his memory may be sent to: Larry H. Israel Memorial Scholarship, University of Missouri School of Journalism, Office of Advancement, 103 Neff Hall, Columbia, Missouri 65211. 1/3

PACE--Norma T.,of North Palm Beach and New York City passed away on September 4, 2015 at the age of 93. Wife of the late Angelo Pace. Sister of the late Milton, Alex, Joseph and Richard LePore. Loving aunt of Geraldine Feola, Alex, Joseph and Richard LePore. Proud great-aunt to many nieces and nephews. Norma was a graduate of Hunter College and went on to have a long and successful career as an economist. She advised management of companies such as GM, Ford, Chrysler, Sears and Robuck, GE, Sperry, and American Paper Institute. Visitation: Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave., NYC, Tuesday 2pm- 5pm and 7pm-9pm. Mass: Wednesday 10:30am, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Ave., NYC. 1/3

Wake Monday 3 to 7pm Gerard J. Neufeld Funeral Home, 8804 43 Ave Elmhurst NY. Mass Tuesday at 10:45am at St Bartholomew Church. 1/3

Graduate of Loyola High School, NYC (1996), Manhattan College (2000), St. John's University School of Law (2003). Mark, Jr. (2000) Memorial Scholarship, Manhattan College, 4513 Manhattan College Parkway, Bronx, NY 10471. 1/3

ROTHBERG--Dr. Gerald Morris, passed away on June 23, 2015 following a brief illness. Please join family, friends, and colleagues at a memorial event honoring Dr. Rothberg this Wednesday, September 9th, from 4 to 6pm in the Babbio Center at Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, NJ. 1/3

GOLDEN--Joy. The family of Joy Golden celebrates the life of this unique creature, who died on August 19th. She was a pioneer woman in advertising, possessing an original wit and an instantly recognizable sense of humor. Beginning in the 1950s, she fought for what women could achieve in an almost exclusively male world. She is mourned by the Viertel and Man families, especially by her daughters Suzanne and Lisbeth, and her colleagues who spent decades working and laughing with her. We treasured each moment spent in her presence, and we will carry her with us forever. Donations may be made to Kitty Kind of New York City. Tom, Jack, Linda and Joy Viertel, Alice and Dennis Krieger and Pat Daily 1/3

MELCHIONE--Frank, of Glen Cove, NY on September 5, 2015. Beloved husband of the late Angela. Loving father of Joseph (Christine), Nanette and Frank (Lynn) Melchione. Cherished grandfather of six and great-grandfather of three. He is also survived by his sister-in-law Marie (Robert) Staada. Visiting Wednesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm, Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Head, NY www.whitting.com Funeral Mass on Thursday, 9:30am at St. Boniface Martyr Church, Sea Cliff, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. 1/3
RUBENSTEIN--Melvin. Two years gone, missed like crazy. Shirley 1/3

We can never fill the void left by this remarkable woman, but we will continue to be enriched by her total devotion to family. Sharyn and Stephen Mann and Family Judy and Norris Wolff and Family 1/3
WINICK--Pearl. Sept. 8, 1924 - Aug. 3, 2013. Mom you would have turned 91 today. We miss you dearly and think of you always. Your sons, Kim & Paul 1/3

PAULUS--Karl Heinrich, 79, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died on September 3, 2015 after a very brief illness. Beloved husband of Eva, devoted father of Caroline (Kurt) Schreder and Kristine (Kevin) Wojnovich, treasured grandfather of Julia, Davis, Natalie, Eva, Matthew, and Brady. In lieu of flowers, donations to the World Wildlife Fund. 1/3

SIMON--Dina, age 72, died September 7, 2015 after a lengthy illness. Dina loved to help and serve others which was evident from her 30 year career at the U.N. including three peace keeping missions abroad. As a member of the U.N. Women's Guild, she helped many children around the world. Dina was a strong, independent woman who lived her life her way and continuously found creative ways of being thoughtful and generous with her family and friends. Dina's passions included world travel, fashion and spending time with treasured family and friends. Survived by her sister and several nieces, nephews and grand-nephews. She will be missed by her family and friends. Services 1pm at the Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ. 1/3

ISRAEL--Gayle. Gayle was a strong, compassionate and wise woman. As a beloved Nonie, wife, mother, daughter and sister she inspired us. KAUFMAN--Dr. Richard J. Dr. Richard J. Kaufman, died on Monday, September 7, 2015 at the age of 90. Born on August 5th, 1925, to Dr. Julius and Gertrude Kaufman in Brooklyn, NY, he attended Boys High and Harvard College, interrupted by service in World War II as a combat infantryman in the European theater. Upon completion of his degree at Harvard he entered the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, receiving his M.D. degree in 1952. After residency training in internal medicine at the Texas VA Hospital in Dallas, he joined Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases as a fellow in medical oncology and remained there on the attending staff of the Breast Service for his entire career. He was an expert clinician and teacher, much appreciated by his patients, for whom he cared deeply. His research in modes of treatment of breast cancer resulted in over 40 published papers. Married in 1953 to his classmate and beloved wife, Dr. Katherine Lobach (Kaufman), he was the devoted father of three children, James L. Kaufman (m. Carol Fitzpatrick), Susan Kaufman (m. Shawn Young), and John R. Kaufman (m. Kathryn Poulos), and grandfather to Alicia, Alexandra, Kristen, Ricky, and Nicole (Kaufman), step-grandfather to James, Kyle, and Lauren (Fitzpatrick), and brother to the late Jane Weinstock. A lover of music, photography, and travel, he was recognized by all for his quick wit and sense of humor, along with his warm and affectionate personality. He will be sorely missed by family, friends and everyone who knew him. Memorial Visitation will be held at the Geo. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, New York (914-632-0324), on Wednesday, September 9, 2015 and Thursday, September 10, 2015 from 6pm-8pm. On Friday, September 11, 2015, at 11am there will be a Memorial Service at the Geo. T. Davis Funeral Home. The family requests in lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his name to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. 1/3

ROTHBERG--Dr. Gerald Morris, passed away on June 23, 2015 following a brief illness. Please join family, friends, and colleagues at a memorial event honoring Dr. Rothberg this Wednesday, September 9th, from 4 to 6pm in the Babbio Center at Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, NJ. 1/3

BREINDEL--Sonia, daughter of Meir and Dina Weissenberg (nee Lunevitch), sister of Sasha Weissenberg, died on September 2, 2015. She was 92. Sonia was born in Luxembourg and survived the Holocaust, escaping from internment camps, hiding in Marseille, before eventually fleeing to Switzerland with her mother. Her father perished at Auschwitz; her brother disappeared. Sonia trained as an interpreter in Geneva, and worked for O.R.T. in Paris, before coming to New York in 1952. There she met and fell in love with Joseph Breindel, an OB-GYN, originally from Zablotow, a small town in what is now Ukraine. They married and had two children, Eric (born 1955), a journalist, who died in 1998, and Monique (born 1954), a doctor. In New York, Sonia worked as an interpreter (she spoke Italian, French, German and English), progressive educator (she received her BA from Goddard and her Masters from Bank Street), gallery assistant, and in recent years as a volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. More importantly, she was passionate about the arts and culture -- music (she had a beautiful voice); opera; paintings; sculpture; theater; and literature -- and a world traveler. Sonia was also an adoring and adored mother and grandmother, quintessential New Yorker (for all that she was also quite European), and perpetual intellectual sparring partner. Sonia, the Queen of Sheba, is survived by her daughter, Monique, her son-in-law Jonathan, her three grandchildren, Hannah, Naomi and Sarah Rose, and friends and family of all ages, who loved hervery much and will miss her tremendously. 1/3

ROTHBERG--Dr. Gerald Morris. Passed away on June 23, 2015 following a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Elaine, by his children, Roshanna and Rei, and by his grandchildren, Samantha, Ian, Erica, Marina, and Daniel. He was deeply loved. Dr. Rothberg was born in Atlantic City, NJ, on May 14, 1931, the second son of Harry and Sarah. He developed a profound fascination with the mysteries of the universe as a child that would guide the rest of his life. Jerry was a star athlete and Westinghouse honoree at Atlantic City High School, and attended MIT on an academic scholarship, earning money over the summers selling ice cream on the beach. It was during this halcyon period that Jerry met and fell in love with Elaine Sophie Williams, a summa cum laude graduate of Philadelphia's Girls High and soon-to-be of Temple University. Jerry and Elaine married in 1954, shortly after he returned from a year spent in Paris as a Fulbright scholar and traveling poet with an Irish circus troupe. They both attended graduate school at Columbia University, where Gerald earned his Ph.D. in physics as a student of Dr. I.I. Rabi and a doctoral advisee of Dr. Polycarp Cush. Dr. Rothberg had a long and distinguished career teaching and conducting research at Stevens Institute of Technology, where he was George Meade Bond Professor of Materials Science and Engineering and head of the Materials Science and Engineering department, Director of the Cryogenics Center and Director of the Program on Science and Engineering Aspects of Materials Surfaces. He was also a Senior Fellow of the American Physical Society. During his career, Dr. Rothberg accepted many opportunities to conduct research and train graduate students at universities and laboratories in the U.S., and throughout Europe and Asia, notably in Japan where he held the Nippon Steel Corporation Chair of Advanced Materials at the University of Tokyo. He was a thoughtful and inspiring teacher and many of his graduate students have gone on to important academic and industrial positions. Jerry and Elaine shared a deep love of travel, and a deeper love of family, and often found creative ways to combine the two. They travelled the world, delving into its remotest corners, frequently with children or grandchildren in tow, making up playful songs and games along the way. They visited every continent and travelled through almost a hundred countries, making friends everywhere. Dr. Rothberg will be remembered by all who knew him for his kindness, wisdom, humor, and his great love of life. 1/3

BLAIR--The Hon. William McCormick Jr.,98, was a long time public servant, and colleague of Adlai E. Stevenson and John F. Kennedy. In the 1960s, he served as Ambassador to Denmark, Ambassador to the Philippines, and the first General Director of the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington D.C. In the 1940s and 1950's, he was senior advisor and assistant to Adlai E. Stevenson when Stevenson was Governor of Illinois, and Democratic candidate for President in 1952 and 1956. Stevenson often said that Blair was indispensable. After his service as Ambassador, Blair was elected head of the Council of American Ambassadors in Washington D.C. Known for his impeccable style and passion for movies and politics, Blair was often consulted for his nuanced perceptions on coming elections. He followed all of the candidates' histories and progress with the same ardor he gave to every news station. He was a graduate of Stanford University and the University of Virginia Law School, and was an Air Corps officer in World War II in the China-Burma-India theater and awarded the Bronze Star. He became Stevenson's key assistant when Stevenson was elected Governor of Illinois in 1948. In Stevenson's two national campaigns and later, he traveled with Stevenson in 50 states and 64 countries. He played a top role in bringing Stevenson and John F. Kennedy together in Kennedy's 1960 campaign. Bill Blair joined the Kennedy administration in 1961. After Stevenson was defeated by President Eisenhower, he joined Stevenson in 1955 in a new law firm in Chicago including W. Willard Wirtz and Newton N. Minow, which later became part of the New York firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton and Garrison. After Kennedy became President, the President appointed Stevenson Ambassador to the United Nations, Wirtz as Undersecretary and later Secretary of Labor, Blair as Ambassador to Denmark, and Minow as Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. Stevenson said, "I regret having only one law firm to give to my country." In recognition for service in Denmark, Blair received the Commander's Cross of the Order of the Dannebrog, First Class, and from the Philippines the Order of Sikatuna, Rank of Commander. Growing up in Chicago, he was deeply influenced by his grandmother, Louise DeKoven Bowen, who worked very closely with Jane Addams to help the underprivileged. Known for his profound social conscience, Bill cared deeply about civil and human rights and was a man who treated everyone with dignity. He was also deeply concerned about animal welfare and insisted on only owning shelter dogs. Ambassador Blair was preceded in death by his son, William, and is survived by his wife of more than 53 years, Deeda, in New York. Died Saturday, August 29 and the service will be private. If desired, contributions in his memory may be made to William Blair III Fund, the Washington Humane Society, 4590 Mac Arthur Boulevard, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20007. 1/3

VAUPEN--Burton. Born in New York on the 28th of April, 1930 to Alex and Betty Vaupen, passed away on the 31st of August, 2015 in the company of his wife Frederika and daughter Jill. Burton was raised with his younger brother, Jack, in a one bedroom doorman apartment on the Grand Concourse. He attended P.S. 46, Dewitt Clinton High School and graduated from Columbia University with a degree in Fine Arts. Burt paid his way through college by working at a resort in the Catskills. He began his career as an NBC page, where he first became enamored with companies which combined creativity with corporate know- how. In the 1950s, Burt was hired by Young & Rubicam and began a thirty-year career in advertising, taking him from New York City to San Francisco and Sydney, Australia, where he rose from a corporate financial executive to Treasurer Worldwide and finally, Chief Financial Officer for the company. In 1983 when Dentsu merged with Young & Rubicam to form DYR in Los Angeles, Burt came aboard as Executive Vice President and Administrative Officer, and moved his family to the west coast. After DYR, Burton parlayed his expertise in cutting costs and raising profits by taking a job as a Corporate Finance Executive for the film and television company, Lorimar Telepictures. In addition to his very successful career, Burt also pursued many other passions. A truly talented chef, he loved bringing people together for home-cooked gourmet meals, whether in his kitchen in Saddle River, New Jersey or in his dream home on the Caribbean island of Anguilla, where, an ardent captain and fisherman, he often caught the main dish himself. After retiring from corporate life, Burton became bicoastal, splitting his time between Santa Fe, New Mexico and Anguilla. The Southwestern landscape and culture, local food and artistry were a much-welcomed change for the native New Yorker who was an avid fan and big supporter of the Santa Fe opera. One of Burts greatest pleasures was surprising Frederika, his wife of 44 years (married December 31, 1971), with exotic trips, including climbing Mt. Kilimanjaro, Patagonia, Machu Picchu, The Orient Express, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, and Fiji to name a few. He loved to share the gift of travel, and when he lived in Australia it opened the doors for the whole family to visit parts of the world they might have never seen. Burton will always be remembered for his quiet disposition, wry sense of humor and impeccable sense of style. An avid photographer, he captured candid moments and created picture books for all to enjoy. Close family and friends remember Burton as a patient, diligent and introspective perfectionist as well as an epicurean with a passion for adventure. A man of few words, he had a kind heart and generous spirit. His philanthropy extended to making charitable donations to numerous homeless and orphanage groups. Burt is survived by his wife Frederika, a brother Jack, his children Robert, Susan, Pamela, Paul and Jill; and ten grandchildren. 1/3

LEVINSON--Patricia S. The Trustees, Faculty, Students, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our longtime friend Patricia S. Levinson, an extraordinary philanthropist whose commitment to Mount Sinai was deep and abiding. A cherished member of the Boards of Trustees since 1981, Pat brought insights and generosity that touched many areas of the Health System. She was a champion of students, and her personal commitment included the creation of the Robert and Patricia Levinson Student Center, and the endowment of scholarships and fellowships at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. Pat also co-chaired the advisory board of the Center for Multicultural Affairs, was a member of The Mount Sinai Hospital's Auxiliary Board, and supported nursing, social services, and Linkage House, a home for the elderly. Her son, Drew, created the ADS-Dreams Come True Fund, which raises funds for terminally ill children at the Hospital. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Pat's husband, Robert, her children, Margot, John, and Drew, and the entire Levinson family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System 1/3

ENTEN--Judge Harold. The Honorable Harold Enten, former Supervising Judge of the Bronx Criminal Court and former Chief of the Supreme Court Bureau of the Bronx District Attorney's Office, died at home on September 9, 2015. Judge Enten was born in Manhattan to Molly and Louis Enten. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 30 years, Dr. Barbara E. Strassberg, and their wonderful and much loved children Louise and Harry, future son Dan, sister-in-law and brother-in- law, Leba and Neil Sedaka, cousins, nieces and nephews, as well as numerous friends and former colleagues. He was a voracious reader and loved discussing Samuel Johnson and Winston Churchill. He loved baseball and Bobby Thomson, but hated the Yankees. He will be sorely missed. Services Friday, September 11, 2015, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St, at 11:15 am. 1/3

FISHKIN--Harold. Died on September 9, 2015. Loving husband of 68 years to Rhoda, devoted father of Michael (Ellen) Fishkin and Michelle (Jerry) Levine, adored grandfather of three grandchildren, three great- grandchildren and dear brother of Bernard. Retired from the Upjohn Co. The patriarch of his family. 1/3

RAIMI--Shepherd. Died September 8, 2015 at home in New York City. Born Detroit, MI, April 6, 1931 to Jacob and Sylvia Raimi. Graduate of Cornell University 1952 and Harvard Law School 1955. Member of the New York Bar. Served with the United States Army 1956-57, stationed in Korea. Worked for Citibank in Japan 1958-60 and worked on Asian business matters at The Bank of New York throughout the 1960's. Was admitted to the New York Bar in 1970. Founding Member of Board of Directors of Lambda Legal Defense 1972. Member of the Board of Trustees of Alcoholics Anonymous 1985-89 and Chairman of AA World Services 1986-87. 1/3
MEYERHOFF--Inge. (nee Zuber). Passed on September 9, 2002. She was a most generous and caring person to all who knew her. Erich Meyerhoff 1/3

VANCE--Susan 85, of New York City, died peacefully at home in Manhattan, September 8. Beloved wife of the late Gordon R. Vance, who passed earlier this year at 89. She is survived by her loving daughter Kathleen Vance and son-in-law John Bianchi, beloved granddaughters Julia and Dinah Bianchi, of Greenwich Village; her devoted sister Jenny Krevolin and brother-in-law Lewis Krevolin of Rhinebeck, NY, and many much-loved nephews, nieces and cousins. A graduate of Hunter College and Pratt Institute, her career as a rare female package designer in the toy industry, and later in media and retail design, brought her great personal satisfaction. In her later life, she devoted her time to her grandchildren, to volunteering as an English-language tutor, and to the community of Davis Park, Fire Island. She will be greatly missed by all. A private family service will be held in the near future. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Vivian. Her children Allan, Stacey and Glenn are inconsolably sad to advise those who knew her, that as of Monday past, Vivian (Gail Tobias) has exited her mortal coil. Also survived by her three loving grandchildren, Hannah, Henry, Evie and myriad friends and extended family. Services today 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

LEVINSON--Patricia S. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of our long- time board member and vice chairman, an exceptional woman and champion of hospitals, health care innovation and improvement, and voluntarism in New York City. Committed to a vision of patient-centered health care and equal access to the highest quality of care, Pat was unwavering in her support of UHF's mission for more than 20 years. Her wise counsel and candor, strong values, and great energy and focus were complemented by her charm, warmth, and infectious good humor. She has made a lasting imprint on UHF and will be remembered with respect and affection, and greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband Bob and her children. J. Barclay Collins II, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr., President 1/3

GOLS--John. Gentleman, Veteran and ABS Real Estate Executive passes away. John Gols, a true gentleman, loved and respected by all who knew him has passed away at the age of 82. He is survived by his wife Joan, children Jean, Susan and John as well as his sister Anita and his 11 grandchildren. John served in the US Navy aboard the USS Hornet and thereafter began his real estate career as a leasing broker with Helmsley Spear. John worked at Helmsley Spear for more than 35 years, responsible for the leasing of many prominent buildings within their portfolio. Eventually he anchored his experience with ABS Partners Real Estate as one of their top Executives. During his 16 year tenure with ABS, John negotiated countless agreements and leases and managed a large portfolio of commercial real estate. He was a mentor to many in the firm and epitomized the company motto of 'Building Partnerships that last'. His thoughtfulness, kindness and good nature will certainly be missed by all of those who touched his life as well as those he touched. John was truly a "guys guy". Our thoughts and prayers are with Joan and the family. May he rest in peace, Earle S. Altman Gregg L. Schenker Peter Burack Steven Hornstock Jason Fein Gary Forster and the ABS Partners Real Estate Family 1/3

SYKES--Dr. Joyce Jones, model, actress, drama therapist, died September 7, 2015. Survived by husband Dr. Wilbert R. Sykes, sons Derek and Drew, four grandchildren and twin sister Dr. Janet Laidman. Services will held on Friday, September 11th at 6pm at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, NY. 1/3

SACKS--Oliver, M.D. The staff, trustees and Fellows of The New York Academy of Medicine mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Dr. Oliver Sacks. A gifted neurologist, Oliver was keenly attuned to the lives of his patients. A man of wide-ranging interests and curiosity, his writing conveyed the fascination of medicine to audiences everywhere. We send our condolences to Oliver's partner, Bill Hayes, to his longtime assistant, Kate Edgar, and to his extended family. 1/3

PERLMUTTER--Sue. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the passing on Tuesday, September 8th of Sue Perlmutter, beloved wife of our friend and partner Marc E. Perlmutter. We express our deepest sympathies to Marc and their children, Eric and Dara and to all other members of the family. 1/3

HOROWITZ--Tina, (nee Ladimer) of West Palm Beach, Florida, died on September 7, 2015. A native of New York City, a graduate of NYU (1948), and former resident of Woodbury, New York, she was an accomplished artist and sculptress, loving wife of Morris Horowitz for 67 years, mother to Victor, Sheldon and Loreen (Blumenthal) and grandmother to eight devoted grandchildren. 1/3

LEVINSON--Patricia S. Our sincerest condolences to Bob, his children Margot, John and Drew and grandchildren. Pat was an extraordinary woman who we will missed for her friendship, kindness, wit and empathy. Her wise leadership on Mount Sinai's Center were multi cultural and community affairs was inspiring. Diane and Fin Fogg 1/3

LEVINSON--Patricia S. Known for her summertime straw hat and roll-up-your-sleeves work attitude, Patricia Schulte Levinson died at Mount Sinai Hospital on September 8th after a brief but heroic fight with cancer. She had been active in board work and non-profit affiliations, especially as a Trustee of the Mount Sinai Healthcare System, and was a lifelong New Yorker, a lover of the arts and culture, and who enjoyed spending time with her family and in the summers at her Long Island home. Pat was the daughter of Arthur D. Schulte and Luise Meyer Schulte. She graduated from the Spence School and attended Connecticut College and Columbia University before marrying Robert A. Levinson in 1954. Pat joined the Boards of Trustees of Mount Sinai Hospital in 1981 when she was named President of the Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board, a group she first joined in 1961. Pat served on several of the hospital's board committees both as a member and chair; most recently on the Patient Care and Quality Assurance, Medical Education and Community Relations Committees. Board members grew to anticipate receiving articles and clippings from her, all on recycled paper and all pertinent to the issues of the day. For many years she also served as a Board liaison to the Nursing Department. Pat had been co-chair of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai's Center for Multicultural and Community Affairs (CMCA) Advisory Board since its inception. A champion of students, her personal commitment included the creation of the Robert and Patricia Levinson Student Center, and the endowment of scholarships and fellowships at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. She was a founding member and vice president of New York City's New Alternatives for Children (NAC) where she helped children move from hospitals to loving homes, a director of Linkage House, and vice chair of the United Hospital Fund, as well as a member of Health First's Board of Managers of Senior Health Partners and a former trustee of the Blythedale Children's Hospital. Pat brought friends from all parts of her life to help grow these important causes - whether through raising awareness or opening her home for salon gatherings - always with her famous cheese crackers. She was the recipient of a United Hospital Fund Distinguished Trustee Award for her leadership, guidance, and extraordinary service to Mount Sinai as well as The Jacobi Medallion, awarded by The Mount Sinai Alumni, in recognition of her distinguished service to the Hospital and the School. An involved New Yorker, Pat enjoyed the city in particular ballet, music, theater and all the arts, and made certain that her multitude of friends shared her pleasures. Pat was a devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many. She was respected for her energy, work ethic and her vast knowledge of the health care issues she worked so diligently to address in her Mount Sinai, NAC and UHF board work. Pat, born in 1933, is survived by her husband of 61 years, Robert A. Levinson, her daughter Margot and two sons, Andrew and John as well as their spouses: John Ganz, Jr, Karen Levinson, and Ronna Levinson. Pat and Bob have five grandsons: Craig, Jamie, Kyle, Jack and Dean. Pat was pre-deceased by her brother Anthony M. Schulte. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to New Alternatives for Children and/or the Patricia Levinson Scholarship Fund, CMCA, at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 24th at 5pm in the Leo C. Stern Auditorium, Annenberg Building, Mount Sinai. Reception to follow. Funeral services will be private. 1/3

HAMMETT--Cynthia Hull, artist and arts patron, opera lover, animal rescuer, global traveler, chef and hostess extraordinaire, passed away on Tuesday, September 8, 2015, after battling courageously for three months complications of ovarian cancer at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. Cynthia, 75, was the daughter of the late Peggy and the late John Hammett. She had an incredible career in communications, journalism and art. Cynthia was born in New York City and raised in New Jersey, mostly in Summit and Bay Head. For the past 25 years, Cynthia lived with her husband, Richard A. Russack, in Fort Worth, Texas, New Harbor, Maine, and since 2008, they had an apartment in New York City. Cynthia graduated from the Kent Place School, and earned her B.A. and M.A. degrees in art history and urban planning at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. She was awarded a Fullbright Scholarship to study at the University of Florence, a Kresge Fellowship for study at the Courtauld Institute of Art in London and the London School of Economics. Ms. Hammett began her communications career with the Prudential Life Insurance Company, and also worked with Chase and was the director of communications for Philip Morris International for 10 years, producing brochures, films and managing the Company's Art Exhibition Program in various capitals of the world. She briefly worked for Planned Parenthood International in New York, before becoming managing editor of the Block Island Times, where she and Richard lived for nearly 20 years. It was in 2000, when she and her husband began building their New Harbor home that Cynthia started oil painting under the guidance of the late John Urbain, a friend and noted collage and oil painter. She took classes at Texas Christian University in Fort Worth under now retired professor of art Jim Woodson, who was the 2014 Texas Artist of the Year. She also has exhibited at numerous galleries and art centers in Fort Worth and mid-coast Maine. Her paintings are a part of collections throughout the United States and Europe. In addition to her husband and their pets, Paolo, Lucia, Raven and Boris, Cynthia's survivors include: sister Elizabeth Taggart and husband, Bill; brother Peter and wife, Prudence; nephews Chris Nolan and wife Carolyn, and children, Morgan and Ian, and Peter Hammett and wife Kristy, and daughter Lucille; nieces Hilary Cohen and son Patrick Penlington, and Priscilla Vincent and husband Rob, and children, Hadley and Cooper; and numerous cousins. Additionally, Cynthia had great influence on the lives of Richard's three children: son Eric and wife Amy; daughter Robin and husband Jim Brown; and son Evan and wife Kelly; and their children, Will, Chloe, Claire and Kate Russack; Samantha, Scott and Ted Brown; and Trevor and Lucas Russack. Cynthia's ashes will be buried in New Harbor. 1/3

LEVINSON--Patricia. The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board mourns the passing of our greatly esteemed member, Patricia A. Levinson. Pat was a pillar of the Auxiliary Board who exemplified our mission to provide compassionate patient care and education to the Mount Sinai community. Her insight, wisdom, generosity as well as her longtime commitment to our Board will be greatly missed. Her stellar example of service was seen throughout the community. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family, friends, and colleagues. Jennifer Price, President The Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board 1/3

HAMMETT--Cynthia Hull, artist and arts patron, opera lover, animal rescuer, global traveler, chef and hostess extraordinaire, passed away on Tuesday, September 8, 2015, after battling courageously for three months complications of ovarian cancer at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. Cynthia, 75, was the daughter of the late Peggy and the late John Hammett. She had an incredible career in communications, journalism and art. Cynthia was born in New York City and raised in New Jersey, mostly in Summit and Bay Head. For the past 25 years, Cynthia lived with her husband, Richard A. Russack, in Fort Worth, Texas, New Harbor, Maine, and since 2008, they had an apartment in New York City. Cynthia graduated from the Kent Place School, and earned her B.A. and M.A. degrees in art history and urban planning at the University of Wisconsin, Madison. She was awarded a Fullbright Scholarship to study at the University of Florence, a Kresge Fellowship for study at the Courtauld Institute of Art in London and the London School of Economics. Ms. Hammett began her communications career with the Prudential Life Insurance Company, and also worked with Chase and was the director of communications for Philip Morris International for 10 years, producing brochures, films and managing the Company's Art Exhibition Program in various capitals of the world. She briefly worked for Planned Parenthood International in New York, before becoming managing editor of the Block Island Times, where she and Richard lived for nearly 20 years. It was in 2000, when she and her husband began building their New Harbor home that Cynthia started oil painting under the guidance of the late John Urbain, a friend and noted collage and oil painter. She took classes at Texas Christian University in Fort Worth under now retired professor of art Jim Woodson, who was the 2014 Texas Artist of the Year. She also has exhibited at numerous galleries and art centers in Fort Worth and mid-coast Maine. Her paintings are a part of collections throughout the United States and Europe. In addition to her husband and their pets, Paolo, Lucia, Raven and Boris, Cynthia's survivors include: sister Elizabeth Taggart and husband, Bill; brother Peter and wife, Prudence; nephews Chris Nolan and wife Carolyn, and children, Morgan and Ian, and Peter Hammett and wife Kristy, and daughter Lucille; nieces Hilary Cohen and son Patrick Penlington, and Priscilla Vincent and husband Rob, and children, Hadley and Cooper; and numerous cousins. Additionally, Cynthia had great influence on the lives of Richard's three children: son Eric and wife Amy; daughter Robin and husband Jim Brown; and son Evan and wife Kelly; and their children, Will, Chloe, Claire and Kate Russack; Samantha, Scott and Ted Brown; and Trevor and Lucas Russack. Cynthia's ashes will be buried in New Harbor. 1/3

RUDOLPH--Barbara (Adelman), of New York City, formerly of Philadelphia, PA and Longport, NJ died on September 10, 2015. Barbara was the daughter of the late Bea and Sol Adelman and beloved mother of Emily, Brad, Suzanne, loving Bubby to Levi and cherished friends. Whether it was solving a New York Times crossword puzzle in record time, entertaining, writing, beading, baking, cooking, accessorizing . . . she excelled. As a mature techie she patiently brow beat her same age friends into staying current with new technical skills. Her turn of phrase and sense of humor was unmatched. We will remember and miss Barbara; this beautiful woman who made us laugh till it hurt and left us much too soon. Services at Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., (91st St.), Friday, September 11th at 2pm. 1/3

WARD--Renee J.,passed away peacefully on September 9th. As one of three women in Columbia Law School's graduating class of 1957, Renee began her legal career as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York. She will be remembered as a zealous advocate with a long history of public service and devotion to many charitable causes. Adored mother of Lawrence, Jonathan, and Lauren Roberts, loving sister of Karen, and devoted grandmother of Molly and Jackson. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., at 9:30am on Sunday, September 13th. 1/3

HALLAC --Charles. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Charles Hallac, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Charles's parents, Linda and David; his beloved wife, Sara Wolf; his brothers, Jimmy and Daniel; his children, David, Rebecca, and A.J. ; and entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

DeBIASI--Ralph Michael, Jr.,a resident of East Rockaway, New York, passed away quietly in his summer home in Stonington, Connecticut on Tuesday, September 8, 2015. Born in Brooklyn on June 30, 1946, the son of Ralph Michael DeBiasi Sr. and Ida DeBiasi, he was near the water all of his life. His passion for sailing started at a young age with his first boat, a sunfish, where he first experienced the joy of the water. He attended Lynbrook High School and NYU where he studied finance and accounting. Over the years, he developed and maintained many meaningful family and personal relationships. In his last few years, he returned "home" to be closer to the family homestead in Noank. Ralph enjoyed sitting on the front porch of his grandfather's home and would frequently say, "Who would ever leave this place?" For all his contributions, Ralph was generous, jolly and had a great sense of humor. Ralph enjoyed going to Block Island by boat or with his bike. Over the last few years The Stonington Yacht Club was a fun place for Ralph to laugh, eat and have good times with his friends. He leaves his beloved wife and partner of 38 years, Mary DeBiasi; his two children, Nancy DeBiasi Gillen of Rockville Centre, NY (Peter Gillen), Ralph DeBiasi III (Erin Murphy DeBiasi) and grandson, Connor DeBiasi. Farewell Dad...fair winds and following seas! Calling hours will be held Today from 5-8pm at the Mystic Funeral Home on Route 1 in Mystic, CT. A funeral mass will be celebrated Saturday, September 12th at 10am at St. Mary Mother of the Redeemer Church, 69 Groton Long Point Rd., Groton. Burial will follow at the Noank Valley Cemetery in Noank on Route 215. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his memory to the Noank Historical Society, 17 Sylvan St., Noank, CT 06340. The family invites you to visit: mysticfuneralhome.com to leave an online expression of sympathy. 1/3

LANDSBERG--Carol Lee, passed away on September 8, 2015. She was born November 4, 1932. Carol is a beloved wife, mother and grandmother. She will be dearly missed. Carol is survived by her husband of 64 years, Norman; her sons, Jeffrey, Barry, and Jonathan; and her seven grandchildren. She inspired us. 1/3

MALCOLM--Barbara Hamilton. Formerly of Nantucket, MA, Montclair, NJ and Vero Beach, FL died September 8, 2015 in Washington, DC. Reighley and Peter C. Malcolm. 1/3

WARD--Renee. The board and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services acknowledge with profound sadness the death of long-time trustee Renee Ward. Renee became a trustee in 1992 and served as Vice President, chair of the Early Childhood and Board Governance committees, and as a member of countless other committees during her long and illustrious tenure. She also served on the board of The Shield Institute, an affiliate of The Jewish Board, including as president and chair. Renee rarely missed a meeting; her thoughtful questions and deep passion for our work will be sorely missed. We send our condolences to her entire family. 1/3

LACHMAN--Judith Lehman, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died peacefully on September 9th, just a few days past her 94th birthday. Her passionate devotion to her family lives on in her sons, Bob and Charles Lachman and her grandchildren, Amy, Elly and Peter. She was predeceased in death by husband, Lawrence, brother E. Barry Lehman and granddaughter, Jill. 1/3
DARVIN--Renee. Remembering . . . Love is a destiny. We don't find love alone. Always, love Jerry 1/3

BRENER--Dr. Jacob L. Sol Goldman Investments and the Goldman family express deepest condolences to the family of Dr. Jacob L. Brener, father of our dear friend, long time employee and confidant, Judy Brener Grumet. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Brener family during this difficult time. 1/3
SHANKS--Nelson. We knew you once; we will remember you always. Daniel & Barbara Liberman 1/3

REISER--Richard J. After bravely enduring a long illness, Richard died on August 31st. Former husband of Lois Larkey, he was brilliant, funny, loving and generous. We will miss his adventurous spirit and think of him often. Donations may be made to the National Parkinson's Disease Foundation. 1/3

WARD--Renee J. The Shield Institute mourns the loss of the Chair of its Board, Renee J. Ward. Renee devoted herself tirelessly to the mission of The Shield, having served over the years in multiple roles, including Vice President, President, and Member of the Audit, Pension Plan, Executive Compensation, and Nominations Committees. Whenever there was a call for a volunteer, Renee was always ready, willing, and able to serve. All of the Members of The Shield Board and its Executive Management Team will truly miss Renee's thoughtful and probing questions, her intellectual curiosity, enthusiasm, warmth, and outgoing personality, and extend our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolence to the members of Renee's family. 1/3

WIND--Shirley. We will miss Aunt Shirley's humor, love, support, and wisdom. She always made you feel special, whether you were a family member, friend, or stranger. She loved New York City and the Yankees. With much love, The Fischler Family 1/3

DeBIASI--Ralph M.,Jr., of East Rockaway, NY and Stonington, CT. Beloved husband, father, and brother. Peacefully, in Stonington, near his cherished Noank. Survived by his wife Mary, daughter Nancy Gillen (Pete), son Ralph, III (Erin Murphy), sister Adele Pelz (Sanford), grandson Connor, soon-to-arrive grandchild, and two nephews, Jonathan and Christopher Pelz. 1/3
LEVIN--Neil. In beloved memory of my son Neil and the men and women who perished with him on 9/11/01. My love never fades. Gloria Levin 1/3

DeBIASI--Ralph M.,Jr., of East Rockaway, NY and Stonington, CT. Beloved husband, father, and brother. Peacefully, in Stonington, near his cherished Noank. Survived by his wife Mary, daughter Nancy Gillen (Pete), son Ralph, III (Erin Murphy), sister Adele Pelz (Sanford), grandson Connor, soon-to-arrive grandchild, and two nephews, Jonathan and Christopher Pelz. 1/3

FALCONE--Libby, passed away on September 10, 2015 at the age of 91 in Westerly, RI. She was the loving wife of the late Alphonse F. Falcone of Brooklyn, NY. She is survived by a daughter, Madeline Previti and her husband Anthony of Westerly, RI; a son, Alphonse Falcone and his husband Paul (Rozario-Falcone) of Brooklyn, NY. She is also survived by her greatly loved grandchildren Libby Previti of Chicago, Frank Previti and his wife Aubrey of Providence, RI, their three children, Mikaela, Kimberly and Cole, and many much loved nieces, nephews and cousins. She was widowed early, but she refused to be defined by hardships. She was the life of every party. By her example, she showed friends and family how to defiantly seize life with gusto and courage. She will be remembered for her remarkable sense of humor, generosity, wisdom, modern thinking and a life force that filled a room. Visitation will be at Scotto Funeral Home, 106 First Place, Brooklyn, Saturday 7-9pm, Sunday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Monday, St. Agnes RC Church at 9:45am. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. 1/3

WARD--Renee. We mourn the passing of our dear companion and friend, Renee Ward. She was a loving, dynamic and engaging person who brightened our lives. We will all miss her. Bill Lippman and Family 1/3
MALARIK--Emilia. March 8, 1931 to September 7, 2015. Beloved mother of Peter and Dr. Paul Malarik Jr. Cherished mother-in-law of Linda Malarik. We love you more than the entire Universe! 1/3

WARD-- Renee. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Renee Ward, longtime partner of our devoted trustee, Bill Lippman. Renee had an abiding love for humanity and a passion for justice - she made a difference in the lives of those who knew her. Together, she and Bill have championed excellence and compassion in healthcare, among many other benevolent causes. We are grateful for their innumerable contributions to the Gold Foundation that have improved the delivery of healthcare across the nation. We extend our sympathy and love to Bill and to Renee's entire family, especially her treasured children and grandchildren. She will be dearly missed. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D. Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D. President/CEO 1/3

HALLAC--Charles. YRF Darca mourns the loss of longtime supporter Charlie Hallac. Over the past 25 years Charlie and his family have understood and embraced the issues facing the education system in Israel. They have been critical and generous in supporting our mission. Our thoughts and prayers are with Sarah, David, Rebecca and A.J. at this difficult time. Marc Rowan, Chairman; Paul Schnell, President; Sam Katz, CEO 1/3

Reighley and Peter C. Malcolm. 1/3

WARD--Renee J.,passed away peacefully on September 9th. As one of three women in Columbia Law School's graduating class of 1957, Renee began her legal career as an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York. She will be remembered as a zealous advocate with a long history of public service and devotion to many charitable causes. Adored mother of Lawrence, Jonathan, and Lauren Roberts, loving sister of Karen, and devoted grandmother of Molly and Jackson. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., at 9:30am on Sunday, September 13th. 1/3

BRAM--William B. May 25, 1927. Beloved husband, father, grandfather died peacefully in his sleep on September 11. He was a devoted and loving family man and passionate in any endeavor he undertook. He worked at Merrill Lynch for almost 55 years, investing in the stock market. He loved sports and particularly golf in the last 20 years. He travelled the world and loved fine dining. He was a serious and focused man yet he possessed a wry sense of humor. He will be sorely missed, but we take comfort that he had a full and interesting life. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Jane Eisner Bram, his three children, Judith Bram Murphy, Steven Eisner Bram (Miriam), and Elizabeth Bram Rothstein (Eric) and six grandchildren: Jessica, Leila, Joshua, Danielle, Zoe, and Kacy. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, September 13 at 11:00am. 1/3
WEINER--Adam Samuel. November 8, 1976 - September 12, 1990. Courageous, extraordinary boy. Cherished son of Susan and Jonathan, brother of Joanna. 1/3

CLEMENTS--Philip J.,62, of Chester, NJ passed away on September 8th. Phil's illustrious career started at Coopers and Lybrand, continued at PricewaterhouseCoopers and culminated as Executive Vice President of Standard & Poor's. Phil went on to co-found Cathedral Consulting Group, LLC and found Calyx Capital Advisors, LLC; The Center for Christian Business Ethics Today, LLC; Academic Development Consulting, LLC; and PJC Real Estate, LLC. He earned a J.D. from the University of Puget Sound School of Law, an L.L.M. in Taxation from NYU School of Law and a Masters in Theological Studies from RTS. He is survived by his wife, Julie, his three daughters and their husbands, two grandchildren with a third expected, his mother, his brother and his wife, and his sister. Funeral services can be found at www.higginsfuneralhome. com. 1/3

HELLER--Susan, 87, died September 10, 2015, survived by devoted husband Leon, children Michael (Heli) and Stephen (Evelyn), five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Graduate of Hunter College '48, Susan was a wonderful musician, librarian, dog lover and world traveler with her husband of 68 years. She will be remembered as a beautiful, classy and good hearted friend, mother and wife. Funeral 9:00am, Sunday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

WARD--Renee J. Beloved mother of Lawrence, Jonathan, and Lauren Roberts. Devoted grandmother of Molly and Jackson. Loving sister of Karen and Robert Freedman. STEIN--Thekla Nordwind. Dear Thekla, gone too soon. Love, Natalie 1/3

LESSER--John, 87 years old, passed away on September 11, 2015. Beloved husband of Jean. Devoted father of Ellen Sangiamo and her husband Dino and Robert Lesser and his wife Beth Harwood. Cherished grandfather of Nicholas, Daniel and Jason Sangiamo. Dearest brother of Anne Abeles. Services Sunday, September 13, 2015 at 12 noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York. Donations may be made to The Founder's Society of North Shore -LIJ Health System. 1/3

PLUNKETT--Caryl D. Faith, family, friends: These were the cornerstones of the life of Caryl Donnelly Plunkett. A generous and devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many, Caryl passed away peacefully on September 9th, 2015 surrounded by her family. Caryl was a ray of light and a beacon of strength and energy. She lived each day to its fullest, even as she fought cancer these last ten years. Originally from Plantsville, CT, Caryl graduated from Marymount College in Tarrytown, New York. She returned to Tarrytown soon after graduation when she married William F. Plunkett Jr. and stayed for 48 years to raise their six children. She was an accomplished businesswoman, public servant and active charitable volunteer. She has been honored on several occasions for her accomplishments and good works. Marymount College awarded Caryl both the Gloria Gaines and Golden Dome awards, the highest awards bestowed on alumnae, for her years of service to the College. Caryl was a Dame in the Sovereign Order of Malta and a member of the Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum. She served as Chairwoman of the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Tarrytown, a member of the Pregnancy Care Center of Westchester, a volunteer at Maria Fareri Children's Hospital Foundation, and a Board Member of AMIC Clearview School. In 2006, she was appointed by the Governor as Honorary Chair of the New York State Observance of United Nations Day. Always known for her quick wit and generous spirit, she was elegant, fun loving and active. She was a gracious hostess and joyful friend and colleague. More importantly, she selflessly gave her love and humor to all she came into contact with. She was happiest spending time with her family at Bantam Lake, CT or on the beach in Kiawah Island, SC. Caryl, born in 1941, is survived by her husband, Bill, their six children Ryan Plunkett, John Brendan (Jake) Plunkett, Erin Plunkett Niehaus, Kathleen Plunkett O'Connor, Timothy Plunkett, Patrick Plunkett and their spouses, and nineteen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St Patrick's Cathedral at 1:30pm Monday September 14th. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Caryl Plunkett HOPE in Lung Cancer fund at at Martin Health Foundation, 2135 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL 34996 or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in honor of Caryl Plunkett. 1/3

PLUNKETT--Caryl D. Faith, family, friends: These were the cornerstones of the life of Caryl Donnelly Plunkett. A generous and devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many, Caryl passed away peacefully on September 9th, 2015 surrounded by her family. Caryl was a ray of light and a beacon of strength and energy. She lived each day to its fullest, even as she fought cancer these last ten years. Originally from Plantsville, CT, Caryl graduated from Marymount College in Tarrytown, New York. She returned to Tarrytown soon after graduation when she married William F. Plunkett Jr. and stayed for 48 years to raise their six children. She was an accomplished businesswoman, public servant and active charitable volunteer. She has been honored on several occasions for her accomplishments and good works. Marymount College awarded Caryl both the Gloria Gaines and Golden Dome awards, the highest awards bestowed on alumnae, for her years of service to the College. Caryl was a Dame in the Sovereign Order of Malta and a member of the Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum. She served as Chairwoman of the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Tarrytown, a member of the Pregnancy Care Center of Westchester, a volunteer at Maria Fareri Children's Hospital Foundation, and a Board Member of AMIC Clearview School. In 2006, she was appointed by the Governor as Honorary Chair of the New York State Observance of United Nations Day. Always known for her quick wit and generous spirit, she was elegant, fun loving and active. She was a gracious hostess and joyful friend and colleague. More importantly, she selflessly gave her love and humor to all she came into contact with. She was happiest spending time with her family at Bantam Lake, CT or on the beach in Kiawah Island, SC. Caryl, born in 1941, is survived by her husband, Bill, their six children Ryan Plunkett, John Brendan (Jake) Plunkett, Erin Plunkett Niehaus, Kathleen Plunkett O'Connor, Timothy Plunkett, Patrick Plunkett and their spouses, and nineteen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St Patrick's Cathedral at 1:30pm Monday September 14th. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Caryl Plunkett HOPE in Lung Cancer fund at at Martin Health Foundation, 2135 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL 34996 or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in honor of Caryl Plunkett. 1/3

BERRY--Thomas Joseph, (1925-2015), passed away at the age of 90 on June 22, 2015. Tom Berry was born to Mary and Joseph Berry in Boston, Massachusetts on February 20th, 1925. He grew up in Dorchester and completed high school in 1942. Shortly thereafter he entered the Naval Air Service and served as a navigator on PBY's, amphibious aircraft used widely by the Navy. He left the service in 1946, and enrolled at Boston University, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts. He took no time off for summers and completed his degree in two years. While at B.U. Tom met his future wife, Pauline [Yankauskas]. They married in 1948. Tom possessed a strong work ethic. He started out selling soaps and chemicals for Veritas Co., then shifted to teaching. He taught mathematics and French at a school in Old Saybrook, Connecticut. He then began working for the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company selling phone books. He remained with various branches of the Bell System and AT&T for 34 years. His final position was Corporate Vice President, Management Information and Network Systems. He served as a Director on numerous boards, including Computer Horizons, Sun Bank, the Children's Museum of Indianapolis, and the Indianapolis 500. The Berry family moved often following his career path at AT&T, including Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Indiana, and twice to New Jersey. Their last move was to New Vernon, New Jersey in 1980. Shortly after Tom's retirement from AT&T in 1986, he accepted a position as Executive Assistant to the Postmaster General in Washington, DC. He spent eight years in that position, working with three different Postmasters General, splitting time between his home in New Jersey and an apartment in Washington, DC. Tom was a devoted squash player, playing daily at his local club, as well as competing in tournaments around the country until his late 80's. He was forever a student and in recent years studied ancient Greek, Latin and Hebrew. Tom is survived by his brother Ed, children Thomas, Paul, Pamela and David, grandchildren Megan, Owen, Daniel, Kyle, Katherine, Campbell and Grayson, and great grandchildren Lillian, Asher, Helena and Thatcher. He will be interred next to his wife Pauline, who passed away in 2000, in the New Vernon Cemetery in New Jersey. 1/3

Worked for Citibank in Japan 1958-60 and worked on Asian business matters at The Bank of New York throughout the 1960's. Was admitted to the New York Bar in 1970. Founding Member of Board of Directors of Lambda Legal Defense 1972. Member of the Board of Trustees of Alcoholics Anonymous 1985-89 and Chairman of AA World Services 1986-87. 1/3

WANG--Rosabel A.,79, of Brooklyn died at Mount Sinai Hospital on July 12, 2015. Born in Hartford, Connecticut and raised in East Poultney, Vermont, Rosabel graduated from Columbia University in 1957 majoring in music and broadcasting and studying piano with Edwin Hughes of Juilliard School of Music. She helped to computerize the American Airlines scheduling system, placing her in the first generation of female computer programmers. In 1959, she attended UC at Berkley studying Far Eastern Studies. In 1963, she and her husband, James C. Wang, taught at Tuskegee Institute. In 1964, they went to Chicago University to teach and to install a computer registration system. In 1965, Rosabel and family moved to Brooklyn where she served on the faculty of Brooklyn College, worked in administration and completed her Masters Degree from Columbia University in Library Science. In 1977, Rosabel began developing the groundwork for what would become a twenty-five year project: the International Bibliography of Theatre and Dance resulting in seventeen volumes, funded mainly by the National Endowment of the Arts. As Director, systems analyst and an editor, IBT is now under the auspices of EBSCO Publishing which offers the database within its Academic Search Premier. Rosabel was predeceased by her husband, James C. Wang in 1985. Rosabel is survived by her two sons: Donald B. Wang (Becky Liu) of Scarsdale and granddaughters Katie and Abbie of Los Angeles; Landy T. Wang (Katie) and grandson Jason and granddaughter Alyssa of Honolulu; sister, Joan Loveridge- Sanbonmatsu (Akira) of Syracuse; nephew Jamie Sanbonmatsu (Celeste Browne) of San Francisco and niece Karissa Sanbonmatsu (Daniella Carter) of Santa Fe; cousins Rosemary and Lisa Adams of Los Angeles, Gil Truedsson (Joanna) of Bayville, New Jersey, Diane Jugy (Pascal) of Florida, and many cousins in Vancouver and Ottawa and friends. Services will be held at May Memorial Unitarian Universalist Church in Syracuse on October 25, 2015 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Brooklyn Public Library. 1/3

REINIG--William Charles, 91, died on August 25, 2015, in Annapolis, MD. A graduate of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, Reinig was the leader of the radiation protection program for the first peacetime nuclear reactor at Brookhaven National Laboratory. He subsequently led the research team that performed the preoperational survey of the Savannah River Site near Aiken, SC, the first large-scale assay of naturally occurring radioactivity. He later served as Superintendent of Health Physics and Deputy General Manager at SRS. He was a fellow and President of the Health Physics Society, Chairman of the American Board of Health Physics, and served on the NCRP. He enjoyed gardening, watching movies and reading The New York Times. He maintained an out-of-town subscription to the Times for 64 years. After retirement, he wrote a remarkably detailed memoir about growing up in Queens describing the smallest details of daily life including the daily meals, how Mayor La Guardia read the Sunday comic pages of the New York papers over the radio in the 1930s during a newspaper distribution strike, the presence of a speech teacher at PS 108 who attempted to correct the Brooklyn accents of many of the students, including Bill, and watching Memorial Day parades down Rockaway Blvd led by Civil War Veterans followed by Spanish-American War Vets wearing Teddy Roosevelt hats and World War I Vets marching behind. He greatly enjoyed movies for the simple pleasure of watching, a habit begun in the movie theaters of Queens during the Depression. Bill was a survivor of the 1950 LIRR crash in Rockville Center. In 1949, he married Marion Borgstrom whom he met at Brookhaven. She died in 2007. He is survived by Dr. James Reinig (Ellen) of Annapolis, Dr. Christine Reinig of Santa Fe, NM, and grandchildren Margaret and Ann Reinig and Dennis and Alice Flournoy. 1/3
