MARK--Stephen. On Sunday, August 30, Stephen Mark, 51, died peacefully, surrounded by family, after a three year battle with brain cancer. He will be forever missed by his wife, Pearson Marx, by his siblings, John, Katie, and William, by his niece and nephews, and his many friends. Steve attended Landon High School and Walt Whitman School in Washington, DC. He graduated from Yale University in 1986 and received a PH.D. in economics from The University of Pennsylvania. He went on to a varied career in finance. He was a light, a joy, a perfect person gone too soon. 1/3
ZEITLIN--Lynn Goldberger. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister and aunt. She will be greatly missed. 1/3

WARD-- Renee. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation mourn the loss of our cherished friend, Renee Ward, longtime partner of our devoted trustee, Bill Lippman. Renee had an abiding love for humanity and a passion for justice - she made a difference in the lives of those who knew her. Together, she and Bill have championed excellence and compassion in healthcare, among many other benevolent causes. We are grateful for their innumerable contributions to the Gold Foundation that have improved the delivery of healthcare across the nation. We extend our sympathy and love to Bill and to Renee's entire family, especially her treasured children and grandchildren. She will be dearly missed. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D. Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D. President/CEO 1/3

BABCOCK--Mary Lois Scheerer, died peacefully September 1, 2015 at home in Stuart, FL. Born March 9, 1927 Orange, NJ. Graduated Miss Porters School, attended Finch College and Arts Student League NYC. Married John B. Babcock 1946, raised her family in Lewellyn Park, NJ and later in Millbrook, NY. A woman of many talents. President of the Garden Clubs of the Oranges and Millbrook, NY. Recipient of the Puckett and Corning awards from the GCA for creativity and exhibition judging. Multiple club champion in golf and tennis. Horse breeder and rider, member of the Milbrook Hunt. Highly regarded painter and sculptor. Maplebrook School Trustee. Mary was predeceased by her husband, daughter, Linda Wilson, survived by sister Lynda Stokes, brother Paul Scheerer, children John B. Jr, Joanne Wlmerding, Frederick H. III, 10 grandchildren and 16 great- grandchildren. Memorial service St Peters Church, Lithgow, NY, October 3, 2pm. 1/3

DANFORTH--Mallory Webb, formerly of West Orange, New Jersey and Katonah, New York died at VNA/Hospice House in Vero Beach, Florida, on Friday, September 4th. She was the daughter of the late Burton Mallory Webb and Virginia Williams Webb and sister of the late Thomas Dudley Webb. Burton Webb was a founding partner of Jewett, Newman and Company, a Wall Street brokerage house. He held a seat on the New York Stock Exchange for 52 years. Mrs. Danforth attended Miss Beards School in Orange, New Jersey and graduated from Miss Porter's School, Farmington, Connecticut in 1946. While living in Katonah, she was a member of the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, and in retirement she was a member of the Mariner Sands Country Club in Stuart, Florida where she excelled in tennis and golf. She was also a member of The Vero Beach Country Club. Mrs. Danforth was the great- great-granddaughter of Andrew Erkenbrecher, who founded the Cincinnati Zoo (Cincinnati Zoological Garden) and the granddaughter of the late Clara Erkenbrecher Webb and Thomas Dudley Webb originally from Cincinnati, Ohio. Mrs. Danforth was predeceased by her husband Alan P. Danforth in July 2013. She leaves her son Kevin Webb Crane, Nicholas Danforth and Stepchildren Alan P. Danforth, Jr. (Kathleen), Penelope Danforth, 10 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by a stepson Michael P. Danforth. A memorial service is planned for her at the place of her residence, Regency Park in Vero Beach, Florida, at a date to be determined. Donations may be made to your local VNA/Hospice House. 1/3

CROSBY--Henry Ashton Jr.,75, of New York City and Southport, CT. Born in 1940 he attended St. Bernard's, Groton, Williams College and received a masters from NYU. He pursued his passions of teaching and more so, acting on stage, television and in film. He is predeceased by two brothers, John Player Crosby and Mario Gifford Fernandez. He is survived by four siblings; Eleanor Hall, Sheldon Crosby, Letitia Haynes and George Crosby. He leaves behind two daughters; Jennifer Crosby Cargill and Heather Crosby Mnuchin and five grandchildren; Sammy Jr, Rosalie, Emma, Dylan and John Player. He also had 10 nieces and nephews. He was loved and will be greatly missed. Services will be held at his beloved St. John the Devine at a date to be set. 1/3

ELLIOTT--Neil, child actor, Air Force Veteran, war correspondent, Hollywood screenwriter, author, political heavy, Cook County Sheriff, real estate developer and all around great guy, has died. Services and interment private. For more info, email: thebookofneil@gmail.com or Donnellan Family Funeral Services, (847)675-1990 or www.donnellanfuneral.com. 1/3

boats for papaWritten and illustrated by Jessixa Bagley. 32 pp. Neal Porter/Roaring Brook. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 8)
 
Buckley, a beaver child, lives happily with his mother, but he misses his father. So he builds small boats and brings them to the beach, sailing them off with a note to Papa. This enchanting debut never lets on where Papa has gone, reminding us that loss comes in many forms, and that there’s no need to rush a child’s reckoning with it. Bagley mixes dreamy watercolors and fine-grained, lovingly detailed pen-and-ink drawing, creating a paradoxical mood that’s both adorable and heartbreaking.

WASSERMAN--Julia, a former Connecticut legislator, and local official from Newtown, CT, died on August 18, 2015. Mrs. Wasserman's death concluded a formidable life, from narrowly escaping the Nazi's 1938 Kristallnacht to achieving the highest academic and professional honors in public health and environmental stewardship. Mrs. Wasserman graduated from Sarah Lawrence College, then joined the Women's Army Corps during the Korean War, and served as a captain in the Medical Service Corps. She received her Master's Degree from Columbia University School of Public Health, and remained on their Board until her death. She was predeceased by her husband, Dr. Louis R. Wasserman, a world-renowned hematologist associated with Mt. Sinai Medical Center in New York. Julia Wasserman served on the Newtown Legislative Council and, in 1990 was elected as State Representative from the 106th District from Newtown. Her popularity was such that she rarely had an opponent in the 18 years she served, retiring in 2008. She was then appointed to the Board of Pardons and Paroles by then Gov. M. Jodi Rell, serving until June 30, 2015. Memorial contributions may be made to the Beardsley Zoo, 1875 Noble Ave., Bridgeport, CT 06610. A Celebration of Life will take place at Fairfield Hills, Newtown, CT on Saturday, September 26, 2015 2-5pm 1/3

WARSHOW--Henry, textile manufacturer, died on September 11, 2015, at the age of 85. A true New Yorker, Henry lived in New York City from his birth on September 9, 1930 until his death. In his business, Henry remained determined to keep all aspects of his manufacturing done in America, which was very important to him. Henry is survived by his loving wife Miriam Kessler Warshow, as well as his five children, Michal Warshow (Joel Bluestein), Douglas Warshow, Becki Warshow, Margaret Hayward, and Elaine Kates, as well as his seven grandchildren, Sarah and Steven Bluestein, Olivia, William, Samuel and Charlotte Hayward, and Jack Parker, as well as his brother Alan. Henry will be remembered for his wisdom and humor. 1/3

LACHMAN--Judith Lehman, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died peacefully on September 9th, just a few days past her 94th birthday. Her passionate devotion to her family lives on in her sons, Bob and Charles Lachman and her grandchildren, Amy, Elly and Peter. She was predeceased in death by husband, Lawrence, brother E. Barry Lehman and granddaughter, Jill. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Sandra, age 86, of Fair Lawn, New Jersey. A devoted wife to her late husband Leo, a loving mother and mother-in-law to Alan and Anna, Lawrence and Michele, and an adoring grandmother to Renee, Robert, Julian and Douglas. Also an inspirational teacher to three decades of kindergarten and first grade students in Fair Lawn, and a dedicated member of the Glen Rock Jewish Center. 1/3

LEVINSON--Patricia. The Board of Trustees, Administration and staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital mourn the passing of our dear friend and former trustee. Pat served on the Board for 40 years in a number of capacities, including Vice President. She was a dedicated advocate for children's health and welfare. She will be missed by all. David Pedowitz, Chair Larry Levine, President & CEO Blythedale Children's Hospital Valhalla, New York 1/3

KIRBY--Joan, RSCJ, died September 9 in New York City. Born in New York May 24, 1926, she was the second of four daughters of Daniel B. and Cecilia K. Kirby. Predeceased by her parents and her sisters Betty Wooters and Janet Clark, she is survived by her sister Cecilia (Billie) Mullen, Bronxville, numerous nieces and nephews and her sisters in the Society of the Sacred Heart. A graduate of the Convent of the Sacred Heart (Maplehurst) and Manhattanville College, Sr. Kirby served as headmistress at Convent of the Sacred Heart (91st Street), 1969-81. Throughout the '80s, she served with various non-profit organizations especially in Hell's Kitchen. In 1994, she became director of the Temple of Understand, an interfaith organization affiliated with the United Nations. She was the TOU representative to the UN at the time of her death. Funeral Mass Thursday, September 17, 11:00am at Sacred Heart of Jesus Church, 457 West 51st Street, New York. Burial will be at the Society of the Sacred Heart Cemetery in Kenwood, Albany at a later date. 1/3

MURPHY--Warren Burton. Award-winning author of more than two hundred books, entered into eternal rest in his home on the morning of September 4th. He was 81 years old. Born in Jersey City, NJ, he worked in politics until creating the Destroyer series of books with Richard Sapir in 1964. Winner of a dozen national awards, including two Edgar awards and two Shamus awards, Murphy's writing spanned many genres, from action- adventure to political thrillers to screenplays (The Eiger Sanction, Lethal Weapon 2), and was a significant influence on many young writers. He is survived by his five children: Deirdre Abbotts of Westport, CT, Megan Murphy of Virginia Beach, VA, Brian Murphy of Virginia Beach, VA, Ardath Hering of Secaucus, NJ, and Devin Murphy of Virginia Beach, VA, as well as his six grandchildren: Adam, Samantha, Morgan, Adelaide, Thomas, and Tyler. The family will receive friends at Hollomon-Brown Funeral Home, Lynnhaven Chapel on Virginia Beach Boulevard, Saturday, September 12th from 12pm to 2pm and 6pm to 8pm. Condolences may be offered to the family at: www.hollomon-brown.com 1/3
BRAM--William: The Board and staff of The Anne Frank Center mourns the passing of our longtime friend and member of the Board of Directors. May his memory be a blessing. 1
EDEPLI--Emre Knight Feb. 18, 2003-Sept. 13, 2007 Our cheetah lover and dinosaur expert, you remain our super hero. 1/3
WEXLER--Melissa Ann. 5/9/58 - 9/12/81. As time goes by, the emptiness grows. Love Mommy, Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri and Larry 1/3

SMITH--Dorothea F. Kidder Born New York City, March 27, 1916. Died at home in Springfield Center, NY, September 8, 2015, age 99. Beloved wife of the late G.E. Kidder Smith, architect, author, and photographer. Beloved mother of Kidder Jr. of Ann Arbor, MI and Hopkinson of Basel, Switzerland. Beloved grandmother of Zacharias, Samuel, Tatjana, and Alice. Daughter of the late Dorothea and Throop Martin Wilder, predeceased by sister Florence Foster and brother T.M. Wilder Jr. Survived by sister Sylvia Wilder. Dot graduated from the Brearley School in 1933 and from Bryn Mawr College in 1937. She accompanied her husband on world travels, contributing to his books on architecture and enjoying every minute. As a member of various organizations and clubs, she delighted in life. She was an enthusiastic tennis player and gardener in Springfield Center, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Brearley School, 610 East 83rd St., New York, NY 10028 or Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010, or St. Mary's Church, Springfield Center, NY 13468. To light a candle or send condolences visit: ottmanfuneralhome.com Services were entrusted to the Ottman Funeral Home, Cherry Valley, NY. 1/3

KIRBY--Joan, RSCJ. The Trustees, faculty and staff, students, parents and alumnae of Convent of the Sacred Heart, New York City, deeply mourn the passing of an exceptional leader, teacher and friend. An advocate for the importance of rigorous academics as well as interfaith and intercultural dialogue, educating the public on combating climate change and fighting for global citizenship, Sr. Kirby inspired innumerable women with her compassion and purpose as she led our school as Headmistress from 1969 to 1980. Sr. Kirby left an indelible mark on countless members of the Sacred Heart community by steering the school's transition following Vatican II, including introducing the Board of Trustees and Parents Association, revitalizing the Alumnae Board and adopting the Network's first Goals and Criteria. 1/3

CRAWFORD--James (Arthur James Crawford III), of Fairfield CT. Died September 6, 2015, age 90. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Jean MacKinnon Crawford, three children, four grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. Manager of Corporate Data Processing, and Electronic Data Processing Auditor for Colgate-Palmolive of New York City, retired in 1988. WWII Veteran (1943-1946), serving in a rifle squad of the 407th Infantry Regiment of 102nd Infantry Division, from the Holland border of Germany to the Elbe River, then serving after war in Criminal Investigation Division (Army of Occupation) and in Counter Intelligence Corps Reserve until resigning as 1st Lieutenant in 1954. Member of Fairfield Representative Town Meeting 1961-1965, Zoning Board of Appeals 1991-1995, and Conservation Commission 1996-1999. As a final gift and as part of his legacy, Mr. Crawford donated his body to the Yale University School of Medicine for educational purposes. Private interment will take place at a later date at Mountain Grove Cemetery, Bridgeport, CT. 1/3

MOLDAUER--Esther, on September 9, 2015. Led a remarkable existence for 97 years. Active in New York theatre and Women's Golf Tour. Studied Torah for decades. Was a psychologist and later an astrologist. All with passion and conviction. Widow of Irving, mother of Nancy, Yona, and the late Patricia. Proud grandmother of 13 and great-grandmother of 45, ba"h. 1/3

WARD--Renee J. The Shield Institute mourns the loss of the Chair of its Board, Renee J. Ward. Renee devoted herself tirelessly to the mission of The Shield, having served over the years in multiple roles, including Vice President, President, and Member of the Audit, Pension Plan, Executive Compensation, and Nominations Committees. Whenever there was a call for a volunteer, Renee was always ready, willing, and able to serve. All of the Members of The Shield Board and its Executive Management Team will truly miss Renee's thoughtful and probing questions, her intellectual curiosity, enthusiasm, warmth, and outgoing personality, and extend our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolence to the members of Renee's family. 1/3

WOLF--Eleanor, passed away at 92 on September 11 after a lengthy debilitating illness that she braved with will and strength. An identical twin and one and a half pounds at birth, she fought for her life in her first days in a way that mirrored her battle in her last. Her grace for life was matched only by her warmth and spirit. She wasn't just beautiful, she was glamorous, as well as protective, embracing and affectionate, a strong personality with a kind soul. With husband Marvin, a 66-year love affair that lasted until his death, she raised a family of three, had cherished friends and traveled the world for pleasure and business. Her impeccable sense of style made her an invaluable asset to the family business. An avid bridge and tennis player, she also was a great enthusiast of theater, film, opera and day at the museum. She is survived by her daughter Barbara Emden, son-in-law James Emden, and son Robert, and predeceased by her daughter Marcia. For those she loved and left behind, her loss will be profoundly felt. 1/3

WALLACH--Roy Alan, 85, formerly of New Rochelle and Eastchester, NY, died peacefully on August 31, 2015. Beloved husband of Margery; devoted father of Margot (Roger) Milliken, Evan (Beth) Wallach, Wendy (Michael) Wallach-DeLucia, and the late Robert; cherished grandfather of Max, Tara, Dan, Hayley, Hannah, and Jake. Roy loved his family, kids, sports, and community, and was loved by all who knew him. Donations in Roy's memory can be made to Temple Shearith Israel, 46 Peaceable Street, Ridgefield, CT 06877. 1/3

BRODY--Ruth, on September 9, 2015 at the young age of 93. Though her death gives us sadness, we also celebrate an amazing life that was lived to the fullest. We feel enriched by her wonderful spirit, eclectic style and charming wit. We cherish her amazing joy of life, kindness and deep love of animals large and small. Ruth travelled the world and experienced all life has to offer. She had no regrets and left no stone unturned. She worked for peace, education and equal rights. She was proud to be a WWII Coast Guard officer. Ruth excelled in a male dominated world of advertising, winning top awards and creating memorable campaigns and she did it all with unequalled grace, personal style and humor. Ruth easily made lifetime friends who were captivated by her warmth, creative mind and soulful brilliance. She treasured her time in the Peace Corps, which she joined in her late 60s. She loved tango, her pets, Africa, great chocolate, card games, Penn State, restaurant week, and a good dirty joke. We wish we could list everyone who meant so much to her. Ruth, if you are reading the cloud version of The New York Times we want to say thank you for being the best mother ever, a true blue friend and a lifetime treasure. On the inside of her apartment door she has in bold painted letters the words DON'T GO. Ruth wanted to keep her friends with her. She succeeded. Our love, Jon, Laura, Kelly, Ellen, Joan, Ringo and Bunny. 1/3

COLE--A. Hunt, died peacefully in his home on September 1, 2015. "He was a real gentleman." That is the sentiment most commonly expressed by the many people who loved Hunt Cole. Gracious, elegant, kind, and witty, Hunt often opened his home to friends and family, hosting convivial dinners and entertaining guests at the piano. Hunt and his longtime partner Isadore From (died 1994) had friends all over, from Europe to L.A. to the West Village. They adored their home in the Dordogne region of France, where they spent the summer every year. A lifelong lover of words, Hunt started out as a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle after graduating from college, and went on to be a longtime independent book editor, working chiefly for McGraw-Hill in New York. He had passions for theater and film, which he carried into his twilight years, along with activities such as acting, directing, singing, and reading. Last but not least, he was an accomplished pianist, sitting down to the piano daily. At home on the Upper West Side, he lived amongst the things he loved best: books, a grand piano, and a ready kitchen. He will be deeply missed and will remain, always, in our hearts. Born in Tulsa, Oklahoma, Hunt was a longtime resident of New York City, a graduate of Harvard University, and a veteran of the Coast Guard. He is survived by his brother, John Cole, four nieces, and three nephews. 1

Services at Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc., 8900 Reisterstown Road, Baltimore, MD on Sunday, September 20, at 4pm. WARD--Renee J. Beloved mother of Lawrence, Jonathan, and Lauren Roberts. Devoted grandmother of Molly and Jackson. Loving sister of Karen and Robert Freedman. Gold Foundation, 619 Palisade Ave., Englewood Cliffs, NJ 07632. 1/3

POWERS--Charles A. "Cap," of Locust Valley, NY on September 2, 2015 age 73. Beloved husband of Lou Rae. Loving father of Charlie (Laura) and Christy (Colin Allen). Dear brother of Pamela Prokop (Bob) and Patty Woodlock (Doug). Proud grandfather of Charlotte and Caitlyn. Born in Manhattan in 1942 and raised in Sands Point. He graduated from Lawrenceville in 1960. He was an active member of the wrestling team which he continued on at Princeton where he graduated in 1965. Married Lou Rae Larson in 1966 and settled in Locust Valley. He went on to work and became the Chairman of Powers Chemco. After the sale of Powers Chemco, he became a financial advisor at Wellington Shields & Co. where he continued to work until his passing. Always committed to serving his community, he had been the President of the Locust Valley Rotary Club, the Locust Valley Library, and the Melillo Center. He was also on the Board of the Family and Children's Association. 1/3

RUDOLPH--Barbara (Adelman), of New York City, formerly of Philadelphia, PA and Longport, NJ died on September 10, 2015. Barbara was the daughter of the late Bea and Sol Adelman and beloved mother of Emily, Brad, Suzanne, loving Bubby to Levi and cherished friends. Whether it was solving a New York Times crossword puzzle in record time, entertaining, writing, beading, baking, cooking, accessorizing . . . she excelled. As a mature techie she patiently brow beat her same age friends into staying current with new technical skills. Her turn of phrase and sense of humor was unmatched. We will remember and miss Barbara; this beautiful woman who made us laugh till it hurt and left us much too soon. Services at Plaza Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., (91st St.), Friday, September 11th at 2pm. 1/3

SAMOTIN--Murray, Beloved husband of Myra. Loving father to Sheila (Lloyd) Hoffman and Guy (Robin) Samotin. Adored grandfather of Ronnee (Karsten) Pedersen. Much loved great-grandfather of Hunter, Annika, and Grant. A most unique man, loved by all who met him. 1/3

BRAM--William B. May 25, 1927. Beloved husband, father, grandfather died peacefully in his sleep on September 11. He was a devoted and loving family man and passionate in any endeavor he undertook. He worked at Merrill Lynch for almost 55 years, investing in the stock market. He loved sports and particularly golf in the last 20 years. He travelled the world and loved fine dining. He was a serious and focused man yet he possessed a wry sense of humor. He will be sorely missed, but we take comfort that he had a full and interesting life. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Jane Eisner Bram, his three children, Judith Bram Murphy, Steven Eisner Bram (Miriam), and Elizabeth Bram Rothstein (Eric) and six grandchildren: Jessica, Leila, Joshua, Danielle, Zoe, and Kacy. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue on Sunday, September 13 at 11:00am. 1/3

LEVINSON--Patricia S. Known for her summertime straw hat and roll-up-your-sleeves work attitude, Patricia Schulte Levinson died at Mount Sinai Hospital on September 8th after a brief but heroic fight with cancer. She had been active in board work and non-profit affiliations, especially as a Trustee of the Mount Sinai Healthcare System, and was a lifelong New Yorker, a lover of the arts and culture, and who enjoyed spending time with her family and in the summers at her Long Island home. Pat was the daughter of Arthur D. Schulte and Luise Meyer Schulte. She graduated from the Spence School and attended Connecticut College and Columbia University before marrying Robert A. Levinson in 1954. Pat joined the Boards of Trustees of Mount Sinai Hospital in 1981 when she was named President of the Mount Sinai Auxiliary Board, a group she first joined in 1961. Pat served on several of the hospital's board committees both as a member and chair; most recently on the Patient Care and Quality Assurance, Medical Education and Community Relations Committees. Board members grew to anticipate receiving articles and clippings from her, all on recycled paper and all pertinent to the issues of the day. For many years she also served as a Board liaison to the Nursing Department. Pat had been co-chair of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai's Center for Multicultural and Community Affairs (CMCA) Advisory Board since its inception. A champion of students, her personal commitment included the creation of the Robert and Patricia Levinson Student Center, and the endowment of scholarships and fellowships at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. She was a founding member and vice president of New York City's New Alternatives for Children (NAC) where she helped children move from hospitals to loving homes, a director of Linkage House, and vice chair of the United Hospital Fund, as well as a member of Health First's Board of Managers of Senior Health Partners and a former trustee of the Blythedale Children's Hospital. Pat brought friends from all parts of her life to help grow these important causes - whether through raising awareness or opening her home for salon gatherings - always with her famous cheese crackers. She was the recipient of a United Hospital Fund Distinguished Trustee Award for her leadership, guidance, and extraordinary service to Mount Sinai as well as The Jacobi Medallion, awarded by The Mount Sinai Alumni, in recognition of her distinguished service to the Hospital and the School. An involved New Yorker, Pat enjoyed the city in particular ballet, music, theater and all the arts, and made certain that her multitude of friends shared her pleasures. Pat was a devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many. She was respected for her energy, work ethic and her vast knowledge of the health care issues she worked so diligently to address in her Mount Sinai, NAC and UHF board work. Pat, born in 1933, is survived by her husband of 61 years, Robert A. Levinson, her daughter Margot and two sons, Andrew and John as well as their spouses: John Ganz, Jr, Karen Levinson, and Ronna Levinson. Pat and Bob have five grandsons: Craig, Jamie, Kyle, Jack and Dean. Pat was pre-deceased by her brother Anthony M. Schulte. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to New Alternatives for Children and/or the Patricia Levinson Scholarship Fund, CMCA, at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 24th at 5pm in the Leo C. Stern Auditorium, Annenberg Building, Mount Sinai. Reception to follow. Funeral services will be private. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence. The board and staff of American Jewish World Service (AJWS) mourn the passing of our beloved founder and long-time supporter, Larry Phillips, a visionary philanthropist who thirty years ago realized his dream of creating a Jewish organization dedicated to ending poverty and expanding human rights in the developing world. He served as AJWS's original investor and board chair and he persuaded other American Jews to send aid to some of the world's poorest and most oppressed people who were pursuing their own visions for change. Throughout his life, Larry acted with generosity and compassion to extend the promise of a brighter future to millions worldwide, fulfilling the Jewish obligation to repair the world. Since 1985, the organization he founded has given away $270 million worldwide. Larry made a difference and countless individuals, organizations and communities are indebted to him for his passion, his vision and his commitment. Honor Larry by watching this video testament to his leadership: www.ajws.org/phillipstribute. We extend our sincere condolences to his sister Carol, son David, daughter Laura and to the entire family. Kathleen Levin Board Chair Ruth Messinger President and CEO 1/3

MIXTER--David Mason, 92, resident of Vero Beach, FL and formerly of Darien, CT, died in Vero Beach on August 28, 2015. Mr. Mixter was the husband of Stephanie Leonard Mixter, who predeceased him in 2009, and is survived by his wife, Mrs. Carol Baldwin. Family include daughter Valerie (Mrs. Guy O., III) Dove of Middleburg, VA; sons Peter J. Mixter of New York City and Stephen L. (Elizabeth) Mixter of Naples, FL and the late David Ives Mixter who was lost in Vietnam. He had seven grandchildren, Dorothy Cavanagh Stout, Carroll J. Cavanagh III, J. Tyler, Peter J. Jr., William G., David W. and Laura E. Mixter and two great-grandchildren. He was born in Boston, MA in 1922, son of Dr. William Jason and Dorothy (nee Fay) Mixter. He was educated at the Dexter School and Milton Academy and graduated from Yale College, New Haven, CT, with the class of 1945. Mr. Mixter served in the United States Marine Corps during World War II and the Korean Conflict at a rank of Captain. After his service to our country he began his career with the Benton & Bowles and Ted Bates & Company advertising agencies in New York City and was a partner in and Vice Chairman of North Castle Partners in Greenwich, CT. He was proud to serve on the boards of numerous charitable organizations, including, starting in 1960, the Hospital for Special Surgery, New York City, of which he became a Life Trustee and the Indian River Medical Center Foundation in Vero Beach. He was a member of The Yale Club of New York City, Wee Burn Country Club in Darien and Riomar Country Club in Vero Beach. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospital for Special Surgery, Development Dept, 535 East 70th Street, New York, NY 10021. Interment will be in Darien, CT. Services are by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory, Vero Beach. A guest book is available at strunkfuneralhome.com 1/3

EVANS--John Barraby, time has not eased the pain of your passing since September 11, 2013. You are loved and missed more than ever and are always in my heart. May God let me find you again. Your loving wife, Barbara. Love also from brother Keith and family. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence. The Wellfleet and Truro communities of Massachusetts, along with our family at Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater (WHAT), is saddened by the loss of our beloved friend and supporter Larry Phillips. Larry was well known in the community and loved by all. He had a true philanthropic spirit that was born at the center of his giving heart. There were many organizations that Larry supported and his support of growing Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater had an immense impact on the cultural economic growth of the community. We shall all miss him terribly. Our love and support are with his family and, in particular our very special friend and trustee, Larry's sister Carol Green. 1/3

BRODY--Ruth, on September 9, 2015 at the young age of 93. Though her death gives us sadness, we also celebrate an amazing life that was lived to the fullest. We feel enriched by her wonderful spirit, eclectic style and charming wit. We cherish her amazing joy of life, kindness and deep love of animals large and small. Ruth travelled the world and experienced all life has to offer. She had no regrets and left no stone unturned. She worked for peace, education and equal rights. She was proud to be a WWII Coast Guard officer. Ruth excelled in a male dominated world of advertising, winning top awards and creating memorable campaigns and she did it all with unequalled grace, personal style and humor. Ruth easily made lifetime friends who were captivated by her warmth, creative mind and soulful brilliance. She treasured her time in the Peace Corps, which she joined in her late 60s. She loved tango, her pets, Africa, great chocolate, card games, Penn State, restaurant week, and a good dirty joke. We wish we could list everyone who meant so much to her. Ruth, if you are reading the cloud version of The New York Times we want to say thank you for being the best mother ever, a true blue friend and a lifetime treasure. On the inside of her apartment door she has in bold painted letters the words DON'T GO. Ruth wanted to keep her friends with her. She succeeded. Our love, Jon, Laura, Kelly, Ellen, Joan, Ringo and Bunny. 1/3

Phillips, beloved brother of Carol Phillips Green, who is a member of the Board of Trustees of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing and cherished uncle of Janet Green, Co-Chair of the Board of Phillip Beth Israel School of Nursing. UGELOW--June passed away suddenly September 12, 2015 at the age of 91. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Survived by her children Susan Konigsberg (Fred), Judith Blak, Linda Ugelow (husband, Endre Jobbagy), grandchildren Eric Konigsberg (Shari), Brian Konigsberg (Sara), Clint and Thor Blak, Lexi Ugelow, five great-grandchildren, sister Betty Zale (Marvin), sisters-in-law Elaine London and Pauline Feldman. She had a wonderful spirit and dynamic personality. She loved everything- music, dance, theater, travel, people and above all, laughter. She was an avid golfer, tennis player, modern dancer and bridge player. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Rest in peace Mom. Your loving Family 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence S.,died peacefully at his home in Florida on September 11, 2015. Born March 20, 1927 in New York, Larry was the son of Madelyn Shapiro Phillips and Seymour J. Phillips. He received his B.A. from Princeton University after serving in the Armed Forces during World War II. He was former President and Chairman of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, the apparel company founded by his grandfather and great- grandfather in the 19th century. Larry was an active philanthropist who in 1985 founded the American Jewish World Service (AJWS), the international relief organization, where he served as president and active board member for many years. Larry made the first gift that created the Phillips Ambulatory Care Center of Beth Israel Hospital, and was a devoted member of the New York Beth Israel community, including the School of Nursing. In 1995 Larry moved to Boca Raton where he became a vital participant in the South Palm Beach County Jewish Federation. There he funded and participated in an annual Thanksgiving lunch for 600 needy elderly people. He also contributed funds to a special program with the Joint Distribution Committee that brought orphans to Israel and sponsored their education. He served on the Federation's Israel and Overseas Committee for over 10 years. Deeply engaged in civil and human rights issues in the U.S., Israel and throughout the world, Larry was a political activist who gave generously to candidates and causes. Larry was passionately devoted to Tikkun Olam, repairing the world. Larry loved learning and appreciated lively political discourse. President Richard Nixon included him on his 1971 Enemies' List, a source of endless pride to Larry and his family. Larry is survived by his daughter Laura Phillips, his son David L. Phillips and daughter-in-law Sarah Phillips; his grandchildren Joseph Phillips Black, Sasha Phillips Black, Tara Phillips and Maya Phillips; his sister Carol Green; his former wife Ann Phillips, mother of his children; and former wife Roxane Lipton. Memorial services will be at a later date. Contributions may be made in his honor to the Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County, 9901 Donna Klein Blvd., Boca Raton, FL 33428. 1/3

CROSBY--Henry Ashton Jr.,75, of New York City and Southport, CT. Born in 1940 he attended St. Bernard's, Groton, Williams College and received a masters from NYU. He pursued his passions of teaching and more so, acting on stage, television and in film. He is predeceased by two brothers, John Player Crosby and Mario Gifford Fernandez. He is survived by four siblings; Eleanor Hall, Sheldon Crosby, Letitia Haynes and George Crosby. He leaves behind two daughters; Jennifer Crosby Cargill and Heather Crosby Mnuchin and five grandchildren; Sammy Jr, Rosalie, Emma, Dylan and John Player. He also had 10 nieces and nephews. He was loved and will be greatly missed. Services will be held at his beloved St. John the Devine at a date to be set. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence. The board and staff of American Jewish World Service (AJWS) mourn the passing of our beloved founder and long-time supporter, Larry Phillips, a visionary philanthropist who thirty years ago realized his dream of creating a Jewish organization dedicated to ending poverty and expanding human rights in the developing world. He served as AJWS's original investor and board chair and he persuaded other American Jews to send aid to some of the world's poorest and most oppressed people who were pursuing their own visions for change. Throughout his life, Larry acted with generosity and compassion to extend the promise of a brighter future to millions worldwide, fulfilling the Jewish obligation to repair the world. Since 1985, the organization he founded has given away $270 million worldwide. Larry made a difference and countless individuals, organizations and communities are indebted to him for his passion, his vision and his commitment. Honor Larry by watching this video testament to his leadership: www.ajws.org/phillipstribute. We extend our sincere condolences to his sister Carol, son David, daughter Laura and to the entire family. Kathleen Levin Board Chair Ruth Messinger President and CEO 1/3
